3 

层

3 

Layers

大学毕业一年后我才成为一名程序员。

I didn’t become a programmer until a year after college.

那时我已经写了十年的程序，主修计算机科学，并在一家小型软件初创公司工作了一年。我不知道，那只是我为期末考试的练习。

By that point I had been writing programs for a decade, majored in computer science, and worked at a small software start-up for a year. Unbeknownst to me, that was just practice for my final test.

命运多舛的一系列事件始于我的经理把我叫到办公室。我的公司 Dendrite Americas 正在编写软件，让制药公司的代表能够带着笔记本电脑规划与医生的销售会议。每天晚上，他们都会拨入我们的中央计算机，上传白天收集的笔记，然后下载更新到他们的医生数据库——这在 20 世纪 80 年代末是相当先进的。在某些情况下，一位医生的街道地址会被替换为另一位医生的街道地址，而且没有任何明显的规律。没有人能够弄清楚发生了什么，我的经理想让我试一试。

The fateful sequence of events began when my manager called me into his office. My company, Dendrite Americas, was writing software that allowed representatives of pharmaceutical companies, armed with laptops, to plan their sales meetings with doctors. Every night they would dial in to our central computer to upload notes they had gathered during the day and then download updates to their database of doctors—quite advanced for the late 1980s. In certain cases, in no discernible pattern, the street address of one doctor was being replaced with that of a different doctor. Nobody else had been able to figure out what was going on, and my manager wanted me to give it a try.

从公司大约十五名程序员中被选中承担这项任务，对我来说是一种褒奖。一部老西部片里的警长正在挑选他的手下，并告诉我：“特克斯，你是我们最好的射手。”尽管如此，我还是感到心头一沉——这是我在面对编程任务时从未有过的感觉。在这种情况下，挑战性的部分不是解决问题，而是找到问题，我很担心自己是否能找到它。

Being selected for this assignment, from among the fifteen or so programmers at the company, was a compliment. The sheriff in an old Western movie was choosing his posse and telling me, “Tex, you’re the best shot we’ve got.” Nonetheless, I felt my stomach sink—a feeling that I had never felt when facing a programming task. The challenging part in situations like this is not so much fixing the problem as it is finding it, and I was nervous about whether I would be able to find it.

软件中的错误通过重现步骤来描述：用户重现错误的顺序，例如，“运行拼写检查，然后尝试保存文档，您将收到错误。” 它们可以大致分为两类：每次都会发生的错误和偶尔发生的错误，尽管遵循相同的重现步骤。 每次发生的错误是更可取的，至少从试图解决它们的程序员的角度来看是如此，因为如果您可以让错误可靠地发生，您最终可以缩小问题的范围。 就像汽车中恼人的嘎嘎声在机械师倾听时消失一样，间歇性发生的软件错误会让您抓狂。 实际上，即使是间歇性的错误也会“每次”发生； 只是需要某些因素结合在一起，而已知的重现步骤不够详细，无法始终触发确切的情况。

Bugs in software are described by repro steps: the sequence that the user follows to reproduce the bug, as in, “Run spell-check, then try to save the document, and you’ll get an error.” They can be broadly divided into two categories: bugs that happen every time, and bugs that happen only sometimes, despite following the same repro steps. Those that happen every time are vastly preferable, at least from the point of view of a programmer trying to solve them, because if you can make the bug happen reliably, you can eventually narrow down where the problem is. Like the annoying rattle in your car that goes away when the mechanic is listening, software bugs that occur intermittently make you pull your hair out. In reality, even intermittent bugs do happen “every time”; it’s just that a certain set of factors have to come together, and the repro steps, as best as they are known, are not detailed enough to always trigger the exact situation.

还有另一种划分软件缺陷的方法：你自己编写的程序中的缺陷和别人程序中的缺陷。如果缺陷出现在别人的程序中，你对细节一无所知，所以你只能从头开始，或者从第一行开始。我被要求修复的问题属于最糟糕的象限：别人程序中间歇性出现的缺陷。这对我来说是全新的体验。以前，在高中和大学时，我很少接触别人编写的代码。即使接触过，我处理的数据也足够少，程序也足够简单，因此任何缺陷都很容易重现。

There is another way to divide software bugs: bugs in a program that you wrote yourself, and bugs in somebody else’s program. When the bug is in somebody else’s program, you know nothing about the details, so you are starting at square one, or line one. The problem I was being tapped to fix was in the worst quadrant: an intermittent bug in somebody else’s program. This was a new experience for me. Previously, in high school and college, I had rarely worked with code written by somebody else. And even when I had, the data I was working with was small enough, and the programs I was working with were simple enough, that any bug was easy to reproduce.

再加上当场的压力，付费客户在等待解决问题，而他们的销售人员在新泽西漫无目的地闲逛，这就是我作为一名程序员获得认可的时刻。

Throw in the pressure of being put on the spot, with paying customers waiting for a fix while their salespeople wandered aimlessly around New Jersey, and this was the moment when I was going to earn my stripes as a programmer.

如果您看过家居装修节目，您肯定见过“旋钮和管子”的揭秘，承包商告诉房主“我有个坏消息”，然后在广告休息后，会有人撕掉一块墙，露出可怕的“旋钮和管子”系统。这种在房屋内传输电力的古老方法存在潜在的火灾隐患，因此，当对房屋进行升级时，如果认为不安全（或者如果认为节目情节缺乏戏剧张力），就必须更换旋钮和管子。

If you watch home improvement shows, you have no doubt seen the knob-and-tube reveal, in which the contractor informs the homeowners, “I have bad news,” and then after a commercial break is seen ripping off a piece of the wall to uncover the dreaded knob-and-tube system. This archaic method for transmitting electricity inside a house is a potential fire hazard, such that when upgrades are made to a house, the knob and tube has to be replaced if it is deemed unsafe (or possibly if the plot of the show is deemed to be lacking in dramatic tension).

发现电气问题有点像调试，显然，由于旋钮和管子已经过时了 75 年，它属于别人工作中的错误类别。不同之处在于，尽管旋钮和管子隐藏在墙后面，但很容易找到：从墙上的插头开始，然后从那里追溯。当我被叫去调试我们软件中的这个神秘问题时，我不知道自己在寻找什么。是旋钮吗？是管子吗？我应该在哪面隐喻性的墙后面寻找？如果我找到了正确的地方，问题会在我观察的时候发生吗？

Finding electric problems is a bit like debugging, and clearly, since knob and tube has been obsolete for seventy-five years, it falls in the category of a bug in somebody else’s work. The difference is that knob and tube, despite being hidden behind a wall, is easy to locate: start with the plug on the wall and track it back from there. When I was called in to debug this mysterious problem in our software, I had no idea what I was looking for. Was it knobs? Was it tubes? Which metaphoric wall was I supposed to look behind? And if I found the right place, would the problem occur while I was watching?

我会透露结局：经过几天的挖掘，我发现了这个错误，并得到了一瓶香槟作为奖励，同事们也对我表示尊重，然后我就可以高高兴兴地回到更平凡的任务中去——直到下一次我不得不去追踪别人程序中的一个不稳定的错误。但让我们绕道考虑一下程序员究竟是如何编写和调试软件的。

I’ll give away the ending: after a couple days of excavation, I found the bug and was rewarded with a bottle of champagne as well as the respect of my peers and a blissful return to more mundane tasks—until the next time I had to track down a flaky bug in somebody else’s program. But let’s take a detour to consider exactly how programmers approach writing and debugging software.

我们需要调试一些东西，下面是 C# 程序中的两行代码。此代码的目的是向用户显示存储在名为ErrorMessage、类型为 的变量中的错误消息string。这是一个程序片段，因此我们为ErrorMessage（文本字符串“这是我的错误消息”）分配一个特定值，而不是由实际错误决定：

We will need something to debug, so below are two lines from a program in C#. The purpose of this code is to show the user an error message stored in a variable named ErrorMessage, of type string. This is a snippet of a program, so we assign a specific value to ErrorMessage (the text string “This is my error message”), as opposed to having it determined by an actual error:

string ErrorMessage = "This is my error message";
MessageBox.Show(ErrorMessage);
string ErrorMessage = "This is my error message";
MessageBox.Show(ErrorMessage);

忽略稍微落后的语法和看起来随意的标点符号；您可能会正确推断出此代码将导致计算机显示一个消息框（悬停在屏幕上的弹出窗口之一），其中包含错误消息的文本，如变量 所含。ErrorMessage在我的 Windows 10 系统上，消息框（不是最漂亮的消息框，但您可以看到代码和结果之间的联系）如下所示：1

Look past the slightly backward syntax and arbitrary-looking punctuation; you may correctly infer that this code will cause the computer to show a message box—one of those pop-up windows that hovers over the screen—containing the text of the error message, as contained in the variable ErrorMessage. On my Windows 10 system, the message box—not the prettiest of message boxes, but you can see the connection between the code and result—looks like this:1

MessageBox.Show是一种 API，类似于我们在 Fortran 和 BASIC 中看到的 API，尽管在 C# 的行话中它也被称为方法。您可能会说，“我的代码调用了该MessageBox.Show方法。”或者，由于程序员倾向于将他们的代码视为他们自己的扩展，因此您可以断言，“我调用了该MessageBox.Show方法。”或者最常见的是，由于不起作用的代码会产生最丰富的对话素材，因此您可能会抱怨，“我调用了该MessageBox.Show方法，但我不明白为什么它不能正常工作。”

MessageBox.Show is an API, similar to what we saw in Fortran and BASIC, although in the argot of C# it is also known as a method. You might say, “My code calls the MessageBox.Show method.” Or since programmers tend to talk of their code as an extension of themselves, you could assert, “I call the MessageBox.Show method.” Or most commonly, since code that doesn’t work yields the richest bounty of conversational fodder, you would be complaining, “I call the MessageBox.Show method and I can’t figure out why it isn’t working properly.”

鉴于软件是分层构建的，此代码位于上一层MessageBox.Show，并向下调用。现实世界中也存在类似的概念 - 房屋的屋顶可能建在预制大梁上，而大梁本身由木头、钢材和钉子制成。您家中的电器位于墙壁的电力系统上方，依靠它来在需要时供电。但这些层并没有那么深；旋钮和管子只隔了一层，房主可以看到它们。用羊角锤快速处理一下，所有东西都在摄像头下一览无余。该MessageBox.Show方法包含其自己的代码，而该代码又调用数十层深的堆栈中的其他代码。这意味着旋钮和管子可能埋得很深，以至于您永远不会发现它们，除非您的软件着火了。

Given that software is built up in layers, this code is at a layer above MessageBox.Show, calling down into it. A similar concept exists in the physical world—the roof of a house may be built on prefabricated girders, which are themselves made of wood, steel, and nails. The electric appliances in your house are layered above the electric system in your walls, relying on it to provide power when needed. But these layers don’t go that deep; the knobs and tubes are only one layer removed from what all visible to the homeowner. Some quick work with a claw hammer and all is laid bare for the camera. The MessageBox.Show method contains its own code, which in turn calls other code in a stack that is dozens of levels deep. Which means the knobs and tubes may be buried so deeply that you will never discover them until your software metaphorically catches fire.

在上面的代码片段中，ErrorMessage作为参数传递给MessageBox.Show。在 C# 中，与许多现代编程语言一样，参数在括号中的逗号分隔列表中指定，因此我们将遵循惯例，即 C# 方法名称后跟空的左括号和右括号，以将它们与其他编程结构区分开来。MessageBox.Show今后将被设计为MessageBox.Show()。

In the code snippet above, ErrorMessage is passed as a parameter to MessageBox.Show. In C#, as in many modern programming languages, parameters are specified in a comma-separated list enclosed in parentheses, so we’ll follow the convention that C# method names are followed with empty opening and closing parentheses in order to distinguish them from other programming constructs. MessageBox.Show will henceforth be styled as MessageBox.Show().

程序中的代码通常涉及确定方法所需的参数、调用该方法，并使用该方法返回的信息来决定下一步要做什么。随着代码变得越来越复杂，层数也会增加，而方法调用就是将这些层结合在一起的粘合剂。许多代码示例只显示了一个层，但这在实际程序中并不常见；代码很少会在没有调用方法的情况下运行超过五行。

The code in a program generally involves figuring out the desired parameters to a method, calling that method, and using the information returned from that method to decide what to do next. As code gets more complicated, the number of layers increases, and method calls are the glue that holds those layers together. A lot of code examples show only one layer, but that is unusual in real programs; code rarely proceeds for more than five lines without calling a method.

让我们修改代码，以大写形式显示错误消息，以便于记忆。使用名为 的方法可以轻松将大写转换为大写；在 C# 中，您可以使用点符号调用变量（在本例中ToUpper()为 ）的方法，如下所示。我们还将添加另一个名为 的字符串变量来保存大写字符串：ErrorMessageEM_Upper

Let’s change our code to display the error message in uppercase so as to be extra memorable. Uppercasing is easy using a method named ToUpper(); in C#, you call a method on a variable—in this case, ErrorMessage—by using dot notation, as shown below. We’ll also add another string variable named EM_Upper to hold the uppercased string:

string ErrorMessage = "This is my error message";
string EM_Upper = ErrorMessage.ToUpper();
MessageBox.Show(EM_Upper);
string ErrorMessage = "This is my error message";
string EM_Upper = ErrorMessage.ToUpper();
MessageBox.Show(EM_Upper);

第二行将设置EM_Upper为保存调用方法的结果ErrorMessage.ToUpper()，然后我们将其作为参数传递给MessageBox.Show()，而不是原始的ErrorMessage。错误消息现在以大写显示，如下所示：

The second line sets EM_Upper to hold the result of calling the ErrorMessage.ToUpper()method, and we then pass that as a parameter to MessageBox.Show(), instead of the original ErrorMessage. The error message is now displayed in uppercase, like this:

现在我们再给这段代码添加一点变化：除了在消息框中显示错误消息外，我们还将在顶部显示一个标题。我们将使用标题“ERROR！”，将其作为第二个参数传递给MessageBox.Show()：

Now we add one more twist to this code: in addition to having the error message displayed in the message box, we will show a title at the top. We’ll use the title “ERROR!,” which we pass as a second parameter to MessageBox.Show():

string ErrorMessage = "This is my error message";
string EM_Upper = ErrorMessage.ToUpper();
MessageBox.Show(EM_Upper, "ERROR!");
string ErrorMessage = "This is my error message";
string EM_Upper = ErrorMessage.ToUpper();
MessageBox.Show(EM_Upper, "ERROR!");

不同之处在于第三行代码；MessageBox.Show()现在有两个参数，以逗号分隔。字符串“ERROR！”显示为消息框的标题，而之前没有标题：

The difference is in the third line of code; MessageBox.Show() now has two parameters, separated by a comma. The string “ERROR!” is displayed as the title of the message box, where previously there had been no title:

这两个参数MessageBox.Show()都是 类型string（第二个参数不是变量名，而是包含字符串的实际文本，用双引号括起来）。 您可以使用MessageBox.Show()不同的参数集通过多种方式进行调用，因为编写人员MessageBox.Show()（在本例中是微软，它发明了 C# 并编写了允许 C# 程序执行诸如显示消息框等操作的方法集合）认为提供这种选择很有用。 C# 编译器知道参数的类型及其顺序，它们形成了一种签名；这个调用MessageBox.Show()有签名“第一个参数是string，第二个参数是string”。

Both those parameters to MessageBox.Show() are of type string (the second parameter is not the name of a variable but instead contains the actual text of the string, surrounded by double quotes). There are multiple ways you can call MessageBox.Show() with different sets of parameters, because the people who wrote MessageBox.Show() (in this case at Microsoft, which invented C# and wrote the collection of methods that allow C# programs to do things such as show message boxes) decided it would be useful to offer the choice. The C# compiler knows the type of the parameters and their order, which form a signature of sorts; this call to MessageBox.Show() has the signature “first parameter is a string, second parameter is a string.”

如果你不小心弄反了，将第一个参数指定为消息框的标题，将第二个参数指定为文本，会怎么样？下面是一个例子：

What if you accidentally got those backward, and specified the first parameter as the title of the message box, and the second as the text? Here is an example:

string ErrorMessage = "This is my error message";
string EM_Upper = ErrorMessage.ToUpper();
MessageBox.Show("ERROR!", EM_Upper);
string ErrorMessage = "This is my error message";
string EM_Upper = ErrorMessage.ToUpper();
MessageBox.Show("ERROR!", EM_Upper);

对我们来说，意图是什么似乎很明显，因为我们一直在思考代码，并且知道“ERROR！”是标题，而消息在 中EM_Upper。但编译器不知道这一点，因为调用仍然与方法签名匹配；一个字符串被视为与任何其他字符串一样，并且它让不正确的代码不受质疑地通过：

It seems obvious to us what the intent is since we have been thinking about the code, and know that “ERROR!” is the title and the message is in EM_Upper. But the compiler doesn’t know that, since the call still matches the method signature; one string is treated like any other string, and it lets the incorrect code through unchallenged:

弗雷德·布鲁克斯 (Fred Brooks) 曾管理 IBM 的硬件和软件团队，后来又创建了北卡罗来纳大学的计算机科学系，他曾将编程中的创造力与诗歌中的创造力进行了比较，但他指出：“与诗人的文字不同，程序构造是真实的，因为它可以移动和工作，产生与构造本身不同的可见输出。……神话和传说中的魔法在我们这个时代已经成为现实。人们在键盘上输入正确的咒语，显示屏就会活灵活现，显示出从未存在过也不可能存在的东西。”但他警告说：“必须完美地执行。在这方面，计算机也类似于传说中的魔法。如果咒语中的一个字符、一个停顿不是严格按照正确的形式，魔法就不会起作用。人类并不习惯于完美，而且人类活动很少有领域需要完美。”2

Fred Brooks, who managed both hardware and software teams at IBM, and later founded the Department of Computer Science at the University of North Carolina, once compared the creativity in programming to that in poetry, but noted, “The program construct, unlike the poet’s words, is real in the sense that it moves and works, producing visible outputs separate from the construct itself. … The magic of myth and legend has come true in our time. One types the correct incantation on a keyboard, and a display screen comes to life, showing things that never were nor could be.” But he cautioned, “One must perform it perfectly. The computer resembles the magic of legend in that respect, too. If one character, one pause, of the incantation is not strictly in proper form, the magic doesn’t work. Human beings are not accustomed to being perfect, and few areas of human activity require it.”2

我们骂计算机的原因往往是它们完美地执行了一组指令，但这些指令并没有按照我们的意愿去做。西雅图的长期观察家弗雷德·穆迪在他的书《我歌唱电子身体》中讲述了 1990 年代与微软开发团队合作的一年，书中讲述了他与一位程序员的一次讨论：

The things that make us swear at computers often involve them perfectly executing a set of instructions that don’t do what we want them to do. In his book I Sing the Body Electronic, which chronicles a year embedded with a Microsoft development team in the 1990s, longtime Seattle observer Fred Moody recounts a discussion with a programmer:

开发人员喜欢引用洗发水瓶上的常见说明来强调计算机世界与计算机之外的世界之间的差异——“涂抹泡沫。冲洗。重复。”……在日常生活中，常识会告诉你不要一直涂抹泡沫和冲洗。但在计算机世界中，没有常识，一切都必须严格定义，这样的指示是粗心和危险的。3

Developers like to highlight the difference between the world of computing and the world outside of computing by citing the common directions on a bottle of shampoo—“Lather. Rinse. Repeat.” … In the everyday world, common sense tells you not to keep lathering and rinsing forever. In the world of computing, where there is no common sense and where everything must be rigorously defined, such an instruction is careless and dangerous.3

笑话在于，说明书并没有告诉你何时停止重复；计算机会一直这样做，直到洗发水用完为止（或者可能更长时间，如果它在洗发水瓶空了时忘记停止）。

The joke is that the instructions don’t tell you when to stop repeating; a computer would keep doing this until it ran out of shampoo (or possibly longer, if it neglected to stop when the shampoo bottle was empty).

将两个参数反转为一个方法是一种程序员很难发现的错误，因为我们人类的常识过滤器在阅读代码时会发挥作用——同样的常识让我们按照洗发水的意图来解释它们的使用说明。正确的代码看起来与错误的版本非常相似；你看到了传递给的标题和消息MessageBox.Show()，那么可能有什么问题呢？

Reversing two parameters to a method is the sort of mistake that can be hard for a programmer to catch, because our human commonsense filter kicks in when reading the code—the same common sense that makes us interpret the shampoo directions the way they were intended. The correct code looks maddeningly similar to the incorrect version; you see the title and message being passed to MessageBox.Show(), so what could be wrong?

幸运的是，有文档可以MessageBox.Show()解释哪个参数放在哪里，即使您不阅读文档并获取参数，运行程序时错误也会很明显。在这种情况下，您可以快速解决问题：您知道代码MessageBox.Show()中调用的位置，很明显您交换了两个参数，然后，问题就解决了。现在想象一下，您调用的方法是由公司另一位程序员编写的，并且没有清晰的文档——这是调试时更典型的情况。或者想象一下，错误没有导致两个字符串的视觉上明显且无害的转置。

Luckily there is documentation available for MessageBox.Show() explaining which parameter goes where, and even if you don’t read the documentation and get the parameters backward, the error will be apparent if you run the program. In this case, you can quickly solve the problem: you know where the call to MessageBox.Show() is in your code, it’s pretty obvious that you switched the two parameters, and presto, it is fixed. Now imagine that the method you were calling was written by another programmer at your company and did not have clear documentation—a much more typical situation when debugging. Or imagine that the mistake did not result in a visually obvious, and otherwise harmless, transposition of two strings.

虽然您可以通过更改代码来修复此问题，但您不能将责任直接归咎于您的代码或 中的代码MessageBox.Show()；您只是对参数的工作方式有不同的理解。实际问题涉及您的代码与其参数排序细节之间的交互MessageBox.Show()；错误存在于它们之间的某个地方。

Although you can fix this problem by changing your code, you can’t pin the blame squarely on your code or on the code in MessageBox.Show(); you just had a different understanding of how the parameters worked. The actual problem involves an interaction between your code and the details of how MessageBox.Show() orders its parameters; the bug is somewhere in the gap between them.

我想强调这一点：方法调用将软件的所有层连接在一起，而这些层之间的沟通不畅是导致意外问题的主要原因。层边界上的方法集合是一个 API；我将使用该术语在抽象意义上指代单个方法和方法集合。

I want to emphasize this point: method calls hold together all the layers of software, and miscommunication across these layers is a major cause of unexpected problems. A collection of methods at a layer boundary is an API; I’ll use that term to refer in an abstract sense to both a single method and collection of methods.

所以重申一下：API 将软件的所有层连接在一起，这些层之间的沟通不畅是导致意外问题的主要原因。这种沟通不畅可能表现为多种形式，从没有意识到 API 期望参数的正确值，到没有意识到 API 将如何解释该参数以指导其内部逻辑，再到误解 API 返回值的时间和形式。许多调试会话结束时，程序员在仔细检查了自己的代码后，没有发现任何问题，打开文档，拍拍额头，惊呼：“哦，我没有意识到我调用的 API 是这样工作的。”

So to restate: APIs hold together all the layers of software, and miscommunication across these layers is a major cause of unexpected problems. This miscommunication can take a variety of forms, from not realizing the proper value that the API expects in a parameter, to not realizing how the API will interpret that parameter in guiding its internal logic, to misunderstanding when and in what form the API returns values. Many debugging sessions end with a programmer, after having examined their own code with a fine-tooth comb and found nothing amiss, cracking open the documentation, slapping their forehead, and exclaiming, “Oh, I didn’t realize that the API that I was calling worked that way.”

这里的决策权在编写 API 代码的程序员手中；API 的调用者必须遵守其他人的决定。通常，您无法看到所调用 API 中的代码；它仅以编译后的代码形式提供给您，没有源代码。不幸的是，编写向其他人提供 API 的代码的人通常不会花很多时间担心 API 的外部清晰度，而是陷入 API 的内部实现中。这是因为对于您要编写的任何给定代码，可能有多种编写方法，而对于选择哪一种则没有太多的智慧。

The decisions here are in the hands of the programmer writing the code inside the API; the caller of the API is stuck with whatever that other person decided. Often you cannot see the code in the API you are calling; it is provided to you only as compiled code, with no source code available. Unfortunately, people who write code that supplies APIs to other people generally don’t spend a lot of time worrying about the external clarity of their API but instead get bogged down in the internal implementation of the API. This is because for any given code you want to write, there are likely multiple ways to write it, and not a lot of wisdom about which one to choose.

心理学家巴里·施瓦茨 (Barry Schwartz) 撰写的《选择的悖论》一书指出（在题为“我们为何受苦”的部分），拥有更多选择并不会让人更幸福：

The book The Paradox of Choice, by the psychologist Barry Schwartz, argues (in a section of the book titled “Why We Suffer”) that having more choices does not make people happier:

自由和自主对我们的幸福至关重要，而选择对自由和自主至关重要。尽管如此，尽管现代美国人拥有比以往任何群体都多的选择，因此，可能也拥有更多的自由和自主，但我们似乎并没有从中得到心理上的好处。4

Freedom and autonomy are critical to our well-being, and choice is critical to freedom and autonomy. Nonetheless, though modern Americans have more choice than any group of people ever has had before, and thus, presumably, more freedom and autonomy, we don’t seem to be benefiting from it psychologically.4

然后他继续解释道，过多的选择有时会给我们带来负担。程序员经常是这种情况的受害者；编写甚至像上面这样的微不足道的代码的方法有很多，很难知道哪种方法才是“正确的”。

He then goes on to explain that too much choice can sometimes be a burden on us. Programmers are frequently victims of this; there are so many ways to write even trivial code like the stuff above, it is hard to know what the “right” way is.

回到我们之前的代码，这是MessageBox.Show()我们上次看到的正确版本（没有交换参数）：

Getting back to our code from before, here is the correct version (without the swapped parameters to MessageBox.Show()) as we last saw it:

string ErrorMessage = "This is my error message";
string EM_Upper = ErrorMessage.ToUpper();
MessageBox.Show(EM_Upper, "ERROR!");
string ErrorMessage = "This is my error message";
string EM_Upper = ErrorMessage.ToUpper();
MessageBox.Show(EM_Upper, "ERROR!");

请注意，在第二行中，我们声明了一个新变量 ，EM_Upper用于保存大写版本。这似乎是合理的；尽管我们不需要原始的混合大小写错误消息，但我们可能在将来的某个时候需要它，因此我们分配了第二个变量来保存大写版本，并将原始版本保留在 中ErrorMessage。

Observe that in the second line, we declare a new variable, EM_Upper, to hold the uppercase version. This seems reasonable; although we don’t need the original mixed-case error message, we may want it at some point in the future, so we allocate a second variable to hold the uppercase version and keep the original in ErrorMessage.

等等。我们需要保留 的原始值ErrorMessage吗？当然，我们可能在将来版本的代码中需要它，但现在我们不需要。如果我们不需要它，我们可以EM_Upper完全避免，而是ErrorMessage用其大写版本替换并将其传递给MessageBox.Show()：

Hang on. Do we need to retain the original value of ErrorMessage? Sure, we might need it in a future version of this code, but right now we don’t. And if we don’t need it, we can avoid EM_Upper entirely and instead replace ErrorMessage with its uppercase version and pass that to MessageBox.Show():

string ErrorMessage = "This is my error message";
ErrorMessage = ErrorMessage.ToUpper();
MessageBox.Show(ErrorMessage, "ERROR!");
string ErrorMessage = "This is my error message";
ErrorMessage = ErrorMessage.ToUpper();
MessageBox.Show(ErrorMessage, "ERROR!");

仔细想想，由于我们对大写错误消息所做的一切就是将其传递给MessageBox.Show()- 我们不会在任何后续代码中使用原始版本或大写版本 - 我们可以将最后两行代码合并为一行：

Come to think of it, since all we do with the uppercase error message is pass it to MessageBox.Show()—we don’t use the original or the uppercase version in any later code—we can combine the last two lines of code into one:

string ErrorMessage = "This is my error message";
MessageBox.Show(ErrorMessage.ToUpper(), "ERROR!");
string ErrorMessage = "This is my error message";
MessageBox.Show(ErrorMessage.ToUpper(), "ERROR!");

但是——我指出这一点只是为了帮助大家，你们明白吗——现在我们还没有将大写版本保存在任何地方。我们将它传递给MessageBox.Show()，然后它就消失在以太中了。这重要吗？如果代码稍后再次需要大写值，我们需要ToUpper()再次调用，这似乎很浪费，所以我们不应该将输出保存在ToUpper()某个地方以防万一吗？如果我们决定保存它，我们应该将它存回去ErrorMessage还是创建EM_Upper一个单独的变量，这样也可以保留原始版本，但会使用更多的计算机内存？

Except—and I’m just pointing this out to be helpful, you understand—now we haven’t saved the uppercase version anywhere. We passed it to MessageBox.Show() and then it disappears into the ether. Does this matter? If the code later needs the uppercase value a second time, we would need to call ToUpper() again, which seems wasteful, so shouldn’t we save the output of ToUpper() somewhere just in case? And if we do decide to save it, should we stash it back in ErrorMessage or create EM_Upper as a separate variable, thus retaining the original version as well but using a little more of the computer’s memory?

最后几段讨论都是理论上的。代码现在可以正常工作，那么为什么要让它复杂化呢？既然代码不需要做这两件事，为什么还要担心保存两个版本或调用两次呢？ToUpper()

These last few paragraphs of discussion are all theoretical. The code works right now, so why complicate it? Why are you worrying about saving both versions or calling ToUpper() twice when the code needs to do neither of those things?

当然，另一边的魔鬼回答说，但也许如果你现在就为未来做好准备，当你熟悉代码时，你以后犯错的机会就会减少，总体上节省时间。准备充分的魔鬼可能会指出，一项关于软件维护的研究指出，“有一个独特的维护方面，称为‘知识恢复’或‘程序理解’。随着软件老化，它成为主要的成本组成部分（假设增强和缺陷修复各占 50%）。”5您未来维护成本的一半将用于重新学习您在此期间可能已经忘记的程序细节！当然，最好现在就进行这些更改，因为代码在您的脑海中还记忆犹新。

Sure, replies the devil on the other shoulder, but maybe if you set yourself up for the future now, when you are familiar with the code, you will have less chance of making a mistake later and save time overall. A well-prepared devil might point out that one study of software maintenance noted, “There is a unique maintenance aspect called ‘knowledge recovery’ or ‘program understanding.’ It becomes a major cost component as software ages (assume 50% of both enhancements and defect fixing).”5 Half your future maintenance costs will be spent relearning the details of your program that you will have forgotten in the meantime! Surely it is better to make those changes now, when the code is fresh in your mind.

请记住我们这里讨论的是三行代码。

Keep in mind we’re talking about three lines of code here.

这个问题并非软件所独有；许多任务可以通过多种方式完成。不同之处在于，您可以轻松改变主意并更新代码，并且缺乏确定哪种方法从长远来看最有用的标准。如果您正在建造一座桥梁，您将知道它应该跨越的距离和应该承受的重量，并且大家都知道当前的设计是基于这些因素的。没有人会认为，只需进行一些修改，相同的桥梁设计就能处理两倍的距离或重量，或者在桥梁建造到一半时很容易适应这种变化。更改软件非常容易——只需按几下键，挥挥编译器，您就完成了——因此诱惑总是存在的，出于同样的原因，提前弄清楚一切的动机更少了。最终的结果是，几乎每个编写的软件最终都会被修改来解决与设计目的不同的问题。

This problem is not unique to software; many tasks can be accomplished in multiple ways. What’s different is the ease with which you can change your mind and update your code, and the lack of criteria for determining which approach will be most useful in the long term. If you are building a bridge, you will know the distance it is supposed to span and weight it is supposed to hold, and it is understood that the current design is based on those factors. Nobody is going to assume that the same bridge design, with just a few modifications, will handle twice as much distance or weight, or that it will be simple to accommodate such a change when the bridge is halfway built. Changing software is so easy—a few keystrokes, a wave of the compiler, and you are done—that the temptation is always there, and the incentive to figure everything out ahead of time is less, for the same reason. The end result is that almost every piece of software written eventually winds up being modified to solve a different problem than what it was designed for.

“计算机的灵活性是独一无二的”，研究员约翰·肖尔 (John Shore) 在其论文《正确性的神话》中指出：

“The computer’s flexibility is unique,” points out the researcher John Shore in his essay “Myths of Correctness”:

没有其他类型的机器可以在不进行物理修改的情况下进行如此大的改变。此外，进行大幅度修改和进行小幅度修改一样容易，这是不幸的，因为大幅度修改更容易导致问题。对于其他类型的机器，进行大幅度修改比进行小幅度修改更难。这一事实为修改提供了自然约束，而计算机软件则不存在这种约束。6

No other kind of machine can be changed so much without physical modifications. Moreover, drastic modifications are as easy to make as minor ones, which is unfortunate, since drastic modifications are more likely to cause problems. With other kinds of machines, drastic modifications are correspondingly harder to make then minor ones. This fact provides natural constraints to modification that are absent in the case of computer software.6

《软件设计师在行动》一书的编辑 André van der Hoek 和 Marian Petre观察到，“几乎任何产品在交付后都可能以某种方式发生变化。软件的独特之处在于客户、用户和其他利益相关者对软件变化的期望。”7由于软件几乎总是有潜在的替代未来，因此对建议的改进没有时效限制。除非你能预见未来，否则你永远不知道哪些改进会带来真正的节省，哪些改进会带来不必要的麻烦。

André van der Hoek and Marian Petre, editors of the book Software Designers in Action, observe, “Almost any product can be changed, in some way, after it is delivered. What makes software unusual is the expectation of the customer, the user, and other stakeholders, that it will change.”7 Since software almost always has a potential alternate future ahead of it, there is no statute of limitations on suggested improvements. And you never know, unless you can see the future, which ones will result in real savings and which ones will be needless complications.

虽然我们在这里讨论的选择（调用什么 API，或者是否使用变量）在这种情况下似乎无害，但这些选择恰恰是那种如果做出错误就会导致软件出现真正问题、崩溃、挂起或允许其他用户窃取您的文件的选择。20 世纪 30 年代安装旋钮和管道布线的电工遵循了当时正确、最先进的做法；只是事后才发现，他们实际上为后代带来了一个巨大、昂贵且可能危及生命的问题。您做出的 API 选择是一个明智的决定，还是未来的程序员会认为这是一个可怕的错误，因为他们会诽谤您的名字？

While the choices we’re discussing here—what API to call, or whether to use a variable or not—seem innocuous in this situation, these are precisely the sort of choices that can, if made incorrectly, lead to software that has real problems, that crashes, hangs, or allows other users to steal your files. The electricians who installed knob-and-tube wiring back in the 1930s were following correct, state-of-the-art practices for the time; it was only determined in retrospect that they were actually creating a large, expensive, and potentially life-threatening problem for future generations to deal with. Is that API choice you are making a clever decision, or will it be determined by a future programmer, as they slander your name, to be horribly misguided?

不过，您不能永远犹豫不决，因此最终您会在现在与未来满足之间选择一个点，并编写代码以匹配。您现在完成了吗？

Still, you can’t dither forever, so eventually you choose a spot on the continuum of present versus future gratification, and write your code to match. Are you done now?

不，除非你独自一人编程，而这通常只发生在阳光明媚的大学（或高中）时期。你现在是一名专业程序员，与其他程序员一起工作，因此接下来就是一个机会，让你的所有同事都通过一个看似吉利的活动发表意见，这个活动就是代码审查。

No, unless you are programming all by yourself, which usually only happens during the sunny idyll known as college (or high school). You are now a professional programmer, working with other programmers, so what comes next is an opportunity for all your coworkers to give their opinions through an activity with the seemingly auspicious name of code review.

代码审查是指其他人对您的代码提出建设性批评。这听起来是个好主意，就像找第二个电工来检查一下您的工作一样。这正是人们从自己在家进行布线项目毕业成为专业电工时所期望的：找别人来指出您的旋钮和管子，以免它们引起火灾！使用的语言将这个类比推向了错误的方向，因为电工受电气规范（再次使用这个词）的约束。电气规范中写明：“新建房屋不得使用旋钮和管子布线”，更重要的是，“评估现有的旋钮和管子布线时，您需要查看以下事项以确定其是否安全。”“代码审查”一词意味着您的同事程序员正在注意与公认实践和标准的偏差，将您的代码与“专业程序员的 [另一种] 代码”进行比较。

A code review is where other people offer constructive criticism of your code. This sounds like a good idea, like grabbing a second electrician to give your work the once-over. That’s what you would expect people to do as they graduate from do-it-yourself wiring projects in their own home to becoming professional electricians: find somebody else to point out your knobs and tubes before they can cause any fires! The language used gives this analogy a helpful shove in the wrong direction, because electricians are governed by an electric code (that word again). The electric code is where it is written down, “Thou shalt not use knob-and-tube wiring for new homes,” and more important, “When evaluating existing knob-and-tube wiring, these are the things you look for to determine if it is safe.” The phrase “code review” implies that your fellow programmers are noting deviations from accepted practices and standards, comparing your code to a “professional programmer’s [the other kind of] code.”

不幸的是，软件没有电子代码，程序员可以阅读的书籍虽然在某些方面提供了建议，但没有任何实证研究的支持；它们往往会加剧争论的双方。代码审查实际上是其他程序员就如何编写代码给出个人意见，这些意见仅基于他们自己的经验。由于您的同事知道代码的灵活性，他们可能会觉得应该采纳他们的建议，无论游戏进行到多晚，因为游戏永远不会结束。这使得他们更有可能建议更改，并且如果您不同意他们的观点，他们更有可能对您的代码嗤之以鼻。

Unfortunately there is no equivalent of an electric code for software, and the books available to programmers, although they offer advice in some of these areas, are not backed up by any empirical studies; they tend to add fuel to both sides of a debate. A code review is really about other programmers giving their personal opinions on how they would have written the code, backed up by nothing more than their own experiences. And since your peers know all about how flexible code is, they are likely to feel that their suggestions should be adopted, no matter how late in the game it is, because the game never ends. This makes them more likely to suggest changes and more likely to pooh-pooh your code if you don’t agree with them.

代码审查最有可能的反馈是其他程序员对您在发送代码进行审查之前思考的相同问题的看法：您是否应该根据目前尚不清楚的未来需求修改代码？

The most likely feedback from a code review is other programmers’ opinions on the same questions that you noodled over before you even sent the code out for review: Should you modify your code now in anticipation of future needs, of which you are currently unaware?

考虑变量名——一个人们经常谈论的话题。上面的代码有两个变量，ErrorMessage和EM_Upper。这些名称不一致；第二个名称对变量的含义进行了解释（大写），而第一个名称中没有这个解释，而第一个名称说明了变量的用途（它是一个错误消息），但第二个名称使用了首字母缩写。我们，代码的作者，知道它是如何演变到这一点的：我们从一个变量开始，ErrorMessage后来添加了第二个变量。在添加第二个变量之前，我们不知道它与第一个变量有什么区别，因此使用普通的旧变量ErrorMessage似乎是合理的。同时，在发明时EM_Upper，我们决定节省一些打字工作并缩短第一部分。

Consider variable names—a favorite topic. Our code above has two variables, ErrorMessage and EM_Upper. Those names are inconsistent; the second one has an explanation of the meaning of the variable (it’s in uppercase) that is absent from the first one, while the first one spells out the purpose of the variable (it’s an error message), but the second one uses initials. We, the author of the code, know how it evolved to this point: we started with only one variable, ErrorMessage, and added the second one later. Until we added the second one, we didn’t know what was going to distinguish it from the first, so plain-old ErrorMessage seemed reasonable. Meanwhile, when inventing EM_Upper, we decided to save a bit of typing and shorten the first part.

现在，一旦我们添加了第二个变量，并且大小写（大小写混合与大写）成为区分因素，我们可以将原来的所有用法重命名ErrorMessage为ErrorMessageMixed，但实际上我们应该改为EM_Upper，ErrorMessageUpper或者交替改为ErrorMessageMixed。EM_Mixed仔细想一想，初始错误消息可能已经是大写；我们不能假设它是大小写混合，因此也许ErrorMessageOriginalCase是一个更好的名称。这意味着ErrorMessageUpper应该变成ErrorMessageUpperCase。同时，我们仍然不能 100% 确定我们需要两个变量，那么我们愿意进行所有这些输入吗？迫在眉睫的是犯错的可能性不为零（特别是，意外地将 的一个用法替换为ErrorMessage而ErrorMessageUpper不是ErrorMessageMixed，这可以编译成功，但运行时会搞砸一切）。

Now once we did add the second variable and the case—mixed versus upper—became the distinguishing factor, we could have renamed all uses of the original ErrorMessage to be ErrorMessageMixed, but really we should then go change EM_Upper to ErrorMessageUpper, or alternately change ErrorMessageMixed to EM_Mixed. And come to think of it, the initial error message might already be in uppercase; we can’t assume it is mixed case, so perhaps ErrorMessageOriginalCase would be a better name. Which would mean ErrorMessageUpper should become ErrorMessageUpperCase. Meanwhile we’re still not 100 percent sure we need two variables, so are we willing to commit to all that typing? Looming over this is the nonzero chance of making a mistake (in particular, accidentally replacing one of the uses of ErrorMessage with ErrorMessageUpper instead of ErrorMessageMixed, which would compile fine, but botch everything when you ran it).

第二个程序员来到现场进行代码审查时，他们不知道这段历史，也不会理解你内心的挣扎。他们看到的是名称ErrorMessage和之间的不一致EM_Upper，他们很可能会指出这一点。顺便说一句，变量名在程序编译时就消失了，因此更改变量名不会影响程序的运行方式或用户运行它的体验。这只是程序员为了未来遇到代码的程序员而争论可读性。

A second programmer arriving on the scene for a code review knows none of this history, nor do they appreciate your inner struggle. What they see is the inconsistency between the names ErrorMessage and EM_Upper, which they will likely point out. By the way, variable names go away when the program is compiled, so changing the variable name has no effect on how the program runs or the user’s experience running it. This is just programmers arguing about readability for the sake of future programmers who encounter the code.

信不信由你，最有争议的问题之一是，在书中阅读代码时根本看不到这个问题：缩进代码时（这种情况经常发生），您是输入一系列空格还是单个制表符？有些人喜欢每次看到代码缩进四个空格，有些人喜欢看到代码缩进八个空格；使用制表符意味着每个人都可以通过调整自己计算机上的制表符设置来查看他们喜欢的缩进级别，但有些人认为这是异端邪说，并认为原始程序员应该能够精确控制缩进的显示方式。更糟糕的是，混合使用制表符和空格的文件可能会演变成视觉折磨。当我在 20 世纪 90 年代初开发 Windows NT（当今 Windows 的前身）的第一个版本时，有一条严格的规定，即源代码中不能有制表符，否则您的同事会用恶狠狠的眼神看着您（一旦他们从您的代码中删除制表符）。直到今天，如果你想看到程序员翻白眼，就说出那句神奇的短语“制表符与空格”。8

Believe it or not, one of the most contentious questions, which you can’t see at all when reading code in a book, is this: When indenting code, which happens a fair bit, do you type a series of spaces or a single tab character? Some people like to see code indented four spaces each time, and some like to see it indented eight spaces; using tab characters means each person can see the indent level they like by adjusting the tab settings on their own computer, but some people consider that heresy and think the original programmer should be able to control exactly how the indenting is seen. Worse, a file with a mix of tabs and spaces can devolve into a visual torment. When I worked on the first versions of Windows NT (the precursor to today’s Windows) back in the early 1990s, there was a strict rule that there would be no tab characters in the source code, on pain of baleful stares from your coworkers (once they got finished removing the tabs from your code). To this day, if you want to see an eye roll from a programmer, utter the magic phrase “tabs versus spaces.”8

现在您已经了解了变量名和缩进，以及进一步的讨论主题，比如是否应该在分配给变量时在等号前、方法调用的左括号前、分隔方法参数的逗号后、行末的分号前放置一个空格，或者实际上在任何有空格或没有空格的地方（几乎任何地方都有，因为大多数编程语言都会忽略代码中的多余空格），或者代码中的空行是罪恶的浪费还是光荣的奢侈。

So you’ve got the variable names and indenting, and further discussion topics such as whether you should put a space before the equal sign when assigning to a variable, before the opening parenthesis of a method call, after the comma that separates method parameters, before the semicolon at the end of a line, or really anywhere there is or isn’t a space (which is almost anywhere, since most programming languages ignore extra spaces in the code), or whether blank lines in your code are a sinful waste or glorious luxury.

哈兰·米尔斯（Harlan Mills）曾经写过类似的情况，他坚持认为：“由于没有数学严谨性来抑制这些讨论，有些人变得非常激烈。”9说是激烈还只是轻描淡写；这些论点通常被称为“宗教论点”，因为它们完全依赖于信仰，而不是已证实的证据。

Harlan Mills once wrote about a similar situation, maintaining, “Since there was no mathematical rigor to inhibit these discussions, some became quite vehement.”9 Vehement is an understatement; these arguments are often called “religious” because they rely entirely on faith, not demonstrated evidence.

尽管付出了精力，代码审查很少发现真正用户可见的错误。它们更多的是执行本地规范，例如“这就是我们命名变量的方式”。真正严重的错误、安全问题或潜在的崩溃通常涉及一系列错误，每个错误都小到可以单独忽略，只是与错误的数据集不幸地协同作用。它们通常是负责 API 边界上两个相邻代码层的程序员之间的误解。布鲁克斯四十年前就认识到了这个问题：“最有害和最微妙的错误是由于各个组件的作者做出的不匹配的假设而产生的系统错误”（定义不明确的术语组件和模块通常用于表示“提供一组相关 API 的代码包”）。10代码审查人员确实会尝试预测代码的未来修改，但在审查提供 API 的代码时，他们很少会尝试预测 API 调用者未来可能产生的误解，尤其是因为代码尚未编写。当你从 API 内部向上看时，一切似乎都合乎逻辑。

Despite the energy expended, code reviews rarely turn up real user-visible bugs. They are more about enforcing local norms such as “this is how we name our variables.” Really bad bugs, security issues, or potential crashes usually involve a series of mistakes, each small enough to go unremarked in isolation, acting in unfortunate concert with just the wrong set of data. Oftentimes they are a misunderstanding between the programmers responsible for two adjacent layers of code at the API boundary. Brooks recognized this problem forty years ago: “The most pernicious and subtle bugs are system bugs arising from mismatched assumptions made by the authors of various components” (the loosely defined terms component and module are often used to denote “a bundle of code that provides a set of related APIs”).10 Code reviewers do try to anticipate future modifications to the code, but when reviewing code that provides an API, they rarely try to predict future misunderstandings by callers of the API, especially since that code hasn’t been written yet. When your perspective is from the inside of an API upward, it all seems perfectly logical.

因此，代码审查几乎从未涉及导出到上一层的 API 的可用性和清晰度问题。API 名称和参数列表是保存被审查代码的盒子，通常被接受为事实，而你的目光会滑过它以看到里面的具体算法部分。从某种意义上说，这是有道理的，因为内部是“隐藏”的部分，可能永远不会再被看到，而 API 的外部表面将被调用它的任何其他程序员看到，但后者对两个不同程序员的代码是否能按计划协同工作有着不成比例的影响。一旦提供 API 的代码被判断为完整，程序员更改 API 名称和参数的可能性甚至比重命名一个不清楚的变量的可能性更小；首先，他们还需要更改现在调用该 API 的任何代码。

As a result, code reviews almost never get into the issue of the usability and clarity of the APIs being exported to a layer above. The API name and parameter list is the box that holds the code being reviewed, normally accepted as fact while your eye slides over it to get to the meaty algorithmic parts inside. In a way that makes sense, since the internals are the “hidden” part that may never get looked at again, while the API external surface will be seen by any other programmers who call it, but the latter will have a disproportionate effect on whether code from two different programmers will work together as planned. And once the code providing an API is judged complete, programmers are even less likely to change the API name and parameters than they are to rename an unclear variable; for one thing, they would also need to change any code that is now calling that API.

话虽如此，我还是赞赏代码审查人员担心代码的可读性和可维护性，因为虽然这可能不会对 API 调用的清晰度产生太大影响，但它与另一个重要的 bug 来源直接相关，即跨时间的代码交接：另一个程序员需要修改代码以供将来使用的情况（或者如前所述，你过一段时间再回来看代码；你自己的代码变得陌生所需的时间很短）。代码审查人员可以很好地模拟未来的人，因为他们自己也不懂代码。问题是，虽然代码审查是出于好意，但他们指出的问题是否会影响未来的可维护性却并不明显；这经常是一种“他说，她说”的争论（或者不幸的是，经常是“他说，他说”的争论）。

Having said that, I do applaud code reviewers for worrying about the readability and maintainability of the code, because while it may not have much effect on clarity across API calls, it relates directly to another important source of bugs, which is code handoff across time: the situation where another programmer needs to modify the code for future use (or where you, as mentioned earlier, come back to the code some time later; the amount of time it takes your own code to become foreign to you is depressingly short). The code reviewer is a good simulation of that future person since they themselves do not know the code either. The problem is that while the code reviews are well intentioned, it’s not at all clear that the problems they point out will have an effect on future maintainability; it’s frequently a “he said, she said” sort of argument (or unfortunately, often a “he said, he said” one).

在微软的历史上，曾有人推崇使用匈牙利命名法来编写代码，即在变量名前面加上描述其类型的小数字 - 例如数字、字符串等等（“等等”的存在是因为程序员可以创建自己的类型，由字符串和数字的集合组成）。例如，所有字符串变量都以 开头sz，因此匈牙利风格的代码中充斥着像szUsername和 这样的变量名szAddress。理论上讲，不需要了解代码的任何其他工作原理，一眼就能知道某个变量是字符串还是数字，这很有用，可以防止你不小心在需要其中一个时使用了另一个。这导致了像 这样的完全不靠谱的例子szA，其中sz告诉大众这是一个字符串，但这A部分让人回想起 BASIC 时代，当时它并没有告诉您字符串的用途。

At one point in Microsoft’s history, there was a push to write code using Hungarian notation, where variable names were prepended with little duodenums that described their type—such as a number, string, and so on (the “and so on” exists because programmers can create their own types, built up from collections of strings and numbers). For example, all variables that were strings would start with sz, so Hungarian-styled code was peppered with variable names like szUsername and szAddress. The theory was that it was useful to know at a glance, without knowing anything else about how the code worked, if a particular variable was a string or number, to prevent you from accidentally using one where the other was called for. This led to extreme all-sizzle-no-steak examples like szA, where sz informed the masses that this was a string, but the A part was a flashback to the days of BASIC, which did nothing to tell you what the string was used for.

匈牙利语是微软内部争论的焦点；Office 团队采用了它，但 Windows NT 团队认为它很愚蠢，所以我也认为它很愚蠢（如果上面的讨论是关于 versus 的，EM_Upper那么关于versus的ErrorMessageUpperCase讨论会不会产生有意义的影响？）。Windows NT 的命名风格倾向于使用长首字母交叉命名，例如，这种风格被称为“驼峰式命名法”，因为大写字母看起来像多峰的苏斯博士骆驼；这个名字告诉你了很多关于变量用途的信息，但对其类型却讳莫如深。szEM_UpperszErrorMessageUpperCaseMaximumBufferLength

Hungarian was a source of contention in the halls of Microsoft; the Office team adopted it, but the Windows NT team thought it was silly, so I thought it was silly by osmosis (would the discussion above, about EM_Upper versus ErrorMessageUpperCase, have been meaningfully impacted if it instead were about szEM_Upper versus szErrorMessageUpperCase?). The Windows NT naming style tended toward long intercapped names, such as MaximumBufferLength, a style known as “camel casing” because the capital letters look like a multihumped Dr. Seuss camel; the name told you a lot about the purpose of the variable but kept mum on its type.

（对于某些读者来说，我需要澄清的是，驼峰式命名法实际上是将首字母小写，就像 一样exampleVariableName，而我们在 Windows NT 中使用的首字母大写的命名法被称为“帕斯卡式命名法”，但驼峰式命名法是一个更具启发性的短语。11不管怎样，回到我们的故事。）

(It will be important to certain readers for me to clarify that camel case actually has the initial letter in lowercase, as in exampleVariableName, and the ones with the first letter capitalized that we used in Windows NT were called “Pascal case,” but camel case is a much more evocative phrase.11 Anyway, back to our story.)

匈牙利命名法的支持者则嘲笑这些长的、不完全是驼峰式命名法的名称容易出错，而且浪费按键和磁盘存储空间（这两样东西在历史上一直都是程序员所短缺的，尽管说实话在历史上那个时刻已经不再短缺了）。这导致了反驳的观点，即变量CurrentlyLoggedInUserName是一个字符串已经足够清楚了，不需要在开头添加额外的字符来表明这一点。此外，到 20 世纪 90 年代初，编译器可以更好地识别代码传递了错误类型的变量（强制方法调用与方法签名匹配，例如在需要数字时不使用字符串，这是编译器技术的一项创新，而过去如果没有它，曾导致各种有趣的错误）。这使得匈牙利命名法不像 1986 年那样必要了：如果编译器要捕获类型不匹配，那么就不需要匈牙利命名法；更有趣的错误并不涉及混淆字符串和数字，而是在需要不同更复杂类型的地方使用一种更复杂的类型，而那些复杂类型不会有容易识别的匈牙利前缀来指导您。

Proponents of Hungarian in turn derided these long, not-quite-camel-case names as being error prone as well as wasteful of keystrokes and disk storage (two things that had historically been in short supply for programmers, although truthfully no longer were at that moment in history). Which led to the counterargument that it is clear enough that the variable CurrentlyLoggedInUserName is a string and no extra characters at the beginning are needed to indicate that. In addition, by the early 1990s compilers were better at recognizing when code was passing the wrong type of variable around (enforcing that your method call matched the method signature, such as not using a string when a number was called for, was an innovation in compiler technology whose absence had in the past caused all sorts of entertaining bugs). This made Hungarian less necessary than it was in, say, 1986: if the compiler is going to catch a type mismatch, then you don’t need Hungarian; and the more interesting mistakes do not involve bollixing up strings and number but are instead about using one more complicated type where a different more complicated type is needed, and those complicated types won’t have easily recognized Hungarian prefixes to guide you.

由于 Office 和 Windows NT 团队有各自独立的源代码堆，因此支持和反对匈牙利规则的争论可以毫无根据地来回进行；双方都有对方最严重的违规行为在公共广场上游行，驼峰命名法支持者窃笑，pwszA匈牙利规则支持者嗤之以鼻SomeReallyLongVariableName。如果曾经有过妥协的想法（长驼峰命名法名称加上匈牙利前缀怎么样？），我从未听说过。这是严肃的事情，没有时间考虑这些愚蠢的想法！此外，除了对方完全投降之外，任何其他做法都意味着要在自己的代码中修复大量变量名——这是一个令人生畏的前景，没有人愿意解决。少数有勇气换团队的程序员很快融入了他们的新文化，双方从未见过面。

Since the Office and Windows NT teams had their own separate piles of source code, pro- and anti-Hungarian arguments could be lobbed back and forth with no ground given; each side had the other’s worst-case offenders to parade around the public square, with camel casers chuckling at pwszA and Hungarian advocates snorting at SomeReallyLongVariableName. If there was ever a thought of compromise (how about long camel-cased names with Hungarian prefixes also?), I never heard about it. This was serious business, with no time for such foolish ideas! Besides, anything other than complete capitulation by the other side would have meant fixing up a lot of variable names in your own code—a daunting prospect that nobody wanted to tackle. The few programmers who were brave enough to switch teams were quickly assimilated into their new culture, and the twain never met.

让这场争论火上浇油的是，双方争论的并不是同一件事。最初的匈牙利系统被称为 Apps Hungarian，因为它被用在编写 Office 等应用程序的部门，它规定的前缀比变量的类型更具信息性；您可以使用前缀row或 来区分包含行号的变量和包含列号的变量col。12不知何故（人们通常把责任归咎于编写 Windows API 文档的团队，显然是出于简化符号的错误冲动），它以一种称为系统匈牙利符号的形式公开亮相，其中变量名前缀只标识类型——如数字与字符串——这没那么有用（尽管匈牙利符号前缀越像真实的单词，匈牙利符号和 Windows-NT 风格之间的差异就越明显，即首字母的大小写——当然，这仍然是宗教争论的沃土）。13因此，Office 团队所推崇的 Apps Hungarian 与被 Windows 团队当作出气筒的 Systems Hungarian 有所不同。

To add fuel to this bonfire of whataboutism, the two sides weren’t arguing about the same thing. The original Hungarian system, which became known as Apps Hungarian because it was used in the division that wrote applications such as Office, prescribed prefixes that were more informative than just the type of a variable; you might distinguish a variable that held a row number from one that held a column number by using the prefix row or col.12 Somehow (the blame is generally placed on the team that wrote the documentation for the Windows API, apparently following a misguided impulse to simplify the notation) it made its public debut in a form known as Systems Hungarian, in which the variable name prefixes only identified the type—as in number versus string—which is much less useful (although the more your Hungarian prefixes resemble real words, the more the difference between Hungarian and Windows-NT-style boils down to the capitalization of the first letter—still fertile ground for religious argument, of course).13 Thus the Apps Hungarian that was venerated by the Office team was different from the Systems Hungarian that was used as a punching bag by the Windows team.

幸运的是，一位名叫 G. Pascal Zachary 的作家写了一本有关 Windows NT 项目的书，并记录了他对当时华盛顿州雷德蒙德匈牙利战争的印象：

By good fortune, a writer named G. Pascal Zachary wrote a book about that Windows NT project and recorded his impressions of the Hungarian battle raging in Redmond, Washington, at the time:

然而，有些争议涉及程序员所谓的“宗教分歧”。争议的焦点似乎只对狂热分子来说很重要；中立方可能会说双方都是对的。但狂热分子无法用逻辑论据让对手闭嘴，因此会辱骂对手。

最奇怪的争议之一，也让狂热分子们露出了最坏的一面，它涉及用 C 语言编写指令时使用的符号系统，C 语言是最流行的计算机语言之一。多年来，微软采用了自己的惯例，称为匈牙利符号，以其创始人布达佩斯出生的查尔斯·西蒙尼命名。……它缺乏传统符号的熟悉感，传统符号主要依赖于英语单词而不是晦涩难懂的缩写。这两种风格之间的差异引发了许多争论，而局外人却无法理解这些争论的优点。14

Some disputes, however, involved what programmers call “religious differences.” The points at stake seem important only to zealots; a neutral party might say that both sides are right. But zealots—unable to silence their opponents with logical arguments—hurl insults.

One of the oddest disputes, which brought out the worst in zealots, involved the notational system used to write instructions in C, one of the most popular computer languages. Over the years Microsoft had adopted its own conventions, called Hungarian, after its creator, Budapest-born Charles Simonyi. … [I]t lacked the ready familiarity of conventional notation, which relied largely on English words rather than opaque abbreviations. The differences between the two styles spawned many arguments, whose merits were lost on outsiders.14

团队中的一名程序员（不是我）曾将匈牙利语描述为“我见过的最愚蠢的东西”，尽管不清楚他指的是应用匈牙利语还是系统匈牙利语。他补充道：“编码风格之争是对宝贵资源的浪费，尽管匈牙利语造成的混乱可能会浪费更多时间。”15如果他的论点听起来合理，请记住，他是痴迷于缩进源代码时使用制表符还是空格的团队的一员。同样的程序员可以对方法参数之间的空格抱有完全理性的“自己活也让别人活”的态度，但一看到源代码中不需要的空行就会大发雷霆。就此而言，我不会将 Windows NT 中使用的变量名描述为“传统符号”；当我第一次加入团队时，它们对我来说似乎很长，因为我习惯了没有匈牙利前缀的“晦涩缩写”。

One of the programmers on the team (not me) is quoted describing Hungarian as “the stupidest thing I’d ever seen,” although it’s unclear if he is referring to Apps Hungarian or Systems Hungarian. He adds the quasiwise summary, “Coding style wars are a waste of valuable resources, although the confusion caused by Hungarian probably wastes more time.”15 And if his arguments sound reasonable, remember he was part of the crew that obsessed over tabs versus spaces for indenting source code. The same programmer can have a perfectly rational, “live and let live” attitude about, say, spaces between method parameters, but go into conniptions at the sight of an unneeded blank line in the source code. For that matter, I wouldn’t have described the variable names used in Windows NT as “conventional notation”; they seemed oddly long to me when I first joined the team, being used to “opaque abbreviations” sans Hungarian prefixes.

幸运的是，代码审阅者最终会停止评论，或者你会厌倦听取他们的意见，然后你可以更新代码以反映你选择听取的反馈。当然，对代码的任何更改都可能犯下新的错误，而这些错误反过来又需要他们自己进行调试；当你决定今天要履行公民义务并重命名那个模糊变量时，却发现你在进行更改时不小心破坏了某些东西，而编译器现在抱怨“表达式树 lambda 可能不包含左侧为空文字的合并运算符”——这是一个真正的 C# 编译器错误，尽管不太可能是由变量名称的拼写错误引起的。16

Luckily the code reviewers will eventually stop commenting, or you will get tired of listening, and you can update your code to reflect the feedback you choose to heed. Of course, any change to your code is an opportunity to make new mistakes that will in turn require their own debugging; it is a particularly numbing experience to decide that today is the day you are going to do your civic duty and rename that obscure variable, only to discover that you have accidentally broken something while making the change, and the compiler is now complaining that “an expression tree lambda may not contain a coalescing operator with a null literal left-hand side”—an actual C# compiler error, albeit one that is unlikely to be caused by a typo in a variable name.16

让我们对代码再做一点修改：让它只在错误消息中包含单词“JavaScript”时显示该消息（JavaScript 是另一种编程语言）。由于我们已将消息大写，因此我们可以使用方法检查它是否包含大写单词“JAVASCRIPT” Contains()（我删除了第一行，其中明确设置ErrorMessage为“这是我的错误消息”，因为这会使代码看起来有点荒谬；显然该字符串不包含“JAVASCRIPT”，因此没有理由检查）：

Let’s make one more change to our code: have it only display the error message if that message contains the word “JavaScript” in it (JavaScript is another programming language). Since we have uppercased the message, we can check if it contains the capital word “JAVASCRIPT” using the Contains() method (I’ve removed the first line, where it explicitly sets ErrorMessage to “This is my error message,” because it would make the code look slightly ridiculous; clearly that string does not contain “JAVASCRIPT,” so there’s no reason to check):

string EM_Upper = ErrorMessage.ToUpper();
if (EM_Upper.Contains("JAVASCRIPT")) {
    MessageBox.Show(EM_Upper, "ERROR!");
}
string EM_Upper = ErrorMessage.ToUpper();
if (EM_Upper.Contains("JAVASCRIPT")) {
    MessageBox.Show(EM_Upper, "ERROR!");
}

上面写着

The line that reads

if (EM_Upper.Contains("JAVASCRIPT")) {
if (EM_Upper.Contains("JAVASCRIPT")) {

执行测试；如果EM_Upper其本身的任何位置包含字符串“JAVASCRIPT”，则运行之间的代码{ }，否则不运行。该词if是 C# 语言中公认的关键字；为了方便标记，我将用大写字母书写此类关键字，即使在传统上用小写字母书写的语言中也是如此，因此它将被称为语句IF。

performs a test; if EM_Upper contains the string “JAVASCRIPT” anywhere within itself, then the code between the { } runs, and otherwise it doesn’t. The word if is a recognized keyword in the C# language; for notational convenience, I am going to write such keywords in capital letters, even in languages that traditionally are written in lowercase, so it will be referred to as an IF statement.

作为认真负责的程序员，我们知道我们的代码可以在多个国家运行，错误信息可能会被翻译成不同的语言，但我们确信，作为一种编程语言的名称，JavaScript 这个术语不会被翻译。

As conscientious programmers, we are aware that our code can run in multiple countries, where the error messages might be translated into a different language, but we have been assured that the term JavaScript, being the name of a programming language, won’t be translated.

这是正确的吗？嗯，基本思想是正确的，但它确实有一个错误，而且您可能暂时不会意识到这一点，因为它取决于您（以及许多经验丰富的程序员）可能完全不知道的方法实现的细节。

Is this correct? Well, the basic idea is correct, but it does have a bug, and you might not realize that for a while, because it depends on a detail of the implementation of a method that you—and many experienced programmers—are likely completely unaware of.

作为非显而易见的方法实现细节的示例，请考虑 的内部结构MessageBox.Show()，即显示消息框的实际代码。编写代码的一个重要方面是确定哪些行为对其方法的调用者有意义，以及如何通过参数访问该行为。

As an example of nonobvious method implementation details, consider the internals of MessageBox.Show(), the actual code that shows a message box. An important aspect of writing the code was deciding what behavior made sense to callers of their method and how that behavior should be accessible via the parameters.

您可能已经从本章前面的屏幕截图中注意到，除了显示消息和标题之外，消息框还将显示一个标有“OK”的按钮，用户可以点击：

You may have noticed, from the screenshots earlier in this chapter, that in addition to showing the message and title, the message box will display a button labeled “OK” that the user can click:

这是完全合理的，在文档中有所说明，并且在运行程序时很明显，但从方法名称和参数列表中并不清楚。

This is perfectly reasonable, noted in the documentation, and apparent when you run the program, but not clear from knowing the method name and parameter list.

这种情况看起来是无害的：MessageBox.Show()将显示调用者未明确请求的按钮，但这有害吗？在这种情况下，答案是“否”。事实上，通过传递额外的参数，您可以控制显示哪些按钮 - 假设您知道该方法支持这一点。然而，具有未知副作用的方法会导致许多错误。

The situation appears benign: MessageBox.Show() will show a button that the caller didn’t explicitly request, but is that harmful? The answer is “no” in this case. In fact, by passing extra parameters, you can have some control over what buttons are shown—assuming you know that the method supports this. Yet methods having unknown side effects is the cause of many bugs.

我大学毕业后的第一份工作就遇到过这样的问题，某些医生的街道地址被替换了。当我被请去帮忙时，很快就发现问题出在从计算机数据库检索医生信息的 API 上（而不是检索到正确的地址但显示代码却乱了）。我记不清那个 API 的确切名称了，但这不重要；我们称之为GetDatabaseRecord()。这个 API 大概带有指定要检索哪位医生的参数，尽管这些也不重要。当然GetDatabaseRecord()它本身是建立在其他 API 调用之上的，而这些 API 调用又建立在其他 API 调用之上，依此类推。我的任务是仔细研究这些底层代码，找出它们偶尔出现故障的原因。

That was exactly the situation with the bug at my first job out of college, where the street address of certain doctors was being replaced. When I was enlisted to help, it was quickly apparent that the problem was in the API that retrieved the doctor’s information from the database on the computer (as opposed to, say, retrieving the right address but messing up the code to display it). The exact name of that API escapes my memory, but it doesn’t matter; we’ll call it GetDatabaseRecord(). This API presumably took parameters specifying which doctor to retrieve, although those don’t matter either. Of course GetDatabaseRecord() was itself built on other API calls, which were built on other API calls, and so on. My task was to paw through these underlying layers of code and find out why they were occasionally misbehaving.

经过一番调查，我发现另一个程序员修改了程序的一部分，以计算和显示数据库中有关医生的额外数据。在某些情况下，这需要他们从数据库中加载其他医生记录（我不记得细节了，但假设两位医生曾一起上过医学院，数据库在某处记录了这一点——这只在某些情况下才会发生，并且不会在显示损坏地址的医生和其他医生之间产生明显差异，因此在重现步骤中没有记录）。因为医生的街道地址在数据库中的所有其他数据字段中是独一无二的，是一个长度可能变化很大的字符串，所以我们将“从数据库中加载的最后一个医生的街道地址”存储在内存中的特定变量中，该变量有足够的空间容纳任何合理大小的地址。这是您为节省当时性能不足的计算机的内存而进行的优化。

After some investigation, I discovered that another programmer had modified a section of the program to calculate and display extra data about the doctors in the database. In certain cases, this required them to load other doctor records out of the database (I don’t recall the details, but let’s say that in the case where two doctors had attended medical school together, the database had this noted somewhere—something that would only be true in certain instances, and didn’t jump out as an obvious difference between the doctors showing a corrupted address and the others, so it was not noted in the repro steps). Because the street address of a doctor, somewhat uniquely among all the other data fields in the database, was a string that could be of wildly varying length, we stored the “street address of the last doctor loaded from the database” in a specific variable in memory that had enough room for any reasonably sized address. This is the sort of optimization you made to save memory on the underpowered computers of the day.

在另一个程序员添加的功能中，街道地址是不需要的，所以这个改变无关紧要，但这意味着有时那个特殊的“我们从数据库加载的最后一位医生的街道地址”变量中的地址并不是我们所想的那样，因为在加载一位医生的信息时，我们继续加载他在医学院的伙伴的信息，这就更新了“我们从数据库加载的最后一位医生的街道地址”变量。这一切都发生在调用的代码的几层之下GetDatabaseRecord()；那段代码没有改变，但是的内部行为GetDatabaseRecord()——或者更准确和更令人恼火的是，在下面几层被调用的 API 的内部行为GetDatabaseRecord()——发生了变化。这并不是另一个程序员的恶意，但它足够微妙，以至于当她自己第一次调查“错误地址”问题时，也没有意识到她之前的更改导致了问题。

In the feature that the other programmer was adding, the street address wasn’t needed, so this change didn’t matter, but it meant that sometimes the address in that special “street address of the last doctor we loaded from the database” variable wasn’t what we thought it was, because while loading information for one doctor, we proceeded to load information for his medical school buddy, and this updated the “street address of the last doctor we loaded from the database” variable. This was all happening several layers below the code that called GetDatabaseRecord(); that code hadn’t changed, but the internal behavior of GetDatabaseRecord()—or more precisely and vexingly, the internal behavior of an API that was itself called several layers below GetDatabaseRecord()—had changed. This wasn’t maliciousness on the part of the other programmer, yet it was subtle enough that even she herself, when the “wrong address” problem was first being looked into, didn’t realize that her earlier change was causing the problem.

再次，您完全听命于编写您调用的 API 的人——不仅要按逻辑顺序定义参数，还要记录所有预期的副作用，即使它们的重要性并不明显。调用 API 时，您几乎无法获得有关其实现细节和可靠性的信息——只有名称和参数列表，就像一条细线将软件粘合在一起。

Once again you are at the mercy of whoever wrote the API you are calling—not only to define the parameters in a logical order, but also to document all the intended side effects, even if it isn’t obvious why they would matter. When calling an API, you have precious little information about the details of its implementation and how reliable it is—just a name and a parameter list, as a thin line of glue holding together your software.

我不记得我是如何解决这个问题的，但找到它之后就很容易了；解决方案可以留给读者作为练习。我可能会添加一个额外的参数来GetDatabaseRecord()告诉它“不要加载额外的医生信息”，并在这种特定情况下将该参数设为“真”。如果我有动力，我可以重写使用单个“我们从数据库加载的最后一位医生的街道地址”变量的代码，以便它根据需要使用多个变量。第二种方法可能更“正确”，但它也会是一个更大的变化，推迟我的香槟奖励，并且在修复过程中更有可能破坏其他东西。从好的方面来看，这意味着未来 API 的调用者GetDatabaseRecord()对实现的了解更少，这将使事情更不容易出错。正如人们在代码审查过程中争论如何正确编写代码一样，他们也会在找到错误原因后争论如何正确修复错误，通常涉及“短期风险较小但有点丑陋”与“更复杂但从长远来看更优雅”之间的权衡。

I don’t remember exactly how I fixed the problem, but it was easy once I had found it; the solution can be left as an exercise for the reader. I might have added an extra parameter to GetDatabaseRecord() to tell it “don’t load extra doctor information” and made that parameter “true” in this specific case. If I was feeling motivated, I could have rewritten the code that used the single “street address of the last doctor we loaded from the database” variable so that it instead used multiple variables as needed. This second way would have been more “correct,” but it also would have been a larger change, delaying my champagne reward, with more risk of breaking something else while making the fix. On the plus side, it would have meant that a future caller of the GetDatabaseRecord() API had less to understand about the implementation, which would make things less error prone. Just as people argue, during code reviews, about the correct way to write a piece of code, they also argue about the correct way to fix a bug once the cause is found, typically involving this sort of trade-off between “less immediately risky but somewhat ugly” and “more complicated but more elegant for the long term.”

最后，让我们回到检查错误消息是否包含“JAVASCRIPT”的代码，我在几页前声称它有一个真正的错误：只会说英语的人可能没有意识到大写的概念会受到区域解释的影响。英语的小写i上面有一个点，大写I上面没有点；为了供您参考，我在本句中提供了两者的几个例子。用相同字母书写的大多数语言都有相同的小写i和大写I。然而，在土耳其语中，有小写带点的i和大写带点的İ，以及小写不带点的ı和大写不带点的I。当你大写时，带点与不带点的情况不会改变，所以i的大写是İ，而不是英语中的I 。当您将包含i 的单词大写时，例如字符串“JavaScript”，英语中的大写字母为“JAVASCRIPT”，土耳其语中的大写字母为“JAVASCRİPT”（请注意，大写字母I上方有一个点）。尽管常识丰富的人类可能会认为它们不同，但对于计算机来说，它们绝对不是一回事。

Let’s return, finally, to our code that checks if the error message contains “JAVASCRIPT,” which I claimed a few pages ago had a real bug in it: a monolingual English speaker may be unaware that the concept of uppercasing is subject to regional interpretation. English has a lowercase i with a dot on top and an uppercase I with no dot on it; for your reference, I have included several examples of both in this sentence. Most languages written in the same alphabet have the same lowercase i and uppercase I. In Turkish, however, there is a lowercase dotted i and uppercase dotted İ, and a lowercase undotted ı and uppercase undotted I. And the dotted-or-not aspect doesn’t change when you capitalize, so the capital of i is İ, not I as it is in English. When you uppercase a word with an i in it, such as the string “JavaScript,” the capital in English is “JAVASCRIPT” and the capital in Turkish is “JAVASCRİPT” (notice there is a dot above the uppercase I). And despite what a common sense–laden human might think, to a computer those are most definitely not the same thing.

如果您ToUpper()像我们一样不使用任何参数进行调用，则实现将根据计算机上配置的语言设置进行大写处理，用户可以选择该语言设置。如果您的用户使用的计算机配置为土耳其语，则“JavaScript”的大写形式将与计算机配置为英语时不同，并且该Contains()方法不会按预期进行匹配。您可能认为让您的代码与大写版本的错误消息进行比较很聪明，但这可能会导致难以诊断的问题，尤其是当您尝试在配置为英语的计算机上重现错误时。

If you call ToUpper()with no parameters, as we did, the implementation uppercases based on the language setting configured on the computer, which the user can choose. If your user is on a computer configured for Turkish, the uppercasing of “JavaScript” will be different than if the machine is configured for English, and the Contains() method won’t match it as expected. You might have thought it was clever to have your code make the comparison against the uppercased version of the error message, but this could cause hard-to-diagnose problems, especially if you try to reproduce the bug on a machine configured for English.

一旦你了解了土耳其语大写问题，修复它就很简单了；将你的ToUpper()电话从17

The fix to our Turkish uppercasing problem is simple once you know about it; change your ToUpper() call from17

EM_Upper = ErrorMessage.ToUpper();
EM_Upper = ErrorMessage.ToUpper();

到

to

EM_Upper = ErrorMessage.ToUpper(InvariantCulture);
EM_Upper = ErrorMessage.ToUpper(InvariantCulture);

与MessageBox.Show()方法一样，ToUpper()有多个版本，每个版本都采用不同的参数。最简单的版本假设它应该使用计算机配置的文化（首选术语，因为它不仅涵盖语言，还扩展到货币符号等领域）。这通常是正确的，但在比较大写字符串的情况下则不正确；InvariantCulture作为参数传递ToUpper()给它以保证在所有计算机上都相同的方式将其转换为大写（这里有一个内部提示：秘诀是“始终像英语那样做”；它不必政治正确，只要保持一致即可）。

As with the MessageBox.Show()method, ToUpper() has multiple versions that take different parameters. The simplest version assumes that it should use the culture (the preferred term since it encompasses more than just language, extending to areas such as currency symbols) that the computer is configured for. This is normally right, but not in the case of comparing uppercased strings; passing InvariantCulture as a parameter to ToUpper() tells it to uppercase in a way that is guaranteed to be the same on all computers (here’s an insider tip: the secret is “always do it like they do in English”; it doesn’t have to be politically correct, just consistent).

这可以正常工作，但就像想要MessageBox.Show()显示“确定”按钮以外的其他内容一样，您必须知道如何做。无参数的“使用当前文化”版本ToUpper()调用起来更方便（方便定义为程序员输入更少的内容）并且更容易发现，但它的存在使调用代码无法意识到大写字母的文化差异概念，这是不好的。问题不仅在于默认的本地文化与不变文化选择ToUpper()是其他人做出的隐藏选择；而是调用者可能不知道这种选择的存在，要么是因为程序员根本不了解文化，要么是他们没有意识到存在“告诉我使用哪种文化”版本。

This works fine, but just like wanting MessageBox.Show() to display something other than an “OK” button, you have to know to do it. The parameterless “use current culture” version of ToUpper() is more convenient to call (with convenience defined as less typing by the programmer) and easier to discover, but its existence allows the calling code to be unaware of the notion of cultural differences in uppercasing, which is bad. The problem is not just that the default local versus invariant culture choice made by ToUpper() is a hidden choice made by somebody else; it’s that the existence of such a choice might be unknown to the caller, either because a programmer doesn’t know about cultures at all or they don’t realize that the “tell me which culture to use” version exists.

设计方法的一个棘手方面是决定将什么设为必需参数（始终必须传入，例如消息框的标题或要大写的字符串）与可选参数（在消息框中显示的按钮或大写时要使用的文化），相关问题是如果未指定可选参数，则默认行为应该是什么，最后，甚至没有通过参数指定什么（例如在消息框中使用的字体），因此调用者根本没有选择。

One of the tricky aspects of designing a method is deciding what to make a required parameter (which always has to be passed in, such as the title of the message box or string you want to uppercase) versus an optional parameter (the buttons to display in a message box or culture to use when uppercasing), the related question of what the default behavior should be if the optional parameters are not specified, and lastly, what is not even specified via a parameter (such as the font to use in a message box) and therefore gives the caller no choice at all.

像往常一样，尽管在这些问题的代码审查上已经耗费了很多脑力，但仍然没有一个正确的答案。无论做出什么决定，对方法的默认行为的无知都是一个常见问题。从这个角度来看，默认文化版本的存在ToUpper()并不是一种便利，而是一个悲剧性的错误，是不必要的错误的来源，并且错失了教育程序员了解区域差异的机会——所有这些都是为了节省一点打字时间！默认参数虽然通常被认为是一种有用的便利，但可能弊大于利。它们本质上就像允许桥梁建造者说“给我一些钢材来建造我的桥梁”，而不是要求他们始终指定他们需要的钢材的确切属性。程序员不知不觉地认为最简单的调用是正确的——直到他们接到来自安卡拉的愤怒电话。

As usual there is no one right answer, despite many brain waves having been expended on code reviews of these questions. Whatever decisions are made, ignorance of the default behavior of a method is a common problem. Viewed through that lens, the existence of the default-culture version of ToUpper() is not a convenience but rather a tragic mistake, source of needless bugs, and missed opportunity to educate programmers about regional differences—all for the sake of saving a little bit of typing! Default parameters, while generally considered a useful convenience, likely do more harm than good. They are essentially like allowing a bridge builder to say, “Give me some steel to build my bridge,” rather than requiring them to always specify the exact properties of the steel that they need. Programmers unknowingly think the simplest call is the right one—until they get an irate call from Ankara.

布鲁克斯解释了程序（“本身完整，可由作者在开发它的系统上运行” ）与编程系统产品（“大多数系统编程工作的预期产品”）之间的区别。18要从前者到后者，你需要在两个维度上引入复杂性。第一个复杂性是从单一作者变成一个可以“由任何人运行、测试、修复和扩展”的程序。第二个复杂性是从单一程序变成“一组相互作用的程序，这些程序在功能上协调一致，在格式上规范有序，因此这些程序的集合构成了一套用于大型任务的完整设施。”19

Brooks explained the difference between a program—“complete in itself, ready to be run by the author on the system on which it was developed”—and a programming systems product—“the intended product of most systems programming efforts.”18 To get from the former to the latter, you introduce complications in two dimensions. The first complication is going from a single author to a program that can be “run, tested, repaired, and extended by anybody.” The second complication is going from a single program to “a collection of interacting programs, coordinated in function and disciplined in format, so that the assemblage constitutes an entire facility for large tasks.”19

高中和大学时，我从事的是普通程序，但在行业中，我从事的是编程系统产品。正如布鲁克斯所指出的，实现这一转变的两个新难题是程序员之间的跨时间通信和组件之间的跨 API 边界通信。20这两个领域正是我的自学教育严重不足之处。

Back in high school and college, I was working on plain-old programs, but in industry I was working on programming systems products. As Brooks noted, the two big new complications in making this transition are communication between programmers across time and communication between components across API boundaries.20 These are two areas where my self-taught education had left me severely lacking.

布鲁克斯补充道：“这就是编程，既是一个让许多努力都失败的焦油坑，又是一项充满欢乐和悲伤的创造性活动。”21程序员难道没有学会如何正确处理这些问题吗？他们最终可能会学会。但由于他们都是自学成才，他们往往专注于软件的另一个方面，我将在下一章讨论这一点。

Brooks added that “this then is programming, both a tar pit in which many efforts have foundered and a creative activity with joys and woes all its own.”21 Don’t programmers learn how to deal with these problems correctly? They may eventually. But given their self-taught beginnings, they tend to be focused on another aspect of their software, which I’ll discuss in the next chapter.

笔记

Notes

1. 如果您想在家尝试，Microsoft 提供免费工具。首先，搜索并下载 Visual Studio Community，然后运行它（需要几分钟）。然后，在我 2018 年初使用的版本中，您必须从安装窗口中选择 .NET 桌面开发。安装完成后，启动 Visual Studio（如果出现提示，则无需登录，并保留默认设置）。从文件菜单中，选择新建…，然后选择项目。使用 Visual C# 中的 .NET Framework 创建控制台应用程序（您可以使用默认名称，在我的版本中为 ConsoleApp1）。接下来，在右侧的解决方案资源管理器窗口中，右键单击引用，选择添加引用…，然后选择 Systems.Windows.Forms（您必须单击左侧的框才能真正选择它），然后单击确定。在主窗口代码顶部附近Program.cs添加一个新行，该行位于using System.Windows.Forms;以“using”开头的其他行之后。将本书中的代码示例粘贴在缩进最多的行{和}行之间（行之后的行static void Main(string[] args)）。按 F5 编译并运行程序（或选择“调试”，然后开始调试）。如果出现错误，请确保您输入了正确的所有内容，包括所有标点符号以及保留大小写字母——现在您就可以体验调试的快感了！不要忘记在消息框中点击“确定”将其关闭，这样程序就可以完成运行，否则您将无法对代码进行进一步的更改。

17. 请注意以下几点。首先，如果您在家输入此代码并希望它编译，则必须using System.Globalization;在源代码文件顶部添加一行，并且还必须使用CultureInfo.InvariantCulture而不是纯文本InvariantCulture（或者您可以调用 API ToUpperInvariant()，它的作用完全相同）。其次，在进行此类比较时，最佳做法是避免自己进行大写处理，因此，您不应先调用ToUpper()然后Contains()，而应直接在 上调用 API ErrorMessage：您必须调用而不是 的if (ErrorMessage.IndexOf("javascript", StringComparison.InvariantCultureIgnoreCase) != -1)原因是没有允许您指定 的重载。为什么它没有这个？我不知道；您再次受 API 设计者的摆布。IndexOf()Contains()Contains()InvariantCultureIgnoreCase
18. 布鲁克斯，《焦油坑》，4、6。
19. 同上，第5-6页。

21. 布鲁克斯，《焦油坑》，第9页。

4 

夜贼

4 

The Thief in the Night

我们那个时代的程序员最担心的是什么？他们的程序运行效率如何。为了一窥真相，我们翻阅了 1986 年出版的《编程珠玑》一书，这是乔恩·本特利 (Jon Bentley) 为《ACM 通讯》杂志撰写的专栏文章的合集，乔恩·本特利曾是卡内基梅隆大学的计算机科学教授，曾在贝尔实验室工作。

What do programmers from my era worry the most about? How efficiently their programs run. For a glimpse, we turn to the 1986 book Programming Pearls, a collection of columns that Jon Bentley, a former Carnegie Mellon computer science professor who worked at Bell Labs, wrote for the journal Communications of the ACM.

本特利致力于 UNIX 的研发，该系统可以在不像个人电脑那样拥挤的小型计算机上运行。1尽管如此，回顾他所选择的文章后，他评论说，性能——确保程序尽可能快地运行并且尽可能少地使用内存——是贯穿所有文章的主题。2事实上，他担心读者可能会忽视性能的重要性。在题为“压缩空间”的一章中，本特利写道：“如果你和我认识的几个人一样，读到这个标题时，你的第一反应是‘太过时了！’在计算的糟糕旧时代，程序员受到小型机器的限制，但那些日子早已一去不复返。新的理念是‘这里一兆字节，那里一兆字节，很快你就会谈论真正的内存。’”3

Bentley worked on UNIX, which ran on minicomputers that weren’t as cramped as PCs.1 Nonetheless, looking over the articles he chose, he comments that performance—making sure that programs run as quickly as possible and using as little memory as possible—is a theme that runs through all of them.2 In fact, he fears that readers might be ignoring the importance of performance. In a chapter titled “Squeezing Space,” Bentley writes, “If you’re like several people I know, your first thought on reading the title is ‘How old-fashioned!’ In the bad old days of computing, so the story goes, programmers were constrained by small machines, but those days are long gone. The new philosophy is ‘a megabyte here, a megabyte there, pretty soon you’re talking about real memory.’”3

Bentley 出身于 UNIX 环境，他担心小型计算机的计算能力不断提高，再加上内存限制相对较少，会导致一代程序员对性能漠不关心。其实他不必担心。越来越多的程序员在个人电脑上工作，他的信息得到了他们的广泛接受。自 1982 年我们最初的 IBM PC 及其 64 千字节内存问世以来，个人电脑的存储容量迅速增长，但即使是更先进的 IBM PC AT（于 1984 年秋季发布），总内存也限制在 16 兆字节，因此这里一兆字节或那里一兆字节确实很重要。

Coming from a UNIX environment, Bentley was concerned that the increased computing power of minicomputers, coupled with the relative lack of memory constraints, was going to lead to a generation of programmers who were oblivious to performance. He needn’t have worried. More and more programmers were doing their work on personal computers, and his message found a receptive audience among them. PCs had grown rapidly in storage capacity since our original IBM PC and its 64 kilobytes of memory in 1982, but even the more advanced IBM PC AT, released in fall 1984, was limited to 16 megabytes of total memory, so a megabyte here or there really did matter.

Bentley 是一位性能专家；他于 1982 年出版的《编写高效程序》一书专门讨论了这一主题。但他并不是一个盲目的性能改进者。他警告说，性能改进技术应谨慎应用，并且只在需要时才应用：“我们将要研究的规则是通过对程序进行更改来提高效率，而这些更改通常会降低程序的清晰度、模块化和稳健性。当这种编码风格在整个大型系统中不加区别地应用时（通常都是这样），它通常会略微提高效率，但会导致后期软件充满错误且无法维护。”4

Bentley was a performance guru; his 1982 book Writing Efficient Programs focused exclusively on the topic. Yet he was not a mindless performance improver. He cautioned that performance improvement techniques should be applied with care, and only when needed: “The rules that we will study increase efficiency by making changes to a program that often decrease program clarity, modularity, and robustness. When this coding style is applied indiscriminately throughout a large system (as it often has been), it usually increases efficiency slightly but leads to late software that is full of bugs and impossible to maintain.”4

在当时受 PC 启发的时代精神中，这种微妙之处常常被忽略。尽管《编写高效程序》中有 Pascal 语言的示例，《编程珠玑》也使用了多种语言，但大多数语言，甚至那些允许合理“结构化”程序的语言——Pascal、PL/I、ALGOL 和较新版本的 Fortran——都被我在大学二年级时第一次接触的语言——一种非常注重性能的语言——C 所取代。

That subtlety was frequently lost amid the PC-inspired zeitgeist of the time. And although Writing Efficient Programs had examples in Pascal, and Programming Pearls used a mix of languages, most languages, even those that allowed reasonably “structured” programs—Pascal, PL/I, ALGOL, and newer versions of Fortran—were in the process of being swept aside by the language that I was first exposed to in my sophomore year of college—a language that had a strong focus on performance: C.

C 语言是在 20 世纪 70 年代初由贝尔实验室发明的，本特利最终也在那里工作。贝尔实验室是贝尔电话公司的研究机构，该公司当时垄断了长途电话业务；它需要复杂的软件来处理电话呼叫的路由。为了支持这项服务，它编写了操作系统 UNIX，最初是用汇编语言编写的，当时几乎所有操作系统都是这样。高级语言被认为生成的代码太慢、太庞大，无法在操作系统的核心中运行。然而，当需要将 UNIX 移植到新计算机上时，他们决定用高级语言重写它。没有合适的语言，这导致了 C 的诞生。5

The C language was invented in the early 1970s at Bell Labs, the same place where Bentley wound up working. Bell Labs was the research arm of the Bell Telephone Company, which at the time had a monopoly on long-distance calling; it needed complicated software to handle the routing of phone calls. To support this, it wrote the operating system UNIX, originally in assembly language, as almost every operating system was back then. Higher-level languages were viewed as producing code that was too slow and bulky to run in the guts of an operating system. Yet when it came time to port UNIX to run on a new computer, the decision was made to rewrite it in a high-level language. No suitable language existed, which led to the birth of C.5

很难描述对于像我这样习惯于在 IBM PC 上与内存限制作斗争的人来说，C 语言有多么“合适”。在 Pascal 中，代码块用关键字BEGIN和来划分END；在 C 中，它们使用{和}。如果一种编程语言结构可以描述为空气动力学的，那就是它了。这是一个小问题，对编译器生成的代码没有影响，但它让 C 语言感觉时尚而现代，而 Pascal 则保留了一点粗花呢夹克和肘部补丁的气息。

It is hard to describe how “right” C felt to someone like me, who was used to fighting memory limits on an IBM PC. In Pascal, blocks of code are delineated with the keywords BEGIN and END; in C, they use { and }. If a programming language construct could be described as aerodynamic, this was it. It’s a small thing that has no effect on the code that the compiler produces, but it made C feel sleek and modern, while Pascal retained a faint air of tweed jackets and elbow patches.

C 语言的设计者们煞费苦心地确保该语言不会对性能造成任何影响。最终，该语言能够处理将变量名映射到内存位置、处理循环和IF语句（无需显式GOTO输入）以及将参数传递给函数等繁重工作，而不会妨碍其他任何事情。C 语言的特点是它是汇编语言的薄包装器。6这既可能是赞美，也可能是侮辱，但它完全符合从在大型机上运行的软件到在 PC 上运行的软件的过渡需求，一旦该软件的复杂性远远超出 DONKEY.BAS。

The designers of C took great pains to ensure that the language did not insert any roadblocks to performance. The result is a language that takes care of the grunt work of mapping variable names to memory locations, handling loops and IF statements without requiring explicit GOTOs, and passing parameters to functions, without getting in the way of anything else. C has been characterized as a thin wrapper around assembly language.6 This could be meant as both a compliment and insult, but it perfectly fit the needs of the transition from software running on mainframes to software running on PCs, once the complexity of that software got much beyond DONKEY.BAS.

正如 Bentley 所说，一味地追求性能可能会带来问题，但 C 语言的设计迫使你这样做，因为这就是该语言的工作原理。C 语言中一个特别注重性能的特性是最糟糕的，需要一点背景知识来解释。

As Bentley said, concentrating on performance “indiscriminately” can cause problems, but the design of C forces you to do so, because that’s how the language works. One particular performance-focused feature of C is the worst of the bunch, and it requires a little background to explain.

C 语言与处理器相似的一个重要方面是它如何处理不同位数的数字。在机器/汇编语言层面，你可以控制用多少个字节来存储一个数字。最小可能的大小是 1 个字节，即 8 位，7，其中 1 位是单个二进制数字，即 0 或 1（如果你年龄足够大，还记得在新数学课上学习过基数，“二进制”和“基数 2”是同一个东西）。用二进制表示的最低 8 位数字是

An important way in which C was close to the processor was how it handled numbers of different bitness.
