Down at the level of machine/assembly language, you can control how many bytes are used to store a number. The smallest size possible is 1 byte, which is 8 bits,7 with 1 bit being a single binary digit that is either 0 or 1 (if you are old enough to remember learning about bases in new math class, “binary” and “base 2” are the same thing). The lowest 8-bit number, written in binary, is

00000000
00000000

为 0，最高 8 位数字以二进制表示为

which is 0, and the highest 8-bit number, written in binary, is

11111111
11111111

即 255。因此，8 位数可以存储从 0 到 255 的值；您还可以告诉处理器（通过您如何编码任何单个机器语言指令），它应该将最高位视为符号位，表示正数或负数，在这种情况下，您可以存储从 -128 到 127 的值，而不是从 0 到 255。8当 8 位数字被解释为从 0 到 255 时，它们被称为无符号，而当它们的范围从 -128 到 127 时，它们被称为有符号。

which is 255. So an 8-bit number can store values from 0 to 255; you can also tell the processor (via how you encode any single machine language instruction) that it should treat the highest bit as a sign bit, indicating positive or negative, in which case you can store values from –128 to 127 instead of 0 to 255.8 When 8-bit numbers are interpreted as ranging from 0 to 255, they are referred to as unsigned, and when they range from –128 to 127, they are referred to as signed.

移动到 2 个字节的存储空间可获得 16 位数字，范围从 0 到 65,535（对于有符号数字，则为 -32,768 到 32,767）；32 位可获得 0 到 4,294,967,295（或 -2,147,483,648 到 2,147,483,647）；64 位可获得 0 到超过 18 千万亿 — — 这是一个相当大的数字（或有符号范围为 -9 千万亿到 9 千万亿，这些也是很大的数字）。9当有人谈论 32 位或 64 位处理器时，他们指的是处理器在单个机器语言操作中可以处理的最大数字，这与每个寄存器的大小相对应。32 位计算机有 32 位寄存器，可以对两个 32 位数字进行加、减等运算（我对此做了一些掩饰，但在这里并不重要）。10

Moving up to 2 bytes of storage gets you 16-bit numbers, ranging from 0 to 65,535 (or –32,768 to 32,767 for signed numbers); 32 bits gets you 0 to 4,294,967,295 (or –2,147,483,648 to 2,147,483,647); and 64 bits gets you 0 to over 18 quintillion—quite a large number (or a signed range of –9 quintillion to 9 quintillion, which are also large numbers).9 When somebody talks about a 32- or 64-bit processor, they are referring to the largest number that the processor can deal with in a single machine language operation, which corresponds to the size of each register. A 32-bit computer has 32-bit registers and can add, subtract, and so on two 32-bit numbers (I’m glossing over things a bit, but not in a way that matters here).10

处理器还可以一次对更少的位进行操作，因此您可以告诉 32 位处理器（同样通过对机器语言指令进行编码的细节）仅对 8 位数进行加法、减法或移入/移出内存的操作。如果您知道某个数字永远不会超过 255，那么您可以将其存储在 8 位中并以 8 位对其进行操作，这将略微节省内存和速度。

The processor can also operate on fewer bits at a time, so you can, for example, tell a 32-bit processor (again via the details of how you encode a machine language instruction) to only add, subtract, or move to/from memory 8-bit numbers. If you knew that a certain number would never go above 255, then you could store it in 8 bits and operate on it in 8 bits, which would result in slight savings in both memory and speed.

C 之前的高级语言具有单一的“整数”类型，其通常与处理器的位数相对应，因此程序可以处理的最大数字取决于它所运行的计算机。11此外，为了简单起见，它们仅支持有符号数，因为在当时编写的程序中，用户更可能希望存储较小的负数而不是较大的正数。最初的 IBM PC 是一台 16 位计算机，因此INTBASIC 中的（整数）类型是有符号的 16 位，因此支持的值从 -32,768 到 32,767。如果您有两个整数变量，A并且B它们都等于 25,000，并且您执行此 BASIC 命令

High-level languages before C had a single “integer” type that generally corresponded to the bitness of the processor, so the largest number a program could handle depended on the computer it was running on.11 Furthermore, for simplicity they supported only signed numbers, since it was more likely, in the universe of programs being written at the time, that the user would want to store a small negative number than a large positive one. The original IBM PC was a 16-bit computer, so the INT (integer) type in BASIC was signed 16 bits and therefore supported values from –32,768 to 32,767. If you had two integer variables A and B that were both equal to 25,000, and you executed this BASIC command

10 D = A + B
10 D = A + B

那么 BASIC 就会意识到应该有的值D50,000 太大，无法放入 16 位有符号整数中，并且它会以“溢出”错误终止。12这并不理想，但比默默忽略溢出并继续进行，好像什么都没有发生，结果却是错误的D（由于复杂的原因，很难详细解释，但概念上涉及溢出数字“回绕”，结果将是意外的 -15,536）。

then BASIC would realize that the value that D was supposed to have, 50,000, was too big to fit into a 16-bit signed integer and it would terminate with an “Overflow” error.12 This is not ideal, but it’s better than silently ignoring the overflow and proceeding as if nothing happened, with a bogus result in D (which for reasons that are complicated to explain in detail but conceptually involve the overflowed number “wrapping around,” would have been the unexpected value of –15,536).

相比之下，在 C 语言中，所有这些细节都直接暴露给程序员；当你声明一个整数变量时，你要指出它是 8 位、16 位还是 32 位数字（后来扩展为支持 64 位数字）。13另外，如果您知道一个变量永远不会为负数，为了允许您容纳两倍的正数，您可以明确声明变量是有符号的还是无符号的，编译器会跟踪并编码适当的机器语言指令。

In C, by contrast, all this detail was exposed directly to the programmer; when you declared an integer variable, you indicated whether it was going to be an 8-, 16-, or 32-bit number (later extended to support 64-bit numbers).13 Also, to allow you to fit in twice as many positive numbers if you knew a variable would never be negative, you could explicitly declare whether a variable was signed or unsigned, and the compiler would keep track and encode the appropriate machine language instructions.

此外，C 在对数字执行数学运算时不检查溢出。为了检查

Moreover, C did not check for overflow when performing mathematical operations on numbers. In order to check for overflow on

D = A + B
D = A + B

编译器必须生成代码（即自动将其包含在它创建的用于计算该表达式的机器语言代码中），该代码执行以下操作：

a compiler must generate code—that is, automatically include it in the machine language code that it creates to calculate that expression—that does this:

  1. 1.计算A + B
  2. 1. Calculate A + B
  3. 2.检查最后一个操作是否溢出（处理器会记录下来）
  4. 2. Check if that last operation overflowed (which is something the processor will have made a note of)
  5. 3.如果溢出，则打印错误并终止
  6. 3. If it did overflow, print an error and terminate
  7. 4.如果没有溢出，则将结果存储在D
  8. 4. If it did not overflow, store the result in D

由于注重性能，C 跳过了第二步和第三步；这是每次执行数学计算时都会累积起来的小事之一。C 会忽略潜在的溢出并将结果存储在中D，不会有任何疑问。在大多数情况下，这没问题；如果视频游戏以 16 位整数存储外星人的屏幕坐标，并且您的屏幕宽度为 1000 像素，则您无需担心外星人在屏幕上移动时溢出。14另一方面，数值溢出可能会导致严重的错误：Therac-25 放射治疗机的一个软件问题就是在 8 位计数器变量在错误的时间溢出回到 0 时发生的，该机器在 20 世纪 80 年代导致 3 人因辐射过量而死亡；1996 年，一枚阿丽亚娜 5 号火箭因另一个溢出错误而自毁，当时它试图将 64 位值复制到 16 位变量中。15

Being performance focused, C skipped the second and third steps; it’s one of those small things that add up if you do it every time you perform a mathematical calculation. C would ignore the potential overflow and store the result in D, no questions asked. In most cases this is fine; if a video game is storing the on-screen coordinates of an alien in a 16-bit integer and your screen is a thousand pixels wide, you don’t need to worry about overflow as the alien moves across the screen.14 On the other hand, numerical overflows can cause major bugs: one of the software problems with the Therac-25 radiation therapy machine, which killed three people in the 1980s due to overdoses of radiation, was a bug that hit when an 8-bit counter variable overflowed back around to 0 at just the wrong time, and an Ariane 5 rocket self-destructed in 1996 due to another overflow bug, trying to copy a 64-bit value into a 16-bit variable.15

C 语言对编程结构（称为数组）进行了类似的优化，几乎所有编程语言中都存在数组。数组允许您声明一个可以容纳多个值的变量。例如，在 Pascal 中，您可以这样声明一个整数：

The C language makes a similar optimization with the programming construct known as an array, which exists in almost all programming languages. An array lets you declare a single variable that can hold multiple values. For example, in Pascal you can declare a single integer this way:

var a: integer;
var a: integer;

当你声明这样的数组时：

while you declare an array like this:

var a: array[0..4] of integer;
var a: array[0..4] of integer;

a[0]然后，您就可以通过、a[1]、a[2]、a[3]和访问数组的 5 个元素，a[4]每个元素都可以保存一个整数值。重要的是，数组的索引，即方括号中的部分（也称为下标），可以是变量而不是常数，因此您可以编写如下循环：

and you can then access the 5 elements of the array as a[0], a[1], a[2], a[3], and a[4], each of which can hold an integer value. Importantly, the index into the array, the part in the square brackets (also known as a subscript), can be a variable instead of a constant number, so you can write a loop like this:

for i:= 0 to 4 do
begin
    writeln(a[i]);
end
for i:= 0 to 4 do
begin
    writeln(a[i]);
end

打印出 的不同元素a（writeln()是 Pascal API，用于打印出值， 和BEGIN，END如前所述，划分代码块）。如果您尝试访问索引a为 5 或更多的数组元素，则程序将因错误而终止。

to print out the different elements of a (writeln() is the Pascal API to print out a value, and BEGIN and END, as noted before, demarcate blocks of code). If you try to access an element of the array a with an index of 5 or more, then the program will terminate with an error.

如果数组索引位于变量中，则意味着编译器在编译程序时无法确定数组访问是否合法，因为它不知道执行该行程序时变量的值。它必须在程序实际运行时添加代码来执行此检查，这称为运行时检查。Pascal 编译器将生成类似这样的代码：

If the array index is in a variable, it means the compiler can’t figure out, at the point when it is compiling the program, if an array access is going to be legal because it won’t know what value the variable will have when that line of the program is executed. It has to add code to do this check when the program is actually running, known as a runtime check. The Pascal compiler is going to generate code something like this:

  1. 1.找出内存中的a位置
  2. 1. Figure out where in memory a is
  3. 2.如果i的下标太高（或太低，即为负数），则a打印错误并终止程序
  4. 2. If i is too high (or too low, meaning it is negative) a subscript for a, print an error and terminate the program
  5. 3.检索i第个元素a
  6. 3. Retrieve the ith element in a

第二步意味着编译器已经储存了有效的索引范围a，这会占用一点内存，但没什么大不了的；问题是每次访问数组时它都会运行此检查的代码，如果你在想，“这听起来像是另一个小型运行时检查，这些检查会逐渐对程序的性能产生不小的影响，而 C 语言的设计者正努力避免自动执行此类检查”，那么你是对的。

That second step implies that the compiler has squirreled away the valid index range for a, which takes a little bit of memory yet is not a big deal; the problem is that it will run the code for this check every time you make an array access, and if you are thinking, “That sounds like another one of those small runtime checks that can build up to have a nontrivial impact on the performance of your program, which the designers of C were trying hard to avoid doing automatically,” you would be correct.

C 语言采用了不同的方法，可以最大限度地减少运行时开销。您可以像在其他语言中一样声明数组（语法略有不同）：

The C language took a different approach—one that minimizes runtime overhead. You can declare arrays as in other languages (with slightly different syntax):

int a[5];
int a[5];

但是 C 不对数组访问进行运行时边界检查，因此它完全省去了“如果i下标太高...”这个步骤。如果当等于 100时a使用表达式，C 编译器会生成代码来计算元素应该在计算机内存中的什么位置（第一个元素之后的 100 个位置，其索引为 0）并检索该值。至关重要的是，如果实际上元素较少，则生成的代码将返回该内存位置的任何内容，即使它超出了为数组保留的区域并且可能属于另一个变量，或者位于当前未用于任何内容且其中具有随机值的内存区域中，或者在访问时导致崩溃。a[i]iaaa

but C does no runtime bounds checks on array access so it dispenses with that “if i is too high a subscript for a …” step entirely. If you use the expression a[i] when i is equal to 100, the C compiler generates code to calculate where in the computer’s memory that element of a should be (100 spots after the first element, which has index 0) and retrieves that value. Crucially, if a in fact has fewer elements, the generated code will return whatever happens to be at that memory location, even if it is past the area that has been reserved for the a array and might belong to another variable, or be in an area of memory that isn’t currently used for anything and has a random value in it, or causes a crash when accessed.

此外，C 将数组的概念与指针的概念融合在一起。指针是一个包含另一个变量地址的变量，可用于在内存中构建某些数据结构；Pascal 也有指针。根据最初的 C 书，“指针和 goto 语句被归为一类，是编写难以理解的程序的绝妙方法。”将某事等同起来GOTO并不是恭维，但正如书中所言，“如果使用不当，这种情况确实存在，很容易创建指向意想不到的地方的指针。但是，只要有纪律，指针也可以用来实现清晰度和简单性。”16

What’s more, C merges the concept of arrays with the concept of pointers. A pointer is a variable that contains the address of another variable, which is useful for constructing certain data structures in memory; Pascal also had pointers. According to the original C book, “Pointers have been lumped with the goto statement as a marvelous way to create impossible-to-understand programs.” Equating something with GOTO is no compliment, but as the book goes on to say, “This is certainly true when they are used carelessly, and it is easy to create pointers that point somewhere unexpected. With discipline, however, pointers can also be used to achieve clarity and simplicity.”16

C 语言设计者认为指针和数组其实是同一件事：指针指向内存中的某个位置，数组也指向内存中的某个位置，即第一个元素的地址。Dennis Ritchie 将此称为 C 语言所基于的语言（称为 BCPL）与 C 之间的“进化链中的关键一跃”。17一个好处是指针比常规数组查找更快。回想一下我对数组访问时发生的情况的分析a[i]：

The insight that the designers of C had was that pointers and arrays are really the same thing: a pointer points to a location in memory, and an array also points to a location in memory, that being the address of the first element. Dennis Ritchie called this “the crucial jump in the evolutionary chain” between the language on which C was based (called BCPL) and C.17 One benefit is that pointers can be faster than regular array lookup. Recall my breakdown of what happens on the array access a[i]:

  1. 1.找出内存中的a位置
  2. 1. Figure out where in memory a is
  3. 2.如果i的下标太高（或太低），则a打印错误并终止程序
  4. 2. If i is too high (or too low) a subscript for a, print an error and terminate the program
  5. 3.检索i第个元素a
  6. 3. Retrieve the ith element in a

除了 C 完全省去了步骤 2 之外，步骤 3 还涉及乘以i单个元素的大小a。使用指针，遍历数组只需将每个数组元素的大小添加到指针即可，而不必每次都重新进行乘法，而且加法比乘法更快。18

Besides the fact that C dispenses with step 2 entirely, step 3 involves multiplying i times the size of a single element of a. Using pointers instead, iterating through an array can be done just by adding the size of each array element to a pointer as opposed to redoing the multiplication each time, and addition is faster than multiplication.18

此外，虽然数组声明时具有固定大小（C 仍然支持这一点），但指针是变量，可以设置为指向任何位置。在 C 中，它们可以设置为指向的特别有用的位置是从系统分配内存的 API 返回的位置。由于指针和数组可以互换使用，因此您可以等到运行时再决定需要多大的数组，动态分配它，并将分配的结果分配给指针，然后继续使用指针，就像它是一个数组一样。结果不是通过声明比您需要的更大的数组来浪费内存，而是仍然能够使用更易读的数组语法。

Furthermore, while arrays are declared with a fixed size, which C does still support, pointers are variables and can be set to point anywhere. In C, the particularly useful place that they can be set to point is the location returned from an API that allocates memory from the system. And since pointers and arrays can be used interchangeably, you can wait until runtime to decide how large an array you need, allocate it dynamically, and assign the result of the allocation to a pointer, and then proceed to use the pointer as if it was an array. The result is not wasting memory by declaring a larger array than you need, but still being able to use the more readable array syntax.

或者您可以继续使用指针。我在普林斯顿的几位教授是贝尔实验室的短期休假员工，他们偶尔会向我们展示从 UNIX/C-Land 大厅收集到的行业技巧。我仍然记得有一天，贝尔实验室的客座教授 Henry Baird 演示了如何将循环从使用数组访问更改为指针算法，这会使您的代码更难理解，但也会更快，更酷。我对指针的态度可以用这样的对话来总结：

Or you can continue to use the pointer. A few of my professors at Princeton were Bell Labs employees on short-term leave, and they would occasionally show us tricks of the trade gleaned from the halls of UNIX/C-Land. I can still recall the day that a visiting professor from Bell Labs named Henry Baird demonstrated how to change a loop from using array access to pointer arithmetic, which makes your code harder to understand but also a little faster and infinitely cooler. My attitude toward pointers could be summarized in a dialogue like this:

明智的程序员： 

我有一些关于指针的好消息和坏消息。

亚当： 

有什么好消息？

明智的程序员： 

它们使你的代码更快。

亚当： 

明白了！更快就是酷。

明智的程序员： 

它们还会使你的代码更难阅读。

亚当： 

我懂了。

明智的程序员： 

速度更快但阅读起来更困难。这就是指针的故事。

亚当： 

我以为你说过有坏消息？

Wise Programmer: 

I have good news and bad news about pointers.

Adam: 

What’s the good news?

Wise Programmer: 

They make your code faster.

Adam: 

Got it! Faster is cool.

Wise Programmer: 

They also make your code harder to read.

Adam: 

I see.

Wise Programmer: 

Faster but harder to read. That’s the story on pointers.

Adam: 

I thought you said there was bad news?

最后一个技巧是，C 基于这三个想法（明确声明不同大​​小的整数、避免数组查找的开销以及使用数组/指针等效性动态分配数组），想出了一种处理字符串的巧妙方法。

For a final trick, C built on those three ideas—explicitly declaring different-size integers, avoiding overhead on array lookup, and allocating arrays dynamically using the array/pointer equivalency—to come up with a clever way to handle strings.

回想一下，字符串是一串文本：“hello”是一个字符串。在机器/汇编语言中，计算机处理数字而不是字符串。要存储字符串，首先需要一种一致认可的方式将字符串编码为一系列数字。最常见的编码系统是 ASCII（美国信息交换标准代码），其最简单的版本使用 7 位来表示各种字符；可打印字符的编码从 32（定义为空格）到 126（波浪号 ~）。这仍然有足够的空间来容纳所有大写字母（从A的 65 到Z的 90 ）、小写字母（从a的 97到z的 122 ）以及所有其他常见标点符号。数字 0 到 9，即实际打印的字符“0”、“1”、“2”等，编码为 48 到 57。

Recall that a string is a sequence of text: “hello” is a string. In machine/assembly language, computers deal with numbers, not strings. To store strings, you first need an agreed-on way to encode your string as a series of numbers. The most common encoding system is known as ASCII (American Standard Code for Information Interchange), which in its simplest version uses 7 bits to represent various characters; the encoding of printable characters goes from 32 (which is defined to be a space) up to 126 (which is the tilde, ~). That’s still enough room to fit all the uppercase letters (ranging from 65 for A to 90 for Z), lowercase letters (from 97 for a to 122 for z), and all other common punctuation symbols. The numbers 0 through 9—that is, the actual printed characters “0,” “1,” “2,” and so on—are encoded from 48 to 57.

所以我的名字“Adam”将被编码为四个数字，

So my first name, “Adam,” would be encoded as four numbers,

65
100
97
109
65
100
97
109

只要软件知道这是一种 ASCII 编码，它就会被处理它们的软件解释为A、d、a和m 。

which would then be interpreted as A, d, a, and m by whatever software was dealing with them as long as it knew this was an ASCII encoding.

这一切都运行良好，但字符串的问题在于它们不像数字那样有界限。数字被定义为一定的位数，并且始终会使用那么多的存储空间，但字符串需要为每个 ASCII 字符占用一个字节的存储空间。虽然您通常可以方便地忽略有符号的 16 位整数溢出超过 32,767 的可能性，但对于字符串，您需要一个地方来存储所有这些字节。担心/懒于处理多个字符串（每个字符串可能很长），这是决定在 Dendrite 代码中使用单个共享的“我们从数据库加载的最后一位医生的街道地址”字符串的根本原因，这导致了我在上一章中讨论的神秘错误。

This all works fine, but the problem with strings is that they are not bounded the way that numbers are. A number is defined to be a certain bitness and will always use that much storage, but a string will need one byte of storage for each ASCII character. And while you can often conveniently ignore the chance of a signed 16-bit integer overflowing past 32,767, in the case of a string you need a place to store all those bytes. Concern/laziness about dealing with multiple strings, each of potentially long length, was the underlying reason behind the decision to have a single shared “street address of the last doctor we loaded from the database” string in the Dendrite code, which led to the mysterious bug I discussed in the previous chapter.

为了解决这个问题，IBM PC BASIC 等语言会跟踪任何字符串的长度，并在字符串长度发生变化时自动分配内存（从当前未使用的内存，即堆中），然后将字符串复制到更大的位置（如果需要），而所有这些过程都对程序员隐藏。这很好，只是将字符串复制到新位置需要花费一些时间。更糟糕的是，堆分配可能随时失败，特别是在内存有限的计算机上。你可以编写代码让你的字符串变长一个字符，并让系统在代码运行时发现堆内存已用完。由于系统无法执行你请求的操作，而代码中的以下语句大概依赖于该字符串是否有效，所以程序别无选择，只能完全停止（对于 IBM PC BASIC，出现“字符串空间不足”错误）。19除此之外，IBM PC BASIC 中允许的最长字符串是 255 个字符，这非常类似于使用 16 位存储数字的“嗯，它可能不会溢出”的态度，因为它通常有效，但不能保证总是有足够的空间。20

To handle this, languages such as IBM PC BASIC would keep track of the length of any string and automatically allocate memory (from the currently unused memory, which is known as the heap) as the length of the string changed, and then copy the string to the larger location if needed, with all this hidden from the programmer. This was fine, except that copying the string to the new location took some small amount of time. Worse, a heap allocation could fail at any time, especially on a computer with limited memory. You could write code that made your string one character longer and have the system discover, at the moment that code was running, that it was out of heap memory. Since the system couldn’t perform the operation you requested, and the following statements in your code presumably depended on that string being valid, the program had no choice but to stop completely (in the case of IBM PC BASIC, with an “Out of string space” error).19 On top of that, the longest-allowed string in IBM PC BASIC was 255 characters, which is a pretty good equivalent of the “well, it probably won’t overflow” attitude of using 16 bits to store a number in that it generally works but is not guaranteed to always be enough room.20

其他语言让程序员在声明字符串时指定其最大字符数；WATFIV 和 Pascal 就是按照这种方式工作的。这意味着您必须猜测字符串可能具有的最长长度，如果您猜得太高，则会浪费大量内存，如果您猜得太低，字符串会变得太长，编译器生成的代码会检测到这种情况，然后无论如何都会终止您的程序。

Other languages had the programmer specify, when they declared a string, the maximum number of characters it would be; WATFIV and Pascal worked this way. This meant that you had to guess the longest-possible length your string might have, and waste a lot of memory if you guessed too high, and if you guessed too low and your string wound up too long, the compiler-generated code would detect this and then kill your program anyway.

C 语言的设计者想出了一个巧妙解决所有问题的解决方案。字符串被定义为一个 8 位（一个字节）数字数组，这种类型称为char，每个数组元素保存一个编码字符（通常为 ASCII）。通常在 C 语言中对数组进行任何操作时，都需要将数组的长度存储在单独的变量中，因为 C 语言内部不跟踪数组长度。这导致了许多 C 函数具有如下签名：

The designers of C came up with a solution that neatly resolved all of this. A string was defined to be an array of 8-bit (one byte) numbers, a type known as a char, with each array element holding one encoded character (in ASCII, typically). Normally when doing any operations with arrays in C, you need to store the length of the array in a separate variable, because C internally does not track array length. This led to a lot of C functions with signatures like this:

myfunc(int a[], int n)
myfunc(int a[], int n)

其中a是一个数组（每个元素都是int），n是数组的长度；这样就可以myfunc()知道数组包含多少个元素，从而避免超出数组的末尾。在 C# 等语言中，它们会在内部跟踪数组的长度，并在需要时提供 API 来检索它，因此第二个参数不是必需的。

where a is an array (with each element being an int), and n is the length of the array; this allows myfunc() to know how many elements the array contains so it can avoid walking off the end of the array. In languages like C#, which does track the length of arrays internally and provides an API to retrieve it when needed, that second parameter is not necessary.

但是由于字符串使用频率很高，C 语言采用了一种约定，允许通过单个变量传递字符串，就像传递数字一样。单个变量是指向第一个元素的指针。那么字符串的长度呢？约定是字符串的结尾由值为 0 的数组元素表示（实际值 0，而不是字符“0”的编码，即数字 48）。任何需要知道字符串长度的代码都会扫描数组，直到找到值为 0 的元素char（strlen()提供了一个 API 来为您完成此操作）。顺便说一句，这就是匈牙利变量名前缀sz的由来——它代表“字符串，以零结尾”。

But since strings are used so often, a convention was adopted in C allowing a string to be passed around via a single variable, the way numbers could be. The single variable was a pointer to the first element. What about the length of the string? The convention was that the end of the string was indicated by an array element with the value of 0 (the actual value 0, not the encoding of the character “0,” which is the number 48). Any code that needed to know the length of a string would scan through the array until it found the char with a value of 0 (an API called strlen() was supplied that did this for you). Incidentally, this is where the Hungarian variable-name prefix sz came from—it stands for “string, zero-terminated.”

因此在 C 语言中，字符串“Adam”被存储在一个由 5 个char值（8 位数字）组成的数组中 - 占用 5 个字节，也称为 5 字节缓冲区- 包含以下 5 个值：

So in C, the string “Adam” was stored in an array of five char values (8-bit numbers)—which occupies 5 bytes, and is also known as a 5-byte buffer—containing the following 5 values:

65
100
97
109
0
65
100
97
109
0

这样就可以动态分配任意长度的字符串，就像任何其他数组一样，但整个字符串可以用单个变量引用，不需要额外的长度值。此外，这意味着与将字符串视为特殊其他类型并需要特定 API 来执行诸如“从这个较大的字符串中提取此子字符串”之类的操作的语言不同，在 C 中，您可以像访问数组中的各个元素一样访问字符串中的单个字符。这是 C，这也意味着对字符串的索引（就像所有数组索引一样）不会检查索引是否有效。尽管有辅助 API 可以使其更容易，但程序员必须编写自己的代码来确保他们分配用于保存字符串的内存缓冲区足够大以容纳该字符串 - 以及最终的 0 值。最著名的是，那个“Adam”字符串（由 返回strlen()）的长度为 4，因为它有 4 个字符，但如果您想复制它，则由于额外的 0 值，所需的存储量为 5 个字节。用 C 编写字符串操作代码的程序员必须始终意识到这一点。

This allowed strings to be allocated dynamically at any length, the same as any other array, but the entire string could be referred to with a single variable, with no extra length value needed. Furthermore, it meant that unlike languages that treated strings as a special other type and needed a specific API to perform operations such as “extract this substring from within this larger string,” in C you could access individual characters in a string the same way you would access individual elements of an array. This being C, it also meant that the indexing into strings, like all array indexing, was not checked for the index being valid. And although there were helper APIs to make it easier, programmers had to write their own code to ensure that the memory buffer they allocated to hold a string was large enough for that string—and the final 0 value as well. Most famously, the length of that “Adam” string (as returned by strlen()) was 4 because it had 4 characters in it, but the amount of storage needed, if you wanted to make a copy of it, was 5 bytes due to the extra 0 value. Programmers writing string manipulation code in C had to be aware of this at all times.

例如，3 个字母的字符串“lap”占用 4 个字节的内存（ l 、 a 、 p和0），3 个字母的字符串“dog”也占用 4 个字节的内存（ d 、 o 、 g和0），但字符串“lapdog”占用 7 个字节的内存 - 您会注意到，它既不是 3 + 3 也不是 4 + 4，这导致程序员不得不在大量字符串长度计算中加 1 和减 1，从而导致各种“差一”的数学错误，其中 0 的额外字节没有得到正确计算。如果缓冲区末尾的字节未被其他任何变量使用，那么这可能是无害的，但也可能导致大问题 - 特别是，您可能会将终止 0 写入另一个超出缓冲区末尾的变量的内存中，然后让该变量用其他内容替换 0，并且突然您的字符串会被视为继续，直到它碰巧遇到内存中的另一个 0。21

For example, the 3-letter string “lap” takes 4 bytes of memory (the l, the a, the p, and the 0), and the 3-letter string “dog” also takes 4 bytes of memory (the d, the o, the g, and the 0), but the string “lapdog” takes up 7 bytes of memory—which as you notice, is neither 3 + 3 nor 4 + 4, which led to programmers having to add and subtract 1 from a lot of string-length calculations, leading to all sorts of “off by one” math mistakes where the extra byte for the 0 was not accounted for properly. This might turn out to be harmless, if the byte just past the end of the buffer wasn’t used by any other variable, but it might also cause big problems—in particular, you might write the terminating 0 into another variable’s memory that was past the end of your buffer, then have that variable replace the 0 with something else, and suddenly your string would be seen as continuing on until it happened to run into another 0 in memory.21

字符串操作中的权衡完美地抓住了 C 的核心：它消除了任何不必要的性能开销，但也消除了自动保护措施。您可以完全控制字符串缓冲区分配，永远不需要使用超过所需内存，并且没有任何运行时检查会减慢索引速度。它确实使阅读代码变得更加困难；您花费大量时间查看字符串长度计算和字符串内存分配代码，试图说服自己它是正确的，通常是通过在脑海中使用短字符串运行示例（“让我们看看，如果这个字符串长 3 个字节，那么这个数字将计算为 4，我们将在这里分配那么多内存……”）。但如果您做对了所有事情，您就会获得所需的功能和所需的性能。

The trade-off made in string manipulation perfectly captures the heart of C: it removes any unneeded performance overhead, but also removes automatic safeguards. You had complete control of your string buffer allocations, were never required to use more memory than you needed, and did not have any runtime checks slowing down indexing. It did make reading code harder; you spent a lot of time looking at string-length-calculating and string-memory-allocating code trying to convince yourself that it was correct, typically by running through examples in your head using short strings (“Let’s see, if this string is 3 bytes long, then this number will be calculated as 4, and we’ll allocate that much memory here …”). But if you did everything right, you got the functionality you needed with the performance you wanted.

而且，我上大学时，重点肯定是性能，而不是清晰度或可维护性。当我还是普林斯顿大学四年级学生时，计算机科学系举行了一场编程竞赛，要求我们编写一个程序来解决一个特定问题；唯一的标准（除了程序是否能运行）是程序运行的速度。22获胜者与土木工程师和航空航天工程师一起在工程大会上获奖，这些工程师可能参与了以速度以外的其他因素进行评估的项目。

And performance, not clarity or maintainability, was definitely the focus at the time I was in college. When I was a senior at Princeton, the computer science department held a coding contest in which we were asked to write a program to solve a specific problem; the only criterion (besides the program working) was how fast it ran.22 The winner won a prize at the engineering convocation, alongside civil and aerospace engineers who presumably had worked on projects that were evaluated on something other than pure speed.

然而对我来说，这一切似乎非常正常，甚至令人鼓舞。当然，性能是重点。还有什么呢？C 为清除性能障碍所做的一切，都感觉像是在一天结束时脱掉紧绷的鞋子。我兴高采烈地编写代码来计算字符串长度和检查数组边界，从未想过任何其他方法会更好。Pascal 程序员愿意牺牲性能来换取不必处理这些复杂问题，这一事实被视为对他们的语言、他们自己或两者的控诉。

Yet to me, this all seemed perfectly normal and even encouraging. Of course performance would be the focus. What else would be? Everything that C did to clear out performance obstacles felt like taking off your tight shoes at the end of the day. I cheerfully wrote code to calculate string lengths and check array bounds, and never thought that any other way would be better. The fact that Pascal programmers were willing to trade away performance in exchange for not having to deal with these complications was seen as an indictment of their language, them, or both.

在普林斯顿大学磨练了我的指针操作技能后，我毕业了，开始在 Dendrite 编写 C 代码。虽然这是在万维网（网站和浏览器）发明之前，但互联网（至少是它的原型版本）确实存在，许多机器连接在一起。许多机器都在运行 UNIX，正如前面提到的，它是用 C 编写的——不仅是操作系统的核心，而且是在其上运行的许多程序。

After honing my pointer-manipulation skills at Princeton, I graduated and went off to work writing C code at Dendrite. Although this was before the invention of the World Wide Web—websites and browsers—the Internet, or at least a prototypical version of it, did exist, with many machines connected together. Many of those machines were running UNIX, which as mentioned was written in C—not just the core of the operating system, but a lot of the programs that ran on it.

1988 年 11 月，在我开始工作几个月后，我得到了一个关于 C 语言性能权衡弊端的实例教训。康奈尔大学计算机科学研究生罗伯特·莫里斯 (Robert Morris) 秘密发布了一个程序，后来被称为“莫里斯蠕虫”。该程序从麻省理工学院 (MIT) 的一台计算机开始，将自身复制到它可以访问的任何其他计算机上，并从那里连接到它可以访问的任何其他计算机，形成了一个快速增长的圈子。23

November 1988, a few months after I began work, brought an object lesson in the downside of the C performance trade-offs. A Cornell computer science graduate student named Robert Morris secretly released a program that came to be known as the “Morris worm.” Starting from a computer at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), the program copied itself to any other computers it could get access to, and from there connected to any other computers it could reach, in a rapidly growing circle.23

尽管莫里斯蠕虫不会做任何恶意的事情，例如删除文件，但它会一遍又一遍地将自己复制到同一台计算机上，而让程序在一台计算机上运行如此多次的开销会降低该计算机的性能。UNIX 系统旨在支持多人同时远程登录（这就是为什么它们被称为“主机”的原因）——这是我们在大学学习冯·诺依曼时所采用的设置，我们所有人都使用终端连接到一台 UNIX 机器——受感染机器上的用户会注意到它逐渐变得反应迟钝，直到机器无法使用。24莫里斯原本想让它传播得更慢，这样可以更长时间不被发现，但他错误地估计了它的传播速度——这是他的代码中的一个错误。

Although the Morris worm did not do anything malicious, such as deleting files, it would replicate itself back to the same computer over and over again, and the overhead of having the program running so many times on a single computer would degrade that computer’s performance. The UNIX systems were meant to support multiple people remotely logging on to them at once (which is why they were known, in an apropos twist, as “hosts”)—this was the setup we had in college grinding away in von Neumann, with all of us using terminals to connect to a single UNIX machine—and users on an infected machine would notice it becoming gradually less and less responsive until the machine was unusable.24 Morris had meant for it to propagate much more slowly and therefore remain undetected for longer, but he miscalculated how fast it would spread—a bug in his code.

经过几天的疯狂取证工作，蠕虫最终被控制住了，25 日，莫里斯被判处三年缓刑，最终成为麻省理工学院的教授，后来被任命为 ACM 研究员。但研究蠕虫如何传播是很有启发性的，因为它是 C 语言设计选择的直接结果，特别是字符串处理。

After some frantic forensic work over a few days, the worm was ultimately contained,25 and Morris was sentenced to three years’ probation, eventually winding up as a professor at MIT, and later named an ACM Fellow. But it’s instructive to look at how the worm propagated itself because it’s a direct result of the choices made in designing C, in particular the string handling.

Morris 蠕虫利用了一个名为“finger”的 UNIX 实用程序，该实用程序用于查询远程计算机上的用户信息。您可以输入

The Morris worm took advantage of a UNIX utility called “finger,” which was used to query information about a user on a remote machine. You could type

finger joe@mit.edu
finger joe@mit.edu

并且它将返回有关计算机 mit.edu 上的用户“joe”的信息（如果有这样的用户的话）（该程序至今仍然存在；甚至有一个版本作为 Windows 的一部分包含在内）。

and it would return information about the user “joe” on the machine mit.edu, if there was such a user (the program still exists today; there is even a version included as part of Windows).

Finger 就像是个人网站的早期版本，只不过在客户端，你运行的是 finger 命令而不是 Web 浏览器，并且它仅限于打印出有关用户的某些特定信息，包括用户为此目的创建的两个文件（名为.plan和 ）的内容.project。二十六

Finger was like an early version of a personal website, except that on the client end, you ran the finger command instead of a web browser, and it was limited to printing out certain specific information about a user, including the contents of two files that a user could create for this purpose, named .plan and .project.26

为了实现这一点，远程计算机上必须运行一个程序，等待接收 Finger 客户端程序发送的“告诉我有关此用户的更多信息”消息，就像 Web 服务器等待来自浏览器的初始消息一样。这个程序被称为 Finger 守护进程，守护进程这个术语在 UNIX 上通常用于指代此类事物（它是希腊语单词的拉丁语形式，意为“力量”或“上帝”，我的字典将其定义为“守护神”）。27尽管单个用户可以选择不允许 Finger 向远程人员返回信息，但是 Finger 守护进程本身必须监听来自任何远程计算机的传入消息，因为它需要确定请求是针对哪个用户的，然后才能决定是否响应。

For this to work, there had to be a program running on the remote computer waiting to receive the “tell me more about this user” message that the finger client program would send, in the same way that a web server waits for the initial message from a browser. This program was known as the finger daemon, with the term daemon being commonly used for this sort of thing on UNIX (it’s the Latin form of a Greek word meaning “power” or “god,” which my dictionary defines as “a guardian spirit”).27 Although an individual user could choose to not allow finger to return information to remote people, the finger daemon itself had to listen to incoming messages from any remote computer since it needed to determine which user the request was for before it could decide whether to respond or not.

当两台机器进行这样的通信时，必须有一个约定，即协议，规定要传输哪些信息 — Finger 客户端和 Finger 守护程序中的代码必须一致。在这种情况下，协议很简单：Finger 客户端会将用户名发送给 Finger 守护程序，Finger 守护程序会回复几行有关该用户的信息，然后 Finger 客户端会不加改变地显示这些信息。虽然 Finger 守护程序返回给客户端的消息大小可能任意，但 Finger 守护程序只希望从客户端收到一条短消息 — 长度刚好够输入用户名。

When two machines communicate like that, there has to be a convention, known as a protocol, on what information will be transferred—the code in the finger client and the finger daemon have to be in agreement. In this case, the protocol was simple: the finger client would send a username to the finger daemon, and the finger daemon would reply with several lines of information about that user, which the finger client would then display unchanged. While the message coming back from the finger daemon to the client could be of somewhat-arbitrary size, the finger daemon only expected a short message from the client—just long enough for a username.

然而，没有什么可以阻止某人编写自己的 Finger 客户端，将其自己的消息发送到另一台计算机上的 Finger 守护进程，也没有什么可以阻止新的 Finger 客户端向 Finger 守护进程发送比预期长得多的消息。当然，官方 Finger 客户端不会做任何这样的事情，而导致 Morris 蠕虫的部分问题在于没有人能想象为什么有人会编写自己的 Finger 客户端，并以这种方式出现问题。

There was nothing stopping somebody, however, from writing their own finger client that sent its own messages to the finger daemon on another computer, and there was also nothing stopping that new finger client from sending a much-longer message to the finger daemon than it expected. Of course the official finger client would not do any such thing, and part of the problem that led to the Morris worm was that nobody could imagine why anybody would write their own finger client that would misbehave in this way.

为了解释为什么这会导致此类问题，我们需要回顾一下程序通常如何使用内存。需要内存来存储数据的程序将调用操作系统提供的 API，该 API 根据请求提供可用的堆内存。如果程序需要 500 字节的缓冲区，它会调用操作系统并说“我需要 500 字节”，然后操作系统会将其之前未分配的 500 字节内存的位置交还，并跟踪这一点，这样它就不会再次提供该内存，直到程序调用另一个 API 说“我用完了这 500 字节”。

To explain why this could cause such problems, we need to review how programs typically use memory. A program that needs memory to store data will call an API that the operating system provides that hands out available heap memory on request. If a program needs a 500-byte buffer, it calls the operating system and says, “I need 500 bytes,” and the operating system hands back the location of 500 bytes of memory that it has not previously handed out, and keeps track of this so it won’t give that memory out again until the program calls a different API to say, “I’m done with those 500 bytes.”

系统返回的“位置”只是一个数字；从概念上讲，如果计算机有 1 兆字节内存，实际上是 1,048,576 字节，那么可用的内存字节将由 0 到 1,048,575 之间的数字标识。当系统返回 500 字节内存时，它会说：“您的 500 字节内存从 [例如] 地址 652,000 开始”，这意味着您现在可以使用地址 652,000 到 652,499。在 C 语言中，这个数字 652,000 将存储在一个指针中，假设名为p，使用指针/数组等效性的魔力，您现在可以通过 访问这些p[0]字节p[499]。

The “location” that the system hands back is just a number; conceptually, if a computer has 1 megabyte of memory, which is actually 1,048,576 bytes, then the available bytes of memory are identified by a number between 0 and 1,048,575. When the system hands you back 500 bytes of memory, it is saying, “Your 500-byte piece starts at [as an example] address 652,000,” which means you can now use addresses 652,000 through 652,499. In C, this number 652,000 would be stored in a pointer, let’s say named p, and using the magic of the pointer/array equivalency, you could now access those bytes as p[0] through p[499].

正如我之前所讨论的，C 不会检查你的数组索引是否有效，因此你可以访问p[1000]（在此示例中为内存地址 653,000）并读取或写入原本用于其他用途的内存，但希望你的代码已经在某处记录了仅指向 500 字节内存的事实p并且不会这样做。二十八

As I have discussed earlier, C doesn’t check that your array index is valid, so you could access p[1000] (memory address 653,000, in this example) and be reading or writing memory that was intended to be used for something else, but hopefully your code has recorded somewhere the fact that p only points to 500 bytes of memory and won’t do that.28

系统会将一部分内存划分出来用于特殊用途，不用于一般分配。这部分内存称为堆栈，用于跟踪函数调用的层次。当程序调用函数时，参数值会存储在堆栈中，返回地址也是如此——函数完成时代码应跳转回的位置。返回地址与其他内存地址一样，因为正在运行的实际代码（机器语言的所有字节）也存储在内存中。它是另一个指针，恰好指向代码字节。本质上，当系统加载程序时，它会将代码放在内存的一部分中，为堆栈保留另一部分，并将其余部分用作堆，以便在运行时进行内存分配。

There is a part of memory that is carved off by the system for a special purpose, unavailable for general allocation. This is called the stack and is used for keeping track of the layers of function calls. When a program calls a function, the parameter values are stored on the stack, as is the return address—the place that the code should jump back to when the function completes. The return address is a memory address like any other, because the actual code that is being run—all the bytes of machine language—is also stored in memory. It’s another pointer, which happens to point to bytes of code. Essentially, when the system loads a program it puts the code in one part of memory, reserves another part for the stack, and makes the rest available as the heap, for memory allocation at runtime.

回顾堆栈，您可以看到当前函数的参数及其返回地址，然后在此之前，您可以看到调用该函数的函数的参数及其返回地址，依此类推；在程序运行的任何给定点，所有函数层都将其参数和返回地址存储在堆栈中。这是一系列面包屑，供处理器找到回到程序启动位置的路径。此外，函数的任何局部变量（声明为在函数内部临时使用的变量）也在堆栈上。

Looking back on the stack, you can see the parameters to the current function and its return address, and then before that you see the parameters to the function that called that function and its return address, and so on; all the layers of functions, at any given point when the program is running, have their parameters and return addresses stored on the stack. It’s a series of breadcrumbs for the processor to find its way back to where the program started. In addition, any local variables for a function—variables declared for temporary use inside the function—are on the stack as well.

图 4.1显示了堆栈的样子（未显示一些不相关的项）29为左侧代码，其中代码调用函数A，然后函数调用函数B，函数又调用函数C，当前我们正在运行函数中的代码C。请注意，堆栈在内存中向下增长（即朝着编号较低的内存地址增长），因此回顾堆栈意味着向上查找，朝着编号较高的内存地址查找。要调用一个函数，首先将参数推送到堆栈上，然后将函数完成后应返回的地址推送到堆栈上。然后，调用代码跳转到函数的开头，函数在此处做的第一件事就是运行代码（由编译器自动生成）以在堆栈上为其局部变量保留空间。30在图中，参数（例如 的的参数列表A中声明的名称描述（）。但请注意，在调用 的代码中内部的参数是调用代码中的变量。因此，调用代码会将 推送到堆栈上， 内部的相同值在堆栈上被检索为。AheightAheightAcur_hcur_hAheight

Figure 4.1 shows what the stack would look like (with a few irrelevant items not depicted)29 for the code on the left, where code calls function A, which then calls function B, which in turn calls function C, and we are currently running code in function C. Note that the stack grows downward in memory (that is, toward lower-numbered memory addresses), so looking back on the stack means looking up, toward higher-numbered memory addresses. To call a function, first the parameters are pushed on the stack, and then the address that the function should return back to when it is done. The calling code then jumps to the start of the function, where the first thing the function does is run code (which the compiler has automatically generated) to reserve space on the stack for its local variables.30 In the diagram the parameters, such as A’s first parameter, are described by the name they are declared as in A’s parameter list—in this example, height. But realize that in the code that calls A, the parameter that becomes height inside of A is the variable cur_h in the calling code. So the calling code pushes cur_h on the stack, and inside of A that same value on the stack is retrieved as height.

有一个称为堆栈指针的处理器寄存器（图 4.1中的“当前堆栈指针”显示了在 C 语言内部运行代码时它指向的位置），它跟踪堆栈上的下一个可用位置。

There is a processor register called the stack pointer (the “current stack pointer” in figure 4.1 shows where it would be pointing when running code inside C), which tracks the next available spot on the stack.

假设您想在函数中使用 500 字节的缓冲区。在 C 中有两种方法可以做到这一点。您可以从堆中进行动态分配，调用内存分配 API malloc()：

Let’s say you want to use a 500-byte buffer inside a function. There are two ways to do this in C. You can do a dynamic allocation from the heap, calling the memory allocation API malloc():

char* c = malloc(500);
if (c == NULL) {
     // the allocation failed, deal with this
}
char* c = malloc(500);
if (c == NULL) {
     // the allocation failed, deal with this
}

或者您可以将其声明为堆栈上的数组：

or you can declare it as an array on the stack:

char c[500];
char c[500];

由于 C 中的数组/指针等效性，访问函数内部 500 个字节的任何代码都将以c相同的方式使用，无论您使用其中哪一种；编译器将隐藏内部差异。但在第一个示例中，调用malloc()，堆栈上唯一的东西是指针c本身——一个在现代计算机上将占用 32 位或 64 位的单个值。在第二个实例中，整个 500 个字节都在堆栈上。如您所见，在堆栈上分配它的代码更少，您不必调用 API 并担心分配失败，这将需要更多代码来处理。而且它运行得更快，因为只需调整堆栈指针即可分配空间。此外，当任何函数完成并返回其调用者时，堆栈指针将移回调用者中的位置，因此您可以自动清理在堆栈上分配的任何局部变量——也不需要调用另一个 API 来释放堆栈数组。像往常一样，更快和更少的代码都被认为是纯粹的商品。

Due to the array/pointer equivalency in C, any code that accesses the 500 bytes inside the function will use c in an identical way no matter which of the two you use; the compiler will hide the internal differences. But in the first example, calling malloc(), the only thing on the stack is the pointer c itself—a single value that will occupy 32 or 64 bits on modern computers. In the second instance, the entire 500 bytes are on the stack. As you can see, it is less code to allocate it on the stack, and you don’t have to call an API and worry about the allocation failing, which would require even more code to deal with. And it runs faster, since the space is allocated just by adjusting the stack pointer. Moreover, when any function completes and returns back to its caller, the stack pointer moves back to where it was in the caller, so you get automatic cleanup of any local variables allocated on the stack—with no need to call another API to free a stack array either. Faster and less code, as usual, are both considered to be unalloyed goods.

动态分配和堆栈分配之间的一个重要区别是，动态分配时，您可以指定一个直到运行时才知道的大小；“500”参数可以malloc()是任何变量。同时，如上所示的本地堆栈分配需要一个常量值（某些版本的 C 允许您在堆栈上分配一个可变大小，但这不是标准化的）。

One important difference between dynamic allocation and allocating on the stack is that when dynamically allocating, you can specify a size that isn’t known until runtime; that “500” parameter to malloc() could instead be any variable. Meanwhile, the local stack allocation as shown above requires a constant value (certain versions of C allow you to allocate on the stack with a variable size, but it’s not standardized).

因此，如果要将字符串连接在一起形成一个新字符串，正确的做法是确定原始字符串的长度（下面的前两行）并分配适当的内存量（第三行，需要+ 2考虑空格和终止 0 字符）在调用 API 实际执行连接之前（最后三行：首先复制名字，然后在空格和姓氏上进行连接）：

So if you are concatenating strings together into a new string, the correct thing to do is to determine the length of the original strings (the first two lines below) and allocate the right amount of memory (the third line, with the + 2 needed to account for the space and the terminating 0 character) before calling the APIs to actually do the concatenation (the last three lines: first copy over the first name, then concatenate on the space and the last name):

int firstnamelen = strlen(firstname);
int lastnamelen = strlen(lastname);
wholename = malloc(firstnamelen + lastnamelen + 2);
if (wholename == NULL) {
     // the allocation failed, deal with this
}
strcpy(wholename, firstname);
strcat(wholename, " ");
strcat(wholename, lastname);
int firstnamelen = strlen(firstname);
int lastnamelen = strlen(lastname);
wholename = malloc(firstnamelen + lastnamelen + 2);
if (wholename == NULL) {
     // the allocation failed, deal with this
}
strcpy(wholename, firstname);
strcat(wholename, " ");
strcat(wholename, lastname);

但人们很容易就问“一个名字能有多长”，然后选择一个数字，如 256：

But it is oh so tempting to simply ask, “How long can a name possibly be,” and then pick a number such as 256:

char wholename[256];
strcpy(wholename, firstname);
strcat(wholename, " ");
strcat(wholename, lastname);
char wholename[256];
strcpy(wholename, firstname);
strcat(wholename, " ");
strcat(wholename, lastname);

这样需要编写的代码更少，而且运行速度也更快，您不必处理“分配失败”部分，这可能会变得很糟糕（而且您还必须在某个时候释放堆分配）。请注意，最后三行代码（即生成连接名称的代码）是相同的；通过将字符串存储在堆栈上，您可以节省 3 个 API 调用，并且不必处理错误情况。这不是很方便吗？唯一的风险是某人的名字/姓氏组合长度超过 256 个字符（实际上是 254 个，因为您需要空间来容纳空格和最后的 0）——这种情况真的有多大可能？

This is less code to write, and as a bonus it runs slightly faster and you don’t have to deal with the “allocation failed” part, which could get ugly (and you also have to free your heap allocation at some point). Note that the last three lines of code, the ones that produce the concatenated name, are the same; by storing the string on the stack, you are saving 3 API calls plus having to deal with an error case. Isn’t that convenient? And the only risk is that somebody has a first name/last name combo that is longer than 256 characters (254, actually, since you need room for the space and final 0)—and how likely is that, really?

现在我可以解释 Morris 蠕虫利用的 Finger 守护进程漏洞了。在读取客户端的请求时（该请求仅包含用户名），Finger 守护进程代码会快速执行“我们假设请求缓冲区不会大于某个大小并在堆栈上为其分配空间”的技巧，它选择的特定大小是 512 字节。它调用的 API（称为gets()）将字符串缓冲区作为其唯一参数来读入数据，但无法指示缓冲区的长度；它假定调用代码知道自己在做什么并且缓冲区足够长。具体来说，旨在gets()读取“一行文本”；回想一下 ASCII 中可打印字符的编码从 32 到 126，gets()读取数据直到看到包含值 10 的字节 - ASCII 编码中不可打印的字符，称为换行符 (LF)。传递的字符串缓冲区gets()是指向内存中某个位置的指针；gets()会读取第一个字节，将其存储在指针位置，将指针前进 1 个字节，然后循环回来读取下一个字节。它会继续执行此操作，直到看到 LF 字符，完全不知道在分配字符串缓冲区时实际指定的大小。完全有可能gets()超出缓冲区的末尾 — 这种情况称为缓冲区溢出。

Now I can explain the finger daemon bug that the Morris worm exploited. When reading the request from the client, which was only expected to contain a username, the finger daemon code did the quick “let’s just assume the request buffer won’t be bigger than a certain size and allocate room for it on the stack” trick, and the certain size it picked was 512 bytes. And the API it was calling, which was called gets(), took as its single parameter a string buffer to read the data into, but with no way of indicating how long the buffer was; it assumed the calling code knew what it was doing and the buffer was long enough. Specifically, gets() was designed to read “a line of text”; recalling that the encoding of printable characters in ASCII goes from 32 to 126, gets() reads data until it sees a byte containing the value 10—a nonprintable character in the ASCII encoding known as the line feed (LF). The string buffer that gets() was passed was a pointer to a location in memory; gets() would read in the first byte, store that at the pointer location, advance the pointer by 1 byte, and loop back to read the next byte. It would continue doing this until it saw the LF character, completely unaware of what size had actually been specified when the string buffer was allocated. It was entirely possible that gets() could go past the end of the buffer—a situation known as a buffer overflow.

设计gets()很糟糕；老实说，我不知道他们在想什么。在上面的字符串连接示例中，如果您选择利用它（就像第一个版本那样），您至少有机会实际计算您需要多少存储空间，甚至有相当大的机会得到正确的结果（只需记住添加 1 以说明最后的 0 字节！）。但在这种情况下，无论您传入的缓冲区有多大，gets()如果它没有及时遇到 LF 字符，仍然可能会溢出。31

The design of gets() is terrible; honestly, I have no idea what they were thinking. In the string concatenation example above, you at least have the opportunity, if you choose to take advantage of it (as the first version does), to do the actual calculation of how much storage you need, and even have a decent chance of getting it right (just remember to add 1 to account for the final 0 byte!). But in this case, no matter how big a buffer you passed in, gets() could still overflow it if it didn’t encounter an LF character in time.31

这是另一个被所调用 API 的实现困住的例子；gets()是程序必须运行才能获得所需数据的 gantlet。该 API 将继续读取数据，直到看到 LF 字符，而您对此无法控制；无论传入的缓冲区有多大，您都不知道它gets()会读取超出分配的数据，因为您不知道它在运行时会读取什么实际数据。gets()同时，在 内部，代码不知道传入的缓冲区分配了多长，也不知道它是在堆栈还是堆上。 唯一的可取之处在于gets()它显然无法知道缓冲区有多长，因为没有指定长度的参数。所以希望人们意识到这是无望的并且不要调用它。

This is another example of being stuck with the implementation of an API you are calling; gets() is the gantlet that the program must run to get the data it needs. That API will continue to read data until it sees that LF character, and you have no control over that; no matter how big a buffer you pass in, you don’t know if gets() will read more than you allocated because you don’t know what actual data it will be reading at runtime. Inside of gets(), meanwhile, the code doesn’t know how long the buffer you passed in was allocated to be, nor does it know if it was on the stack or heap. The only saving grace for gets() is that it is somewhat obvious that it can’t know how long the buffer is, because there is no parameter specifying the length. So hopefully people will realize that it is hopeless and not call it.

只是 Finger 守护进程确实调用了它。有点令人沮丧的是，Finger 守护进程可以轻松调用一个更通用的 API，该 API 可以从任何文件读取，并告诉它从一个名为标准输入的特殊文件中读取，这就是它的作用gets()，并且该 API 确实接受一个参数来指示缓冲区的最大长度：

Except that the finger daemon did call it. Somewhat depressingly, the finger daemon could easily have called a more general API that reads from any file and told it to read from a special file called the standard input, which is what gets() does, and that API does take a parameter indicating the maximum length of the buffer:

fgets(buffer, 512, stdin);   // instead of gets(buffer)
fgets(buffer, 512, stdin);   // instead of gets(buffer)

那么我们在谈论什么——再输入 9 个字符（如果算上逗号则是 11 个，如果算上空格则是 13 个）来切换到不存在缓冲区溢出风险并能防止 Morris 蠕虫的 API？32为什么 finger 守护进程的作者不这样做？ 就此而言，为什么它gets()设计得如此糟糕，而它本来可以模仿fgets()并获取额外的长度参数？ 这些是历史问题，我不知道答案； 作为一个小小的安慰，它gets()最终被逐出 C 语言标准，因此它不再会感染未来的代码（尽管我确信有很多旧系统正在运行gets()其中埋藏有调用的代码）。

So what are we talking about—typing 9 more characters (11 if you count the commas, 13 if you count the spaces) to switch to an API that isn’t at risk of a buffer overflow and prevents the Morris worm?32 Why did the author of the finger daemon not do that? For that matter, why was gets() designed in such a horribly broken way, when it could have mimicked fgets() and taken the extra length parameter? These are historical questions whose answers are unknown to me; as a small consolation, gets() was eventually excommunicated from the C language standard so it can no longer infect future code (although I’m sure there are a lot of old systems out there running code that has calls to gets() buried inside).

在某些情况下，当缓冲区太短而无法容纳数据时，程序没有明显的补救措施。这就像手工填写一份表格，每个字母都有一个方格，然后发现表格的设计者假设姓氏不会超过 15 个字符，而你的姓氏有 16 个字符。你会怎么做？没有正确的答案。但这里的答案很简单。由于 513 字节以上的手指请求显然是错误的，你可以忽略它。事实上，如果你要切换到使用fgets()并忽略过长的请求，那么你可以使用小得多的堆栈分配，例如 64 字节。33 512 的中间值比有效请求所需的长度要长得多，但还不足以保护您免受无效请求的影响，那么意义何在？

In some cases, when a buffer is too short to hold the data, the program doesn’t have an obvious recourse. It’s like filling in a form by hand that has a square for every letter and discovering that the designers of the form assumed that no last name would be longer than 15 characters, and you have a 16-character last name. What do you do? There’s no right answer. But here the answer is simple. Since a 513-plus-byte finger request is clearly wrong, you can ignore it. In fact, if you are going to switch to using fgets() and ignore overlong requests, while you are at it you can use a much smaller stack allocation, such as 64 bytes.33 The middle ground of 512 is much longer than you will ever need for a valid request, but it isn’t long enough to protect you against an invalid request, so what is the point?

最糟糕的是，溢出的 Finger 守护进程缓冲区位于堆栈上。在函数内部运行时，如上图所示，堆栈的排列方式是局部变量紧挨着参数和返回地址；堆栈总体向下增长，但对缓冲区的访问向上增长。因此，参数和返回地址刚好超过 512 字节缓冲区的末尾，该缓冲区被声明为堆栈上的局部变量，而不是从堆中动态分配，因为这样可以减少输入，并且堆栈分配奇迹般地永远不会失败（实际上，堆栈只是内存，可能会用尽空间，导致程序崩溃，但程序员忽略了这一点）。

The fact that the finger daemon buffer that overflowed was on the stack was the worst part of it. When running inside a function, as shown in the earlier diagram, the stack is arranged with the local variables immediately below the parameters and return address; the stack overall grows downward, but access to a buffer goes upward. Therefore, the parameters and return address were just past the end of the 512-byte buffer, which was declared as a local variable on the stack rather than allocated dynamically from the heap because that takes less typing and stack allocations magically never fail (in fact the stack is just memory and can run out of room, crashing the program, but programmers ignore this).

缓冲区溢出总是不好的，因为您可能会破坏缓冲区之后的任何内存，但至少如果缓冲区位于堆中的某个地方，则可能的结果只是奇怪的行为和/或使手指守护进程崩溃，这很烦人和具有破坏性，但并不构成对原始互联网的生存威胁（尽管也有例外：针对 Windows 的远程攻击称为 EternalBlue，这是 2017 年 WannaCry 勒索软件攻击的基础，利用了堆缓冲区中的溢出；它依靠巧妙的策略来确定它向计算机发送的消息究竟是什么，以确保可以有用且可靠地修改溢出缓冲区之后的堆缓冲区）。34当缓冲区位于堆栈上时，恶意的手指请求将破坏内存中最危险的数据：调用函数的返回地址gets()。当处理器决定函数运行完毕后需要跳回到哪里时，它将盲目遵循这些数据。

A buffer overflow is always bad, because you will likely corrupt whatever memory is just after your buffer, but at least if the buffer is somewhere in the heap, the likely outcome will just be strange behavior and/or making the finger daemon crash, which is annoying and disruptive yet not an existential threat to the proto-Internet (although there are exceptions: the remote attack against Windows known as EternalBlue, which was the basis of the WannaCry ransomware attack in 2017, took advantage of an overflow in a heap buffer; it relied on clever tactics regarding exactly what messages it sent to the computer to ensure that the heap buffer just after the one that was overflowed could be usefully and reliably modified).34 When you have the buffer on the stack, your malicious finger request is going to stomp on the most dangerous piece of data in memory: the return address of the function that is calling gets(). This is data that the processor is going to blindly obey when it decides where it needs to jump back to when this function is finished running.

另一个令人震惊的巧合是，你可以将返回地址设置为指向缓冲区本身的较早部分，计算机会愉快地跳转到任何返回地址，即使是在为堆栈保留的区域而不是通常加载代码的区域。因此，恶意的 Finger 请求（此类消息通常称为漏洞）可以在用于溢出堆栈缓冲区的同一伪造 Finger 消息中发送它想要运行的实际代码（称为有效载荷）。

By another appalling lack of serendipity that I won’t get into, you can set the return address to point into an earlier part of the buffer itself, and the computer will happily jump to any return address, even one that is in the area reserved for the stack versus where code is normally loaded. So the malicious finger request (such messages are generally known as exploits) can send over the actual code that it wants to run (known as the payload) in the same bogus finger message that it uses to overflow the stack buffer.

有效载荷必须采用机器语言，因为这是处理器在运行程序时希望在内存中看到的。但您有大约 512 个字节来制作有效载荷——足够容纳蠕虫使用的相当简单的漏洞代码（一个问题是您的机器语言代码不能包含值为 10 的字节，因为这将被解释为gets()LF 字符并阻止其读取数据）。

The payload has to be in machine language, since that is what the processor expects to see in memory when it is running a program. But you have on the order of 512 bytes to craft your payload—more than enough room to hold the fairly simple exploit code that the worm used (the one gotcha is that your machine language code can’t have a byte with the value of 10, since that would be interpreted by gets() as an LF character and stop it reading data).

如果您有意设计一个允许远程攻击的系统，那么您几乎不可能做得更好。这就是我在本章开头提到的“C 语言中最糟糕的性能特性”。缺乏数组保护措施、易于分配本地缓冲区和堆栈安排，以及 UNIX 作为诱饵的吸引力，使 C 语言成为完美的满洲潜伏语言。引用《指环王》中 Arwen 的话，“直到现在我才明白你们人民及其覆灭的故事。我鄙视他们，因为他们是邪恶的傻瓜，但最后我同情他们。如果这确实是 Eldar 所说的上帝赐予人类的礼物，那么接受它是一件痛苦的事。”三十五

If you had been intentionally designing a system to allow remote exploits, you could hardly have done a better job. This is the “worst performance-focused feature of C” that I mentioned at the beginning of the chapter. The lack of safeguards on arrays, ease of allocating local buffers, and arrangement of the stack, as well as the appeal of UNIX as bait, make C the perfect Manchurian sleeper language. To quote Arwen in The Lord of the Rings, “Not till now have I understood the tale of your people and their fall. As wicked fools I scorned them, but I pity them at last. If this is indeed, as the Eldar say, the gift of the One to Men, it is bitter to receive.”35

并不是说 1988 年人们还不知道恶意代码的概念。《计算机病毒》一书在前一年出版，其中讨论了未知代码在计算机上运行的危险，并讨论了各种感染方式。36但该书中探讨的所有病毒都是由于可以笼统地称为“人为错误”而传播的。虽然用法并不准确，但病毒一词通常是指必须“手动”传播的漏洞，例如用户复制文件，而不是蠕虫，蠕虫无需用户操作即可传播。到目前为止，攻击都是病毒，而不是蠕虫。

It’s not that the concept of malicious code was unknown in 1988. The book Computer Viruses had appeared the year before, talking about the dangers of unknown code running on your computer and discussing the various means of infection.36 But all the viruses explored in that book were spread due to what could be loosely called “human error.” Although the usage is not precise, the term virus generally means an exploit that has to be spread “manually,” such as by a user copying a file, as opposed to a worm, which can spread with no user action. The attacks up to this point had been viruses, not worms.

例如，1987 年末曾出现过一种名为“圣诞树”的“感染互联网”的病毒，该病毒通过电子邮件传播，运行时，会将自身通过电子邮件发送给它能找到的所有其他用户。37但圣诞树病毒依赖于用户收到一封电子邮件，该电子邮件本质上说“运行此程序，不问任何问题”（在感染您的朋友之前，它会打印出一棵由星号组成的圣诞树供您欣赏）。还有其他病毒依赖于信任的用户运行受感染的程序，然后该程序会感染它在您的计算机上找到的其他程序（这就是为什么当今的电子邮件程序会拒绝打开，甚至在某些情况下拒绝传输已知有风险的文件附件类型）。

For example, there was a previous “infects the Internet” virus in late 1987 called Christmas Tree, which was spread via e-mail, and when run, e-mailed itself to everybody else it could find.37 But Christmas Tree depended on the user receiving an e-mail that essentially said “run this program, no questions asked” (before infecting your friends, it printed out a Christmas tree made of asterisks for your enjoyment). And there were other viruses that depended on a trusting user running an infected program, which would then infect other programs it found on your computer (this is why e-mail programs today will refuse to open, or in certain cases even transmit, types of file attachments known to be risky).

程序员可能会认为所有这些都不是他们的错：“好吧，如果用户做了一些愚蠢的事情，那么他们就必须承担后果”，而这个愚蠢的行为就是运行一个你不知道其内容的程序（在 Christmas Tree 的例子中，它是用 REXX 语言解释的脚本，只要扫描代码就会发现它在做一些狡猾的勾当；当然这需要你了解 REXX，但我想不是程序员也会被归入愚蠢的用户行为类别）。38在计算机历史上的一个不幸时刻，当大多数用户也是程序员时，程序员会将少数非编程用户称为“ lusers ”——这是“loser”一词的双关语。盲目运行病毒脚本是“lusers”会做的事情。

All these could be dismissed by programmers as not their fault: “Well, if the user does something stupid, then they have to face the consequences,” where the stupid action was running a program whose contents you were ignorant of (in the case of Christmas Tree, which was an interpreted script in the language REXX, just scanning the code would make it obvious it was up to something devious; of course this would require you to understand REXX, but I suppose not being a programmer was also lumped into the category of stupid user behavior).38 At one unfortunate point in the history of computers, when most users were also programmers, programmers would refer to the rare nonprogramming users as lusers—a play on the word loser. Blindly running a virus script was something that a luser would do.

莫里斯蠕虫则不同：它感染了机器，而用户无需采取任何行动。最大的错误是程序员的一次失误，从那时起，就没有什么可以阻止它了，直到蠕虫出现并造成严重破坏，人们才受到启发，部署了新版本的 Finger 守护程序，该程序修复了缓冲区溢出问题。当时甚至有人认为，有些人知道 Finger 守护程序中的代码存在风险，但却忽略了这个问题，大概是因为想象力不足；他们知道真正的 Finger 客户端永远不会发送接近 512 字节的消息，他们从未想到有人会编写一个程序来恶意生成无效请求。三十九

The Morris worm was different: it infected machines with no action by the user. The cardinal sin was a onetime mistake by a programmer, and from that point on there was nothing that could have been done to prevent it, until the worm was out there and wreaking havoc, and people were inspired to deploy a new version of the finger daemon that had the buffer overflow problem fixed. There was even a suggestion at the time that some people knew the code in the finger daemon was risky but ignored the problem, presumably because of a failure of imagination; they knew the real finger client would never send a message anywhere near 512 bytes, and it never occurred to them that somebody would write a program to maliciously generate invalid requests.39

这本可以起到警示 C 爱好者的作用，但事实并非如此。当然，没有人对 C 风格的缓冲区操作表示强烈抗议，尽管有人采取行动，gets()专门从人们的代码中删除这些操作。康奈尔委员会在其调查结果摘要中，首先（正确地）将责任归咎于莫里斯，然后继续指出，

This could have functioned as a wake-up call to C enthusiasts, but it did not. Certainly there was no outcry against C-style buffer manipulation, although there was movement to excise gets() specifically from people’s code. The Cornell Commission, in its Summary of Findings, after first (correctly) laying the blame with Morris, goes on to state,

UNIX，尤其是伯克利 UNIX，存在许多安全漏洞，这一点众所周知，病毒和蠕虫的潜在危害也确实如此。尽管这些安全漏洞可能不为广大公众所知，但 UNIX 使用者却接受它们的存在。利用这种弱点并非天才或英雄之举。学者社区不应该为了保护合理的隐私期望而建起高耸入云的墙，尤其是当这些墙同样会阻碍信息的自由流动时。此外，在一个拥有跨越最高障碍所需的所有知识和技能的个人社区中，试图建造这样的墙很可能是徒劳的。40

The fact that UNIX, in particular Berkeley UNIX, has many security flaws has been generally well known, as indeed are the potential dangers of viruses and worms in general. Although such security flaws may not be known to the public at large, their existence is accepted by those who make use of UNIX. It is no act of genius or heroism to exploit such weakness. A community of scholars should not have to build walls as high as the sky to protect a reasonable expectation of privacy, particularly when such walls will equally impede the free flow of information. Besides, attempting to build such walls is likely to be futile in a community of individuals possessed of all the knowledge and skills required to scale the highest barriers.40

我可以接受他们将互联网视为“学者社区”而不是有史以来最重要的事物的早期版本的观点，因为这是 1989 年，但除此之外，很难知道从何说起。随意接受可利用的代码？对莫里斯技术技能的讽刺性贬低？将“不要调用 verkakte API gets()”与阻碍信息的自由流动混为一谈？最重要的是，这准确地捕捉到了程序员对缓冲区溢出的那种仰天长叹、不知所措的态度。

I can accept their view of the Internet as a “community of scholars” rather than the early version of the most important thing ever, since this was 1989, but beyond that it’s hard to know where to start with this. The casual acceptance of exploitable code? The backhanded denigrating of Morris’s technical skills? The conflating of “don’t call the verkakte gets() API” with impeding the free flow of information? The main thing is that this accurately captures the palms-to-the-sky, what-are-you-gonna-do attitude of programmers toward buffer overflows.

也很难将 C 与 UNIX 区分开来；它们是天生一对。Niklaus Wirth 如此描述：“UNIX 带着 C 语言，而 C 语言的设计初衷就是支持 UNIX 的开发。显然，使用 C 语言开发 UNIX 下运行的应用程序至少是有吸引力的，甚至是必不可少的，而 C 语言就像是 C 的特洛伊木马。”41 Finger 守护进程需要与网络交互，而任何编程语言都无法通过其标准 API 支持这一点，但是在 UNIX 上，C 是首选语言，C 中提供了可用于发送和接收网络消息的 API，因此 Finger 守护进程自然是用 C 编写的。

It is also hard to separate C from UNIX; they were made for each other. Niklaus Wirth described it this way: “In its tow UNIX carried the language C, which had been explicitly designed to support the development of UNIX. Evidently, it was therefore at least attractive, if not even mandatory to use C for the development of applications running under UNIX, which acted like a Trojan horse for C.”41 The finger daemon required interacting with the network, which is not something that any programming language supported with its standard API, but on UNIX, where C was the language of choice, there were API available in C that let you send and receive network messages, so naturally the finger daemon was written in C.

“从软件工程的角度来看，C 语言的快速传播代表着一次巨大的倒退，”Wirth 继续说道，

“From the point of view of software engineering, the rapid spread of C represented a great leap backward,” continued Wirth,

这表明，整个社区几乎没有理解“高级语言”一词的真正含义，而“高级语言”已经成为一个难以理解的流行词。……C 的广泛使用削弱了提高软件工程水平的尝试，因为 C 提供了它实际上并不支持的抽象：数组仍然没有索引检查，数据类型没有一致性检查，指针仅仅是可以进行加法和减法的地址。人们可能会将 C 归类为介于误导和危险之间的一种语言。但相反，大多数人，尤其是学术界人士，发现它很有趣，而且“比汇编代码更好”，因为它具有一些语法。四十二

It revealed that the community at large had hardly grasped the true meaning of the term “high-level language” which became an ill-understood buzzword. … The widespread run on C undercut the attempt to raise the level of software engineering, because C offers abstractions which it does not in fact support: Arrays remain without index checking, data types without consistency check, pointers are merely addresses where addition and subtraction are applicable. One might have classified C as being somewhere between misleading and even dangerous. But on the contrary, people at large, particularly in academia, found it intriguing and “better than assembly code,” because it featured some syntax.42

我对 C 语言感兴趣不仅仅是因为它“具有一些语法”；我发现 Wirth 所批评的东西正是 C 语言最吸引人的特性。事实上，当我听说 Morris 蠕虫利用 C 代码中的缓冲区溢出时，我心里想，“这真聪明！”甚至有一份关于该蠕虫的报告将手指守护程序缓冲区溢出称为蠕虫所做的“最巧妙的攻击”。43

I wasn’t just intrigued by C because it “featured some syntax”; I found the very things that Wirth is criticizing to be the most appealing features of C. Indeed, when I heard about the Morris worm exploiting a buffer overflow in C code, I thought to myself, “That’s kind of clever!” Even one of the reports on the worm referred to the finger daemon buffer overflow as the “neatest hack” that the worm did.43

更重要的是，事后并没有感觉到用 C 编写面向网络的系统工具存在任何根本性错误。该事件被视为一个错误的结果，该错误已在新版本的 Finger 守护程序中得到修复，问题也得到了解决。没有人想到，“哎呀，可能还有很多这样的问题。”如前所述，程序员是自学成才的，这往往导致缺乏自省。我当然从未想到我的代码可能有类似的错误。我相信在处理缓冲区和数组长度时我可以正确计算。

More important, there was no feeling after the fact that anything was fundamentally wrong with writing network-facing system tools in C. The episode was viewed as the result of a single mistake, which had been fixed in newer versions of the finger daemon, and the problem was solved. Nobody thought, “Gee, there might be a lot more of these out there.” As mentioned, programmers were self-taught, and this tended to lead to a certain lack of introspection. It certainly never occurred to me that my code might have similar bugs. I was confident that I could get the math right when dealing with buffer and array lengths.

无论你认为“结构化编程”运动试图强制执行什么规则，它显然对程序员的工作产生了影响。即使归结为“不要GOTO不加区别地使用 s”，这个信息还是传达给了我，尽管我自学了使用 -infested GOTOFortran 和 BASIC 编程。但 C 就像那些在模拟美国村庄长大的外国间谍，当他们到达美国时，他们通过了视力测试：它显然是结构化的，因为它支持序列/选择/迭代模型，并且不需要GOTO语句。然而，它里面潜伏着一颗黑暗的心，它不仅被像我这样的人所怀念，还被庆祝为代表摆脱旧束缚的自由。

Whatever rules you feel that the “structured programming” movement was trying to enforce, it clearly had an effect on what programmers did. Even if it boiled down to “don’t use GOTOs indiscriminately,” the message managed to get through to me, despite having taught myself to program in GOTO-infested Fortran and BASIC. But C was like one of those foreign spies raised in a simulated US village who passes the eye test when they arrive in the United States: it clearly was structured, in that it supported the sequence/selection/iteration model and did not require GOTO statements. Yet a dark heart lurked inside it, which was not only missed by people like me but also celebrated as representing freedom from our old fetters.

C 语言不仅导致了 Morris 蠕虫等极具魅力的超级故障。意外索引超出数组末尾的代码可能会导致各种微妙的故障。如果您的代码读取超出数组末尾的值，程序可能会崩溃，但它也可能成功读取用于其他用途的内存，每次运行程序时情况可能会有所不同。如果您的代码写入超出数组末尾的内存，您可能会破坏内存中的另一个数据结构，同样是以一种不可预测的方式；当您尝试调试问题时，您将无法知道哪个代码写入了错误值。您可能遇到每次都会发生的错误，但方式略有不同，这非常难以诊断。在 Windows NT 开发期间的某个时候，一位程序员同事正在调试这样的错误，他的数据结构被未知代码随机破坏。我仍然记得他考虑扫描大量代码寻找问题时脸上的沮丧表情。

The C language didn’t only enable charismatic megafailures such as the Morris worm. Code that accidentally indexed off the end of an array could cause all sorts of subtle failures. If your code read a value past the end of an array, the program might crash, but it also might successfully read memory intended for another use, which might vary each time you ran the program. If your code wrote to memory past the end of an array, you might corrupt another data structure in memory, again in an unpredictable way; when you tried to debug the problem, you would have no way of knowing what code had written the bad value. You might have a bug that happened every time, but in a slightly different way, which is extremely tricky to diagnose. At one point during the development of Windows NT, a fellow programmer was debugging such an error, where his data structure was being randomly corrupted by unknown code. I can still recall the bleak look on his face as he contemplated scanning reams of code looking for the problem.

C 出现时，也有反对者。上面 Wirth 的话来自他在 2008 年撰写的一篇回顾性文章，但他一直反对 C 语言给程序员的束缚。1979 年，Wirth 推出了 Modula-2 语言，这是 Pascal 的后继者，其设计也足够强大和高效，可以编写操作系统（具体来说，Wirth 也编写了一个名为 Lilith 的系统，所以我认为性能声明是准确的），并且具有边界检查数组查找功能。Modula-2 在 C/UNIX 的压倒性竞争中被击败；如果“Pascal 的改进版本”这个标语传到我耳中，无疑不会给我留下深刻印象，而 Wirth，计算机科学史上真正的巨人，将被不公平地视为一个脾气暴躁的人，可能无法编写正确的指针代码。

There were naysayers at the time C appeared. The above quote from Wirth is from a retrospective article he wrote in 2008, but he was always opposed to the amount of rope that C handed to programmers. In 1979, Wirth came out with the language Modula-2, a successor to Pascal, which was also designed to be powerful and performative enough to write an operating system in (specifically, a system called Lilith that Wirth also wrote, so I assume the performance claim was accurate), and that had bounds-checked array lookup. Modula-2 was swept aside in the C/UNIX landslide; the tagline “an improved version of Pascal,” if it ever reached my ears, would undoubtedly have failed to impress, and Wirth, a true titan in the annals of computer science, would have been unfairly dismissed as a grumpy guy who probably couldn’t write correct pointer code.

好吧，你说的没错。缓冲区溢出是可能发生的。但程序员真的那么蠢吗？也许你可以承认人们在计算字节数时会犯算术错误，也许你可以理解信任堆栈上的返回地址这一部分，如果你认为它不可能被篡改的话。但是，看在上帝的份上，你为什么还要把不受信任的用户消息存储在受信任的返回地址附近呢？为什么不把用户的消息放在其他地方，即使你处理不当，也不会被漏洞利用？为什么不用一种跟踪缓冲区长度并防止其溢出的语言来编写整个程序呢？

OK, fine, you are saying. Buffer overflows can happen. Yet are programmers really that stupid? Maybe you can grant them that people make arithmetic mistakes counting bytes, and perhaps you can understand the part about trusting the return address on the stack, if you don’t think there is any way for it to be tampered with. But why, for heaven’s sake, are you even storing the untrusted user’s message anywhere near the trusted return address? Why not put the user’s message somewhere else, where even if you botched the handling of it, it wouldn’t allow you to be taken over by an exploit? And why not write the whole thing in a language that keeps track of buffer lengths and prevents them from overflowing?

最后这个问题问得非常好。你可以用这种方法来做，而且很多新语言都是这样做的，这就是为什么我们看到的 C# 字符串操作代码比 C 中所需的代码要简单得多。但这个问题归结为编程中一个更深层次的问题——一个被称为“错误与异常”的问题。正如人们所说，这里面有一个故事，我将在后面几章中讲到。不过，首先，我将考虑一个更平淡无奇的问题，即程序员如何确定他们的软件是否能正常工作。

This last is an excellent question. You can do it that way, and a lot of newer languages do, which is why the C# string manipulation code that we have seen is so much simpler than what is required in C. But the question boils down to a deeper question in programming—one known as “errors versus exceptions.” And therein, as they say, lies a tale, which I will get to a few chapters from now. First, though, I’ll consider the more prosaic question of how programmers determine if their software is going to work at all.

笔记

Notes

1.  UNIX 的正确大写引发了一些争论。这个名字不是缩写，但经常用大写字母书写。根据 Jargon File 网站，关于它的原始文章（Dennis M. Ritchie 和 Ken Thompson，《UNIX 分时系统》，ACM 通讯17，第 7 期 [1974 年 7 月]：365-375）只使用了大写字母（实际上是小写字母），因为作者可以使用新的排版系统，并且“陶醉于能够制作小写字母”。Ritchie 后来试图将官方拼写改为“Unix”，但没有成功。为了纪念这一点，Jargon File 本身使用了“Unix”。Jargon File 中的“Unix”条目，访问于 2017 年 12 月 29 日，http://catb.org/jargon/html/U/Unix.html。
2.  Jon Bentley，《编程珠玑》（马萨诸塞州雷丁：Addison-Wesley，1986 年），151。
3.  Jon Bentley，《挤压空间》，《编程珠玑》 （马萨诸塞州雷丁：Addison-Wesley，1986 年），第 93 页。
4.Jon  Bentley，《编写高效程序》（新泽西州恩格尔伍德克利夫斯：Prentice-Hall，1982 年），第十二页。
5.  Dennis M. Ritchie，“C 语言的发展”，2017 年 12 月 29 日访问，https://www.bell-labs.com/usr/dmr/www/chist.html。
6. 尽管出于可移植性的原因，它有意不与任何特定的汇编语言绑定；但是 C 编译器可以为任何处理器编写。
7. 某些较旧的计算机（当然是在 C 语言发明的时代）的字节位数不同（例如，Kernighan 和 Ritchie 的原版 C 语言书籍中提到了 Honeywell 计算机，该计算机的字节位数为 9 位），但如今每字节 8 位是标准。Brian W. Kernighan 和 Dennis M. Ritchie，《C 语言程序设计语言》（新泽西州恩格尔伍德克利夫斯：Prentice-Hall，1978 年），第 34 页。
8. 有关范围为何为 -128 到 127 而不是 -127 到 127 的详细信息，请参阅维基百科“二进制补码”，访问于 2017 年 12 月 29 日，https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Two%27s_complement。当然，-128 到 128 不适合 8 位，因为这是 257 个不同的数字，而只有 256 个唯一的 8 位数。
9. 是的，它实际上比 32 位数的平方略大。64 位范围是 0 到 18,446,744,073,709,551,615（或 -9,223,372,036,854,775,808 到 9,223,372,036,854,775,807）。如果您是美国大学篮球的粉丝，您可能以前听说过 9 千万亿这个数字，因为它被表示为准确猜出每年春季举行的美国大学体育协会一级篮球锦标赛分组的概率。这也是最大的有符号 64 位数字，这并非巧合。该锦标赛是 64 支球队的单淘汰赛；要淘汰 63 支球队并留下一个冠军，你需要 63 场比赛，而由于每场比赛都有两种可能的结果，猜对每场比赛的概率是 2 63，也就是 9 千万亿个数字。然而，近年来，锦标赛已经扩大到 68 支球队，所以实际上猜对每场比赛的概率是 2 67，是原来的 16 倍。
10. 计算机（当然包括所有现代计算机以及 20 世纪 70 年代的许多计算机）也支持浮点数，浮点数以我们所认为的科学计数法存储数字：一个数字和小数，后面跟着一个与它们相乘的十的幂。这导致数字的范围大大扩大，但也消除了使用整数的精度；在 IBM PC 早期，有人发现在 BASIC 中使用浮点数时 (1/3) * 3 并不完全等于 1，这引起了一点小骚动。
11.  “整数是处理器的自然位数”这一规则有一个例外：尽管 Apple、Radio Shack 和 Commodore 的早期个人计算机都是 8 位计算机，但它们都支持 16 位整数；将整数限制在 -128 到 127 的范围内太过局限，而且很可能导致程序因溢出而终止，因此没有用处，因此 BASIC 做了额外的工作来处理 16 位整数，范围从 -32,768 到 32,767。这也不是很大的范围——当然，电子表格可以存储比这更大的数字——但它对于业余编程来说已经足够好了。此外，某些版本的 BASIC 默认使用浮点数而不是整数，范围扩大了，但精度不足，如上所述。Bill Crider 编辑，《BASIC 程序转换》（图森：HPBooks，1984 年），第 21-22 页。
12.  IBM，Basic 1.00（佛罗里达州博卡拉顿：IBM，1982），A-4。
13. 如前所述，默认值int没有严格定义的位数。它应该“反映特定机器的‘自然’大小”（Kernighan 和 Ritchie，《C 编程语言》，34）。此外，char类型（在大多数机器上为 8 位数）最初仅定义为“能够容纳本地字符集中的一个字符”（同上）。同时，short和long，大多数机器上的 16 位数和 32 位数（long在该语言的历史中引入得稍晚一些，开发它的原始 PDP-11 机器只有 16 位机器，而支持 32 位的 PDP 后继者 VAX 直到 1977 年才问世）由编译器编写者来解释，但要注意不应short大于long。实际上，、char和short分别long表示 8、16 和 32 位，当 C 语言于 1990 年由 ANSI 标准化时，这些定义便成为官方定义。
14. 如果您担心，您可以编写代码在溢出发生之前检查溢出（您无法直接在 C 中实现“事后”检查，因为它不会从处理器公开“上一次操作是否溢出”信息，因此预检代码必须在执行操作之前做额外的工作，这最终会变得更慢）。实际上，程序员会将变量的大小设置为他们认为需要的大小，然后忽略溢出的可能性。
15.  Nancy G. Leveson 和 Clark S. Turner，“Therac-25 事故调查”，IEEE 计算机26，第 7 期（1993 年 7 月）：34；James Gleick，“漏洞与崩溃”，2017 年 12 月 30 日访问，https://around.com/ariane.html。
16.  Kernighan 和 Ritchie，《C 编程语言》，89。
17.  Ritchie，“C 语言的发展”。
18. 尽管乘以 2 的幂数（比如二、四或八）（这些是数组通常填充的标准 C 数值类型的字节大小）比乘以任意数要快。
19.  IBM，Basic 1.00，A-5。
20. 据推测，IBM PC BASIC 字符串被限制为精确的 255 个字符的原因是因为它在内部使用 8 位无符号数字来存储长度。
21. 操作系统倾向于将内存分配请求四舍五入为 2 的幂的倍数，比如四或十六，因此您可能会很幸运地得到几个额外的字节可以使用，但这取决于程序该次运行中字符串的确切长度。
22. 问题是，如果两个 5 个字母的单词仅在一个字母上有所不同，则认为它们是“等价的”，并且只要一个单词与存储桶中的另一个单词“等价”，就会将其放入存储桶中，那么在这个 5 个字母的单词列表中有多少个不同的存储桶？——当然，在我们提交程序之前，这个单词列表是未知的。
23.  Ted Eisenberg、David Gries、Juris Hartmanis、Don Holcomb、M. Stuart Lynn 和 Thomas Santoro，《康奈尔委员会：论莫里斯和蠕虫》，《ACM 通讯》 32 卷第 6 期（1989 年 6 月）：706-709 页。
24.  Donn Seeley，“蠕虫之旅”，1989 年 2 月，2017 年 12 月 30 日访问，https://collections.lib.utah.edu/details ?id=702918；Bob Page，“互联网蠕虫报告”，1988 年 11 月 7 日，2017 年 12 月 30 日访问，http://www.ee.ryerson.ca: 8080/~elf/hack/iworm.html 。
25.  Joyce Reynolds，《互联网的蠕虫病》，《计算机网络和 ISDN 系统》第 22 卷，第 4 期（1991 年 10 月）：第 347-361 页。标题是书呆子的玩笑；蠕虫病是医学术语，意为“寄生虫感染”。
26.  David Zimmerman，“Finger 用户信息协议”，互联网网络工作组征求意见稿：1288，1991 年 12 月，2017 年 12 月 30 日访问，https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1288。本文提供了对正式互联网协议规范的简单介绍。文末第 4 节还提供了一个实际 finger 命令的示例，该示例使作者在 1991 年左右的同事永垂不朽。当要求 finger 报告系统上的所有用户时，它会显示终端位置、办公室位置、办公室电话号码、工作名称和空闲时间（自上次输入或工作活动以来的分钟数）。当询问特定用户时，它会返回办公室位置、办公室电话号码、家庭电话号码（！）、登录状态（未登录、注销时间等）以及.plan文件.project内容。
27.  Victoria Neufeldt 编，《韦氏新世界美式英语词典》，第 3 版（纽约：Prentice Hall，1991 年），第 347 页。
28. 您可以在堆外分配内存，直到操作系统意识到内存已全部用完（或者更准确地说，它找不到足够大的连续未分配字节来满足您的请求；如果之前在 1 兆字节内存中间分配了 1 字节，则无法一次分配超过半兆字节的内存）。此时，它将返回分配结果 0，这是一个无效指针。还要注意，操作系统会跟踪每个堆分配的大小，因此它可以正确释放它，但 C 代码无法获得此信息。
29. 除了存储参数、返回地址和局部变量之外，堆栈还用于在每个函数开始时保存一些处理器寄存器的值。
30. 这是一种简化；在某些处理器上，一些参数是通过寄存器而不是堆栈传递的，并且编译器可能会选择通过将局部变量存储在寄存器而不是堆栈中进行优化。但是，大型缓冲区始终会存储在堆栈中。
31. 我没有当时运行的 Finger 守护程序的源代码；我依靠当时发布的病毒调查来了解gets()缓冲区溢出的载体细节。不清楚为什么代码会这样写；这意味着 Finger 守护程序会获取数据包中的数据，然后调用另一个程序来处理它，而另一个程序会调用gets()。对于像 Finger 这样简单的东西来说，这似乎有点过度设计了。但这仍然是可能的，特别是如果 Finger 守护程序实际上是更通用的守护程序的子集，该守护程序配置为接收更通用的数据包，然后将它们提供给特定程序进行响应。
32. fgets()还有一个不同之处，就是它可能会将一个额外的字符（“行尾”字符）复制到缓冲区中，因此守护进程可能需要编写一些代码来处理这个问题。这是 和 之间另一个无法解释的区别gets()。请参阅 Eugene Spafford 等人的《互联网蠕虫程序：分析》，2018 年 1 月 1 日访问， http:fgets() //spaf.cerias.purdue.edu/tech-reps/823.pdf 。
33.  Finger 守护进程可以选择性地支持将请求链接在一起，这样您就可以要求一台机器将您的请求转发到第三台机器，长度任意；现在这已经没那么有用了，因为几乎每台机器都可以从其他每台机器直接访问，但从技术上讲，这意味着 64 字节可能太短了。
34.  Trend Micro，“TrendLabs 安全情报博客”（2017 年 6 月 2 日），2018 年 1 月 2 日访问，http://blog.trendmicro.com/trendlabs-security-intelligence/ms17-010-eternalblue/。
35.  JRR Tolkien，《王者归来》（波士顿：霍顿·米夫林，2002 年），第 1074 页。她指的是人类无法预测却又不可避免的死亡，尽管这句话也适用于 C 语言中缓冲区处理代码无法预测却又不可避免的可利用性。
36.  Ralf Burger，《计算机病毒：一种高科技疾病》（密歇根州大急流城：Abacus，1988 年）。
37. 同上，第187–189页。
38. 同上。即使快速扫描一下代码，也能发现有些不对劲。在最初的注释之后，有 22 行代码用于打印树本身，每行都调用名称迷人的SAYAPI，这是 REXX 打印文本的方式，星号树的每一行都可见为参数，然后是一条注释，说“浏览这个文件一点也不好玩”，这似乎是试图让人们不再往下看，然后是另外 60 行，这些代码显然与打印树无关，因为这已经完成了。
39.  Spafford，“互联网蠕虫计划”，第 23 页。
40.  Eisenberg 等，“康奈尔委员会”，709。
41.  Niklaus Wirth，“软件工程简史”，IEEE 计算史年鉴30，第 3 期（2008 年 7 月 - 9 月）：第 34 页。
42. 同上。
43.  Seeley，《蠕虫之旅》，第8页。

5 

纠正错误

5 

Making It Right

如今，“软件危机”这个词已经不常听到了，但在 20 世纪 60 年代，人们对​​此议论纷纷。正如 Matti Tedre 在其 2015 年研究透彻的历史著作《计算科学：塑造一门学科》中所述，

The term “software crisis” is not heard as much today, but there was a lot of talk about it in the 1960s. As Matti Tedre relates in his well-researched 2015 history The Science of Computing: Shaping a Discipline,

在 20 世纪 60 年代，计算的发展曲线即将被打破。计算机系统的复杂性几乎已经达到了当时流行的软件开发方法的极限。危机言论在 20 世纪 60 年代上半叶进入了计算用语。……到 20 世纪 60 年代末，项目经理、程序员和许多学者都对指责和羞辱感到厌倦，认为有必要立即进行改进。

In the course of the 1960s, computing’s development curve was about to break. The complexity of computer systems had all but met the limits of the popular software development methods of the time. The crisis rhetoric entered computing parlance over the first half of the 1960s. … By the end of the 1960s project managers, programmers, and many academics alike had grown so weary of the blame and shame that immediate improvements were deemed necessary.

（Tedre 还评论说，“源于 20 世纪 60 年代、在 20 世纪 70 年代初流行起来的危机话题自此一直存在于计算领域——无论持续数十年的困境是否还应该被称为‘危机’。”）1

(Tedre also comments, “The crisis talk that was rooted in the 1960s and popularized in the early 1970s has remained with computing ever since—whether or not a decades-long quagmire of problems should be called ‘crisis’ anymore.”)1

1968 年，北大西洋公约组织 (NATO) 在德国加米施举办了一次会议，将学术界和业界聚集在一起讨论这些问题。这次会议是软件工程历史上具有开创性意义的时刻（首先，它普及了这一术语），尽管其实际影响尚不清楚。会议报告列出了软件中所有至今仍困扰着我们的问题 — 可靠性、管理、调度、测试等等。2不过，当时许多作者都在描述同样的问题；这些问题对于编写过非平凡软件的人来说并不是秘密。一些人认为这次会议是行业和学术界分裂的关键点，尤其是在第二年在罗马举行的后续会议演变为理论家和实践者之间更明确的分歧之后。3有一种理论认为，整个事情都是 Dijkstra 的邪恶阴谋的一部分，目的是让人们更多地关注他的结构化编程概念。4

In 1968, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) sponsored a conference in Garmisch, Germany, bringing together academia and industry to discuss these problems. This conference was a seminal moment in the history of software engineering (for one thing, it popularized the term), although its net effect is unclear. The conference report laid out all the problems in software that continue to plague us today—reliability, management, scheduling, testing, and so on.2 Then again, many writers were describing the same problems at the same time; the issues weren’t a secret to anybody who had written nontrivial software. Some have described the conference as a critical point in the schism between industry and academia, especially after a follow-up conference in Rome the next year devolved into a more explicit division between theorists and practitioners.3 Then there is a theory that the whole thing was part of a fiendish plot by Dijkstra to get people to pay more attention to his notions of structured programming.4

无论北约会议取得了什么成果，所有这些担忧的根本原因是程序员无法弄清楚如何编写没有错误的软件。迄今为止，软件工程中的问题要么直接与错误有关（可靠性和测试），要么与处理错误的不可预测性有关（管理和调度）。

Whatever the NATO conferences did or did not accomplish, the root cause of all this concern was that programmers couldn’t figure out how to write software without bugs. The problems in software engineering to this day either relate directly to bugs (reliability and testing) or to dealing with the unpredictability of bugs (management and scheduling).

软件错误到底是什么？虽然软件没有按照用户期望的方式运行可能会让人感觉像是一个错误，但从程序员的角度来看，软件没有按照程序员期望的方式运行才是错误。对他们来说，错误是意料之外的事情。有些书专门讨论程序员的期望与普通人的期望，以及谁应该设计软件并设定期望，但这是另一个话题。5当然，许多对软件的更改都是因为用户希望软件以不同于设计的方式运行，但我认为那些是“增强”而不是“错误”。Donald Knuth 在对他对大型软件包所做的更改进行分类时，给出了最清晰的区分：“修复错误时我感到内疚，但进行增强时我感到很有道德。”6

Just what are software bugs? Although it might feel like a bug when software doesn’t perform the way the user expects, from a programmer’s perspective a bug is when the software doesn’t perform the way the programmer expected. To them, bugs are surprises.
