The FIXED_STACK example is representative of a common kind of multiple inheritance, which may be called the marriage of convenience. It is like a marriage uniting a rich family and a noble family. The bride, a deferred class, belongs to the aristocratic family of stacks; it brings prestigious functionality but no practical wealth—no implementation. The groom comes from a well-to-do bourgeois family, arrays, but needs some luster to match the efficiency of its implementation. The two make a perfect match.3

在我的加密电子邮件示例中，您将定义加密器的接口，它看起来类似于我AESEncrypter上面的类的定义（接口名称传统上以I开头）：

In my encrypting e-mail example, you would define an interface for encrypters, which looks similar to my definition of the AESEncrypter class above (interface names traditionally start with an I):

interface IEncrypter {
   Encrypt();
}
interface IEncrypter {
   Encrypt();
}

现在，任何加密器的实现都可以从接口继承IEncrypter并实现方法，就像通常那样，只不过方法现在从接口继承了它们的签名，而不是全权在每个单独的加密器中定义它们（这是一件好事：强制执行标准方法签名是从接口继承的要点）。您只需要在特定加密器的声明中进行一行更改即可添加从 的继承IEncrypter：

Any implementation of an encrypter can now inherit from the IEncrypter interface and implement the methods, as it normally would, except the methods now inherit their signature from the interface rather than having carte blanche to define them in each individual encrypter (this is a good thing: the enforcement of a standard method signature is the point of inheriting from the interface). You only need a one-line change in the declaration of a specific encrypter to add the inheritance from IEncrypter:

class AESEncrypter: IEncrypter {
   public Encrypt() { }
}
class AESEncrypter: IEncrypter {
   public Encrypt() { }
}

然后，需要加密的电子邮件程序可以使用IEncrypter接口调用它将要使用的任何加密器，而无需编写额外的代码来决定它真正调用哪个加密器：

and then your e-mail program that needs encryption can use the IEncrypter interface to call through into whatever encrypter it is going to use, without your having to write extra code to decide which encrypter it is really calling into:

class Emailer {
   private IEncrypter e;   // can call e.Encrypt()
}
class Emailer {
   private IEncrypter e;   // can call e.Encrypt()
}

这就留下了一个问题，即如何e初始化。在最坏的情况下，您可以在的构造函数Emailer（使用下面的类名类似方法名语法定义）中使用代码，根据加密类型设置它。这仍然需要有一个已知的加密类型和加密器列表，但至少添加对更多加密器的支持只涉及更改这一个地方，而不是您想要调用的每个地方IEncrypter：

This leaves open the question of how e is initialized. In the worst case, you can have code in the constructor of Emailer (which is defined using the class-name-like-a-method-name syntax below) that sets it based on an encryption type. This still requires having a known list of encryption types and encrypters, but at least adding support for more encrypters only involves changing this one place, as opposed to every place you want to call into an IEncrypter:

Emailer() {
   if (encryptionType == AES) {
      e = new AESEncrypter();
   } else if (encryptionType == RC4) {
      e = new RC4Encrypter();
   } else if (encryptionType == TripleDES) {
      e = new TripleDESEncrypter();   }
}
Emailer() {
   if (encryptionType == AES) {
      e = new AESEncrypter();
   } else if (encryptionType == RC4) {
      e = new RC4Encrypter();
   } else if (encryptionType == TripleDES) {
      e = new TripleDESEncrypter();   }
}

但更简洁的方法是让的构造函数Emailer将IEncrypter作为参数，并将其保存e以供以后使用：

But a much cleaner way is to have the constructor of Emailer take the IEncrypter as a parameter, saving it in e for later use:

Emailer(IEncrypter enc) {
   e = enc;
}
Emailer(IEncrypter enc) {
   e = enc;
}

这可能只是将问题推高了一个层次，因为这意味着创建对象的人Emailer现在必须知道如何创建，IEncrypter以便将其传递给Emailer构造函数。对此有几种解决方案：您可以编写一个Emailer构造函数，如上面的示例，该构造函数e根据传递给构造函数的加密类型进行设置，但如果未指定，则默认为特定的加密器。无论如何，请保留这个想法（我稍后会回到它），而是专注于Emailer这种设计的内部有多干净。

This arguably just pushes the problem up a level since it means the person creating the Emailer object now has to know how to create the IEncrypter so it can pass it to the Emailer constructor. There are a few solutions to that: you could write an Emailer constructor like the sample above that sets e based on an encryption type passed to the constructor but defaults to a specific encrypter if none is specified. In any case, hold that thought (I will come back to it later), and instead focus on how clean the internals of Emailer are with this design.

阐明接口有用性的概念是设计模式。设计模式最早是在 1994 年的一本同名书中提出的，该书的副标题是《可重用面向对象软件的元素》。4本书改编自克里斯托弗·亚历山大 (Christopher Alexander)、萨拉·石川 (Sara Ishikawa) 和默里·西尔弗斯坦 (Murray Silverstein)于 1977 年出版的《模式语言》一书。5这本书与软件无关；它的副标题是《城镇·建筑·施工》，内容是关于建筑的。亚历山大等人的书的主题是，建筑设计问题在几个世纪以来一直被反复解决，收集、描述和命名这些问题是有意义的，这样建筑师就可以使用和讨论它们，而不需要冗长的重新发明或解释。建筑问题（共有 253 个）从大到小不等。使用书中的大写/编号约定以及书中从大到小的一般顺序，它们包括农业谷（4）、环路（17）、许多商店的市场（46）、公交车站（92）、室内阳光（128）、街窗（164）、地板天花板拱顶（219）和半英寸装饰（240）。6

The concept that clarified the usefulness of interfaces was design patterns. Design patterns were first introduced in 1994 in a book of the same name, subtitled Elements of Reusable Object-Oriented Software.4 The book was based on the 1977 book A Pattern Language by Christopher Alexander, Sara Ishikawa, and Murray Silverstein.5 That book has nothing to do with software; it is subtitled Towns · Building · Construction and is about architecture. The theme of Alexander and company’s book is that there are design problems in architecture that have been solved repeatedly throughout the centuries, and it makes sense to collect, describe, and name them, so that architects can use and discuss them without lengthy reinvention or explanation. The architectural problems (there are 253 of them) range from large to small scale. Using the capitalization/numbering convention in the book as well as the book’s general ordering from largest to smallest, they include AGRICULTURAL VALLEYS (4), RING ROADS (17), MARKET OF MANY SHOPS (46), BUS STOP (92), INDOOR SUNLIGHT (128), STREET WINDOWS (164), FLOOR-CEILING VAULTS (219), and HALF-INCH TRIM (240).6

《软件设计模式》一书的四位作者（后来被称为“四人帮”）将同样的理念应用于常见的软件问题。与亚历山大和他的合著者一样，他们给每个解决方案命名并详细描述。例如，“策略”模式解决了我们上面讨论的问题：程序想要使用模块执行加密等操作（策略模式通常使用加密模块来演示），以一种干净的方式，使更改加密模块或添加更多加密模块成为可能，而对代码的更改却很少。正如您所料，策略模式中的解决方案是通过接口访问加密模块，而不是继承或包含具体的加密器类。

The four authors of the software Design Patterns book (who became known as the Gang of Four) applied the same idea to common software problems. Like Alexander and his coauthors, they give each solution a name and describe it in detail. For example, the “Strategy” pattern addresses the problem we talked about above: a program wants to use a module to perform an operation such as encryption (the Strategy pattern is often demonstrated using an encryption module) in a clean way that makes it possible to change the encryption module or add more encryption modules with minimal changes to the code. The solution in the Strategy pattern is, as you might expect, to access the encryption module through an interface rather than inherit from or contain a concrete encrypter class.

《四人帮》这本书有点晦涩难懂，有些模式的见解不如其他模式。例如，“单例”模式由以下代码组成，该代码确保任何调用它的人都会收到相同的 实例SingletonClass，如果该实例尚不存在，代码将创建该实例：

The Gang of Four book is a bit dense, and some of the patterns are less insightful than others. For instance, the “Singleton” pattern consists of this code, which ensures that anybody who calls it will receive back the same instance of SingletonClass, which the code will create if it doesn’t exist yet:

if (instance == null) {
   instance = new SingletonClass();
}
return instance;
if (instance == null) {
   instance = new SingletonClass();
}
return instance;

这没有什么错，但它更明显而不是革命性的；它更接近半英寸修剪（240）的水平。同时，策略模式可以帮助您设计出更干净、更可扩展的加密器插入设计，但它无法帮助您解决更常见的问题，即编写代码来调用加密器的人不完全理解该方法的Encrypt()工作原理，并犯下导致崩溃的错误，或者使数据未加密。

There is nothing wrong with this, but it’s more obvious than revolutionary; it’s closer to the level of HALF-INCH TRIM (240). Meanwhile, the Strategy pattern can help you with a cleaner, more extensible design for plugging in encrypters, but it won’t help you with the more common type of problem, which is that the person writing code to call an encrypter doesn’t understand exactly how the Encrypt() method works and makes a mistake that cause a crash, or leaves the data unencrypted.

不过，开始创建一种通用语言还是很有用的。“我将使用 Singleton 模式”比“我将有一个方法来检查实例是否存在，如果不存在就分配它”更简短、更清晰。Singleton 是最简单的模式，尽管不是那么简单：该模式涉及最多两个或三个类的排列。然而，在他的文章“设计模式的证据”中，Walter Tichy 指出，程序员和其他人一样，在短期记忆中能记住的东西数量有限；使用模式名称允许他们将一组类压缩为一个模式，从而为其他想法留出更多空间。7事实上，Tichy 的论文中提到的最明显的好处与代码细节的文档和交流有关，而不是更好的设计。

Still, it is useful to start creating a common language. “I will use the Singleton pattern” is shorter and clearer than “I will have a method that checks if the instance exists and allocates it if it doesn’t.” Singleton is the simplest pattern, although not by much: the patterns involve an arrangement of at most two or three classes. In his essay “The Evidence for Design Patterns,” though, Walter Tichy makes the point that programmers, like anybody else, have a limited number of things they can keep in their short-term memory; using the names of patterns allows them to collapse a set of classes down to a single pattern, which leaves more room for other ideas.7 And indeed the clearest benefits ascribed in Tichy’s paper are related to documentation and communication of code details, not better design.

四人帮提出了所有模式中都存在的良好面向对象设计的两个原则：“对象组合优于类继承”和“针对接口编程，而不是实现”。8第一个意思是“不要像我们之前的例子那样，Emailer直接从 继承AESEncrypter；而是将加密器的一个实例作为类数据成员之一。”第二个意思是，“你包含的那个加密器？让它成为一个像 这样的接口IEncrypter，而不是像 这样的具体类AESEncrypter。”这给了你最大的灵活性来更改你正在使用的加密器的内部细节，或者更改你的Emailer以使用不同的加密器。

The Gang of Four stated two principles of good object-oriented design that were present in all the patterns: “favor object composition over class inheritance” and “program to an interface, not an implementation.”8 The first one means “don’t do what we had in our early example, where Emailer inherited directly from AESEncrypter; instead contain an instance of the encrypter as one of your class data members.” And the second one says, “That encrypter you are containing? Make it an interface like IEncrypter, not a concrete class like AESEncrypter.” This gives you the maximum flexibility to change the internal details of the encrypter you are using or change your Emailer to use a different encrypter.

设计模式很有用，但将其作为解决所有设计问题的方案是不明智的。四人帮成员之一埃里希·伽马在讨论“模式越多系统就越好”这一误解时，后来写道：“模式让系统变得复杂变得容易。它们通过引入间接层来实现灵活性和可变性，这会使设计复杂化。最好从简单开始，然后根据需要改进设计。”9设计模式的核心思想很好，但标准化程度却只限于木工中使用的螺母和螺栓的尺寸标准化程度；这是一个很大的好处，尽管没有人会声称它完全解决了建造不会倒塌的建筑物的问题。策略模式很优雅，但真正的设计问题——影响您的软件是否崩溃、运行速度快或被俄罗斯青少年接管的问题——都与它相去甚远。不管怎样，这些模式都是以事实的形式呈现的，没有任何研究来支持它们的好处。尽管如此，时间已经证明，设计模式是它们所解决的问题的干净解决方案，任何花时间分离不适当混合的“has-a”基类和派生类的人都可以证明这一点。

Design patterns are useful, but their anointing as the solution to all design problems has been imprudent. Erich Gamma, one of the Gang of Four, when discussing the misconception that more patterns always make a system better, later wrote, “Patterns make it easy to make a system more complex. They achieve flexibility and variability by introducing levels of indirection, which can complicate a design. It’s better to start simple and evolve a design as needed.”9 There is a good idea at the core of design patterns, but the standardization is on the level of standardizing the sizes of nuts and bolts used in carpentry; it’s a great benefit, although nobody would claim that it fully solves the problem of building a building that won’t fall down. The Strategy pattern is elegant, but the real design questions—the ones that affect whether your software crashes, runs fast, or is taken over by Russian teenagers—are all far removed from it. For what it’s worth, the patterns are presented as fact, without any studies to back up their benefits. Nonetheless, time has shown that the design patterns are clean solutions to the problems they address, as anybody who has spent time separating an improperly commingled “has-a” base and derived class can attest.

此外，设计模式有一个我非常喜欢的方面：它们是通过工业界和学术界的富有成效的合作而开发的。四人帮由一名 IBM 研究员、一名瑞士程序员、一名顾问和一名伊利诺伊大学教授组成。设计模式起源于四人帮之一（瑞士成员 Gamma）的博士论文，这个想法在 20 世纪 90 年代初的各种 OOPSLA 会议上得到了孵化。这正是工业界和学术界应该如何互动。不幸的是，这是过去三十年中唯一的杰出典范。设计模式之所以能够作为工业界/学术界的合作而发展，正是因为它们并不那么复杂；它们的范围处于教授仍然可以参与和理解代码的水平。

Plus, design patterns have an aspect that I really like: they were developed through a productive collaboration between industry and academia. The Gang of Four consisted of an IBM researcher, a Swiss programmer, a consultant, and a professor at the University of Illinois. Design patterns originated as the PhD thesis of one of the Gang of Four (the Swiss member, Gamma), and the idea was incubated at various OOPSLA conferences in the early 1990s. This is exactly how industry and academia should interact. Unfortunately, it’s the only shining example from the past three decades. And the reason that design patterns could evolve as an industry/academia collaboration is precisely because they are not that complicated; their scope is at the level at which a professor can still engage and understand code.

关于模式还有另外一点需要注意。回想一下我们在第 3 章中的讨论，关于程序员在决定为未来的变化做多少计划与解决眼前的问题之间所经历的精神痛苦：模式的许多好处与未来的可扩展性有关。如果您的电子邮件程序使用单个加密器，那么整个继承、包含与接口的争论就毫无意义了；无论您是否遵循策略模式，您编写的代码在复杂性或大小上都不会有太大差异（如果确实有差异，策略版本会稍微复杂一些）。重要的是当您将来想要修改它时，您需要调整或替换多少代码才能使其变得简单。您需要“第二件事”——比如第二种加密类型——才能使模式发挥作用。

There’s another thing to note about patterns. Recall our discussion in chapter 3, concerning the mental anguish of a programmer deciding how much to plan for future changes versus solving the problem in front of them: a lot of the benefits of patterns relate to future extensibility. If your e-mail program uses a single encrypter, then the whole inheritance versus containment versus interface argument is somewhat pointless; the code you write won’t differ much in complexity or size whether you follow the Strategy pattern or not (and if it does differ, it’s the Strategy version that will be slightly more complex). It’s when you want to modify it in the future that it matters, in terms of how much code you have to tweak or replace to make it easy. You need that “second thing”—a second type of encryption, say—for the pattern to pay off.

幸运的是，在模式出现的同时，编程界也出现了另一个好主意，那就是保证您在所有代码中都需要第二个东西。这就是单元测试的想法。

Luckily, at around the same time that patterns were emerging, another good idea was percolating in the world of programming, guaranteeing that you would need that second thing in all your code. This was the idea of the unit test.

如今使用的单元测试概念的起源很模糊，因为这个术语已经流传了一段时间，问题在于你谈论的单元有多大。它的现代含义肯定出现在 Kent Beck 于 1989 年撰写的一篇题为“简单的 Smalltalk 测试：使用模式”的论文中。它着眼于测试对对象上单个方法的调用（因为这是 Smalltalk，所以它实际上是测试对对象的单个消息），这比当时许多所谓的单元测试更加本地化。10自动化测试的想法已经存在了一段时间，即编写一个单独的程序，其唯一目的是测试您发给客户的程序。通常，这些自动化测试将针对软件的用户界面进行操作，模拟击键和鼠标点击，并验证程序是否按预期响应。它们在功能上与人工测试员相同，但具有易于重复的优点。问题与人工测试时出现的问题相同：软件的用户界面堆叠在许多方法调用层之上，因此如果软件在顶层的行为不正确，则很难在所有这些层之间隔离故障。

The concept of unit tests, as used today, has a murky origin, since the term has been in circulation for a while, and the question is how big a unit you are talking about. The modern meaning was certainly present in a paper written by Kent Beck in 1989 titled “Simple Smalltalk Testing: With Patterns.” It looks at testing a call to a single method on an object (since this is Smalltalk, it’s actually about testing a single message to an object), which is much more localized than a lot of quote-unquote unit tests were at the time.10 The idea of automated testing, writing a separate program whose only purpose was to test the program you shipped to customers, had been around for a while. Typically these automated tests would operate against the user interface of the software, simulating keystrokes and mouse clicks, and verifying that the program responded as expected. They were functionally the same as a human tester, but with the benefit of easy repeatability. The problem is the same one that occurs when humans do the testing: the user interface of the software is stacked on top of many layers of method calls, so if the software behaves incorrectly at the top level, it is hard to isolate the fault among all those layers.

假设您的程序有一种对数字数组进行排序的方法，该方法不能直接供用户访问，而是深埋在中间代码中以供使用。在传统的基于用户界面的测试中，直接测试此代码可能很困难。尽管如此，您仍然希望确信排序例程能够正常工作。单元测试是直接调用排序方法的代码（不会发送给客户） ，向其传递一个未排序的数组，然后在最后检查该数组是否已排序。单元测试不会随机生成未排序的数组；它传入一个已知数组，该数组的排序版本也是已知的，排序完成后，它会将结果数组与已知的排序版本进行比较。

Let’s say your program has a method to sort an array of numbers, not directly accessible to the user but instead buried deep for use by intermediate code. In traditional user-interface-based testing, it may be hard to directly test this code. Still, you want to be confident that your sort routine works correctly. A unit test is code (test code that does not ship to customers) that directly calls the sort method, passing it an unsorted array, and then checks at the end that the array was sorted. The unit test doesn’t randomly generate an unsorted array; it passes in a known array, for which the sorted version is also known, and after the sort is done, it compares the resulting array against the known sorted version.

排序例程中的错误可能只在某些输入时才会显现出来。也许只有当数组中的第一个元素需要移动到数组中的其他位置时，例程才会无法正确排序。值得庆幸的是，没有什么可以阻止您为同一方法编写多个单元测试；您可以传入已排序的数组、按相反顺序排列的数组、没有元素处于正确位置的数组、所有元素都相等的数组，或者您认为可能找出错误的任何其他排列。目标是让大量测试快速运行：“运行时间为 1/10 秒的单元测试是慢速单元测试”，正如单元测试倡导者 Michael Feathers 所说。11

Bugs in sort routines may manifest themselves only with certain inputs. Perhaps the routine fails to sort properly only if the first element in the array needs to move to a different location in the array. Thankfully, there is nothing stopping you from writing multiple unit tests for the same method; you can pass in an already-sorted array, an array that is in reverse order, an array where no element is in the correct place, an array with all the elements equal, or whatever other arrangements you think might ferret out a bug. The goal is to have lots of tests that run quickly: “A unit test that takes 1/10th of second to run is a slow unit test,” as the unit testing advocate Michael Feathers put it.11

历史上一些著名的错误显然需要单元测试。请考虑第 5 章中讨论的在闰年最后一天影响 Microsoft Zune 媒体播放器的错误。这正是单元测试可以检查的事情。在测试整个 Zune 时，测试人员可能不会想到将时钟设置为闰年的最后一天，因为他们没有意识到那天有任何不寻常的代码运行。但编写该ConvertDays()函数的开发人员知道代码会特殊处理闰年，因此可能会想要编写一个单元测试来检查闰年的最后一天是否得到正确处理。

Some well-known bugs throughout history were clearly crying out for unit tests. Consider the bug that hit Microsoft’s Zune media players on the last day of a leap year, as discussed in chapter 5. This is precisely the sort of thing a unit test could check. When testing the entire Zune, it might not occur to a tester to set the clock to the last day of a leap year, because they didn’t realize that any unusual code ran on that day. But the developer who wrote the ConvertDays() function, aware that the code special cases the leap year, would presumably want to write a unit test that checked that the last day of a leap year was handled correctly.

这种方法很容易测试，因为它是独立的，只依赖于作为参数传递的值；代码都是基于此的计算。如果您要进行单元测试的方法本身依赖于另一种方法，并经过多层依赖，该怎么办？更糟糕的是，如果其中一些方法具有您不希望在测试期间发生的副作用，该怎么办？您可能正在编写单元测试来验证格式化数据然后将其发送到打印机的代码。由于多种原因，您无法让单元测试打印任何内容：它需要一段时间并且浪费纸张，还需要您连接并打开打印机，即使这样，您的单元测试如何验证打印是否在 1/10 秒内正确发生？

Such a method is easy to test because it is self-contained, depending only on a value passed as a parameter; the code is all calculations based on that. What if the method you want to unit test is itself dependent on another method and so on through many layers? And worse, what if some of those methods have side effects that you don’t want to occur during testing? You may be writing a unit test to verify code that formats data and then sends it to the printer. You can’t have your unit test print anything, for a variety of reasons: it takes a while and wastes paper, and also requires you to have a printer connected and turned on, and even then how would your unit test verify that the proper printing happened within 1/10th of a second?

最简洁的方法是编写一个支持与真实打印机相同方法的伪打印机对象；你以某种方式告诉正在测试的代码（即使用该打印机的代码），它应该使用伪打印机。如果不应用设计模式，这可能会产生一堆围绕对打印机方法的每次调用的代码，如下所示：

The cleanest approach is to write a fake printer object that supports the same methods as the real printer; you somehow tell the code that you are testing, which is using the printer, that it should use the fake printer instead. Without applying a design pattern, this might wind up with a bunch of code surrounding each call to the printer methods, like this:

if (runningTests) {
   fakePrinter.Print();
} else {
   realPrinter.Print();
}
if (runningTests) {
   fakePrinter.Print();
} else {
   realPrinter.Print();
}

在每个调用打印机方法的地方都需要有这个方法。如果这让你想起了上面用于选择要调用的加密器的预模式代码，那绝非巧合。策略模式，即经典的设计模式，在这里很适用，即使策略这个名字在这里有点用词不当；可以把它看作是一种模式，表示“我想把一些可能会改变的东西封装在一个接口后面。”你为打印机定义一个接口，真正的打印机类从该接口继承并因此实现它，同时还要编写一个从同一接口继承的伪打印机类。伪打印机收集它被告知要“打印”的任何内容，并包含额外的方法，让你验证发送的内容是否正确（这些方法只存在于伪打印机类中，而不是真正的打印机类中）。

which would need to exist every place you called any of the printer methods. If this reminds you of the prepatterns code above for selecting an encrypter to call, that’s no coincidence. The Strategy pattern, the canonical design pattern, works well here, even if the name Strategy is a bit of a misnomer here; think of it as a pattern for “I want to take something that might change and encapsulate it behind an interface.” You define an interface for the printer, which the real printer class inherits from and therefore implements, and also write a fake printer class that inherits from the same interface. The fake printer collects whatever it is told to “print,” and includes extra methods that let you validate that what was sent looks correct (these methods exist only on the fake printer class, not the real one).

在最初的《设计模式》一书出版大约十年后，Alan Shalloway 和 James Trott 写了一本名为《设计模式解析》的书，在书中他们添加了原始设计模式中隐含的一条新规则：“将使用对象的代码与创建对象的代码分开。”12这与你可能仍然困惑的问题有关。在上面的例子中，

About ten years after the original Design Patterns book came out, Alan Shalloway and James Trott wrote a book called Design Patterns Explained in which they added a new rule that was implicit in the original design patterns: “Separate the code that uses an object from the code that creates an object.”12 This relates to the question that might still have you scratching your head. In the example above,

Emailer(IEncrypter enc) {
   e = enc;
}
Emailer(IEncrypter enc) {
   e = enc;
}

我们有一个构造函数，Emailer将IEncrypter接口作为参数，并以一种很好的抽象方式保存以供以后使用，但它从何而来IEncrypter？答案是提供一个单独的类，称为工厂，它知道如何创建具体的加密器类。然后，任何需要构造的代码都Emailer可以调用加密器工厂来获取加密器对象并将其传递给构造Emailer函数。这使得创建真实的加密器变得容易，同时保留了在针对运行单元测试时使用假的加密器Emailer构造加密器的能力。EmailerIEncrypterEmailer

we have the constructor of Emailer taking an IEncrypter interface as a parameter and saving it to use later in a nicely abstracted way, but where does that IEncrypter come from? The answer is to provide a separate class, known as a factory, which knows how to create a concrete encrypter class. Then any code that needs to construct an Emailer can call the encrypter factory to get the encrypter object and pass that to the Emailer constructor. This makes the creation of the real Emailer easy, while preserving the ability to construct an Emailer with a fake IEncrypter when running unit tests against Emailer.

您可以在我的打印机示例中执行类似操作，这样您就可以设置单元测试以使用假打印机，而无需对要测试的代码进行任何更改。单元测试是唯一知道传入代码的打印机接口实际上是假打印机的代码，也是唯一调用假打印机对象支持的额外验证方法的代码。

You can do a similar thing in my printer example, allowing you to set up your unit test to use the fake printer with zero changes in the code you want to test. The unit test is the only code that is aware that the printer interface passed in to your code is in fact the fake printer, and is the only one that calls the extra verification methods that the fake printer object supports.

在这个模型中，单元测试所需的虚假对象（通常称为mock）成为你的代码需要调用的“第二件事”，所以即使你的真实代码只使用一个打印机类，单元测试也会要求它使用第二个打印机类，因此设计模式规定的惯例并不是过度的，而是一种简化。

In this model, the fake objects (generally known as mocks) that are required for unit testing become the “second thing” that your code needs to call, so even if your real code is only going to ever use one printer class, unit testing will require it to use a second printer class, and therefore the convention that the design pattern dictates is not overkill but rather a simplification.

要清楚的是，单元测试并不完美。仅仅因为您为某个方法编写了单元测试并不意味着它在所有情况下都能正常工作；您可以为某个排序编写一个单元测试，将一个已排序的数组交给它，无论算法是否有问题，该单元测试都可能会通过。用于评估单元测试完整性的指标之一是代码覆盖率，即执行所有单元测试后产品代码的运行百分比。理想情况下，覆盖率应达到 100%，但即使这样也不能保证代码正确；Zune 错误最终是由于代码完全缺失（语句ELSE的一个分支IF）造成的，因此，即使一组代码覆盖率为 100% 的单元测试仍可能遗漏该错误。

To be clear, unit tests are not perfect. Just because you write a unit test for a method doesn’t mean it will work in all cases; you could write a unit test for a sort that handed it an already-sorted array, and the unit test would likely pass whether the algorithm was broken or not. One metric used to evaluate how complete your unit tests are is known as code coverage, which is the percent of your product code that is run if you execute all your unit tests. Ideally you would hit 100 percent, but even that won’t guarantee correct code; the Zune bug was ultimately due to code that was completely missing (an ELSE branch of an IF statement), so a set of unit tests with 100 percent code coverage might still have missed the bug.

虽然单元测试不能保证您的代码没有缺陷，但它是防止代码恶化的好方法。正如我们所见，软件经常会超出其原始用途进行​​扩展，作为这种增长的一部分，必须重新编写代码以适应变化。有些更改可以几乎没有风险地插入，特别是如果它是设计模式允许的那种更改 - 例如添加一种新型加密器。但通常更改更复杂，意外破坏某些东西的风险很高。拥有一套持续 100% 通过的良好单元测试是快速发现这一问题的好方法。如果您还记得我在 Dendrite 工作时无意中引入的医生地址错误，这正是单元测试在进行更改时可能发现的问题，但由于损坏的功能不是当时添加的功能，因此开发人员的正常抽查没有发现它。

While they don’t guarantee that your code has no defects, unit tests are a good way to guard against it getting worse. As we have seen, software is frequently expanded beyond its original purpose, and as part of this growth, code has to be reworked to accommodate the change. Some changes can be inserted with little risk, especially if it is the sort of change that design patterns allow—adding a new type of encrypter, for instance. But often the changes are more complicated, and the risk of accidentally breaking something is high. Having a good set of unit tests that continue to pass 100 percent is a great way to catch this quickly. If you recall the bug with doctors’ addresses that was inadvertently introduced back when I worked at Dendrite, this is exactly the sort of thing that a unit test would likely have caught at the time the change was made, but because the feature that broke was not the one being added at that time, normal spot-checking by the developer didn’t catch it.

此外，单元测试可以防止软件过时。软件开发中一个不幸的事实是，即使您没有更改代码，您的程序也可能开始出现故障；另一家公司的代码库的新版本、您使用的编译器的更新或运行它的操作系统的补丁——所有这些都可能以不可预测的方式破坏您的代码，而这并不是您的错。这往往会阻止软件向前发展，将其锁定在支撑它的技术的旧版本上，要求用户继续使用旧技术。你们中有多少人有一个牙医使用十年以上的 Windows 版本？拥有一套强大的单元测试可以让软件迁移到较新的系统，而不用担心出现意想不到的后果。

Furthermore, unit tests can guard against your software getting stale. It is an unfortunate fact of software development that your program can start to fail without your having changed your code at all; a new version of another company’s code library, an update to the compiler you use, or a patch to the operating system that it runs on—all these could break your code in an unpredictable way, through no fault of your own. This tends to prevent software from being moved forward, keeping it locked to older versions of whatever technology underpins it, requiring users to keep that older technology running. How many of you have a dentist who runs a version of Windows that is more than ten years old? Having a strong set of unit tests allows software to be moved to newer systems with much less fear of unintended consequences.

单元测试是个好主意，可以说，任何不编写单元测试的人都没有尽到程序员的职责。当然，如果你想让软件不那么脆弱，单元测试是值得的，如果我们在考虑如何将软件变成一门真正的工程学科，不编写单元测试就好比在建造一座桥时没有先计算它是否能保持屹立。要求进行单元测试是一种很好的方式，可以向开发人员强调他们要对自己代码的质量负责，并摆脱过去盛行的“把问题扔给测试人员”的态度。

Unit tests are a great idea, and arguably anybody who is not writing them is not doing their job as a programmer. Certainly if you want to make software less fragile, unit tests are worthwhile, and if we are thinking about how to turn software into a real engineering discipline, not writing unit tests would be akin to building a bridge without first calculating if you expect it to stay standing. Requiring unit tests is a great way to emphasize to developers that they are responsible for the quality of their own code and get away from the “throw it over the wall to the testers” attitude that used to prevail.

单元测试的最大障碍是许多软件在编写时都没有考虑到单元测试。如果您已经编写了一个模拟打印机类，并且使用打印机的代码通过接口访问它，并且已正确分离创建和使用，那么再编写一个单元测试就相当简单了。如果没有这些支持，您需要编写整个模拟打印机类，并进入并将所有硬编码的打印机调用替换为对接口的调用，并找出一种将接口传递给使用它的代码的方法，那么编写第一个单元测试将成为一座难以逾越的高山，并且您在重新编写代码以支持单元测试时可能会意外破坏代码（这真是一个具有讽刺意味的结果）。

The biggest hurdle to unit tests is that a lot of software was written without any consideration for them. If you already have a mock printer class written, and your code that uses the printer accesses it through an interface, and has properly separated creation and use, then writing one more unit test is fairly simple. If none of that support is there, and you need to write the entire mock printer class as well as go in and replace all the hard-coded printer calls with calls to an interface, and figure out a way to pass the interface through to the code that uses it, then writing that first unit test becomes a high mountain to climb, and you risk accidentally breaking your code while reworking it to support unit tests (a truly ironic result).

2004 年，Feathers 出版了《有效使用遗留代码》一书，这个书名道出了程序员最沮丧的事情之一：被赋予了修复大量旧软件中 bug 的任务，但你对细节了解不够（如果你知道的话）以至于无法确保修复这个 bug 不会破坏其他东西（另一本关于同一主题的书名为《软件驱魔》）。13尽管“遗留代码”这个短语通常被用来表示“我不理解的旧代码”，但 Feathers 的书直接将其定义为“没有测试的代码”，这本书可以总结为“在接触任何东西之前，你需要进行单元测试”。14例如，您可能会修复 Zune 时钟驱动程序代码中的“闰年最后一天”错误，当然，您会验证它在特定情况下是否正常工作，但您的更改可能会无意中引入另一个错误 - 也许它在闰年的第一天、正常年份的最后一天或其他谁知道的情况下都无法工作 - 如果没有现有的单元测试，那么成为第一个决定编写单元测试的人意味着要做大量工作 - 可能比修复错误并祈祷好运的工作量多数百倍。考虑到程序员作为一个物种，在 C 代码中引入了整类安全错误只是为了避免一点额外的输入，因此可以理解为什么人们不愿意成为第一个发现单元测试漏洞的人。

In 2004, Feathers published the book Working Effectively with Legacy Code—a title that speaks to one of the great frustrations of being a programmer: being handed the task of fixing a bug in a large piece of old software, where you don’t know enough about the details (if you know anything at all) to ensure that fixing the bug won’t break something else (another book on the same subject has the title Software Exorcism).13 Although the phrase legacy code is often used to mean “old code that I don’t understand,” Feathers’s book straight up defines it as “code without tests,” and the book could be summed up as “before you touch anything, you need to have unit tests in place.”14 For example, you might fix the “last day of the leap year” bug in the Zune clock driver code, and of course you would verify that it worked correctly in that specific situation, but your change might inadvertently introduce a different bug—maybe it won’t work on the first day of a leap year, last day of a regular year, or who knows—and if there are no existing unit tests, being the first person to decide to write a unit test means signing up to do a lot of work—potentially hundreds of times as much work as just fixing the bug and crossing your fingers. Given that programmers, as a species, introduced entire classes of security errors in C code just to avoid a little extra typing, it’s understandable why people are unwilling to be the first person into the unit test breach.

这里还有其他因素。尽管单元测试的总体概念已经存在了一段时间，但单元测试是程序员必须交付的核心部分这一观念在过去十年左右才逐渐流行起来。没有接受过这种观念的经理会本能地得出估计值（编写一段软件需要多长时间），而这些估计值与编写高质量代码的现实完全不符。将时间平均分配给编写代码和编写单元测试是一个合理的指导方针，但对于任何老派或不那么老派的经理来说，这种计算听起来都是错误的。

There is something else at play here. Although the general idea of unit tests has been around for a while, the notion that they are a core part of what a programmer has to deliver has only gained strength in the last decade or so. A manager who didn’t come of age with this idea will instinctively come up with estimates (of how long a piece of software will take to write) that are completely out of kilter with the reality of writing quality code. Splitting your time evenly between writing code and writing unit tests is a reasonable guideline, but this math will sound wrong to any old- or not-quite-so-old-school managers.

如果结构化编程的推动最终归结为“不要使用GOTOs”，那仍然是一个值得的结果。如果设计模式的主要贡献是使你的代码适合单元测试，那也是值得的：单元测试信息已经超越了所有自学知识，并嵌入程序员的头脑中，这是一项相当大的成就。然而，它确实提出了一个问题：如果设计模式和单元测试只有助于小规模的设计和测试，那么什么可以帮助大型软件系统的更广泛设计？个人计算机软件行业在经历了许多痛苦之后，重新吸取了“无法在质量中测试”的教训，转而推动“在质量中设计”。谁来提供设计专业知识？

If the structured programming push wound up boiling down to “don’t use GOTOs,” that is still a worthwhile result. And if the main contribution of design patterns is making your code amenable to unit testing, that’s also worthwhile: the unit testing message has tunneled past all the self-taught knowledge and embedded itself in the skulls of programmers, which is quite an accomplishment. Still, it does bring up a question: If design patterns and unit tests only help with small-scale design and testing, what can help with the broader design of big software systems? Once the personal computer software industry had, after much suffering, relearned the lesson that you could not “test in” quality, there was a push to “design in” quality instead. Who would provide the design expertise?

如果你仔细阅读程序员的招聘信息，你可能会看到一个名为“软件架构师”的职位。在大学里，我听到有人谈论他们在暑期工作期间设计的软件（我认为是在银行工作），他们不屑一顾地说：“那时我把它交给了程序员。”无论暑期实习生是否会把任何东西交给任何人，这确实抓住了软件架构师的基本概念：就像“真正的”建筑师（从事建筑工作的建筑师）提出设计然后交给其他人去建造一样，软件架构师也会提出软件设计然后交给其他人去编写。

If you peruse job listings for programmers, you may see a job titled “Software Architect.” In college, I heard somebody talk about software they had designed during a summer job (I think it was for a bank), and they said, dismissively, “At that point I handed it off to a coder.” Whether or not summer interns get to hand anything off to anyone, this does capture the essential notion of the software architect: just as a “real” architect (one who works on buildings) comes up with designs and then hands them off to other people to build, a software architect would come up with software designs and then hand them off to others to write.

这很好，但架构师上学是为了学习架构；他们不是从事该行业一段时间并拥有无失败记录的建筑工人，而建筑工人是成为软件架构师的途径。架构师可以向建筑商证明他们的设计是合理的，因为他们的设计基于行业共识，即什么可行、什么不可行，而这又基于实验和数学的传承——亚历山大和克鲁的《模式语言》中就包含了这种东西。软件架构师和所有程序员一样，依赖于“我试过一次，效果还不错”的方法。只有在设计模式所涵盖的具体领域，才有与架构师积累的知识相当的知识，软件架构师不会屈尊指定诸如代码应如何调用加密算法等细节，就像建筑设计师不会告诉建筑工人如何握钉枪一样。

This is fine, but architects go to school to learn about architecture; they are not construction workers who have been doing it for a while and have a track record of nonfailure, which is how you become a software architect. Architects can justify their designs to a builder because they are based on an industry consensus on what works and what doesn’t work, which in turn is based on a legacy of experiments and mathematics—the sort of thing that was captured in Alexander and crew’s A Pattern Language. Software architects, like all programmers, rely instead on the “I tried it this way once and it wasn’t too bad” approach. Only in the nuts-and-bolts areas covered by design patterns is there any equivalent of the built-up knowledge that an architect has, and a software architect would not stoop to the level of specifying details as nitty-gritty as how your code should call an encryption algorithm, any more than a building architect would tell a construction worker how to hold a nail gun.

Joel Spolsky 是一位著名的软件博主，他写过一篇关于“架构宇航员”的文章：喜欢思考越来越高抽象层次的软件架构师。他对架构宇航员工作的描述很典型：

Joel Spolsky is a noted software blogger who wrote a post about “Architecture Astronauts”: software architects who like to think about higher and higher levels of abstraction. His description of an Architecture Astronaut at work is typical:

当伟大的思想家思考问题时，他们开始发现模式。他们研究人们相互发送文字处理文件的问题，然后他们研究人们相互发送电子表格的问题，他们意识到存在一个普遍模式：发送文件。这已经是一个抽象层次。然后他们又上升一个层次：人们发送文件，但网络浏览器也会“发送”网页请求。当你想到这一点时，调用对象上的方法就像向对象发送消息！这又是同一件事！这些都是发送操作，所以我们聪明的思想家发明了一种新的、更高级、更广泛的抽象，称为消息传递，但现在它变得非常模糊，没有人真正知道他们在说什么。15

When great thinkers think about problems, they start to see patterns. They look at the problem of people sending each other word-processor files, and then they look at the problem of people sending each other spreadsheets, and they realize that there’s a general pattern: sending files. That’s one level of abstraction already. Then they go up one more level: people send files, but web browsers also “send” requests for web pages. And when you think about it, calling a method on an object is like sending a message to an object! It’s the same thing again! Those are all sending operations, so our clever thinker invents a new, higher, broader abstraction called messaging, but now it’s getting really vague and nobody really knows what they’re talking about any more.15

斯波尔斯基给出了一个警告信号：“这肯定表明你正在受到建筑宇航员的攻击：令人难以置信的夸夸其谈；英雄主义、乌托邦式的夸夸其谈；自吹自擂；完全缺乏现实感。人们相信了！商业媒体为之疯狂！”16

Spolsky gives a warning sign: “That’s one sure tip-off to the fact that you’re being assaulted by an Architecture Astronaut: the incredible amount of bombast; the heroic, utopian grandiloquence; the boastfulness; the complete lack of reality. And people buy it! The business press goes wild!”16

对于只夸夸其谈架构的软件架构师，通常的解决办法是要求他们编写产品代码并交付给客户，以让他们脚踏实地，确保架构具有相关性。这是否是对他们时间的合理利用，是微软内部争论的话题，就像许多事情一样；有一次，我与公司上下进行了一系列讨论，试图记录“什么是优秀的架构师”，但由于诸如此类的分歧，讨论失败了。尽管如此，目前的偏见更多地是倾向于“有时编码”的架构师，而不是“只会说教”的架构师。虽然目前脚踏实地的软件架构师被认为比缺氧的架构师更好，但架构师需要不断沉浸在团队的当前项目中，这一事实也表明，围绕软件工程，公认的知识和词汇量还不够。软件架构师应该能够利用先例来设计抽象的解决方案，并且能够用足够清晰和标准化的语言将其传达给任何编程团队，以便团队能够认识到设计的价值，并能够相信它会被遵循。尽管人们可能会抱怨建筑建筑师的设计，但你永远不会听说解决方案是让他们偶尔挂上石膏板，只是为了确保他们的建筑能够正常使用。

The commonly prescribed antidote to software architects who only spout architecture is to require them to write product code that ships to customers, in order to keep them grounded and ensure their architecture is relevant. Whether this was a good use of their time was a subject of debate inside Microsoft, like many things; at one point I was involved in a series of discussions with people across the company to try to document “what makes a good architect,” which foundered on disagreements such as this one. Nevertheless, the current bias is more toward the “sometimes-coding” architects than the “pontificating-only” ones. Although grounded software architects, at this moment in time, are considered better than oxygen-deprived ones, the fact that architects need continual immersion in their team’s current project is another sign that there is not enough accepted knowledge and vocabulary around software engineering. Software architects should be able to leverage precedent to design a solution in the abstract, and be able to communicate that to any programming team in language that is clear and standardized enough that the team will recognize the value of the design, and be able to trust that it will be followed. Although people may complain about the designs of building architects, you never hear that the solution is having them occasionally hang sheetrock just to ensure that their buildings will work.

软件架构师角色存在的根本原因是，设计有“好”和“坏”，架构师会选择前者，而不是后者。我说的是软件的底层设计——用户看不到的部分（用户界面设计是另一个领域，不在本书的讨论范围内）。人们认为好的设计会以某种方式展示给用户，但我没有看到任何证据表明用户知道或关心任何人如何在他们的代码中嵌入加密算法。

Underlying the existence of the software architect role is the idea that there is “good” and “bad” design, and architects will choose the first and not the second. I’m talking about the underlying design of the software—the part that is not visible to the user (user interface design is a whole other area, outside the scope of this book). There is a sense that good design will show through to the user in some way, but I see no evidence that the user knows or cares about how anybody embeds their encryption algorithm in their code.

除了设计模式之外，好的设计是什么样的？由于缺乏理论支撑，这是一个模糊的领域。Antony Tang、Aldeida Aleti、Janet Burge 和 Hans van Vliet 的一项软件设计研究是这样说的：

Beyond design patterns, what does good design look like? With a lack of theoretical rigor to underpin it, this is a murky area. One study of software design by Antony Tang, Aldeida Aleti, Janet Burge, and Hans van Vliet put it this way:

软件设计具有与其他工程设计学科不同的某些特点。首先，设计师经常需要探索他们以前没有经验的新应用和技术领域。因此，即使是从业多年的设计师，其设计成果的质量也可能不一致。其次，设计是一个抽象模型，而且，通常，在实施之前，很难客观地判断它是否真的有效。17

Software design has certain characteristics that are different from other engineering design disciplines. First, designers often have to explore new application and technology domains that they do not have previous experience with. Therefore, the quality of their design outcomes may not be consistent even for a designer who has practised for years. Secondly, a design is an abstract model and, often, whether it would actually work or not cannot be easily judged, objectively, until it is implemented.17

有些书籍声称可以解释好的设计 - 例如《代码整洁之道》和《程序员修炼之道》 - 其中包含完全合理的建议，但它们并没有提供软件设计的具体方法。18它们更多的是需要记住做的事情的列表：不要忘记考虑让你的代码可本地化（意味着它可以被翻译成其他语言），经常检查以确保你的代码成功构建，等等。

There are books that claim to explain good design—with titles like Clean Code and The Pragmatic Programmer—that are full of completely reasonable advice, but they don’t present a specific approach to engineering your software.18 They are more about lists of things to remember to do: don’t forget to think about making your code localizable (meaning it can be translated into other languages), check frequently to make sure your code builds successfully, and the like.

医生兼作家阿图·葛文德 (Atul Gawande) 写了一本名为《清单宣言》的书，介绍了如何通过使用清单使医疗更加安全。19他的一个发现是，检查表无需非常具体即可发挥作用；例如，与列出麻醉师应采取的所有步骤的复杂检查表相比，列出“医生是否与麻醉师讨论过麻醉计划？”这样的检查表问题要有用得多。你不需要写下所有步骤，因为麻醉师上过医学院，并接受过麻醉学的高级培训。问题更有可能源于沟通问题，而非缺乏医学知识。如果我们可以将这种方法应用于软件，提出诸如“开发人员是否与测试人员讨论过测试计划？”这样的问题，那就太好了。然而，没有足够的共享知识使这个计划奏效；相反，在包含软件检查表的书中，你看到的是一长串需要担心的具体事项，这使得检查表很难在实践中应用。

The physician and writer Atul Gawande wrote a book called The Checklist Manifesto about how medicine can be made safer by using checklists.19 One of his discoveries is that checklists don’t need to be extremely specific to be helpful; for example, it is much more useful to have a checklist question like “Has the doctor discussed the anesthesia plan with the anesthesiologist?” than have a complicated checklist of all the steps the anesthesiologist should take. You don’t need all the steps written down because the anesthesiologist has been to medical school and done advanced training in anesthesiology. Problems are more likely to arise from communication issues than from lack of medical knowledge. It would be great if we could adapt this approach to software, asking questions like “Has the developer discussed the test plan with the tester?” Yet there is not enough shared knowledge for this plan to work; what you see instead, in books that have software checklists, is long lists of specific things to worry about, making checklists hard to apply in practice.

1971 年，杰拉尔德·温伯格 (Gerald Weinberg) 在《计算机编程心理学》中写道：“我们无法用绝对标准衡量程序的优劣，这阻碍了我们前进。但我们能否用相对标准来衡量程序优劣呢？我们能说程序 A 比程序 B 好还是差吗？不幸的是，出于多种原因，我们通常甚至无法做到这一点。首先，什么时候有其他程序可以与之比较呢？”20这一点很重要。由于每次程序都是“从头开始”设计的，因此总是很容易看出为什么新程序与现有程序略有不同，这使得它无法进行比较。当然，无法衡量程序的优劣使得很难衡量程序员的优劣，尤其是很难衡量这两个领域的进步，而你希望软件工程经过这么多年能够实现这些进步。

In 1971, in The Psychology of Computer Programming, Gerald Weinberg wrote, “We shall be hampered by our inability to measure the goodness of programs on an absolute scale. But can we perhaps measure them on a relative scale—can we say that program A is better or worse than program B? Unfortunately, we will generally not even be able to do that, for several reasons. First of all, when is there ever another program with which to compare?”20 This is an important point. Since programs are designed “from scratch” each time, it is always easy to see why a new program is slightly different from an existing one, in ways that make it invalid for comparison purposes. Of course, being unable to measure the goodness of programs makes it hard to measure the goodness of programmers, and in particular it makes it hard to measure progress in either of those areas, which you hope software engineering would be achieving after all these years.

我在微软工作期间，曾在一个名为“工程卓越”的团队工作过，这个团队从事内部培训和咨询工作。为了满足需求，我们为软件开发人员开设了一门关于如何设计软件的课程。我们想出了“开发人员实用设计”这个标题，我们对此感到非常自豪。这门课将去除所有无稽之谈，为开发人员提供他们真正需要的知识！而且这门课的出席率很高，所以我们并不是唯一认为开发人员渴望获得这些信息的人。但过了一段时间，我们意识到，我们越来越不相信这门课有用；当你从软件设计中去除无稽之谈时，你只剩下设计模式，没有其他东西了。

For part of my career at Microsoft, I worked in a group with the slightly overambitious name Engineering Excellence, which did internal training and consulting. In response to demand, we created a course for software developers on how to design software. We came up with the title Practical Design for Developers, which we were quite proud of. Here was the class that was going to strip away all the nonsense and give developers the knowledge they really needed! And the class was quite well attended, so we weren’t the only ones who thought that developers were hungry for this information. But after a while we realized that we were less and less confident that the class was useful; when you strip away the nonsense from software design, you are left with design patterns and not much else.

关于好的设计还有另一个事实：它往往与快速执行的设计背道而驰。鉴于当今许多程序员都专注于性能，这一点很难改变。

There is another truth about good design: it often runs counter to design that executes quickly. And given the performance focus in which many of today’s programmers were steeped, it is hard to fight that.

温伯格曾写过关于统计学家兼生物学家 RA Fisher 提出的 Fisher 基本定理的文章：“在我们讨论效率问题之前，需要提醒大家一点。适应性不是免费的……Fisher 基本定理指出——以适合当前语境的术语——一个系统对特定环境的适应性越好，它对新环境的适应性就越差。只要发挥一下想象力，我们就能明白，这一定理既适用于计算机程序，也适用于蜗牛、果蝇和乌龟。”21换句话说，你对程序速度的优化越多，以后修改它以容纳额外功能就越困难。

Weinberg wrote about Fisher’s fundamental theorem, derived by the statistician and biologist R. A. Fisher: “A word of caution before we proceed to the question of efficiency. Adaptability is not free. … Fisher’s fundamental theorem states—in terms appropriate to the present context—that the better adapted a system is to a particular environment, the less adaptable it is to new environments. By stretching our imagination a bit, we can see how this might apply to computer programs as well as to snails, fruit flies, and tortoises.”21 In other words, the more you optimized your program for speed, the harder it was to modify it later to accommodate extra functionality.

计算机科学家早就认识到，随着计算机速度越来越快，榨干每一分性能不再是主要目标。1972年，Dijkstra在《结构化编程》中写道：

Computer scientists have long recognized that as computers have gotten faster, squeezing out every ounce of performance was no longer the primary goal. In Structured Programming, in 1972, Dijkstra wrote:

我的结论是，现在最迫切的是，我们不应该再将编程主要视为最小化成本/性能比。我们应该认识到，现在编程更多的是一种智力挑战：编程的艺术是组织复杂性、控制众多事物并尽可能有效地避免混乱的艺术。

我拒绝将效率考虑视为程序员的首要关注点，这并不意味着我忽视它们。……然而，我的观点是，只有在程序仍然足够易于管理的情况下，我们才能进行优化（无论是什么）。22

My conclusion is that it is becoming most urgent to stop to consider programming primarily as the minimization of a cost/performance ratio. We should recognise that already now programming is much more an intellectual challenge: the art of programming is the art of organising complexity, of mastering multitude and avoiding its bastard chaos as effectively as possible.

My refusal to regard efficiency considerations as the programmer’s prime concern is not meant to imply that I disregard them. … My point, however, is that we can only afford to optimise (whatever that may be) provided that the program remains sufficiently manageable.22

回想一下 Bentley 在《编写高效程序》中提出的类似警告：为了使程序运行得更快而进行的更改“通常会降低程序的清晰度、模块性和稳健性”。23 Knuth 在 1974 年曾这样表述过这一点，并以他最著名的一句话作为结尾：

Recall Bentley’s similar warning in Writing Efficient Programs that changes to make a program run faster “often decrease program clarity, modularity, and robustness.”23 Knuth phrased it this way in 1974, ending with one of his most famous quotes:

毫无疑问，追求效率会导致滥用。程序员浪费了大量的时间去思考或担心程序中非关键部分的速度，而这些追求效率的尝试实际上在调试和维护时会产生强烈的负面影响。我们应该忘记小效率，大约 97% 的时间：过早优化是万恶之源。24

There is no doubt that the grail of efficiency leads to abuse. Programmers waste enormous amounts of time thinking about, or worrying about, the speed of noncritical parts of their programs, and these attempts at efficiency actually have a strong negative impact when debugging and maintenance are considered. We should forget about small efficiencies, say about 97% of the time: premature optimization is the root of all evil.24

遗憾的是，这种智慧在新一代程序员身上消失了，他们在个人电脑上自学编程，严格的资源限制使程序员远离了良好的设计。他们自己学到了 Dijkstra 和 Bentley 在上一代人中一直在反对的同样糟糕的性能至上、反设计的智慧。这对于个人程序员来说并不奇怪：性能问题可以在任何规模的程序中观察到，任何改进都可以衡量，对心理产生积极影响。另一方面，良好的设计在你开发更大的程序、涉及更多人更长时间时很重要——这种情况不会发生在一个人范围内的程序中。即使是老派程序员，他们本应更了解情况，也会把他们对“那些年轻人”的抱怨集中在他们忽视性能的情况上，而不是他们忽视良好设计的情况上；性能问题更明确，因此更容易指出。

Regrettably, this wisdom was lost on the new generation of programmers who taught themselves to program on personal computers, with strict resource limits that pushed programmers away from good design. They learned, on their own, the same bad pro-performance, antidesign wisdom that Dijkstra and Bentley had been fighting a generation earlier. This is not surprising for individual programmers: performance issues can be observed in a program of any size, and any improvements made can be measured, to positive effect on the psyche. Good design, on the other hand, matters when you are working on larger programs involving more people for longer periods of time—a situation that doesn’t arise for programs within the scope of one person. Even old-fogy programmers, who arguably should know better, will focus their complaints about “those young kids” on a situation where they ignored performance rather than when they ignored good design; performance problems are more clear-cut and therefore easier to call out.

软件中一些最著名的问题是由于性能与设计之间的权衡。Y2K 问题之所以没有出现，是因为没有人意识到只存储日期的最后两年会使 1900 年与 2000 年难以区分。它之所以出现，是因为用两位数存储日期效率略高，而且当考虑到软件在 2000 年到来时仍可使用的可能性时，立即节省的性能被认为是值得的。

Some of the best-known problems in software were due to performance versus design trade-offs. The Y2K problem didn’t arise because nobody realized that storing only the last two years of the date made 1900 indistinguishable from 2000. It arose because storing dates with two digits is slightly more efficient, and the immediate performance savings were viewed as worth it when balanced with the likelihood that the software would still be around when the year 2000 arrived.

无论你是否相信，类似的情况正在逼近——2038 年问题。25在许多 UNIX 系统中，时间以自 1970 年 1 月 1 日以来的秒数形式存储（更准确地说，自该日期的 00:00:00 或新年的开始以来）。使用有符号的 32 位数字保存日期，这将在 2038 年 1 月 19 日 03:14:07 达到最大允许值 - 恰好是 1970 年 1 月 1 日之后的 2,147,483,647 秒。由于有符号数字的工作方式，1 秒后将被解释为 1970年 1 月 1 日之前的2,147,483,648 秒，或 1901 年 12 月 13 日的 20:45:52 - 恰好是星期五。26同样，UNIX 的设计者对此并不陌生；他们面临着使用 64 位数字存储日期（或另一种避免 2038 年问题的方案）与 UNIX 在 2038 年仍然存在的可能性之间的权衡。在 UNIX 被发明的时候，操作系统的平台独立性较差，人们倾向于同时购买硬件和操作系统的组合。可以合理地预期，当下一代硬件问世时，将出现一种新的操作系统，取代 UNIX。从这个意义上说，这些程序员大多犯了低估 UNIX 能够多好地满足程序员的需求，并允许一个独立的软件行业在其之上出现，从而确保其继续存在的错误。 （如果您对我们人类的长期生存持乐观态度，那么许多 Y2K 修复都涉及将 2 位数字替换为 4 位数字，因此现在我们面临着一个隐约可见的 10,000 年问题。但这将是别人要处理的问题。）

Believe it or not, a similar situation is looming—the Year 2038 problem.25 On many UNIX systems, times are stored as the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 (more precisely, since 00:00:00 on that date, or the stroke of the new year). Using a signed 32-bit number to hold the date, this will hit the maximum allowed value at 03:14:07 on January 19, 2038—exactly 2,147,483,647 seconds after January 1, 1970. Because of how signed numbers work, 1 second later will be interpreted as 2,147,483,648 seconds before January 1, 1970, or 20:45:52 on December 13, 1901—which, appropriately, is a Friday.26 Again, this was not unknown to the designers of UNIX; they faced a trade-off of storing the dates using 64-bit numbers (or another accommodation that avoided the 2038 problem) versus the likelihood that UNIX would still be around in 2038. Back when UNIX was being invented, operating systems were less platform independent, and people tended to buy combinations of hardware and operating system together. It was reasonable to expect that when the next generation of hardware arrived, a new operating system would come with it, displacing UNIX. In that sense, those programmers were guilty mostly of underanticipating how well UNIX would hit the sweet spot of what programmers wanted and allow an independent software industry to emerge on top of it that helped ensure its continued presence. (And for what it’s worth, if you are optimistic about the long-term survival of our species, many of the Y2K fixes involved replacing 2 digits with 4, so now we have a faintly looming Year 10,000 problem. But that will be someone else’s to deal with.)

非技术人员可能会认为设计越简单，运行速度就越快。这似乎没错。要做的工作越少，对吗？但事实并非如此；代码越少并不意味着软件运行速度越快。事实上，情况往往恰恰相反。

A nontechnical person may assume that simpler designs are also faster. Somehow this just seems right. There’s less to do, correct? Yet it doesn’t work out that way; having less code doesn’t mean your software runs faster. In fact, it’s frequently the opposite.

考虑一个真实的例子：一家隔夜快递公司想要在美国各地提供送货服务。它在全国各地的主要机场附近设有一系列办事处​​，每个办事处都有卡车和司机，使其能够及时收集外发包裹并在晚上 8 点之前将其送达机场，并且如果包裹在早上 8 点之前到达机场，则可以在第二天送达

Consider a real-world example: an overnight shipping company that wants to offer delivery anywhere in the United States. It has a collection of offices near major airports all around the country, and each office has trucks and drivers that enable it to collect outgoing packages in time to deliver them to the airport by 8 p.m., and can deliver incoming packages the next day if they arrive at the airport by 8 a.m.

最简单的算法是在美国选择一个距离每个机场都有合理飞行时间的中心位置（假设距离不超过 4 小时），并在那里建立一个分拣设施。每天，当地办事处都会收集包裹，并在晚上 8 点之前将其送到机场。飞机晚上 8 点离开每个机场，午夜前到达中央分拣地点。午夜至凌晨 4 点之间，所有包裹都会被分拣并准备装载到同一架飞机上。然后，飞机飞回当地机场，早上 8 点到达。当地办事处在白天递送这些包裹，收集新的包裹，并重复这个过程。

The simplest algorithm is to pick a central location in the United States that is a reasonable flight time from every airport—let’s say no more than 4 hours away—and build a sorting facility there. Every day the local offices collect packages and bring them to the airport by 8 p.m. Planes leave each of the airports at 8 p.m. and arrive at the central sorting location by midnight. Between midnight and 4 a.m., all the packages are sorted and prepared to be loaded onto the same planes. The planes then fly back to their local airports, arriving by 8 a.m. The local offices deliver those packages during the day, collect new ones, and the process repeats.

从需要知道如何处理包裹的当地办事处的角度来看，该算法非常简单：

From the perspective of a local office needing to know what to do with a package, the algorithm is dead simple:

void routePackage(package) {
   package.SendViaPlane(centralHub);
}
void routePackage(package) {
   package.SendViaPlane(centralHub);
}

这样就抽象出了很多复杂性。其中涉及很多活动部件，比如很多卡车和飞机，更不用说人了，而且分拣设施可能相当复杂。再加上跟踪、支付等等，在对的调用之下就有很多层。但SendViaPlane()算法（既然我们在这里讨论算法，那么我们可以暂时忽略地面上的实际问题）有一定的优雅性：所有包裹都在晚上 8 点装上飞机，然后在早上 8 点起飞。分拣设施可能很复杂，但复杂性都封装在一栋建筑物内，就像一个设计良好的类封装了它的内部结构一样——没有其他人需要知道它，而且只要外部接口相同，它就可以更改。如果您决定某个城市更适合由其他机场提供服务，那么您必须告知该城市办公室的人员（这样他们就知道去哪里递送和领取包裹）以及在那里和中心位置之间飞行的飞行员，但其他人不需要知道这件事。

This abstracts away a lot of complexity. There are a lot of moving parts involved, such as lots of trucks and planes, not to mention people, and the sorting facility is probably quite sophisticated. Throw in tracking, payment, and all that, and you have a lot of layers underneath that call to SendViaPlane(). But the algorithm (since we’re talking about algorithms here, we can for the moment ignore real issues on the ground) has a certain elegance: all the packages are loaded on a plane at 8 p.m. and then taken off a plane at 8 a.m. The sorting facility might be complicated, but the complication is all encapsulated within the one building, like a well-designed class encapsulates its internals—nobody else has to know about it, and it can change as long as the external interface is the same. If you decide that a particular city is better served by a different airport, you have to tell the people in the office in that city (so they know where to go to deliver and pick up packages), and the pilots who fly between there and the central location, but nobody else needs to know about it.

这种算法会把每个包裹送到正确的地方，但可能会造成浪费。我要寄给隔壁邻居的包裹会一路送到中央分拣地点，在卡车和飞机上花上几个小时，然后再走相反的路线回来。这会给快递服务或我带来不必要的成本。如果快递服务向我收取全额费用，我可能会抱怨或使用可以更便宜地送货的竞争对手的快递服务。如果快递服务因为净距离不远而向我收取较低的费用，那么这项服务在内部效率低下，会自掏腰包把我的包裹运来运去。

This algorithm will deliver every package to the right place, but it can be quite wasteful. A package I am sending to my next-door neighbor will go all the way to the central sorting location, spending hours on trucks and airplanes, and then taking the reverse route back. This would result in unnecessary cost, either for the delivery service or me. If the service charged me the full cost of this, I might complain or use a rival delivery service that could do it more cheaply. And if it charged me a low rate because the net distance wasn’t far, then the service would be internally inefficient, flying my package around on its own dime.

这激励快递公司精简服务。例如，快递公司可能会告诉当地快递公司，如果发现一个包裹的目的地由同一快递公司提供服务，就将其放在一边，与第二天早上要送达的包裹混在一起，这样就避免了将其空运到中心快递点再运回。然后算法就变成：

This gives the delivery service an incentive to streamline its service. For example, it might tell the local office that if it saw a package whose destination was served by the same office to set it aside and mix it in with the incoming packages to be delivered the next morning, thus avoiding flying it to the central location and back. The algorithm then becomes:

void routePackage(package) {
   if package.Destination == thisOffice) {
      package.Store(thisOffice);
   } else {
      package.SendViaPlane(centralHub);
   }
}
void routePackage(package) {
   if package.Destination == thisOffice) {
      package.Store(thisOffice);
   } else {
      package.SendViaPlane(centralHub);
   }
}

这总体上提高了效率，但使算法复杂化。当地办事处必须检查所有包裹，而不是直接把它们扔上飞机。这增加了他们必须做的工作的时间和专业知识。

This is an overall efficiency improvement, but it complicates the algorithm. The local offices have to check all the packages instead of just tossing them on a plane. This adds time and expertise to the work they have to do.

现在想象一下，您决定进一步优化您的送货服务，不再将所有包裹都空运到中心位置。您意识到洛杉矶和旧金山之间的交通已经足够繁忙，因此直接在这两个城市之间飞行更有意义。也许从纽约开卡车到波士顿比乘飞机更有意义，所以您还需要检查该选项：

Now imagine that you decide to further optimize your delivery service by not flying all packages to the central location. You realize that there is enough traffic between Los Angeles and San Francisco, say, that it makes more sense to fly a plane directly between those two cities. And maybe it makes sense to drive a truck from New York to Boston rather than fly a plane, so you need to check for that option also:

void routePackage(package) {
   if package.Destination == thisOffice) {
      package.Store(thisOffice);
   } else {
      if (TruckAvailable(package.Destination)) {
         package.SendViaTruck(package.Destination);
      } else if PlaneAvailable(package.Destination)) {
         package.SendViaPlane(package.Destination);
      } else {
         package.SendViaPlane(centralHub);
      }
   }
}
void routePackage(package) {
   if package.Destination == thisOffice) {
      package.Store(thisOffice);
   } else {
      if (TruckAvailable(package.Destination)) {
         package.SendViaTruck(package.Destination);
      } else if PlaneAvailable(package.Destination)) {
         package.SendViaPlane(package.Destination);
      } else {
         package.SendViaPlane(centralHub);
      }
   }
}

很快，您就会得到一个关于每个办公室如何路由包裹的复杂算法。看看上面的代码，您能否说服自己，它不会出现什么都不做的情况（这可能很糟糕）——它总是会调用 、package.Store()或package.SendViaTruck()？package.SendViaPlane()代码的编写方式是，它总是会对每个包裹做一些事情，但需要一点思考（或一套彻底的单元测试）才能确信这一点，确保每个包裹IF都有一个ELSE，并且无论通过代码采用什么路径，包裹最终都会到达某个地方。此外，每个办公室现在都需要知道哪些卡车和飞机在何时何地飞行，这使得以后更改这些细节变得更加困难。

Pretty soon you have a complicated algorithm for how each office should route packages. Looking at the code above, can you convince yourself that there are no cases in which it does nothing at all (which would presumably be bad)—that it will always wind up calling either package.Store(), package.SendViaTruck(), or package.SendViaPlane()? The way the code is written, it will always do something with each package, but it takes a bit of thinking (or a thorough set of unit tests) to be confident of that, making sure every IF has an ELSE, and that whatever path is taken through the code, the package winds up going somewhere. Furthermore, each office now needs to have knowledge of which trucks and planes are traveling where, and when, which makes it harder to change those details later.

我并不是说，隔夜快递服务做出这些改进是错误的。我的观点是，优化算法的性能通常会使其变得更复杂，而不是更简单。程序员认为设计和性能是相关的，因此更好的设计运行得更快。实际上，它们通常是反相关的：更简单、更优雅的设计运行得更慢，而通过特殊情况使设计复杂化可以提高性能。

I am not claiming that it is a mistake for an overnight delivery service to make these improvements. My point is that optimizing the performance of an algorithm generally makes it more complicated, not simpler. Programmers think that design and performance are correlated, such that better design runs faster. In reality, they are frequently inversely correlated: simpler, more elegant designs run slower, and you improve performance by complicating your design with special cases.

为什么会这样？软件设计其实就是抽象层的设计，赏心悦目的设计应该具有漂亮、干净的抽象层。我首先想到的运输算法版本就具有干净的抽象层：每个发出的包裹都会被装上飞机运往中央分拣地点，每个收到的包裹都会从中央分拣地点下飞机。它干净、简单，任何人都能理解。当您尝试优化它时，就会出现复杂情况。考虑到程序员想要提高效率的倾向，他们往往会把事情复杂化。无论是在编写任何代码之前程序员在脑海中想象出需要减轻的性能影响，还是在软件部署后在现实世界中体现出来，干净的设计很少能存活下来。

Why is this so? Software design is really the design of abstraction layers, and a design that is pleasing to the eye has nice, clean abstraction layers. The version of the shipping algorithm that has clean abstraction layers is the first one I came up with: every outgoing package gets put on a plane to the central sorting location, and every incoming package comes off a plane from the central sorting location. It’s clean, it’s simple, and anybody can understand it. The complications arise when you try to optimize it. And given the tendency of programmers to want to make things efficient, they tend to complicate things a lot. Whether the performance impacts that need to be mitigated are imagined in a programmer’s head before any code is written or manifest in the real world after the software is deployed, the clean design rarely survives.

性能和简洁设计相互冲突的最基本方式之一涉及如何处理错误 —— 这最终会成为一个相当有趣的故事。

One of the most basic ways in which performance and clean design battle each other involves how errors are handled—which winds up being quite a story.

笔记

Notes

1. 在某些语言中，通过私有继承，Emailer类可以避免将AESEncrypter类暴露给调用者，但类内部的代码Emailer仍然可以访问AESEncrypter类的成员，并且通常与类的耦合度比它需要的更紧密（因此更容易因内部变化而中断AESEncrypter），而它所需要的只是访问加密功能。
2. 在密码学领域，这并不太令人惊讶，一旦计算机功能变得更强大，曾经被认为是安全的加密算法往往就会被破解。
3.  Bertrand Meyer，《面向对象软件构建》（纽约：Prentice Hall，1988），242。他确实给出了一些例子，他认为具体的多重继承是一个好主意，但没有一个特别令人信服。
4.  Erich Gamma、Richard Helm、Ralph Johnson 和 John Vlissides，《设计模式：可重用面向对象软件的元素》（波士顿：Addison-Wesley，1995 年）。
5.  Christopher Alexander、Sara Ishikawa 和 Murray Silverstein，与 Max Jacobson、Ingrid Fiksdahl-King 和 Shlomo Angel 合著，《模式语言：城镇·建筑·施工》（纽约：牛津大学出版社，1977 年）。
6. 同上，第 19-34 页。这是模式列表；本书的大部分内容（超过一千页）是对每个模式的详细讨论。
7.  Walter Tichy，《设计模式的证据》，《制作软件：什么真正有效，以及我们为何相信它》，Andy Oram 和 Greg Wilson 编辑（加利福尼亚州塞巴斯托波尔：O'Reilly，2011 年），第 393–414 页。
8.Gamma 等人，《设计模式》，20，18。

10.  Kent Beck，“简单的 Smalltalk 测试：使用模式”，访问日期：2018 年 1 月 8 日，http: //swing.fit.cvut.cz/projects/stx/doc/online/english/tools/misc/testfram.htm 。

13.  Bill Blunden，《软件驱魔：遗留代码调试和优化手册》（加州伯克利：Apress，2003 年）。
14.  Feathers，《有效地使用遗留代码》，xvi。

16. 同上。
17.  Antony Tang、Aldeida Aleti、Janet Burge 和 Hans van Vliet，《什么使软件设计有效》，《软件设计师在行动：以人为本的设计工作》，André van der Hoek 和 Marian Petre 编辑（佛罗里达州博卡拉顿：CRC Press，2014 年），第 134 页。
18.  Robert Martin 编，《代码整洁之道：敏捷软件工艺手册》（Upper Saddle River，新泽西州：Prentice Hall，2009 年）；Andrew Hunt 和 David Thomas 编，《务实的程序员：从熟练工到大师》（波士顿：Addison-Wesley，2000 年）。
19.  Atul Gawande，《清单宣言：如何把事情做好》（纽约：大都会图书，1999 年）。
20.  Gerald M. Weinberg，《计算机编程心理学》，银周年纪念版（纽约：Dorset House，1998 年），16。
21. 同上，第21页。
22.  Ole-Johan Dahl、Edsger W. Dijkstra 和 CAR Hoare，《结构化程序设计》（伦敦：Academic Press，1972 年），第 6 页。
23.  Jon Bentley，《编写高效程序》（新泽西州恩格尔伍德克利夫斯： Prentice-Hall，1982 年），第十二页。
24.  Donald E. Knuth，《使用 Go To 语句进行结构化编程》，《计算概览》第 6 卷，第 4 期（1974 年 12 月）：第 268 页。
25. 维基百科，“2038 年问题”，2018 年 1 月 9 日访问，https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Year_2038_problem。
26.  William Porquet，《2038 项目常见问题 (FAQ)》，2007 年 8 月 15 日，2018 年 1 月 9 日访问，http://maul.deepsky.com/~merovech/2038.html。该常见问题解答显示了第二个时钟滴答作响的影响；它还列出了已主动解决该问题的操作系统。

8 

你最喜欢的语言

8 

Your Favorite Language

让我们回顾一下计算机蠕虫的传奇，上一次出现是在 1988 年莫里斯在刚刚起步的互联网上释放蠕虫的时候。在接下来的几十年里，随着计算机之间的互联性越来越强，蠕虫繁殖的机会也越来越多，尤其是当 Windows 成为主导平台时。蠕虫的渗透路径通常只存在于一个操作系统中；而 Windows 是蠕虫编写者集中精力攻击的诱人目标。

Let us return to the saga of computer worms, last seen when Morris unleashed his on the fledgling Internet in 1988. As computers became more interconnected over the ensuing decades, the opportunities for worms to reproduce grew, especially with Windows becoming the dominant platform. A worm’s infiltration path will usually only exist in one operating system; Windows was a juicy target for worm writers to concentrate their energies on.

Windows 的核心内部结构，即操作系统的内核，是用 C 编程语言编写的。C 语言对程序员的错误提供了独特的支持，这些错误会导致缓冲区溢出——漏洞利用机制会将漏洞注入计算机（Linux 和 Apple 的 macOS 是 Windows 目前的两个主要竞争对手，它们的内核也是用 C 语言编写的）。1999 年，当我还是微软 Windows 团队的一名工程师时，我们接受了缓冲区溢出方面的培训；这是我第一次了解到远程漏洞利用的潜在风险，以及在 C 语言中犯下导致漏洞利用的错误是多么容易。我们试图通过仔细阅读代码来清理代码，但并没有发现所有问题。2001 年 7 月，一种名为 Code Red 的蠕虫攻击了运行 Windows 的计算机，它利用了缓冲区溢出，就像 Morris 蠕虫一样。除了通过反复传播自身来使整个互联网陷入瘫痪之外，该蠕虫还用大量消息轰炸白宫网站，使其崩溃（一旦漏洞获得控制权，损害主要受到蠕虫作者想象力的限制）。1

The core internals of Windows, known as the kernel of the operating system, are written in the C programming language. C is uniquely supportive of the programmer errors that allow buffer overflows—the mechanism by which an exploit is injected into computers (both Linux and Apple’s macOS, currently the two main competitors to Windows, also have kernels written in C). When I was an engineer on the Windows team at Microsoft in 1999, we were given training on buffer overflows; this was the first time I understood the potential risk of remote exploits and how easy it was to make a mistake in C that allowed one. We attempted to scrub the code by reading it carefully, but we didn’t catch everything. In July 2001, a worm known as Code Red, which exploited a buffer overflow just as the Morris worm had done, attacked computers running Windows. In addition to bogging down the entire Internet by transmitting itself around repeatedly, the worm bombarded the White House website with messages, crashing it (once an exploit gains control, the damage is mostly limited by the imagination of the worm author).1

蠕虫通常在被广泛发布之前就被报告给拥有代码的公司，通常会详细说明缺陷所在（尽管攻击者可能无法访问源代码，但在构建漏洞利用时，他们会对编译后的机器代码足够熟悉，从而可以相当准确地猜测原始源代码是什么样子）。修复通常很简单，因为大多数缓冲区溢出是由于计算缓冲区长度或复制到缓冲区的内容长度时出错造成的。公司可以发布补丁，用修复后的版本替换有缺陷的代码。在 Code Red 的案例中，在 Code Red 爆发之前，微软已经发布了补丁一个月，但不幸的是，许多用户还没有应用它。2一旦有足够多的机器安装了补丁，每个人都可以松一口气了——直到 2001 年 9 月，一种名为 Nimda 的蠕虫病毒来袭（同样，在蠕虫病毒发布之前就已经有一个补丁可用）。

Worms are often reported to the company that owns the code before being widely released, usually with details on where the defect is (although attackers may not have access to the source code, while constructing the exploit they will become familiar enough with the compiled machine code that they can make a reasonably precise guess as to what the original source code looked like). The fix is typically simple, since most buffer overflows are due to errors in calculating the length of the buffer or the length of what is being copied into the buffer. Companies can issue a patch, which replaces the defective code with the fixed version. In the case of Code Red, the patch had been available from Microsoft for a month before Code Red struck, but unfortunately many users had not yet applied it.2 Once enough machines were patched, everybody could breathe a sigh of relief—until September 2001, when a worm known as Nimda struck (once again, a patch had been available before the worm was released).

接下来的一年很平静。负责 Windows 的集团副总裁 Jim Allchin 表示：“我们检查了所有代码，并通过自动化方式找到了可能存在缓冲区溢出的地方，并在 Windows XP（2001 年底发布）中删除了这些溢出。”3可惜，事与愿违。2003 年出现了 Slammer 和 Blaster 蠕虫，2004 年出现了 Sasser，而 2005 年则是 Zotob 的黄金时代。4值得赞扬的是，微软一直在投资于自动检测可利用代码的工具，尤其是最明显的错误，即将过多的数据复制到堆栈上分配的缓冲区中。5

The next year was quiet. Jim Allchin, the group vice president in charge of Windows, was quoted as saying, “We have gone through all code and, in an automated way, found places where there could be buffer overflow, and those have been removed in Windows XP [which shipped in late 2001].”3 Alas, it was not to be. The year 2003 featured both the Slammer and Blaster worms, 2004 brought Sasser, and 2005 was Zotob’s moment in the sun.4 Microsoft, to its credit, has continued to invest in tools to automatically detect exploitable code, especially the most obvious mistakes, where too much data is copied into a buffer allocated on the stack.5

攻击者开始以应用程序（例如 Microsoft Office）为目标，通过创建经过特殊设计的文档、电子表格和演示文稿，在加载时导致应用程序出现缓冲区溢出。这些将被视为病毒，而不是蠕虫，因为用户必须打开文件才能使漏洞生效，但它们可以采取巧妙的手段诱使用户这样做。通常，漏洞代码会将受感染的文档作为附件通过电子邮件发送给用户的所有联系人，主题行包括“您必须亲眼看到才能相信”（结果是，“用户打开了他们从朋友那里收到的附件……接下来发生的事情会让您大吃一惊！”）。蠕虫和病毒的破坏性也越来越低；与其迅速传播并造成破坏（这会导致快速检测和修补），不如隐藏在后台，将被利用的计算机出租给其他用户，供其在非工作时间进行比特币挖掘、网站攻击等。尽管我了解远程蠕虫如何攻击操作系统，但当我意识到查看受病毒感染的 JPEG 图像也可能导致计算机被控制（并且 Microsoft Office 因此成为另一个攻击目标）时，我又一次感到“等等，什么？”。

Attackers have started targeting applications, such as Microsoft Office, by creating documents, spreadsheets, and presentations that are specially crafted to cause a buffer overflow in the application when they are loaded. These would be considered viruses, not worms, since the user has to open the file for the exploit to take effect, but they can do clever things to entice the user to do this. Typically the exploit code will e-mail the infected document as attachments to all the user’s contacts, with subject lines such as “You HAVE to see this to believe it” (the result is, “A user opens an attachment they received from a friend … and what happens next will shock you!”). Worms and viruses are also becoming less immediately destructive; rather than propagate rapidly and cause havoc (which leads to quick detection and patching), it is better to hide in the background, renting out the exploited computer to other users for off-hours Bitcoin mining, website attacks, and the like. Despite my understanding of how remote worms could attack the operating system, the realization that viewing a virus-infected JPEG image could also cause your computer to be taken over—and that Microsoft Office was therefore another target for attacks—was another “Wait, what?” moment for me.

虽然最近的这些漏洞都没有涉及调用根本不安全的 API 的代码（就像gets()Morris 蠕虫那样），但其中一些漏洞确实涉及错误地信任从网络接收的数据，包括 2014 年的 Heartbleed 攻击，这是由于安全套接字层 (SSL) 协议实施中存在缺陷造成的。6

While none of these recent exploits involve code calling an API that was fundamentally unsafe, the way gets() was for the Morris worm, some of them do involve the mistake of trusting data received off the network, including the Heartbleed attack from 2014, which was due to a flaw in the implementation of the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) protocol.6

SSL 用于加密网络流量，支持所谓的心跳包，发送该包是为了验证连接是否仍然处于活动状态。对心跳包的正确响应是复制传入数据包中的数据并将其发送回去。问题是，传入数据包除了包含要回显的数据外，还有一个 2 字节字段，用于指示数据的长度，而某些 SSL 实现信任该长度字段，而不将其与数据包的实际长度（SSL 代码调用以接收数据包的 API 将返回该长度）进行检查。两个字节最多可以容纳 65,535 个值，因此，如果传入数据包声称有 65,535 个字节的数据，但实际上只有 1 个字节，那么有缺陷的代码将尝试将 65,535 个字节复制到响应中，该响应将由传入数据包中正确的 1 个字节组成，然后是内存堆中的 65,534 个字节。由于此代码经常在 Web 服务器上运行，因此内存中可能包含密码、信用卡号和其他易于识别的数据。Heartbleed 不会接管计算机，但仍会泄露敏感信息。

SSL, which is used to encrypt web traffic, supports what’s called a heartbeat packet, sent to verify that a connection is still active. The proper response to a heartbeat packet is to copy the data in the incoming packet and send it back. The problem is that the incoming packet, in addition to containing the data to echo back, also has a 2-byte field inside it that indicates how long that data is, and some SSL implementations trust that length field without checking it against the actual length of the packet (which would be returned by the API that the SSL code calls to receive the packet). Two bytes can hold a value up to 65,535, so if the incoming packet claims to have 65,535 bytes of data but it really has only 1 byte, then the defective code will try to copy 65,535 bytes into the response, which will consist of the correct 1 byte from the incoming packet, followed by 65,534 bytes of whatever is in the memory heap after that. Since this code is frequently running on web servers, that memory may well contain passwords, credit card numbers, and other readily identifiable data. Heartbleed does not take over the computer, but it still can leak sensitive information.

然而，一些 Windows 漏洞是典型的好意被不了解所调用 API 的程序员所利用的典型案例。细节需要一点背景故事。

Some Windows exploits, however, were classic cases of good intentions getting stuck on the horns of programmers who didn’t understand an API they were calling. The details require a little backstory.

回想一下，在内存中存储字符串时需要对其进行编码，因为计算机最终存储的是数字，而需要有一个将数字解释为字符的标准。在 UNIX/MS-DOS 时代，最常见的编码是 ASCII，其中可打印字符的值介于 32 到 126 之间。这为小写字母、大写字母、数字和常见标点符号留出了空间。一个 ASCII 字符占用 1 个字节；由于一个字节可以容纳最多 255 个数字，因此还有一个扩展 ASCII 字符集，其中包含 128 到 255 范围内的其他有用符号。这仍然不足以容纳所有字母表中的所有字符，因此实际上存在许多扩展 ASCII 字符集，称为代码页，每个代码页都有自己独特的 128 到 255 范围内的字符集。默认代码页“拉丁美洲”包含某些常见的货币符号、希腊字母以及带有重音符号、波浪符号、变音符号、分音符等的字母集合。7它还具有一整套单线和双线绘制字符，以便程序仅使用字符在屏幕上直观地构建框，这对于完全不支持图形的早期 IBM PC 来说非常重要。8此外，还有阿拉伯语、希腊语、西里尔语、希伯来语、葡萄牙语和土耳其语等的单独代码页（土耳其语包括我们的老朋友带点大写字母İ和不带点小写字母ı，分别位于位置 152 和 141）。9

Recall that when storing strings in memory you need to encode them, since ultimately the computer is storing numbers and there needs to be a standard for how numbers are interpreted as characters. Back in the UNIX/MS-DOS days, the most common encoding was ASCII, in which printable characters have values between 32 and 126. This allows room for lowercase letters, capital letters, numbers, and common punctuation symbols. One ASCII character occupied 1 byte; since a byte can hold a number up to 255, there was also an extended ASCII character set that included other useful symbols in the range from 128 to 255. That’s still not enough room to hold all characters in all alphabets, so there were in fact many extended ASCII character sets, known as code pages, each with its own unique set of characters in the 128 to 255 range. The default code page, “Latin US,” had certain common currency symbols, Greek letters, and a collection of letters with accents, tildes, cedillas, diereses, and so on.7 It also featured a complete set of single- and double-line-drawing characters for programs to visually construct boxes on the screen using only characters, which was important for early IBM PCs that did not support graphics at all.8 In addition, there were separate code pages for, among others, Arabic, Greek, Cyrillic, Hebrew, Portuguese, and Turkish (this last included our old friends the dotted capital İ and undotted lowercase ı, at positions 152 and 141, respectively).9

图 8.1是默认的代码页，每行显示 10 个字符。10与此同时，图 8.2是土耳其语代码页；请注意，它们从 32 到 127 是相同的，并且只有大约 50 个字符在 128 到 255 范围内有所不同。

Figure 8.1 is the default code page, with each row showing 10 characters.10 Meanwhile, figure 8.2 is the Turkish code page; notice that they are identical from 32 to 127, and only have about 50 characters that differ in the 128 to 255 range.

一旦用户将计算机配置为使用正确的代码页，文本就会按预期显示在屏幕上。或者，他们可以打开为不同代码页编写的文档，然后看到有趣的乱码。在每个代码页上，原始 ASCII 字符 32-127 保持不变，因此无论计算机配置了哪种代码页，英文文本都显示相同。11因此，微软公司大多数使用英语工作的程序员都没有意识到选择错误代码页的痛苦。

Once a user configured their computer to use the right code page, text would display as expected on the screen. Or they could open a document written for a different code page and see amusing gibberish. On every code page, the original ASCII characters 32–127 remained unchanged, so English text displayed the same no matter what code page the computer was configured for.11 Thus most programmers at Microsoft, working in English, were oblivious to the frustration of choosing the wrong code page.

当 Microsoft Windows 在 20 世纪 80 年代中期首次问世时，它包含了自己的代码页，这些代码页涵盖了相同的基本内容，但在确切的编码上有所不同（首先，由于 Windows 始终在图形模式下运行，因此不再需要画线字符）。12与以前一样，如果您希望系统显示所需的高位 128 个字符，则必须为系统选择正确的代码页，并且与以前一样，英语使用者对这一切都一无所知。

When Microsoft Windows first came out in the mid-1980s, it included its own code pages covering the same basic ground but different in their exact encoding (for one thing, since Windows always ran in graphics mode, the line-drawing characters were no longer needed).12 As before, you had to choose the right code page for your system if you wanted it to display the upper 128 characters that you wanted, and as before, English speakers were blissfully unaware of all this.

代码页效果不错，但对表意字母（如拥有数千个字符的日文汉字）来说，它就显得力不从心了。为了解决这个问题，Windows NT（其第一版于 1993 年问世）决定改用一种名为 Unicode 的编码系统。

Code pages worked reasonably well but ran out of gas for ideographic alphabets, such as the Japanese kanji, which has thousands of characters. To solve this problem, the decision was made that Windows NT, whose first version came out in 1993, would switch to an encoding system called Unicode.

Unicode 无需代码页，所有字符都用两个字节存储，这样可以存储 65,536 个（差不多）字符。实际上，它比这稍微复杂一些，可以存储更多的字符，不过这里并不重要。13 Unicode 拥有庞大的字符数，这使得中文和日文表意字母（无论如何，它们是最常见的子集；它目前支持超过 100,000 个字符，包括最近修订版中的 2,500 多个表情符号）能够与所有带重音符号的拉丁字母以及西里尔字母、希伯来语、韩语等愉快地共存。14当然，其代价是每个字符使用 2 个字节的存储空间，因此字符串占用更多内存，并且需要更长的时间来复制，但（这一次！）这被认为是一个值得的选择。

Unicode dispenses with code pages and stores all characters in two bytes, which allows 65,536 (almost) possible characters. It’s actually slightly more complicated than that, to allow even more characters, yet not in a way that matters here.13 Unicode’s large character count allows the Chinese and Japanese ideographic alphabets (the most common subsets, anyway; it currently supports somewhat over 100,000 characters, including, in recent revisions, more than 2,500 emoji) to happily coexist with Latin alphabets in all their accented varieties, as well as Cyrillic, Hebrew, Korean, and so on.14 The trade-off, of course, is that it uses 2 bytes of storage for every character, so strings occupy more memory and take longer to copy around, but (for once!) this was deemed a worthwhile choice.

Unicode 总体而言是一个巨大的改进，但它有一个不幸的副作用，那就是程序员习惯于 1 个字符占用 1 个字节的观念，并学会了互换使用这两个术语。15 Unicode 为程序员犯“字符与字节”数学错误提供了途径，这些错误可能导致他们试图将数据复制到只能容纳程序员预期一半数据的缓冲区中 — 正是这种错误导致缓冲区溢出。10 个 Unicode 字符占用 20 个字节的内存，因此如果您尝试将 10 个 Unicode 字符复制到 10 字节的缓冲区中，则缓冲区将溢出 10 个字节。对于习惯使用单字节字符的程序员来说，这是意料之外的，因为 10 个字符占用 10 个字节。

Unicode was overall a great improvement, but it had one unfortunate side effect, which is that programmers, used to the idea that 1 character occupied 1 byte, had learned to think of the terms interchangeably.15 Unicode opens up an avenue for programmers to make “characters versus bytes” math mistakes that can lead to trying to copy data into a buffer that can only hold half what the programmer expects—the exact sort of error that causes buffer overflows. Ten Unicode characters take up 20 bytes of memory, so if you try to copy 10 Unicode characters into a 10-byte buffer, you will overflow the buffer by 10 bytes. This is unexpected for programmers used to single-byte characters, for which 10 characters occupy 10 bytes.

当 Unicode 被添加到 Windows 中时，需要扩展用于字符串操作的 C API。回想一下，C 中的字符串是一个 8 位值数组，以 0 结尾；而 Unicode 字符串则被定义为一个 16 位值数组，以 0（即 16 位 0）结尾。该 APIstrlen()通过扫描 0 字节来计算单字节字符串的长度；添加了一个 API，通过扫描 16 位 0（开头的 0 是宽字符串的缩写，以匈牙利前缀客串出现）wcslen()来计算 Unicode 字符串的长度。wcs

When Unicode was added to Windows, the C API for string manipulation needed to be extended. Recall that a string in C is an array of 8-bit values, terminated by a 0; a Unicode string was defined as an array of 16-bit values, terminated by a 0—that is, a 16-bit 0. The API strlen() calculates the length of a single-byte string by scanning for a 0 byte; an API wcslen() was added that calculates the length of a Unicode string by scanning for a 16-bit 0 (that wcs at the beginning, which is short for wide character string, is a cameo appearance by a Hungarian prefix).

问题来了wcslen()：应该返回什么：应该是使用的字节数还是 Unicode 字符数？对于strlen()单字节版本，它们是等效的，因此没有提供任何先例。我们决定wcslen()返回字符数，事实上它确实这样做了。这没错——这是最合乎逻辑的选择16 —但这是您必须了解 API 工作原理的又一种情况，否则您可能会犯错误。尽管有wcslen()匈牙利前缀！但没有什么明显的迹象表明“返回字节数”与“返回字符数”。

The question arises of what wcslen() should return: Should it be the number of bytes used or the number of Unicode characters? For strlen(), the single-byte version, they were equivalent, so that didn’t offer any precedent. It was decided that wcslen() would return the number of characters, and indeed that is what it does. That’s not wrong—it’s the most logical choice16—but this is one more of those situations in which you have to know how an API works or you can make a mistake. There is nothing obvious about wcslen()—despite the Hungarian prefix!—to indicate “returns a byte count” versus “returns a character count.”

在 C 语言中，当您在堆栈上分配一个缓冲区时，确定其大小的最简单方法是通过一个名为的 API（实际上它不是一个 API，但为了简单起见，可以将其视为一个 API）sizeof()，它会告诉您变量占用了多少内存。考虑以下代码（是一个单宽字符，即 16 位 Unicode 字符，是单字节字符串中wchar_t的 Unicode 等效字符；为什么有额外的字符不值得解释）：char_t17

When you allocate a buffer on the stack in C, the easiest way to figure out its size is via an API (which is not really an API, but think of it as one for simplicity) called sizeof(), which tells you how much memory a variable takes.
