Brooks was arguing for changing the division of time between the phases, but not for changing the unidirectional transit through them.

1995 年，布鲁克斯出版了他的著作《人月神话》二十周年纪念版，其中收录了同名论文。他又写了一篇新文章，题为《二十年后的人月神话》，指出“瀑布模型是错误的”。10布鲁克斯直接回应了他自己最初的文章“计划丢弃一个”，该文章声称任何系统的第一个版本都会很糟糕，“太慢，太大，难以使用，或者三者兼而有之”，并且“唯一的问题是是否提前计划构建一个一次性的东西，或者承诺将一次性的东西交付给客户”（正如他所说，“这样看，答案就清楚多了”）。11布鲁克斯最初主张建立一个“试点系统”，即第一个糟糕的系统，但永远不会将其交付给客户，而是利用所获得的知识重新开始。

In 1995, Brooks came out with a twenty-year anniversary edition of his book The Mythical Man-Month, in which the original essay of the same name had appeared. He included a new essay titled “The Mythical Man-Month after 20 Years,” which states that “the waterfall model is wrong.”10 Brooks was responding directly to his own original essay “Plan to Throw One Away,” which claimed that the first version of any system is going to be terrible, “too slow, too big, awkward to use, or all three,” and “the only question is whether to plan in advance to build a throwaway, or to promise to deliver the throwaway to customers” (as he puts it, “Seen this way, the answer is much clearer”).11 Brooks had originally advocated building a “pilot system,” that first terrible system, but never delivering it to your customer and instead starting over with the knowledge you have gained.

我从来都不喜欢这个建议；不能构建第一次就可用的软件是不符合工程学的。布鲁克斯确实说过，化学工程工厂就是这样建造的，用一个较小的工厂来测试一个工艺，但据推测，对于一个给定的化学工艺，这只会做一次，而不是对使用相同工艺的每个工厂都做一次。长桥的设计是基于从建造短桥中收集的信息，但并不是每座长桥都需要建造一个特定的较短版本来证明真正的长桥不会倒塌。

I never particularly liked this advice; it is un-engineer-y to not be able to build software that is usable the first time. Brooks did state that chemical engineering plants are built this way, with a smaller plant used to test a process, but presumably this is only done once for a given chemical process, not for every plant that uses the same process. Long bridge designs are based on information gathered from building shorter bridges, yet not every long bridge needs a specific shorter version constructed to prove that the real one won’t fall down.

因此，我很高兴看到布鲁克斯在二十年后改变了对《抛弃计划》的看法（这是多年后的回想；像大多数程序员一样，我在 20 世纪 90 年代没有读过他的书，当时微软正在盲目地使用瀑布式方法）。他的主要抱怨是他之前的建议接受了瀑布模型作为事实：“第 11 章[《抛弃计划》文章]并不是唯一受到顺序瀑布模型污染的一章；它贯穿了整本书，从第 2 章[《人月神话》文章]中的调度规则开始。”12

So I was glad to see that Brooks, with twenty years of hindsight, had changed his mind about “Plan to Throw One Away” (this was retroactive gladness years later; like most programmers, I wasn’t reading his books in the 1990s, a period when Microsoft was heedlessly using a waterfall-ish approach). His main complaint was that his earlier advice accepted the waterfall model as fact: “Chapter 11 [the ‘Plan to Throw One Away’ essay] is not the only one tainted by the sequential waterfall model; it runs through the book, beginning with the scheduling rule in Chapter 2 [the ‘Mythical Man-Month’ essay].”12

“瀑布模型的基本谬误在于，它假设一个项目只经历一次流程，”布鲁克斯继续说道，

“The basic fallacy of the waterfall model is that it assumes a project goes through the process once,” Brooks continues,

架构优秀且易于使用，实现设计合理，并且随着测试的进行可以修复实现。换句话说，瀑布模型假设所有错误都发生在实现中，因此可以顺利地将修复与组件和系统测试穿插在一起。

“计划丢弃一个”确实正面解决了这个谬误。错误的不是诊断，而是补救措施。……瀑布模型将系统测试（因此也意味着用户测试）放在构建过程的最后。因此，只有在投入全面构建后，才能发现用户无法忍受的尴尬、不可接受的性能或对用户错误或恶意的危险敏感性。十三

that the architecture is excellent and easy to use, the implementation design is sound, and the realization is fixable as testing proceeds. Another way of saying it is that the waterfall model assumes the mistakes will all be in the realization, and thus that their repair can be smoothly interspersed with component and system testing.

“Plan to throw one away” does indeed attack this fallacy head on. It is not the diagnosis that is wrong; it is the remedy. … The waterfall model puts system test[ing], and therefore by implication user testing, at the end of the construction process. Thus one can find impossible awkwardness for users, or unacceptable performance, or dangerous susceptibility to user error or malice, only after investing in full construction.13

整个过程并不像是在瀑布上平稳地流动的水流，反而更像是骑着一个木桶越过瀑布：先是极度恐惧，最后被水流碾死。

Rather than mimicking the smooth flow of water over a waterfall, the process was beginning to look more like riding a barrel over one: moments of sheer terror followed by getting crushed in the churn at the end.

布鲁克斯提到，瀑布模型已被纳入美国国防部针对所有军用软件的规范。回到为自己的软件付费的用户领域，他建议，“实施者可以着手构建产品的垂直部分，其中构建了非常有限的功能集，以便让阳光尽早照进可能存在性能问题的地方。”14这不仅仅是性能问题，而是用户可能遇到的任何问题。如果你知道你的软件需要一个数据库层，那么你不必一开始就实现你认为最终需要的所有功能，而是编写单个用户可见功能所需的最小数据库支持，以及任何其他层所需的最小支持，并将其呈现给客户；这是你确定数据库是否设计正确的最终方法。然后你回头再开发另一个功能：起泡、冲洗、重复。

Brooks mentions that the waterfall model was enshrined in a US Department of Defense specification for all military software. Back in the realm of users who pay for their own software, he recommends, “implementers may well undertake to build a vertical slice of a product, in which a very limited function set is constructed in full, so as to let early sunlight into places where performance snakes may lurk.”14 It’s not just performance snakes; it’s any issues the users might encounter. If you know your software will need a database layer, rather than start by implementing all the functionality you think you will eventually require, you write the minimal database support needed for a single user-visible feature, along with the minimal support needed in any other layers, and present that to the customer; that is the ultimate way you will determine if your database is designed properly. Then you go back and work on another feature: lather, rinse, repeat.

不仅用户喜欢垂直切片，程序员也喜欢。布鲁克斯说，在北卡罗来纳大学任职期间，“我转而教授增量开发。屏幕上第一张图片、第​​一个运行的系统对团队士气的鼓舞作用令我震惊。”15

It’s not just the users who prefer vertical slices; it’s also the programmers. Brooks remarks that at one point during his tenure at the University of North Carolina, “I switched to teaching incremental development. I was stunned by the electrifying effect on team morale of that first picture on the screen, that first running system.”15

Scrum 积极致力于尽可能频繁地向用户提供新功能。交付时间表称为冲刺，通常持续两到四周。围绕冲刺，Scrum 有一些特定的工件，包括产品待办事项（一份可考虑用于未来冲刺的所有工作的清单）和燃尽图（跟踪此冲刺中剩余的总估计工作量，希望在冲刺结束时达到零 - 但需要注意的是，只有完全完成的项目才能划掉其工作时间）。在每个冲刺开始时，团队都会选择他们认为正确的产品待办事项（在“客户下一步想要什么”和“我们认为适合一个冲刺的内容”方面都是正确的），然后在冲刺的剩余时间内努力交付这些项目。术语“冲刺”经常被误解为意味着让你精疲力竭的疯狂活动，但目标是团队可以连续冲刺而不休息。短跑应该更像是马拉松的一英里，而不是疯狂冲向终点线。

Scrum focuses aggressively on delivering new functionality to the user as often as possible. The timeline for delivery is known as a sprint, and typically lasts two to four weeks. Around the sprint, Scrum has certain artifacts, including the product backlog (a list of all work that could be considered for future sprints) and burndown chart (which tracks the total estimated work remaining in this sprint, hopefully hitting zero at the end of the sprint—with the caveat that only items that are entirely complete can have their hours crossed off). At the beginning of each sprint, the team selects what it feels are the right product backlog items (right in terms of both “what the customer wants next” and “what we think will fit in one sprint”) and then spends the rest of the sprint working to deliver those items. The term sprint is frequently misinterpreted to imply frenetic activity that leaves you burned out, but the goal is that teams can work sprint after sprint without breaks. A sprint should feel more like one mile of a marathon, not a mad dash to the finish line.

由于 Brooks 撰写的文章中谈到了用垂直切片的增量交付取代瀑布模型，而 Scrum 正是在 OOPSLA 上发表的同一年，因此 Schwaber 对 Scrum 的描述似乎代表了关于如何摆脱瀑布开发模型的已经形成的共识。实际上，Scrum 是一种更为激进的背离。

Since Brooks was writing about replacing the waterfall model with the incremental delivery of vertical slices in the same year that Scrum was being presented at OOPSLA, it might appear that Schwaber’s delineation of Scrum represented the recording of an already-emerged consensus about how to move away from the waterfall model of development. Actually, Scrum was a much more aggressive departure.

Schwaber 的论文是作为大型 OOPSLA 研讨会“业务对象设计和实现”的一部分发表的，其中“业务对象”是可重用的软件组件，可以与其他业务对象组合在一起以创建应用程序——熟悉的面向对象梦想。Scrum 论文与此没有任何特别的关系。整个业务对象研讨会的总结论文只是指出，“新系统将需要使用紧密耦合的开发方法构建松散耦合、可重用、可插拔兼容的组件，该方法结合了业务流程再造、分析、设计、实现和可重用组件市场交付系统，类似于当今的定制 IC 芯片行业。”但它还包括以下 Scrum 论文的总结：“系统开发的既定和公认的理念是，系统开发过程是一种可以规划、估计和成功完成的很好理解的方法。这是一个不正确的基础。”16从本质上讲，施瓦伯的意思是，研讨会其余部分的前提是有错误的；不存在“紧密耦合的开发方法”，也永远不会有。

Schwaber’s paper was presented as part of a larger OOPSLA workshop titled “Business Object Design and Implementation,” where a “business object” is a reusable software component that can be knitted together with other business objects to create applications—the familiar object-oriented dream. The Scrum paper doesn’t have anything particular to do with this. The summary paper from the entire business object workshop merely states, “New systems will require that loosely coupled, reusable, plug compatible components be constructed using a tightly coupled development method that combines business process reengineering, analysis, design, implementation, and reusable component market delivery systems similar to today’s custom IC chip industry.” Yet it also includes the following summary of the Scrum paper: “The stated, accepted philosophy for systems development is that systems development process is a well understood approach that can be planned, estimated, and successfully completed. This is an incorrect basis.”16 Essentially, Schwaber was saying that the premise of the rest of the workshop was faulty; there was no “tightly coupled development method,” nor will there ever be one.

摘要继续说道，

The summary continues,

SCRUM 指出，系统开发过程是一个不可预测的复杂过程，只能粗略地描述为一个整体进展。SCRUM 将系统开发过程定义为一组松散的活动，将已知的、可行的工具和技术与开发团队为构建系统所能设计的最佳工具和技术相结合。由于这些活动是松散的，因此使用控制来管理流程和固有风险。17

SCRUM states that the systems development process is an unpredictable, complicated process that can only be roughly described as an overall progression. SCRUM defines the systems development process as a loose set of activities that combines known, workable tools and techniques with the best that a development team can devise to build systems. Since these activities are loose, controls to manage the process and inherent risk are used.17

20 世纪 90 年代中期，布鲁克斯撰写了他的最新论文，Scrum 也刚刚起步，《微软的秘密》一书也出版了。据微软员工报告，这本书列出了公司处理开发的各种原则，包括“并行团队工作，但每天‘同步’和调试”、“始终拥有理论上可以交付的产品”和“在构建产品时不断测试产品”。18这听起来非常敏捷，但在 20 世纪 90 年代初参与过一款大型 Microsoft 产品的工作后，我知道所使用的技术与 Scrum 所倡导的技术相去甚远。Brooks 在 1995 年的更新中，对 Microsoft 每天晚上构建和测试其软件印象深刻。19事实是，虽然我们确实确保软件每天晚上都构建完成（这意味着它生成的编译程序没有任何错误），并且每天都进行最低限度的测试，但该产品是我们“理论上可以交付”的，只是“理论”一词最理论化的含义。我们的软件是按每个里程碑持续 6 到 9 个月开发的，虽然我们在每个里程碑期间都没有遵循严格的瀑布流程，但我们肯定会后期加载测试，并且只有在任何给定里程碑的末尾，软件才可靠到可以对外发布。实际上，我们的“冲刺”持续时间以及我们交付的“片段”的时间范围是 6 到 9 个月——比 Scrum 倡导的 2 到 4 周长得多。甚至将里程碑等同于“长冲刺”也是错误的，因为 Scrum 明确反对使用“小瀑布”方法进行冲刺，在这种方法中，您可能会将四周分为一周规划、两周编码和一周测试。冲刺期间交付的每个功能都应该在完成当天准备好发送给客户。

The mid-1990s, when Brooks wrote his updated essay and Scrum was getting started, was also the time that the book Microsoft Secrets came out. The book lays out various principles, as reported by Microsoft employees, for how the company handles development, including “work in parallel teams, but ‘synch up’ and debug daily,” “always have a product you can theoretically ship,” and “continuously test the product as you build it.”18 This sounds marvelously Agile, but having worked on a large Microsoft product in the early 1990s, I know that the techniques used were a far cry from what Scrum was advocating. Brooks, in his 1995 update, is impressed at learning that Microsoft builds and tests its software every night.19 The reality is that while we did ensure that the software built every night—meaning that it produced a compiled program without hitting any errors—and did do minimal testing each day, it was a product we could “theoretically ship” only in the most theoretical meaning of the word theoretical. Our software was developed in milestones lasting six to nine months each, and although we did not follow a strict waterfall process during each milestone, we definitely back-loaded the testing, and only toward the end of any given milestone was the software reliable enough to release externally. Effectively our “sprint” duration, and the timeframe for the “slices” we delivered, was six to nine months—much longer than the two to four weeks that Scrum advocates. Even equating the milestones with “long sprints” is wrong, because Scrum explicitly contraindicates the “mini waterfall” approach to a sprint, where you might split your four weeks into a week of planning, two weeks of coding, and one week of testing. Every feature delivered during a sprint is supposed to be ready to ship to a customer on the day it is completed.

因此，尽管许多公司已经从纯瀑布模型转向更具迭代性的模型（或者从一开始就没有使用过纯瀑布模型），但 Scrum 却大大加速了这一转变。

So while many companies had moved away from the pure waterfall model to something a bit more iterative (or never used pure waterfall to begin with), Scrum made for a dramatic acceleration of that movement.

更引人注目的是第二著名的敏捷方法，极限编程（XP）。XP 由 Beck 发明（他之前曾开创了当前形式的单元测试），它基于一套围绕软件规划、管理、设计、编码和测试的规则。20规划和管理与 Scrum 类似，每天开会，重点关注频繁的小版本发布，尽管在某些情况下 XP 更具规范性。设计/编码/测试阶段的指导涉及软件工程的实际细节，而 Scrum 忽略了这一点。该方法的关键是编写单元测试，并确保经常运行这些单元测试，并在添加新代码或发现当前单元测试集未发现的错误时编写新的单元测试。

Even more dramatic is the second-best-known Agile methodology, Extreme Programming (known as XP). Invented by Beck (who had earlier originated unit testing in its current form), XP is based on a set of rules around the planning, managing, designing, coding, and testing of software.20 Planning and managing are Scrum-like, with daily meetings and a focus on frequent small releases, although XP is more prescriptive in some cases. The guidance on the design/coding/testing phases gets into actual specifics of how the software should be engineered, which Scrum ignores. The key to the approach is writing unit tests, and ensuring that those unit tests are run often, and writing new unit tests whenever new code is added or a bug is found that snuck past the current set of unit tests.

XP 还强制实行有争议的结对编程做法，即两个程序员始终一起工作，共用一台计算机；通常一个程序员负责编码，另一个程序员负责观察。这里的想法是，三个臭皮匠顶个诸葛亮；第二个程序员会持续审查第一个程序员的代码（第二个程序员的观察还可以防止您在工作时被不必要的网络干扰，这无疑会影响工作效率）。

XP also mandates the somewhat-controversial practice of pair programming, in which two programmers work together at all times, sharing one computer; typically one is coding while the other is watching. The idea here is, quite literally, that two heads are better than one; the second programmer provides a continuous code review of what the first programmer is doing (having a second programmer watching also discourages unnecessary web-based diversions while you are supposed to be working, which no doubt has an effect on productivity).

XP 确实试图避免一些关于编码的“宗教”争论。它要求写下并遵守编码约定 — — 不指定特定的编码约定，但至少要确保关于正确编码风格的争论只发生一次，以某种方式解决，此后不再提起（制表符或空格，只需选择一个并使用它）。关于使代码灵活以预测未来变化的问题，XP 明确表示：不要这样做。根据您现在正在处理的功能的要求编写代码，如果由于新功能或用户反馈而导致需求发生变化，则修改代码。由于代码将具有良好的单元测试，因此您可以进行这些未来的修改，而不必担心由于您对代码的理解不够清晰而意外破坏某些东西。而且，在您有新要求之前，您不会知道需要进行哪些更改，因此现在尝试预测它们是愚蠢的。任何相反的意见都可以用“你不会需要它”（YAGNI）的口头禅来驳斥。

XP does attempt to avoid some of the “religious” arguments about coding. It mandates that a coding convention be written down and adhered to—without specifying a particular coding convention, but at least ensuring that arguments over proper coding style will happen once, be resolved in some way, and thereafter not brought up again (tabs or spaces, just pick one and go with it). On the question of making your code flexible to anticipate future changes, XP is clear: don’t do it. Write the code for the requirements of the feature you are working on now, and if the requirements change, because of a new feature or user feedback, modify the code then. Since the code will have good unit tests, you can make these future modifications without worrying about accidentally breaking something because your understanding of the code is not fresh in your mind. And until you have new requirements, you won’t know what changes are needed, so it is foolish to attempt to anticipate them now. Any opinions to the contrary can be dismissed with the mantra “You Ain’t Gonna Need It” (YAGNI).

Scrum 和 XP 是为小型团队设计的；每日会议的规模不会超过 10 到 15 人，因为随着与会人数的增加，任何一个程序员关心另一个程序员状态的机会都会减少。Schwaber 和 Sutherland 于 1995 年发表的原始 OOPSLA 论文以一个公理开头：“由有能力的个人组成的小型团队，在他们拥有和控制的有限空间内工作，将远远胜过大型开发团队。”21如果绩效是基于“每人交付的代码量”这样的指标，那么很难反驳这一点；在软件工程以外的领域，人们普遍认为，随着项目规模的扩大，沟通和协调的开销也会增加。尽管如此，暗示小团队会比任何规模的大团队生产出更多的软件是一种误导。

Scrum and XP are designed for small teams; the daily meeting doesn’t scale well beyond ten to fifteen people because the chance of any one programmer caring about another programmer’s status decreases as the number of attendees rises. Schwaber and Sutherland’s original 1995 OOPSLA paper starts out with an axiom: “Small teams of competent individuals, working within a constrained space that they own and control, will significantly outperform larger development groups.”21 It is hard to argue with this if performance is based on a metric like “code delivered per person”; it is generally understood, in areas far beyond software engineering, that the communication and coordination overhead will increase as you work on larger projects. Nonetheless, it is misleading to imply that small teams will produce more software than larger ones of any size.

Beck 写道：“规模显然很重要。你可能无法用 100 名程序员来运行 XP 项目。50 名程序员不行，20 名程序员也不行。10 名程序员肯定是可行的。”后来他又说：“如果你的程序员分布在两层楼，那就算了吧。如果你的程序员分布在同一个楼层，而且相距甚远，那就算了吧。”22

Beck writes, “Size clearly matters. You probably couldn’t run an XP project with a hundred programmers. Not fifty. Not twenty, probably. Ten is definitely doable,” and later says, “If you have programmers on two floors, forget it. If you have programmers widely separated on one floor, forget it.”22

另一个问题是，当你开发软件的第一个版本时，很难在两到四周内，甚至在两到四周的几倍时间内，做出用户可以使用的东西。在 Windows NT 能够在六到九个月的里程碑结束时开始发布公开版本之前，它花了几年时间才创造出任何可用的产品，因为在操作系统能够处理来自用户的单个请求之前，需要编写操作系统内部的很多内容。

Another problem is that when you are working on the first version of a piece of software, it can be hard to produce anything that users can use in two to four weeks, or even in small multiples of two to four weeks. Before Windows NT could start shipping public releases at the end of six- to nine-month milestones, it took several years to create anything that was usable at all, because so much of the internals of an operating system need to be written before it can handle a single request from a user.

微软过去以功能为导向来开发其产品，这意味着团队会制定一组计划中的功能，然后一直工作到这些功能可用为止，接受任何需要的时间表；在某个时候，公司转向以日期为导向，即团队会设定一个日期，并且只包括可以在该日期之前完成的功能，如果项目进行到一半时发现功能有危险，则会将其删除。这让客户对事情有了更多的可预测性。但这是在您拥有现有产品时才可享受的奢侈；对于 Windows NT 的第一个版本，不能删除“操作系统正常运行”这一关键功能。以日期为导向的进度安排被誉为项目管理的一项突破，但并非巧合的是，微软所有主要产品（Windows、Office、其编译器、SQL Server 数据库程序和 Exchange 电子邮件服务器）都已建立可运行的版本，这些版本随后可以在后续版本中添加（或不添加）单个功能。

Microsoft used to be feature driven in its products, meaning that teams would establish a planned set of features and then work until they were available, accepting whatever schedule slip was needed; at a certain point the company switched to being date driven, where teams would set a date and only include the features that could be completed by that date, cutting features in the middle of a project if they looked to be in danger. This made things much more predictable for customers. But this is a luxury that is available when you have an existing product; for the first version of Windows NT, the critical feature “the operating system works” could not be cut. Date-driven scheduling is heralded as a breakthrough in project management, but it’s no coincidence that the switch away from being feature driven happened around the time that all of Microsoft’s major products (Windows, Office, its compilers, the SQL Server database program, and the Exchange e-mail server) had established, working versions, which could then have individual features added on (or not) in subsequent versions.

事实上，最初的 OOPSLA Scrum 论文指出，“Scrum 关注现有产品的管理、增强和维护，同时利用新的管理技术和上面列出的公理。Scrum 不关心新的或重新设计的系统开发工作。”到 2002 年 Schwaber 的第一本 Scrum 书出版时，这种区别已经消失，Scrum 被认为适用于新项目和正在进行的项目。23

In fact, the original OOPSLA Scrum paper states, “Scrum is concerned with the management, enhancement and maintenance of an existing product, while taking advantage of new management techniques and the axioms listed above. Scrum is not concerned with new or reengineered systems development efforts.” By the time Schwaber’s first Scrum book came out in 2002, this distinction had been lost, and Scrum was presented as applicable to both new and ongoing projects.23

另外，OOPSLA 论文还提出了另一条公理：“面向对象环境中的产品开发需要高度灵活、自适应的开发流程”，后来又说：“面向对象技术为 Scrum 方法提供了基础。对象或产品功能提供了一个离散且可管理的环境。过程代码具有许多相互交织的接口，不适合 Scrum 方法。”24我不确定面向对象与它有什么关系；过程编程也需要高度灵活、自适应的开发过程。如果你相信最响亮的面向对象支持者，那么过程编程将需要更灵活的过程，因为它缺少面向对象编程提供的特殊功能。“对象”和“产品功能”的含糊暗示让我认为这要么是对 OOPSLA 人群的安抚，要么是面向对象狂热早期的反映。不管怎样，我读过几本关于 Scrum 的书（包括 Schwaber 的书，其中没有提到这一点），成为一名认证 Scrum Master，并在微软内部向团队教授 Scrum 几年，我从未听说过 Scrum 不适合过程编程，也没有观察到 Scrum 中存在使用过程语言的团队独有的问题。

As an aside, the OOPSLA paper states another axiom: “Product development in an object-oriented environment requires a highly flexible, adaptive development process,” and later says, “Object Oriented technology provides the basis for the Scrum methodology. Objects, or product features, offer a discrete and manageable environment. Procedural code, with its many and intertwined interfaces, is inappropriate for the Scrum methodology.”24 I’m not sure what being object oriented has to do with it; procedural programming also required a highly flexible, adaptive development process. If you believe the loudest object-oriented supporters, procedural programming would require even more flexible processes since it is missing the special sauce that object-oriented programming provides. The vaguely implied equating of “objects” and “product features” makes me think this was either a sop to the OOPSLA crowd or reflection of the heady early days of the object-oriented frenzy. For what it’s worth, I have read several books on Scrum (including Schwaber’s, which makes no mention of this), become a Certified Scrum Master, and taught Scrum to teams inside Microsoft for several years, and I never heard that Scrum was unsuited to procedural programming or observed problems with Scrum that were unique to teams using procedural languages.

米尔斯曾经将程序员可以参加的课程描述为“常识的新名称”，虽然常识总比缺乏常识要好，但 Scrum 仍然在解决软件中最简单的问题：小团队为单个客户工作，对已经运行的软件进行渐进式改进。25这并不是说它没有用；在那些情况下，团队采取的是过时的方法，比如在获得任何客户反馈之前使用瀑布模型来提供完整的解决方案，而 Scrum 肯定可以让他们走上更好的道路。

Mills once described courses available to programmers as “new names for common sense,” and while common sense is better than a lack of it, Scrum is still tackling the easiest problem in software: small teams working for a single customer on incremental improvements to an already-functioning piece of software.25 This is not to say it is not useful; teams in those situations were taking archaic approaches, such as using a waterfall model to deliver the complete solution before getting any customer feedback, and Scrum can certainly get them on a better path.

瀑布式方法试图仔细规划项目细节并预测完成日期，而 Scrum 则表示团队将勤奋地完成项目的各个部分（Schwaber 的原始论文中“开发团队可以想出的最好方案”——意思是“相信我们，不要唠叨”），并按照正确的顺序，始终专注于在每个冲刺结束时向用户提供工作代码。敏捷方法可以防止出现拖延的长期计划，即避免长期计划。正如 Schwaber 和合著者 Mike Beedle 所解释的那样，“几项研究发现，大约三分之二的项目大大超出了他们的估计”，他们这样处理“估计和计划不周的风险”：“Scrum 通过始终提供较小的估计来管理这种风险……在冲刺周期内，Scrum 容忍并非所有冲刺目标都可能完成的事实。”26 Beck 谈到了“进度延误——交付日到来了，你却不得不告诉客户软件还要六个月才能准备好”，并解释说，“XP 要求发布周期短，最多几个月，因此任何延误的范围都是有限的。”二十七

Where waterfall attempts to plan out the details of a project carefully and predict a completion date, Scrum states that the team will work diligently on pieces of a project (the “best that a development team can devise” from Schwaber’s original paper—meaning, “trust us and stop nagging”), and in the right order, always focusing on delivering working code to the user at the end of each sprint. The Agile approach to preventing long schedules that slip is to avoid long schedules. As Schwaber and coauthor Mike Beedle explain, “Several studies have found that about two-thirds of all projects substantially overrun their estimates,” and they address the “risk of poor estimation and planning” this way: “Scrum manages this risk … by always providing small estimates. … Within the Sprint cycle, Scrum tolerates the fact that not all goals of the Sprint may be completed.”26 Beck talks about “schedule slips—the day for delivery comes, and you have to tell the customer that the software won’t be ready for another six months,” and explains, “XP calls for short release cycles, a few months at most, so the scope of any slip is limited.”27

换句话说，这些方法并没有改变软件工程师不善于估算的事实；它们只是将估算时间缩短，因此，即使百分比出现大幅下滑，从日历角度来看也不算太糟糕。公平地说，它们确实强调频繁向客户交付工作代码，这样可以根据客户需求进行方向调整，并鼓励团队成员首先完成优先级更高的工作，这是朝着正确方向迈出的一步（如果没有这种推动，他们往往会首先解决最有趣的技术问题）。敏捷的支持者准确地指出，如果一个团队团结一致，从事类似的工作，那么他们的估算能力就会提高——但这并不是新信息，也不是敏捷独有的。

In other words, these methodologies don’t change the fact that software engineers are bad at estimating; they just keep the estimates short, so that even a significant slip, in percentage terms, is not that bad in calendar terms. To be fair, they do emphasize frequent delivery of working code to customers, which allows customer-driven course correction as needed and encourages team members to complete higher-priority work first, which is a step in the right direction (absent this nudge, they would tend to tackle the most interesting technical problem first). And Agile proponents point out, accurately, that if a team stays together and works on similar kinds of work, it will become better at estimation—but that is not new information or unique to Agile.

柏拉图的《申辩》中引用了苏格拉底的话：“我比这个人聪明；我们俩可能都不知道任何有价值的东西；但他以为自己知道一些事情，其实他不知道；而当我不知道时，我也不认为我知道；所以我可能比他聪明，只是我不认为我知道我不知道的事情。”从这个意义上说，Scrum 认为软件项目本质上是不可控的，它比瀑布方法更聪明，瀑布方法建议在不知道如何控制的情况下控制它们。尽管 Scrum 的支持者可能希望听取苏格拉底的后续见解：“优秀的工匠似乎和诗人有同样的缺点：他们每个人都因为自己在手艺上的成功而认为自己在其他最重要的追求上非常聪明，而他们的这个错误掩盖了他们的智慧。”二十八

Socrates is quoted in Plato’s Apology as saying, “I am wiser than this man; it is likely that neither of us knows anything worthwhile; but he thinks he knows something when he does not; whereas when I do not know, neither do I think I know; so I am likely to be wiser than he is to this small extent, that I do not think I know what I do not know.” In this sense Scrum, which says that software projects are inherently uncontrollable, is wiser than the waterfall methodology, which proposes to control them without knowing how. Although Scrum proponents may want to heed a follow-on insight from Socrates: “The good craftsmen seemed to have the same fault as the poets: each of them, because of his success at his craft, thought himself very wise in other most important pursuits, and this error of theirs overshadows the wisdom they had.”28

敏捷并不是瀑布式的对立面，部分原因是在敏捷式出现时，真正的瀑布式并没有得到广泛使用。如果您正在寻找一种与敏捷式相去甚远的方法，那就是个人软件流程 (PSP) 和团队软件流程 (TSP)，它们是由卡内基梅隆大学的软件智库软件工程研究所 (SEI) 在 IBM 软件团队长期经理 Watts Humphrey 的指导下开发的。

Agile is not really the opposite of waterfall, partly because true waterfall wasn’t used much at the time that Agile came along. If you are looking for an approach that is as far from Agile as possible, it is the Personal Software Process (PSP) and Team Software Process (TSP), developed at the Software Engineering Institute (SEI), a software think tank at Carnegie Mellon University, under the guidance of Watts Humphrey, a longtime manager of software teams at IBM.

PSP 方法在 Humphrey 1995 年出版的《软件工程学科》一书的前言中有所阐述：

The PSP approach is laid out in the preface to Humphrey’s 1995 book A Discipline for Software Engineering:

如今，社会对软件产品的依赖已经到了无法再继续沿用过去的手艺。社会需要工程师始终坚持使用有效的规则。要做到这一点，就必须教授这些规则，让他们有机会在正规教育期间练习和完善这些规则。

如今，当学生开始编程时，他们通常从学习编程语言开始。他们通过练习小问题，培养个人技能和技巧来处理这种小问题级别的问题。……然而，这些小编程技能本质上是有限的。二十九

Society is now far too dependent on software products for us to continue with the craft-like practices of the past. It needs engineers who consistently use effective disciplines. For this to happen, they must be taught these disciplines, and have an opportunity to practice and perfect them during their formal educations.

Today, when students start to program, they generally begin by learning a programming language. They practice on toy problems and develop the personal skills and techniques to deal with issues at this toy problem level. … These programming-in-the-small skills, however, are inherently limited.29

PSP 解决方案是采用用于大规模软件开发的实践（Humphrey 在 IBM 管理着当时一些规模最大的软件开发），并将其缩小到适用于单人程序。让程序员在小型程序上使用这些技术将为他们做好适当的大规模软件开发的准备（这在 Humphrey 计划的第二阶段 TSP 中得到解决）。在这种方法中，PSP 与 Agile 完全相反，后者采用针对小型团队优化的技术，然后暗示它们将适用于更大的团队。

The PSP solution is to take practices used for large-scale software development—and Humphrey, at IBM, was managing some of the largest-scale software development of his day—and scale them down to work for single-person programs. Having programmers use these techniques on small programs would prepare them for proper large-scale software development (which is addressed in phase two of Humphrey’s plan, the TSP). In this approach, the PSP is the exact opposite of Agile, which takes techniques optimized for small teams and then implies that they will work for larger teams.

汉弗莱意识到这听起来很像劝人们多吃蔬菜，于是提出了一个小小的挑战：“PSP 是一个自我完善的过程。掌握它需要研究、学习和大量的工作。但 PSP 并不适合所有人。回想一下，PSP 旨在帮助您成为更好的软件工程师。有些人只要能胜任工作就很开心了。PSP 适合那些努力实现个人成就并乐于迎接艰巨挑战的人。”他还用一章来介绍如何坚持 PSP 课程，即使你是团队中唯一使用它的人，当你的经理和同事用异样的眼光看着你时。三十

Recognizing that this sounds a lot like exhorting people to eat their vegetables, Humphrey throws down a little challenge: “The PSP is a self-improvement process. Mastering it requires research, study, and a lot of work. But the PSP is not for everyone. Recall that the PSP is designed to help you be a better software engineer. Some people are perfectly happy just getting by on their jobs. The PSP is for people who strive for personal achievement and relish meeting a demanding challenge.” He also includes a chapter on how to stay the PSP course even if you are the only person on the team using it, when your manager and coworkers are giving you funny looks.30

PSP 在很大程度上依赖于计算三项内容（代码行数、缺陷和时间），并在其中执行各种数学计算，以便对未来进行预测。它利用了正式的代码检查（这是 IBM 的 Michael Fagan 于 1976 年首次提出的一项集体活动）。31正式检查与我们在第 3 章中遇到的单独代码审查在许多重要方面有所不同：检查员在会议之前有时间阅读代码；创建并不断更新审查中需要寻找的内容的指南；会议有一个正式的领导者来推动会议的进展；并跟踪和分析检查结果（每行代码发现的缺陷数）。三十二

The PSP relies heavily on counting three things—lines of code, defects, and time—and performing various mathematical calculations among them, so as to enable predictions about the future. It makes use of formal code inspections—a group activity first proposed by Michael Fagan from IBM in 1976.31 Formal inspections differ from the individual code reviews we encountered in chapter 3 in a variety of important ways: the inspectors are given time ahead of the meeting to read the code; guidelines on what to look for in reviews are created and kept updated; the meeting has a formal leader to keep things moving; and the results of the inspection (the number of defects found per line of code) are tracked and analyzed.32

我第一次在微软进行正式的代码审查是在 1993 年，当时我正在编写 Windows NT 中的低级网络代码。我们一群人拿着我打印的代码坐下来，开始仔细检查。那天是 1 月 20 日，比尔·克林顿总统就职典礼的那一天，也是一场风暴席卷西雅图地区并导致微软停电的那一天。我们毫不气馁，聚集在靠近窗户的会议室里——完全没有注意到一棵树倒在我们大楼外的一辆餐饮卡车上，卡车上的披萨随后被免费分发给大楼里的每个人，除了我们这些蹲在昏暗的光线中进行代码审查的人。

My first experience with any kind of formal code review at Microsoft was back in 1993, when I was working on low-level networking code in Windows NT. A group of us sat down with printouts of my code and started walking through them. The date was January 20, the day of Bill Clinton’s presidential inauguration, and the day a windstorm swept through the Seattle area and knocked out power to Microsoft. Undaunted, we gathered in a conference room near the window—and completely missed the fact that a tree had fallen on a catering truck outside our building, with the truck’s cargo of pizzas subsequently being distributed free to everybody in the building, except for those of us hunkered down doing a code review in the fading light.

除了那次创伤之外，回想起来，我发现这根本不像一次检查。没有人事先阅读过代码，也没有跟踪结果；它更像是一组基于任何可以发现的表面缺陷的并行个人代码审查。在汤姆·吉尔布和多萝西·格雷厄姆在书中转载的一份报告中，这些个人的临时代码审查被描述为“所有缺陷消除技术中效率最低但使用最多的”。33与此同时，SEI（以及 Gilb 和 Graham）的研究表明代码检查确实可以带来改进。

Beyond that trauma, I can see in retrospect that this was nothing like an inspection is supposed to be. Nobody had read the code ahead of time, and the results were not tracked; it was more like a set of parallel individual code reviews based on whatever surface-level faults could be spotted. In a report reprinted in a book by Tom Gilb and Dorothy Graham, these individual, ad hoc code reviews were described as “the least effective, but most used, of all defect removal techniques.”33 Meanwhile, SEI (and Gilb and Graham, for that matter) has research demonstrating real improvements from code inspections.

另一方面，与 Agile 一样，PSP 并没有过多地谈论如何编写代码（如何将 B 行放在 A 行之后）。它最接近谈论实际软件设计的地方是提到自上而下和自下而上的设计在不同情况下都有用，从中间开始的设计也很有用，专注于垂直切片可能是一个好主意，但分层构建整个系统也是如此。34由于是 PSP，你需要花时间预先思考你的策略，并反思它是否进展顺利，这比盲目使用与上次相同的策略要好，但并没有提供太多关于如何在新的问题领域继续前进的指导。Scrum 至少为你提供了具体的指导，让你专注于垂直切片，这在特定情况下可能是坏建议，但至少可以防止犹豫不决——因为最终，考虑到大多数项目的一次性性质，很难知道不同的设计策略是否会更好。

On the other hand, like Agile, the PSP doesn’t say much about how to write code—how to put line B after line A. The closest it gets to talking about actual software design is to mention that both top-down and bottom-up designs can be useful in different situations, as can starting in the middle, and that focusing on vertical slices can be a good idea, but so can building the entire system up in layers.34 Since it’s the PSP, you spend time thinking about your strategy up front and also ruminating about whether it went well afterward, which is better than blindly using the same strategy as the last time, but doesn’t provide much guidance on how to proceed in a new problem area. Scrum at least gives you concrete guidance, to concentrate on vertical slices, which may be bad advice in a given situation, but at least prevents dithering—since in the end, given the one-off nature of most projects, it is hard to know if a different design strategy would have worked better.

直到我在微软的工程卓越部门工作，我们在课程中讲授了一些 PSP 概念，我才接触到 PSP，但我明白为什么程序员会本能地对它望而却步。想到所有这些跟踪只是为了我个人的进步，我就头疼。想到 PSP 这本书，我的手臂肌肉就酸痛；它有 750 多页，是我所知道的最长的软件工程书籍（TSP 这本书相对来说只有 450 页）。35它用了整整 30 页的篇幅来讨论如何计算代码行数（诚然，这是编程圈中争论的话题）。根据 PSP，你应该将编译器捕获的每个语法错误都算作一个缺陷，并及时记录下来以供将来分析。修复编译错误是一项机械的、烦人的任务，但不需要那么长时间；加上记录错误的机械的、烦人的任务让我不寒而栗（而且你还应该将错误分为大约二十个不同的类别之一）。三十六

I was never exposed to the PSP until I worked in Engineering Excellence at Microsoft and we taught some of its concepts in our courses, but I can see why programmers would instinctively recoil from it. Thinking about all that tracking, just for my own personal improvement, makes my head ache. Thinking about the PSP book makes my arm muscles ache; at over 750 pages, it’s the longest software engineering book I know (the TSP book clocks in at a relatively svelte 450 pages).35 It spends an entire 30-page chapter talking about how to count lines of code (admittedly a subject of debate in programming circles). Per PSP, you are supposed to count every syntax error that the compiler catches as a defect, which is duly logged for future analysis. Fixing compilation errors is a mechanical, annoying task, but one that doesn’t take that long; adding in the mechanical, annoying task of logging the errors makes me shudder (and you are further supposed to classify the errors into one of about twenty different categories).36

PSP 圈子里甚至有人争论在第一次编译代码之前进行代码审查是否有意义，这本能地似乎是在浪费时间。为什么要花时间寻找编译器几秒钟就能发现的错误呢？PSP 数据表明，大约 10% 的你期望编译器能发现的错误并没有被发现，因为它们无意中形成了有效的语法，而这些是特别难以发现的错误，以后很难发现。37并且，在预编译器审查中可以发现所有错误，这使得代码成为一个更有针对性的领域，这使代码审查更有价值，因此更有可能受到重视。

There is even debate in PSP circles about whether it makes sense to do a code review before you compile the code the first time, which instinctively seems like a waste of time. Why spend time looking for errors that the compiler can catch in a few seconds? Ah, says the PSP data, but around 10 percent of errors that you would expect the compiler to catch are not caught because they inadvertently form valid syntax, and those are particularly sneaky bugs to figure out later.37 And having all the bugs available to be found in a pre-compiler review makes the code a more target-rich area, which makes the code review more rewarding and hence more likely to be taken seriously.

这一切确实有一定的道理；按类型对编译器错误进行分类可能是一项艰巨的工作，但如果我意识到自己比其他人更容易犯某些类型的错误，我就可以集中精力避免这些错误并提高效率，然而……我不认为自己是那种“只满足于工作”的人，用 Humphrey 的指责性话语来说，但我可以理解为什么在工程卓越中，我们的 Scrum 课程比我们受 PSP 启发的估算和检查课程更受欢迎，我觉得这两者在微软内部都比 Scrum 培训更有意义。当你通过自学取得了一定程度的成功时，接受像 Scrum 这样的方法要容易得多，因为它说即使要求你做的跟踪数量有限，也会不必要地束缚你，而像 PSP 这样的方法则说你需要做更多的事情。

It all does make a certain sense; classifying compiler errors by type could be a lot of work, but if I realize that I make specific kinds of mistakes more than others, I can focus on avoiding those and become more efficient, and yet. … I don’t consider myself somebody who is “just happy getting by on their jobs,” in Humphrey’s accusatory phrase, but I can well understand why in Engineering Excellence our Scrum courses had much better uptake than our PSP-inspired estimation and inspection courses, both of which I felt were more relevant inside Microsoft than Scrum training. When you’ve achieved a level of success being self-taught, it is much easier to accept a methodology like Scrum, which says that even the limited amount of tracking you are being asked to do is unnecessarily hobbling you, than one like PSP, which says that you need to do more of it.

要使 PSP 成为一种自然的秩序，尽早灌输是有益的，但对于许多程序员来说，“尽早”是指高中时期；很少有人会担心 PSP 之类的东西，即使他们听说过它。此外，PSP 的理念是将适合大型项目的流程缩小到小型程序，除了作为未来大型程序工作的培训外，这些流程并不需要，这使得 PSP 很难推广。卡内基梅隆大学（SEI 的附属大学）甚至不向本科生教授 PSP。

For PSP to take hold as the natural order of things it would be helpful for it to be instilled early on, but for many programmers, “early on” is during high school; few people trying to hack out a quick mobile app or website are going to worry about something like PSP, if they have even heard of it. Also, the idea built into the PSP of taking processes appropriate to large-scale projects and scaling them down to small programs, where they are not needed except as training for future work on large programs, makes PSP a tough sell. It is not even taught to undergraduates at Carnegie Mellon, the university with which SEI is associated.

从根本上讲，Scrum 和 Agile 总体上都是乐观的：假设事情会进展顺利，信任你的团队，并在必要时修复流程。PSP 和其他命令和控制技术是悲观的：假设除非你投入大量时间来预防问题，否则事情会变得非常糟糕。作为一名经理，我更喜欢采取乐观的态度，我认为为我工作的人也欣赏这一点。但我们仍然做了很多规划和跟踪，远远超出了任何 Agile 方法所建议的范围。

Fundamentally, Scrum in particular and Agile in general are optimistic: assume things will go well, trust your team, and fix the process if needed. PSP and other command-and-control techniques are pessimistic: assume things will go terribly wrong unless you invest a significant percentage of your time in preventing problems. As a manager, I much preferred taking an optimistic approach, and I think the people who worked for me appreciated it too. But we still did a lot of planning and tracking that went well beyond what any Agile methodology would recommend.

Agile 正确地认识到，在目前的估算和软件工程技术条件下，试图预先确定软件项目需要多长时间是徒劳的。在 Scrum 和 XP 为程序员提供让他们放弃的借口之前，管理人员最喜欢的策略是在项目早期要求程序员进行估算，当时他们对项目的细节还不够了解，无法做出合理的估算，然后要求程序员只做那个凭感觉的估算。在一本关于软件估算的书（恰如其分地命名为《揭开黑色艺术的神秘面纱》）中，Steve McConnell 写到了不确定性锥：事实上，软件估算的误差范围一开始很大，但随着您开始对如何实施工作进行更多调查，误差范围会逐渐缩小，并且在开始编码后会进一步缩小。38让程序员提供锥体最宽部分的估算，然后再也不去查看，这是最糟糕的方法。（他进一步指出，让个别程序员提供估算，而不是尝试“群体智慧”方法，即要求多个人提供估算，即使他们不是做这项工作的人，也会进一步导致估算不准确，无论他们在锥体的哪个点完成。）三十九

Agile is correct in recognizing that trying to figure out up front how long a software project will take, given our current techniques for both estimation and software engineering, is a fool’s errand. A favored tactic of managers, before Scrum and XP gave programmers the cover needed to tell them to butt out, was to ask a programmer for an estimate in the early days of a project, when they didn’t yet know enough about its details to be able to make a decent estimate, and then hold the programmer to that seat-of-the-pants estimate. In a book on software estimation (appropriately subtitled Demystifying the Black Art), Steve McConnell writes about the Cone of Uncertainty: the fact that the error range for software estimates starts out large, yet gradually shrinks as you begin to do more investigation into how you will implement the work, and shrinks even further after coding begins.38 Asking a programmer to provide an estimate at the widest part of the cone, and then never revisiting it, is the worst-possible approach. (He further points out that having individual programmers supply estimates, rather than trying a “wisdom of the crowds” approach of asking multiple people for an estimate even if they won’t be the ones doing the work, further contributes to the inaccuracy of estimations, no matter at what point on the cone they are done.)39

特雷西·基德（Tracy Kidder）在其获得普利策奖的著作《新机器的灵魂》中描述了 20 世纪 70 年代末数据通用公司设计新型小型计算机的过程。书中，他描述了早期的估算如何成为定论：

In The Soul of a New Machine, his Pulitzer-Prize-winning book about the engineering of a new minicomputer at a company called Data General in the late 1970s, Tracy Kidder describes how early estimates became etched in stone:

似乎有一个神秘的入会仪式，几乎团队的每个成员都要通过这个仪式。老手们用这个仪式的术语——韦斯特发明了这个词，而不是这种做法——是“签约”。通过签约，你同意为成功做一切必要的事情。如果有必要，你同意放弃家庭、爱好和朋友——如果你还有的话（如果你之前签约太多次，你可能不会放弃）。从经理的角度来看，这个仪式的实际好处是多方面的。员工不再是被强迫的。员工是自愿的。40

There was, it appeared, a mysterious rite of initiation through which, in one way or another, almost every member of the team passed. The term that the old hands used for this rite—West invented the term, not the practice—was “signing up.” By signing up for the project you agreed to do whatever was necessary for success. You agreed to forsake, if necessary, family, hobbies, and friends—if you had any of these left (and you might not if you had signed up too many times before). From a manager’s point of view, the practical virtues of the ritual were manifold. Labor was no longer coerced. Labor volunteered.40

在 2000 年对一家高科技公司的研究中，奥弗·沙罗内 (Ofer Sharone) 提到了这种情况，即员工自我施加人们期望来自其经理的工作压力，这是他所谓的“竞争性自我管理”的一部分，这可能会“导致 [公司] 工程师对其专业能力产生强烈焦虑”。41另一部分是按照严格的曲线对员工绩效进行评估；我不知道这在 Data General 是否有效，但在许多软件公司肯定是有效的。

In a 2000 study of a high-tech company, Ofer Sharone referred to this situation, in which employees self-impose the type of workplace pressure that one would expect to come from their managers, as one part of what he calls “competitive self-management,” which can “engender intense anxiety among [the company’s] engineers regarding their professional competence.”41 The other part is grading employee performance on a rigid curve; I don’t know if this was in effect at Data General, but it certainly is at a lot of software companies.

《新机器的灵魂》讲的是硬件开发，但它仍然提供了我所读过的最准确的描述，描述了从事大型“版本 1”软件项目的情况。创建新计算机的第一个版本（它是 Data General 的第一台 32 位小型计算机）是一项孤注一掷的努力；你不能只交付一半的计算机。结果是压力很大，工作时间很长，包括这幅描绘程序员 Dave Epstein 和他的老板 Ed Rasala 之间“签约”的场景：

The Soul of a New Machine was about hardware development, but it still provides the most accurate depiction I have ever read of what it is like to work on a large “version 1” software project. Creating the first version of a new computer (it was Data General’s first 32-bit minicomputer) is an all-or-nothing endeavor; you can’t ship half a computer. The result was high pressure and long hours, including this portrait of “signing up” in action, between a programmer named Dave Epstein and his boss, Ed Rasala:

几周前，埃德·拉萨拉问爱泼斯坦：“你要花多长时间？”

爱泼斯坦回答说：“大约两个月。”

“两个月？”拉萨拉说。“哦，得了吧。”

于是爱泼斯坦告诉他，“好的，六周。”

爱泼斯坦觉得自己是在给自己写死亡令。六个星期似乎不够，所以他在这里呆了半个晚上处理这件事，而且进展比他想象的要快。这让他非常高兴，刚才他走到走廊对拉萨拉说：“嘿，艾德，我想我会在四个星期内完成。”

“哦，太好了，”拉萨拉说。

现在，回到自己的办公室，爱泼斯坦才意识到，“我刚刚签约要在四周内完成这件事。”

最好快点，戴夫。四十二

Some weeks ago, Ed Rasala asked Epstein, “How long will it take you?”

Epstein replied, “About two months.”

“Two months?” Rasala said. “Oh, come on.”

So Epstein told him, “Okay, six weeks.”

Epstein felt as if he were writing his own death warrant. Six weeks didn’t look like enough time, so he’s been staying here half the night working on the thing, and it’s going faster than he thought it would. This has made him so happy that just a moment ago he went down the hall and told Rasala, “Hey, Ed, I think I’m gonna do it in four weeks.”

“Oh, good,” Rasala said.

Now, back in his cubicle, Epstein has just realized, “I just signed up to do it in four weeks.”

Better hurry, Dave.42

有句关于软件的笑话：“前 90% 的工作占用了 90% 的时间。最后 10% 占用了另外 90% 的时间。”由于估算几乎总是在增长而不是减少，因为在实施过程中会发现新的未说明的工作，因此在早期（不确定性锥最宽时）要求程序员进行估算，最终会让程序员接受过于激进的时间表。然而，管理人员可以为此辩解，因为他们在做一件高尚的事情，根据程序员自己的估算制定时间表，而不是从上级那里强制执行。

There is a joke about software: “The first 90 percent of the work takes 90 percent of the time. The last 10 percent takes the other 90 percent.” Since estimates almost always grow rather than shrink, as new unaccounted-for work is discovered during the implementation, asking programmers for an estimate early on, when the Cone of Uncertainty is at its widest, winds up committing the programmer to a schedule that is too aggressive. Yet managers can justify it because they are doing the noble thing and building up a schedule from the programmers’ own estimates as opposed to mandating one from above.

Schwaber 和 Beck 大概也感受到了这种痛苦。Schwaber 和 Beedle 很清楚，估算仅用于规划冲刺，不具有约束力。43贝克规定每周工作 40 小时，但有少数例外：“XP 规则很简单——你不能连续第二周加班。一个星期，没问题，继续努力，多加班。如果你周一来上班，说‘为了达到目标，我们必须再次加班’，那么你已经遇到了一个无法通过加班来解决的问题。”44 （在上面《新机器的灵魂》的摘录中，爱泼斯坦确实在他签约的四周内完成了他的项目，尽管显然他每周工作时间超过四十个小时。）

Schwaber and Beck had presumably felt the pain of this. Schwaber and Beedle are clear that estimates are only for planning out a sprint and are not considered binding.43 Beck mandates a forty-hour week, with few exceptions: “The XP rule is simple—you can’t work a second week of overtime. For one week, fine, crank and put in some extra hours. If you come in Monday and say, ‘To meet our goal, we’ll have to work late again,’ then you already have a problem that can’t be solved by working more hours.”44 (Epstein, in the excerpt from The Soul of a New Machine above, did finish his project in the four weeks he signed up for, although clearly working more than forty hours a week.)

我承认，当我读到《新机器的灵魂》时，我并没有因为书中对签约工程师疯狂加班的描述而感到厌烦，而是想参与这样一个项目。这不仅仅是光荣离职的概念。像这样的项目，考虑到交付的紧迫性，承诺可以自由地做需要做的事情，绕过你认为阻碍的任何规则或惯例。这与 Agile 向程序员承诺的自由是一样的——只是我们花了比 Schwaber、Beedle 和 Beck 建议的更多的时间来享受这种自由。我最终参与了这样一个项目，从 1990 年到 1994 年，我参与了 Windows NT 的前两个版本。但一旦完成，我就不再签约，而是在微软内部寻找更温和的项目。尽管《新机器的灵魂》这样的故事给人的印象是疯狂加班是一项英勇的事业，但当它发生在软件上时，它会产生仓促和质量低劣的代码，客户会发现大量的错误。特别是，人们很容易忽视对错误情况的处理：这些代码很少运行，但在需要时却是最关键的部分。

I confess that when I read The Soul of a New Machine, rather than being turned off by the descriptions of signed-up engineers working crazy hours, I wanted to be involved in such a project. It wasn’t just the notion of going out in a blaze of glory. A project like that, given the urgency to deliver, promised a freedom to do what was needed, bypassing whatever rules or conventions you felt were in the way. It was the same freedom that Agile promises to programmers—it’s just that we spent a lot more time savoring that freedom than Schwaber, Beedle, and Beck recommend. I was eventually on such a project, working on the first two versions of Windows NT from 1990 to 1994. But once that was completed, I was done with signing up and looked for mellower projects within Microsoft. Despite the impression from a story like The Soul of a New Machine that working crazy hours is a heroic undertaking, when it happens with software, it produces code that is rushed and poor quality, with a long tail of bugs for customers to uncover. In particular, the temptation is great to gloss over the handling of error cases: code that rarely runs, but is the most critical part when it is needed.

敏捷方法只提供简短的估算，不给程序员施加压力，显然比提供详细的估算、在程序员的额头上盖章，然后仍然无法完成总体进度要好。然而，如果你退一步来看，这掩盖了一个更根本的问题。Scrum 不是管理软件项目的进步方式；它是对当前软件开发状态的合理反应，它试图通过不向客户过度承诺来控制损害。某种版本的瀑布式开发是工程项目应该采用的方式；这是任何“真正的”工程项目都旨在实现的目标，因为理想情况下，你会知道足够多的信息来预测问题并做出相应的计划，并能够根据类似项目的先前经验准确地安排工作。重视“响应变化而不是遵循计划”是另一种说法，“不要指望我能预测我会做什么”，这是当前的现实，但我希望事情不要一直这样。因为虽然有些变化是因为客户看到了软件并意识到他们不喜欢它，但很多变化是因为意识到客户看不到的内部实现细节需要重新设计——并且无法提前认识到你走错了路，这使得软件开发变得不可预测。

The Agile approach of only providing short estimates and not holding programmers’ feet to the fire is clearly better than offering long estimates, stamping them on programmers’ foreheads, and then missing the overall schedule anyway. Yet if you step back, this glosses over a more fundamental problem. Scrum is not a progressive way of managing software projects; it’s a logical reaction to the current state of software development, which attempts to contain the damage by not overpromising to customers. Some version of waterfall is the way engineering projects should work; it’s what any “real” engineering project is aiming to achieve, because ideally you would know enough to anticipate issues and plan accordingly, and be able to schedule out the work accurately based on previous experience on similar projects. Valuing “responding to change over following a plan” is another way of saying “don’t expect me to be able to predict what I will get done,” which is the current reality, but I hope things don’t stay that way. Because while some change is due to customers seeing the software and realizing they don’t like it, a lot is due to realizing that your internal implementation details, which the customer can’t see, need to be reworked—and being unable to recognize ahead of time that you are going down the wrong path makes software development unpredictable.

您可能已经阅读过有关 Scrum、产品待办事项和燃尽图的内容，并认为“嘿，我对软件一无所知，但这些东西很有道理。”这强调了一个事实，即 Scrum 并未提及如何实际设计软件；它专注于通过快速迭代获得客户反馈。早在 1990 年，Mary Shaw 就写过关于所谓的软件工程的文章：“不幸的是，这个术语现在最常用于指生命周期模型、常规方法、成本估算技术、文档框架、配置管理工具、质量保证技术和其他标准化生产活动的技术。这些技术是商业发展阶段的特征——‘软件管理’是一个更合适的术语。”45 Scrum 完全属于软件管理类别，而不是软件工程类别。

You may have read about Scrum, the product backlog, and the burndown chart, and thought, “Hey, I know nothing about software, but those things make sense.” Which emphasizes the fact that Scrum has nothing to say about how to actually engineer software; it is focused on getting customer feedback through rapid iterations. Mary Shaw wrote about quote-unquote software engineering back in 1990 that “unfortunately, the term is now most often used to refer to life-cycle models, routine methodologies, cost-estimation techniques, documentation frameworks, configuration-management tools, quality-assurance techniques, and other techniques for standardizing production activities. These technologies are characteristic of the commercial stage of evolution—‘software management’ would be a much more appropriate term.”45 Scrum fits right into the software management category, not the software engineering category.

我确实赞扬 Agile 认识到了有关编程的一个重要事实，而以前的方法往往忽略了这一事实：代码被大量阅读。

I do give Agile credit for acknowledging one important fact about programming, which previous methodologies tended to ignore: code is read a lot.

文献中并没有完全忽视代码阅读的重要性。IBM 员工的结构化编程一书中有一章很长的关于代码阅读的内容，并附有案例研究，开头写道：“有条不紊地准确阅读程序的能力是编程的一项关键技能。程序阅读是修改和验证他人编写的程序、从文献中选择和调整程序设计以及验证自己程序的正确性的基础。”46 Mills 在《软件生产力》一书中有一章题为“将阅读代码作为一项管理活动”（1972 年，早于他与他人合著《结构化编程》一书）。他预测“PL/I 中将出现一种新的可能性：程序员可以并且应该阅读他人编写的程序，这不是紧急情况，而是编程过程中的正常程序。”47 Weinberg 在《计算机编程心理学》一书中也有一章专门讨论阅读程序。48顺便提一下，我的上一本书《寻找错误》也谈到了如何阅读代码。49在《Microsoft Secrets》中，一位 Excel 工程师称赞匈牙利语对代码阅读的积极影响：“匈牙利语让我们能够直接阅读代码。……能流利地说匈牙利语几乎就像是一位希腊学者。你拿起某样东西，就能读懂它。”50这句话的实际内容与现实有些出入，但它确实表明阅读代码是程序员所做、所关心的一项活动，并且试图（在这种情况下是徒劳的）使其变得更容易。

The significance of code reading has not been completely missed in the literature. The IBMers’ Structured Programming book has a long chapter on code reading, complete with case studies, which begins, “The ability to read programs methodically and accurately is a crucial skill in programming. Program reading is the basis for modifying and validating programs written by others, for selecting and adapting program designs from the literature, and for verifying the correctness of one’s own programs.”46 Mills, in Software Productivity, has a chapter titled “Reading Code as a Management Activity” (from 1972, thus predating his coauthorship of the Structured Programming book). He anticipates “a new possibility in PL/I: that programmers can and should read programs written by others, not in traumatic emergencies, but as a matter of normal procedure in the programming process.”47 Weinberg, in The Psychology of Computer Programming, also has a chapter on reading programs.48 I’ll mention in passing that my previous book, Find the Bug, talks about how to read code too.49 In Microsoft Secrets, an engineer on Excel praises Hungarian for its salutatory effect on code reading: “Hungarian gives us the ability to just go in and read code. … Being fluent in Hungarian is almost like being a Greek scholar or something. You pick up something and you can read it.”50 The actual content in that quote is somewhat divergent from reality, but it does show that reading code was an activity that programmers did and cared about, and tried (in vain, in this case) to make easier.

在传统的瀑布式编程中，目标是编写要生产的整个系统的代码，然后将其交给测试。如果发现错误，程序员可能会经历重新查看代码的痛苦，但如果不再查看代码，这将被视为正常现象，甚至是一个积极的信号。

In classic waterfall programming, the goal was to write the code for the entire system you were going to produce and then hand it off to testing. If bugs were found, the programmer might experience the tribulation of revisiting the code, but it would be considered normal and even a positive sign if it were never looked at again.

在敏捷中，其重点是在 YAGNI 的旗帜下提供小规模的功能增量，人们认为代码最终会在“您确实需要它”时进行修改；编写新的垂直切片来触及现有代码，并在称为重构的过程中发现安排最终整体的更好方法。代码并不意味着编写一次就永远不会再被触及；远非如此。与其将其解读为“我们第一次就做对了”，不如将其解读为“我们可能没有回应客户，我们的代码正在发霉”。正如 Beck 所说，“没有重构的一天就像没有阳光的一天。”51认识到代码会经常被阅读和修改，这是与旧方法论截然不同的重要思维转变。

In Agile, with its focus on delivering small increments of functionality under the YAGNI banner, it is understood that the code will be modified eventually, when “You Do Need It”; new vertical slices are written that touch existing code, and better ways to arrange the resulting whole are discovered in a process known as refactoring. Code is not meant to be written once and then never touched again; far from it. Rather than interpret this as “we got it right the first time,” it would be seen as “we are probably not responding to our customers, and our code is getting moldy.” As Beck put it, “A day without refactoring is like a day without sunshine.”51 The recognition that code is going to be read and modified often is an important mental switch from older methodologies.

最极端的基于重构的敏捷方法被称为测试驱动开发，它不仅要求为所有代码编写单元测试，而且还要求在编写要测试的代码之前先编写单元测试。此外，您严格交替编写一个测试和编写代码以使该测试通过 - 不能提前窥视！YAGNI 是口头禅，因此如果您编写代码来为保龄球比赛计分（这是标准的测试驱动开发示例），并且您的第一个单元测试涉及一场全中比赛，那么您当时的实际产品代码应该如下所示：

The most extreme refactoring-based Agile approach is known as test-driven development, which mandates not only that unit tests be written for all code but also that unit tests be written first, before the code they are going to test. Furthermore, you strictly alternate between writing one test and writing the code to make that test pass—with no peeking ahead! YAGNI is the mantra, so if you were writing the code to score a game of bowling (which is the standard test-driven development example), and your first unit test involved a game that was all strikes, your actual product code at that point should look something like this:

int ScoreGame(Board b) {
    return 300;
}
int ScoreGame(Board b) {
    return 300;
}

你看到我做了什么了吗？当然，一旦你编写了第二个单元测试，测试的不是全能游戏，你就需要编写代码来根据参数对游戏进行实际评分Board，而不仅仅是硬编码一个满足第一个测试的 300 分。

Do you see what I did there? Naturally once you wrote a second unit test, which tested something other than a game of all strikes, you would need to write code to actually score the game based on the Board parameter, not just hard code a score of 300 that satisfied the first test.

我对 Agile 最大的担忧是，它目前主导着编程方法论的讨论，但只涵盖了软件工程师可能遇到的一小部分问题。在整章中，该单行方法是唯一需要的代码示例。尽管如此，Agile 仍被誉为编程项目的救星；正如 Schwaber 和 Beedle 在他们的书中所写的那样，“我们在本书中提供的案例研究将表明，Scrum 不会带来边际生产力提升，例如产生 5-25% 效率的流程改进。当我们说 Scrum 提供更高的生产力时，我们通常指的是高出几个数量级，即高出几个 100%。”52实际的案例研究至少可以说不尽如人意（特别是因为它们是精心挑选的，而不是受控的实验），但 Scrum 仍然受到热切的程序员群体的青睐。

My biggest concern about Agile is that it currently dominates the programming methodology discussion while only covering a narrow subset of the problems that software engineers can hit. In this entire chapter, that one-line method was the only code sample needed. Despite this, Agile is pitched as the savior of programming projects; as Schwaber and Beedle wrote in their book, “The case studies we provide in this book will show that Scrum doesn’t provide marginal productivity gains like process improvements that yield 5–25% efficiencies. When we say Scrum provides higher productivity, we often mean several orders of magnitude higher, i.e., several 100 percents higher.”52 The actual case studies are underwhelming, to say the least (especially since they are handpicked, not controlled experiments), but Scrum still sells to an eager audience of programmers.

之前，我讨论了软件理念起源的转变，早期始于大学，然后转移到企业研究实验室，然后转向企业产品组。敏捷是这一趋势的下一个演变。尽管它的发明者最初是程序员，他们的工作是编写程序，但他们很快就变成了顾问，他们的产品就是敏捷知识本身。与许多其他给程序员的建议一样，敏捷不是基于任何研究或经验观察，而是人们在自己的工作中注意到的。

Earlier, I discussed the shift in the origin of software ideas, starting with universities in the early days, then moving to corporate research labs, and then turning to corporate product groups. Agile is the next evolution of this trend. Although its inventors began as programmers whose business was writing programs, they quickly morphed into consultants whose product was Agile knowledge itself. As with much other advice to programmers, Agile was not based on any research studies or empirical observation beyond what people noticed in their own work.

学术界尤其与敏捷几乎毫无关系。原因很容易理解：敏捷的新术语和夸大的承诺，可能给人一种时尚的印象，大学会避免这种时尚。这反过来又让大学在敏捷实践者眼中显得缓慢而古板，在受到敏捷影响的新大学毕业生眼中可能也是如此。为了弥补这一差距，缺少的是更多的研究，即敏捷实践究竟何时有用，何时无用。测试驱动开发之类的方法在某些情况下无疑有用，但并非在所有情况下都有用，因此它必然被提出作为解决方案。这为任何争论的双方提供了充足的弹药。

Academia, in particular, has almost nothing to do with Agile. It’s easy to see why: with its new terminology and overhyped promises, Agile can come across as a fad, which universities would want to avoid. This in turn makes universities seem slow and stodgy to Agile practitioners, and possibly to new college graduates who fall under the sway of Agile. What is missing, to mend this gap, is more research on when exactly Agile practices are helpful, and when they are not. A methodology such as test-driven development is no doubt useful in some situations, but not in every one, which it perforce is proposed as a solution to. This provides ample ammunition for both sides of any argument.

2007 年，斯科特·罗森伯格出版了《代码之梦》一书，书中他与一群经验丰富的程序员一起尝试编写应用程序的第一个版本：一个名叫钱德勒的个人信息管理器。不幸的是，他碰巧加入了一个功能失调的团队。许多成员都受到之前成功的影响，无法区分真正促成成功的因素和无关紧要或完全错误的因素。他们都以不同的方式相信“如果我们只做这件事，那么软件开发的正常复杂性将不适用”这一谬论。

In 2007, Scott Rosenberg published the book Dreaming in Code, in which he embedded himself with a well-credentialed group of programmers trying to write version 1 of an application: a personal information manager named Chandler. He unfortunately happened on a somewhat-dysfunctional team. Many of the members were tainted by previous success in that they were unable to distinguish factors that had legitimately contributed to that success from factors that didn’t matter or were actively wrong. They all believed, in different ways, in the fallacy “if we just do this one thing, then the normal complications of software development won’t apply.”

尽管如此，罗森伯格在软件方面拥有足够的个人经验，他意识到他们的行为并非完全不典型。在某个时候，他举手投降：“当我跟踪钱德勒断断续续的进展，看着项目机器发出嘶嘶声和咳嗽声时，我不断回想起自己在软件时间的经历：不可能总是这样。一定有人已经弄清楚了这些事情。”然后，他用一章的篇幅徘徊在我在这里介绍的一些相同的后巷，包括设计模式、XP 和 PSP。罗森伯格总结道：“我不能说我寻找更好的软件制作方法的探索非常成功”，但他补充说：“我不认为方法论贩子是骗子。”53只是，这些解决方案对于像 Chandler 这样的大型复杂项目没有帮助。Rosenberg 最终厌倦了等待，他的书比 Chandler 先出版。

Nonetheless, Rosenberg had enough personal experience with software to realize that their behaviors were not completely atypical. At a certain point he throws up his hands: “As I followed Chandler’s fitful progress and watched the project’s machinery sputter and cough, I kept circling back to the reactions I’d had to my own experiences with software time: It can’t always be like this. Somebody must have figured this stuff out.” He then spends a chapter wandering around some of the same back alleys I have covered here, including design patterns, XP, and PSP. Rosenberg concludes, “I can’t say that my quest to find better ways of making software was very successful,” but qualifies this by saying, “I don’t think the methodology peddlers are snake oil salespeople.”53 It’s just that the solutions being proposed don’t help with a large, complicated project like Chandler. Rosenberg eventually got tired of waiting, and his book appeared before Chandler did.

敏捷的最新形式之一是软件工程方法与理论 (SEMAT) 计划，该计划旨在“确定软件工程的共同基础……表现为适用于所有软件开发工作的一系列基本要素的核心”。SEMAT 在一本副标题为《应用 SEMAT 内核》的书中进行了介绍，但其标题更为宏大，为《软件工程的本质》。像任何好的长篇大论一样，它具有行动号召，其中指出：

One of the most recent flavors of Agile is the Software Engineering Methods and Theory (SEMAT) initiative, created “to identify a common ground for software engineering … manifested as a kernel of essential elements that are universal to all software development efforts.” SEMAT is introduced in a book subtitled Applying the SEMAT Kernel, but with a more ambitious title, The Essence of Software Engineering. Like any good jeremiad, it features a call to action, which states:

如今，软件工程的发展因不成熟的实践而受到严重阻碍。具体问题包括：

  • 时尚潮流的盛行更像是时尚行业的现象， 而不是工程学科的现象
  • – 缺乏完善的、被广泛接受的理论基础
  • – 方法和方法变体的数量巨大，其中的差异很少被理解且被人为地放大
  • – 缺乏可靠的实验评估和验证
  • – 行业实践与学术研究之间的分歧54

Software engineering is gravely hampered today by immature practices. Specific problems include:

  • – The prevalence of fads more typical of a fashion industry than of an engineering discipline
  • – The lack of a sound, widely accepted theoretical basis
  • – The huge number of methods and method variants, with differences little understood and artificially magnified
  • – The lack of credible experimental evaluation and validation
  • – The split between industry practice and academic research54

正如我在类似情况下所写的那样，很难反驳所有这些。SEMAT 建议如何解决这个问题？至少在最初，它并没有真正进行任何实验评估和验证。正如程序员兼前教授 Greg Wilson 在 SPLASH 2013 会议的“Two Solitudes”主题演讲中所评论的那样，SEMAT 的书没有引用任何实证研究。55相反，在三篇前言和最后的十二页推荐信之间，它试图将软件过程管理方法的共同部分抽象为元方法，然后可以使用元方法诊断实际方法中的缺陷。鉴于敏捷已经与软件工程的实际问题有所脱节，退后一步并不能让你更接近本质。

As I’ve written in similar situations, it’s hard to argue with all that. How does SEMAT propose to address this? Not, initially anyway, by actually doing any experimental evaluation and validation. As programmer and former professor Greg Wilson comments in his “Two Solitudes” keynote talk from the SPLASH 2013 conference, the SEMAT book doesn’t cite a single empirical study.55 Instead, between the three forewords and twelve pages of testimonials at the end, it attempts to abstract out the common parts of software process management methodologies into a metamethodology, which could then be used to diagnose flaws in your actual methodology. Given that Agile is already somewhat removed from the actual problems of software engineering, taking a step back does not get you any closer to the essence.

然而，它确实提出了关于敏捷的一个观点。对某些人来说，软件的问题与流程管理有关：确保需求正确、利益相关者参与其中，并有合适的团队到位。软件的实际编写是留给读者的练习。对于这些读者来说，像 SEMAT 这样的东西正在更接近软件工程的本质。

Yet it does bring up a point about Agile. To some people, the problems with software relate to process management: making sure the requirements are correct, stakeholders are involved, and right team is in place. The actual writing of the software is an exercise left to the reader. For this audience, something like SEMAT is moving closer to the essence of software engineering.

我并没有低估这一切的重要性。敏捷技术起源于从事合同工作的顾问；它可以帮助您专注于客户，因为除非客户喜欢您交付的产品，否则您将无法获得报酬。这种以客户为中心的理念经常被程序员忽视，他们认为客户的变更请求是他们反复无常的“狡猾”的证据，而不是让他们满意的必要步骤。在微软的工程卓越中，我们研究了一个称为人类绩效改进的领域，用于分析微软团队。人类绩效改进的关键原则之一是“将表现良好的人放在糟糕的系统中，系统每次都会获胜。”56换句话说，人们从环境中获得的输入对他们的表现的影响比他们自己带来的输入更大。拥有良好的需求和参与的利益相关者是程序员工作环境的关键部分。

I am not minimizing the importance of all that. The Agile techniques originated with consultants who were working on contract work; it helps you concentrate on the customer when you won’t get paid unless they like what you deliver. This customer focus had often been ignored by programmers, who viewed customer change requests as evidence of their fickle “luserness,” not a necessary step in making them happy. In Engineering Excellence at Microsoft, we studied a field known as human performance improvement, to be used in analyzing Microsoft teams. One of the key tenets of human performance improvement contends, “Put a good performer in a bad system, and the system will win every time.”56 In other words, the inputs people get from the environment have a greater impact on their performance than what they themselves bring to the table. Having good requirements and involved stakeholders is a critical part of the environment in which programmers operate.

但对于很多软件工程师来说，这已经决定了；规范已经写好，团队也已经选好，现在需要编写代码。随着工程变得复杂，敏捷往往会逐渐消失。如果你有一个团队，每天都可以在一个房间里开会，那么它的项目就足够小，可以通过单元测试来测试大部分工作；如果团队在项目期间一直在一起，就不会遇到调用不明确的 API 的神秘问题，因为编写 API 的人可能和团队在同一个房间里。Schwaber 和 Beedle 在讨论其他人需要学习团队编写的代码的问题时，提出了一个简单但不切实际的解决方案：“[我们]制定了以下政策：谁写代码谁就永远拥有它。”57我想，从团队的角度来看，如果他们对时间的感知在他们停止工作后就停止了，就像一种反向大爆炸，那么代码就可以永远被拥有。58不幸的是，顾客没有这种奢侈。

But for a lot of software engineers, this has already been decided; the spec is written, the team is chosen, and now code needs to be written. Agile tends to peter out just as the engineering gets complicated. If you have a team that can meet every day in a room, its project is small enough that it can test most of its work via unit tests; and if the team stays together for the duration of a project, it won’t hit mysterious problems calling unclear API because the person who wrote the API is probably in the room with the team. Schwaber and Beedle, discussing the issue of other people needing to learn the code that the team has written, came up with a simple yet impractical solution: “[We] instituted the following policy: whoever writes code owns it forever.”57 I suppose from the team’s perspective the code can be owned forever, if their perception of time ceases once they stop working on it, in a sort of reverse big bang.58 Unfortunately, customers don’t have this luxury.

软件的复杂性比这类项目更大、持续时间更长。虽然敏捷可能会让简单的问题变得容易一些，但它对解决难题却没有帮助。它对程序员很有吸引力，但要让软件工程更像一门工程学科，还需要其他东西。

The complications of software happen at larger and longer scale than those sorts of projects. While Agile may make easy problems a bit easier, it doesn’t help with the hard problems. It’s appealing to programmers, but to make software engineering more of an engineering discipline, something else is needed.

笔记

2.  Mitch Lacey，“敏捷宣言的历史”（未注明日期的博客文章），2018 年 1 月 11 日访问，http://www.mitchlacey.com/blog/the-history-of-the-agile-manifesto。
