58.  “人们很容易将大爆炸想象成一场音乐会的开场。你坐着摆弄了一会儿程序，然后突然在t = 0时音乐响起。但这种类比是错误的。……宇宙开端的奇点不是时间事件。相反，它是一个时间边界或边缘。在t = 0之前没有时间时刻。……正如格伦鲍姆喜欢说的那样，尽管宇宙的年龄是有限的，但它一直存在，如果你所说的“一直”是指在所有时间瞬间。”吉姆·霍尔特，《世界为何存在？》（伦敦：WW Norton，2012 年），第 75 页。

10 

黄金时代

10 

The Golden Age

如果你和我一样，你梦想有一天软件工程能以一种深思熟虑、系统的方式进行研究，给程序员的指导建立在实验结果的基础上，而不是个人经验的流沙之上。也许有了时光机，我们就可以穿越到未来，生活在这样的世界里。

If you’re like me, you dream of a day when software engineering is studied in a thoughtful, methodical way, and the guidance given to programmers sits atop a foundation of experimental results rather than the shifting sands of individual experience. Perhaps with a time machine, it would be possible to travel into the future and live in such a world.

有点令人惊讶的是，还有另一种方法。它仍然需要一台时间机器，但你可以将它指向相反的方向，即过去。准确地说，是大约 45 年前。

Somewhat surprisingly, there is another way. It still requires a time machine, but you would point it in the opposite direction, toward the past. About forty-five years in the past to be precise.

在 20 世纪 70 年代初下车并找到最近的计算机书店后，你会发现自己正处于软件工程研究的黄金时期。那个时代的书籍​​探讨了我们今天面临的每一个问题，尽管那个时期的出现早于几乎所有仍在运行的软件。UNIX 的第一项工作始于 1969 年；C 语言发明于 1971 年。基本上，之前的所有东西——运行用 COBOL 和 Fortran 等语言编写的程序的大型机系统——都被取代了，而 Y2K 危机为许多软件的棺材钉上了最后一颗钉子。由于那个时代的软件在功能上已经过时，人们很容易将同一时期的研究视为同样过时的研究。

After alighting in the early 1970s and locating the nearest computer bookstore, you would discover that you were in the middle of a fertile time for software engineering research. Books from that era wrestle with every problem that confronts us today, despite the fact that this period predates almost every piece of software still running. The first work on UNIX began in 1969; C was invented in 1971. Essentially everything that came before—mainframe systems running programs written in languages like COBOL and Fortran—has been replaced, with the Y2K crisis providing the final nail in many coffins. Since the software from that era is functionally obsolete, it is tempting to dismiss research from the same time period as equally outdated.

这可能是个错误。如今，我们拥有更快的硬件、更具表现力的编程语言和更好的调试工具。但如果你读过旧书，就会发现基本问题并没有改变。人们需要学习编程，他们编写大量代码，这些代码无法与其他代码集成，调试起来很困难，新程序员不理解它，等等。当时的软件并不像现在最大的程序那么复杂，但语言和工具也更原始，因此难度大致相同——大概在人类认知需求范围内处于大致相同的位置。

This would be a mistake. Today we have faster hardware, more expressive programming languages, and better debugging tools. But if you read the old books, it is clear that the fundamental issues have not changed. People need to learn to program, they write a lot of code, it doesn’t integrate with other code, debugging it is hard, new programmers don’t understand it, and so on. The software wasn’t as complicated as the largest programs now, but the languages and tools were also more primitive, so the difficulty was about the same—presumably at a roughly equivalent position on the spectrum of human cognitive demand.

不同的是，当时学术界和业界有一群人正在采取系统性方法来找出问题及其解决方法。当时正值北约会议刚结束，软件工程这个术语还未成熟，人们正在以过去研究其他工程学科的方式研究该学科。

What is different is that back then, there were a group of people in academia and industry that was taking a systematic approach to figuring out the problems as well as how to solve them. This was the period just after the NATO conferences, the paint was still drying on the term software engineering, and the discipline was being investigated the way other engineering disciplines had been investigated in the past.

请考虑 1971 年出版的《大型系统调试技术》一书。1今天，这个标题会引起人们的兴趣：我们致力于大型软件系统，并且必须对其进行调试。这本书并不是一个人的专著；它是从 1970 年夏天在纽约大学 Courant 数学科学研究所举行的一次会议上摘录的论文集——这是计划中的年度系列会议中的第一场。与会者来自学术界和工业界（IBM 在行业代表中占有重要地位），会议得到了海军研究办公室数学项目的资助。

Consider the 1971 book Debugging Techniques in Large Systems.1 The title would attract interest today: we work on large software systems and have to debug them. The book is not a monograph by one person; it’s a collection of papers pulled from a conference held in summer 1970 at the Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences at New York University—the first in a planned annual series. The participants were from both the academic and industrial communities (IBM figures heavily in the industry representation), and the conference was supported by a grant from the mathematics program of the Office of Naval Research.

我收藏了一些关于调试的现代书籍，这些书籍是我在编写《Find the Bug》时整理的，也是我对这个语料库的贡献。但这些书都不是研讨会的成果；它们都属于“这是我在编写代码时发现的一些东西”这种现代软件书籍中很流行的类型。并不是说这些主题在过去的几十年里发生了很大的变化。《大型系统中的调试技术》涵盖了可以捕获错误的编译器、如何设计软件以减少错误、更好的调试工具、如何测试软件以可靠地发现错误，以及证明程序正确性这个永远难以捉摸的问题。

I own a reasonably complete collection of modern books on debugging, which I pulled together when I wrote Find the Bug, my contribution to the corpus. But none of those books is the result of a symposium; they are all in the “here are some things I figured out while working with code” vein that is so prevalent in modern software books. It’s not that the topics have changed much in the intervening decades. Debugging Techniques in Large Systems covers compilers that can catch bugs, how to design software to reduce errors, better debugger tools, how software should be tested to reliably find bugs, and the ever-elusive issue of proving program correctness.

讽刺的是，当时交换的许多建议比现在更难利用，因为每个人都在使用不同的计算机系统，这些系统运行着不兼容的软件。这并不是说你能从会议中带回一个可以立即使用的新工具；相反，如果你选择承担这项任务，你会知道如何改进你自己系统上可用的工具。尽管如此，人们仍然非常有兴趣分享知识，以推动软件工程学科的发展。

Ironically, a lot of the advice exchanged back then was much harder to take advantage of than it would be today, because everybody was using different computer systems that ran incompatible software. It wasn’t a question of being able to come home from a conference with a new tool that you could use immediately; instead you would have an idea of how you could improve the tools available on your own system, if you chose to undertake the task. Nonetheless, there was great interest in sharing knowledge for the sake of advancing the software engineering discipline.

不幸的是，这种兴奋并没有持续太久。1984 年我上大学的时候，《大型系统中的调试技术》这本书才出版 13 年，但不知何故，除了最初的《C 编程语言》参考书外，我从未接触过这本书或那个时代的任何其他关于软件的书籍。

Unfortunately, the excitement didn’t last. When I started college in 1984, Debugging Techniques in Large Systems book was only thirteen years old, but for whatever reason I never was exposed to it or any other book about software from this era except for the original The C Programming Language reference.

我几乎没听说过当时活跃的软件研究人员。我知道一个简短的版本：布鲁克斯因说“在已推迟的软件项目中增加人员会使项目更晚”而闻名，而迪克斯特拉则说“GOTO 语句被认为是有害的”。我当时不知道他们写的关于软件的内容有多少仍然有意义，并且会继续有意义。正如他们所说，那些无视历史的人注定会重蹈覆辙。如果你真的读过布鲁克斯的《人月神话》，我在这本书中大量引用了这本书，他写了关于文档、沟通、团队角色、估算难度、团队可扩展性、代码注释和代码大小成本的内容——所有这些都是该行业自那以后一直在努力解决的问题。这本书出版于 1975 年，也就是微软成立的那一年——但我们对此一无所知！

I had barely heard of the software researchers who were active back in the day. I knew the sound bite version: Brooks was known for saying that “adding people to a late software project makes it later,” and Dijkstra was the guy who said “GOTO statement considered harmful.” I was oblivious to how much of what they had written about software was still relevant and would continue to be. Those who ignore history, as they say, are doomed to repeat it. If you actually read Brooks’s The Mythical Man-Month, from which I have quoted extensively in this book, he writes about documentation, communication, roles on teams, estimation difficulties, scalability of teams, code comments, and cost of code size—all things that the industry has struggled with ever since. The book came out in 1975, the year that Microsoft was founded—and yet we knew nothing of it!

还有米尔斯，他是那个时代的伟人之一，在我开始为这本书做研究之前，我从未听说过他。通过阅读《软件生产力》，这是米尔斯在 1968 年至 1981 年间撰写的论文集，你可以预览从那时起关于软件的几乎所有争论点：软件中的不同角色、如何设计软件、如何测试软件、如何调试软件、单元测试、文档等等。米尔斯还是二战中的一名轰炸机飞行员，并创建了第一个国家橄榄球联盟的调度算法。公平地说，他当时广受读者喜爱，并在 IBM 有着成功的职业生涯。1996 年他去世后，IEEE 设立了哈兰·D·米尔斯奖，以表彰“通过开发和应用合理理论，对软件工程实践和研究做出的长期、持续和有影响力的贡献”。2然而，我不记得听到过有人获奖的消息（据记载，帕纳斯和迈耶都曾获得过该奖项）。

Then there is Mills, one of the greats of the era whom I had never heard of until I started doing research for this book. Reading through Software Productivity, a collection of Mills’s essays written between 1968 and 1981, you are treated to a preview of almost everything that has been debated about software since then: the different roles in software, how to design software, how to test it, how to debug it, unit testing, documentation, and so on. Mills was also a bomber pilot in World War II and created the first National Football League scheduling algorithm. To be fair, he was widely read at the time and had a successful career at IBM. After he died in 1996, the IEEE created the Harlan D. Mills Award for “long-standing, sustained, and impactful contributions to software engineering practice and research through the development and application of sound theory.”2 I can’t recall ever hearing news about anybody winning it, however (for the record, Parnas and Meyer are both past honorees).

许多其他研究人员采用科学方法来研究编程和程序员。1970 年，哈罗德·萨克曼 (Harold Sackman) 研究了优秀程序员比差劲程序员好多少的问题（其中包括）。3 1977 年，莫里斯·哈尔斯特德 (Maurice Halstead) 研究了给定编程问题的难度是否可以用数学量化。4米尔斯与该领域的先驱之一维克多·巴西利 (Victor Basili) 合作撰写了一篇论文，介绍了一种记录程序的技术，以便程序员能够快速理解程序。5《学习新手程序员》一书收集了一系列关于人们如何学习编程的研究，涵盖了程序员如何理解变量、循环和IF语句的概念等主题，以及与个人相关的主题“高中 BASIC 程序员的误解总结”（“学生们显然将人类的推理能力归因于计算机，从而引起了各种各样的误解”）。6

Many other researchers took a scientific approach to studying programming and programmers. Harold Sackman, in 1970, studied (among other things) the question of how much better good programmers are than bad ones.3 Maurice Halstead, in 1977, examined whether the difficulty of a given programming problem could be quantified mathematically.4 Mills wrote a paper with Victor Basili, one of the pioneers in the field, on techniques for documenting programs so programmers could understand them quickly.5 The book Studying the Novice Programmer collects a series of studies on how people learn to program, covering such topics as how programmers understand the concepts of variables, loops, and IF statements, plus the personally relevant topic “A Summary of Misconceptions of High-School BASIC Programmers” (“The students’ apparent attributing of human reasoning ability to the computer gave rise to a wide variety of misconceptions”).6

所有这些研究最棒的地方在于，除了涉及行业和学术界的合作之外，作者们还真正告诉了你如何编写软件。不再需要无休止的检查清单或关于如何管理软件开发混乱的理论；这是真正实用的建议。这样做而不是那样做，可以使你的代码更容易调试；这样做而不是那样做，可以使其他程序员更容易阅读。

The best part about all this research, besides the fact that it involved collaboration between industry and academia, is that the authors actually told you how to write software. No more endless checklists or theories on how to manage around the mess of software development; this is truly practical advice. Do this instead of that to make your code easier to debug; do that rather than this to make it easier for another programmer to read.

您想平息软件开发领域中永无休止的宗教争论吗？既然这些争论都具有所谓的好处，为什么不让两组人使用以不同风格编写的代码，看看它们如何影响代码的初始理解、修改的难易程度和总体可维护性呢？为什么不呢！这是 Ben Shneiderman在 1980 年出版的《软件心理学》一书中对学生进行的测试，测试不同注释风格如何影响同一 FORTRAN 程序的可读性。7助记变量名称重要吗？ Larry Weissman 对此进行了一系列实验，并于 1974 年发表了报告。8那么缩进呢？Tom Love 和 Shneiderman 只是 20 世纪 70 年代研究缩进是否有助于提高可读性的几个人之一。9真的有害吗GOTO？Max Sime、Thomas Green 和 John Guest 于 1973 年对此进行了研究，Henry Lucas 和 Robert Kaplan 于 1976 年也对此进行了研究。10

You want to settle the never-ending religious debates that continuously roil the waters of software development? Since all these have purported benefits, why not have two groups of people work with code written in different styles, and see how it affected the initial comprehension, ease of modification, and general maintainability of the code? Why not indeed! Here’s Ben Shneiderman in Software Psychology, published in 1980, testing students on how different commenting styles affect readability of the same FORTRAN program.7 Do mnemonic variables names matter? Larry Weissman did a series of experiments on that, reported in 1974.8 What about indentation? Tom Love and Shneiderman were just a few of the people in the 1970s who investigated whether it helps readability.9 Is GOTO really harmful? Max Sime, Thomas Green, and John Guest looked into that in 1973, as did Henry Lucas and Robert Kaplan in 1976.10

流程图之争是一个罕见的例子，展示了一门工程学科应该如何发展。流程图方法让程序员在编写代码之前，先在图表上布置好每一点控制逻辑——每个IF语句、循环GOTO等等。流程图可以用于基本的决策树。它们是《连线》杂志最后一页上关于“我应该做 X 吗”或“我应该买什么样的 Y”的图表的前身——所有这些菱形表示决策点，每个选择都有一个箭头指向外部。甚至视觉语言、方框的形状都与软件流程图相同。玛丽莲·波尔在 1971 年出版的《流程图技术》等书中大力推崇流程图，并在一段时间内继续出现在各种指南书籍中。11

The battle over flowcharts is a rare example of how an engineering discipline is supposed to evolve. The flowchart approach has the programmer lay out every bit of control logic—every IF statement, loop, GOTO, and so on—on a diagram before coding it up. Flowcharts can work for basic decision trees. They are the ancestors of those diagrams on the last page of Wired magazine about “Should I Do X” or “What Sort of Y Should I Buy”—all those diamond shapes for decision points with an arrow leading away for each choice. Even the visual language, the shape of the boxes, is the same as software flowcharts. They were advocated in books such as Marilyn Bohl’s 1971 Flowcharting Techniques, and continued to grace the pages of various how-to books for a while.11

流程图的问题在于，它们无法帮助理解程序中的棘手部分。阅读语句时IF，问题不在于意识到IF代码中有一个语句，而是知道IF逻辑是否正确，从代码中读取这一点和从流程图中读取一样容易。回想一下我们第一章中 DONKEY.BAS 中的“驴撞到车了吗”语句：12

The problem with flowcharts is that they don’t help with the tricky parts of program comprehension. When reading an IF statement, the issue is not realizing that there is an IF statement in the code but instead knowing whether the IF logic is correct, which is as easy to read from the code as from a flowchart. Think back to our “Did the donkey hit the car” statement in DONKEY.BAS from chapter 1:12

1750 IF CX=DX AND Y+25>=CY THEN 2060
1750 IF CX=DX AND Y+25>=CY THEN 2060

您可以将其重新绘制为流程图：

You could redraw this as a flowchart:

但这并不能帮助我们了解IF测试 ( CX=DX AND Y+25>=CY) 是否正确，而错误可能就潜伏在这里。而且，您不知道流程图是否保持同步，因为代码已被中间所有者篡改，所以最终您还是必须阅读代码。

But that doesn’t help us understand whether the IF test (CX=DX AND Y+25>=CY) is correct, which is where bugs might lurk. And for what it’s worth, you don’t know if a flowchart has been kept in sync as the code has been twiddled by intervening owners, so in the end you have to read the code anyway.

根据理查德·迈耶 (Richard Mayer)、无处不在的施奈德曼 (Shneiderman) 和其他人的研究，流程图的真相最终被揭穿。13幸运的是，这与程序员的经验反馈相吻合，程序员们认为，对于比微软面试问题范围更广的问题，流程图带来的麻烦远远大于其价值。布鲁克斯在一篇题为“流程图诅咒”的文章中（标题如此，我需要引用吗？无论如何，我都会引用它，作为另一个例子，说明在小型程序中行之有效的想法在应用于大型程序时会失效）观察到，“流程图是程序文档中最被过度吹捧的部分。……当流程图在一页上时，它们可以相当优雅地显示决策结构，但当流程图有多页时，概览就会严重崩溃，这些页面用编号的出口和连接器缝合在一起。”14

Flowcharts were eventually debunked, based on studies by Richard Mayer, the omnipresent Shneiderman, and others.13 Luckily, this meshed with the empirical feedback from programmers that they were far more trouble than they were worth for anything of larger scope than a Microsoft interview question. Brooks, in a section of an essay titled “The Flow-Chart Curse”—with a title like that, do I need the quote? I’ll provide it anyway as another illustration of how ideas that may work well for small programs break down when applied to large ones—observed that “the flow chart is a most thoroughly oversold piece of program documentation. … They show decision structure rather elegantly when the flow chart is on one page, but the overview breaks down badly when one has multiple pages, sewn together with numbered exits and connectors.”14

但这是我能想到的唯一一个曾经流行的编程方法因为研究而被淘汰的案例——即便如此，我怀疑导致流程图灭绝的主要原因是程序员的懒惰，而不是研究（我个人记得曾有人建议使用流程图，但后来我自己认为这是在浪费时间）。

But that’s about the only case I can think of where a once-fashionable programming methodology has been retired based on research—and even then I suspect it was primarily programmer lassitude, not the research studies, that led to flowcharts’ extinction (I can personally recall both being advised to use flowcharts and later deciding on my own that they were a waste of time).

早期关注软件工程的原因是什么？很难确切知道，但我可以推测。当一门新的大学课程在短时间内涌现时，就会出现“先有鸡还是先有蛋”的效应。当第一批计算机科学教授自己上大学时，他们自己在计算机科学专业出现之前是如何接受培训的？答案是他们大多是数学家；Knuth、Mills 和 Brooks 都拥有数学博士学位。作为一名数学家的儿子，我可以自信地说，尽管数学家可能以独自思考而闻名，但他们非常善于合作，花大量时间开会交流想法，几乎总是在前人的工作基础上进行建设。15

What was the reason for this early attention to how to engineer software? It’s hard to know exactly, but I can speculate. There is a chicken-and-egg effect when you have a new university course of study spring up in a short period of time. How was the first set of computer science professors trained when they themselves went to college before a computer science major existed? The answer was that they were mostly mathematicians; Knuth, Mills, and Brooks all had PhDs in mathematics. As the son of a mathematician, I can state with confidence that despite possibly having a reputation for thinking deep thoughts in isolation, mathematicians are extremely collaborative and spend a lot of time meeting to exchange ideas, almost always building on the work of those who have gone before.15

此外，当软件首次成为可以出售给客户的产品时，编写软件的是硬件公司；当时没有像微软那样的“纯软件”公司。每家公司都在生产自己的硬件，这些硬件与其他硬件不兼容，并且需要操作系统来运行软件以及编译器和工具，以便其他人编写软件。客户购买电脑不是为了给办公室供暖；他们需要软件来解决他们试图解决的特定问题，而谁能比硬件制造商更适合（或者说谁也不适合）编写软件呢？IBM 历来被认为是一家硬件公司，为了销售其机器，它不得不编写大量软件。SABRE 是美国航空公司在 20 世纪 60 年代初推出的最初的基于计算机的航空预订系统，它是由 IBM 作为与该航空公司的硬件/软件联合交易的一部分编写的。米尔斯在 IBM 的联邦系统部门工作，负责编写针对政府客户的定制软件。

Furthermore, when software first became a product that could be sold to customers, it was hardware companies that were writing the software; there were no “software-only” companies like Microsoft was in its early days. Each company was producing its own hardware that was incompatible with other hardware, and it needed an operating system to run the software along with compilers and tools to allow others to write software. Customers didn’t buy computers to heat their office; they needed software for the specific problem they were trying to solve, and who better (or who at all, really) was there to write this than the company that also made the hardware? IBM, which is historically thought of as a hardware company, had to write a lot of software in order to sell its machines. SABRE, the original computer-based airline reservation system that American Airlines rolled out in the early 1960s, was written by IBM as part of a combined hardware/software deal with the airline. Mills worked in the Federal Systems Division at IBM, tasked with writing software customized for government customers.

在设计硬件时，公司是在进行“真正的”工程：电气工程积累了有关电路设计、散热和功率以及其他无法通过“上次对我有用”的方法解决的课题的知识。公司必须依靠学术界和工业界的研究。此外，在硬件设计后期，你无法像软件设计那样轻易地做出更改；前期设计是值得花时间的。想必硬件公司也会用同样严谨的方法来处理软件问题。

When designing hardware, a company is doing “real” engineering: electrical engineering has built-up knowledge about circuit design, heat dissipation and power, and other topics that can’t be solved with a “this worked for me last time” approach. Companies have to rely on research, both from academia and industry. In addition, you can’t easily make changes late in the design of hardware the way you can with software; up-front design is worth the time. Presumably a hardware company would approach a software problem with the same disciplined approach.

鉴于此，早期的软件工程在学术界数学家和工业界硬件公司的共同推动下，开始走其他工程学科的道路，这是可以理解的，你可以在当时的文献中看到这种结果。1975 年的观察者有理由相信这种趋势会持续下去，几十年后，事情就会被弄清楚、编纂成法典，然后传授给学生，并通过专业培训加以强化。

Given that, it is understandable that early software engineering, driven by a combination of mathematicians in academia and hardware companies in industry, started down the path taken by other engineering disciplines, and you can see the results of this in the literature produced during that time. An observer in 1975 would have had reasonable confidence that the trend would continue, and that in a few decades, things would be figured out, codified, and then taught to students and reinforced through professional training.

坦白地说，事情并非如此。到底发生了什么？

That is not the way it turned out, to put it mildly. What happened?

在《计算机编程心理学》一书中，温伯格提出了由终端的出现（这发生在 1971 年）所引起的变化的理论。当他谈到终端时，他指的是在仍然连接到大型计算机但允许你以交互方式编辑和运行程序的控制台上打字——这与我在 1981 年左右从我父母的房间连接到 McGill 的计算机时使用的装置相同，只是可能用的是屏幕显示器而不是打印机。这比旧系统有了显著的进步，在旧系统中，要运行程序，你必须亲自将其作为一叠打孔卡提交，然后等待一段时间才能安排和运行，输出将由有权访问实际计算机的操作员交付给你。温伯格正在讨论阅读代码作为提高自己作为程序员的一种方式，并哀叹这样做比过去少了：

In The Psychology of Computer Programming, Weinberg theorizes about a change caused by the arrival of terminals (this was back in 1971). When he talks about terminals, he means typing at a console that is still connected to a mainframe computer but allows you to edit and run programs interactively—the same rig I used to connect to McGill’s computer from my parents’ room circa 1981, except possibly with a screen display rather than a printer. This is a significant advance over older systems, where to run a program you had to submit it in person as a stack of punched cards, and then wait awhile for it to be scheduled and run, with your output being delivered to you by an operator who had access to the actual computer. Weinberg is discussing reading code as a way to improve yourself as a programmer and lamenting that this is done less than in the past:

随着终端的出现，情况变得越来越糟，因为程序员甚至可能看不到适合阅读的程序。在过去——计算机领域还不是很久以前——我们不太容易接触到机器，无法等待从实际的机器运行中学习。周转时间通常很短，程序员们只能通过阅读彼此的程序来消磨时间。……

但可惜的是，时代变了。就像电视让年轻人不再享受读书的乐趣一样，终端和普遍改善的周转时间也让阅读程序成为无可救药的老派程序员的标志。深夜，当白发苍苍的老前辈蜷缩在床上玩着性感的子程序或令人费解的宏时，年轻的程序员正忙着与终端对话。16

With the advent of terminals, things are getting worse, for the programmer may not even see his own program in a form suitable for reading. In the old days—which in computing is not so long ago—we had less easy access to machines and couldn’t afford to wait for learning from actual machine runs. Turnaround was often so bad that programmers would while away the time by reading each others’ programs. …

But, alas, times change. Just as television has turned the heads of the young from the old-fashioned joys of book reading, so have terminals and generally improved turnaround made the reading of programs the mark of a hopelessly old-fashioned programmer. Late at night, when the grizzled old-timer is curled up in bed with a sexy subroutine or a mystifying macro, the young blade is busily engaged in a dialogue with his terminal.16

忽略上一句中的形象，忽略他随意使用男性人称代词来代替程序员，温伯格的观点是，使用交互式终端进行编程可以让你远离早期软件开发的缓慢方法，在这种方法中，你花费更多的时间在前期使其正确，因为运行它的延迟要大得多（而且你有更多的时间与其他程序员聊天，同时站在那里等待操作员提供结果）。这更像是硬件工程，一旦你构建了物理硬件，解决问题就会变得更加困难。

Wading past the imagery in the last sentence, and ignoring his offhand use of a male personal pronoun as a stand-in for programmer, Weinberg’s point is that programming with interactive terminals moves you away from the slower approach that characterized early software development, where you spent more time up front making it right, because the delay in running it was so much greater (and you had more time to chat with other programmers while standing around waiting for the operators to deliver your results). That was more like hardware engineering, where fixing a problem becomes so much more difficult once you have built physical hardware.

此时，还有另一颗种子正在萌芽，导致事情偏离了预期的轨道。1968 年在德国加米施举行的北约会议因“软件工程”一词的诞生而被人们铭记，并因学术界和工业界一致认为需要采取行动而被人们铭记。人们不太记得的是次年在罗马举行的第二次北约会议，会议结束时并没有同样的团结感。会议记录的编辑 John Buxton 和 Brian Randell 写道：

There was another seed germinating at this time that contributed to things veering away from the predicted path. The 1968 NATO conference in Garmisch, Germany, is remembered for the origin of the term software engineering, and the agreement between academia and industry that something needed to be done. Less remembered is the second NATO conference in Rome the following year, which did not end with the same feeling of togetherness. John Buxton and Brian Randell, editors of the proceedings, wrote the following:

加米施会议以其参与者的兴趣和经验的广泛性而著称。事实上，从象牙塔里的学术界人士到身处前线、参与真正大型软件项目方向的人士，整个范围都得到了很好的覆盖。绝大多数参与者都普遍认为，人类努力领域面临的问题的程度和严重性是一致的，而这个领域可能有点过早地被称为“软件工程”。……

罗马会议组织者的意图是，应该更详细地研究技术问题，而不是将加米施会议中出现的主要管理问题也包括在内。然而，他们再次刻意成功地吸引了同样广泛的参与者。最终的会议与之前的会议大不相同。……至少在编辑们看来，不同部门的参与者之间缺乏沟通成为一个主要特征。最终，这种沟通鸿沟的严重性，以及对它只是现实世界情况的反映的认识，使得沟通鸿沟本身成为一个主要讨论话题。正如对软件危机的全面认识是加米施会议的主要成果一样，在编辑们看来，对沟通鸿沟的严重性和范围的认识是罗马会议最重要的成果。17

The Garmisch conference was notable for the range of interests and experience represented among its participants. In fact the complete spectrum, from the inhabitants of ivory-towered academe to people who were right on the firing-line, being involved in the direction of really large-scale software projects, was well covered. The vast majority of these participants found commonality in a widespread belief as to the extent and seriousness of the problems facing the area of human endeavor which has, perhaps somewhat prematurely, been called “software engineering.” …

The intent of the organizers of the Rome conference was that it should be devoted to a more detailed study of technical problems, rather than including also the managerial problems which figured so largely at Garmisch. However, once again, a deliberate and successful attempt was made to attract an equally wide range of participants. The resulting conference bore little resemblance to its predecessor. … A lack of communication between different sections of the participants became, in the editors’ opinions at least, a dominant feature. Eventually the seriousness of this communication gap, and the realization that it was but a reflection of the situation in the real world, caused the gap itself to become a major topic of discussion. Just as the realization of the full magnitude of the software crisis was the main outcome of the meeting at Garmisch, it seems to the editors that the realization of the significance and extent of the communication gap is the most important outcome of the Rome conference.17

换句话说，一旦人们开始从对问题的广泛认识转向潜在解决方案的细节，学术界和工业界之间的差距就开始显现出来。罗杰·尼德汉姆和乔尔·阿隆在第二次会议的工作论文中讨论了这一差异：

In other words, once people started to get away from broad recognition of the problem and into details of potential solutions, the gap between academia and industry began to manifest itself. Roger Needham and Joel Aron addressed this difference in a working paper at the second conference:

软件工程师想要制造出可以工作的东西；工作包括满足功能、成本、交付和稳健性的承诺。优雅和一致性排在第二位。必须能够以不可预测甚至不合理的方式轻松更改系统——例如，响应管理指令。目前，理论家无法跟上这种事情，就像他们无法跟上大型软件系统的规模和复杂性一样。18

The software engineer wants to make something which works; where working includes satisfying commitments of function, cost, delivery, and robustness. Elegance and consistency come a bad second. It must be easy to change the system in ways that are not predictable or even reasonable—e.g., in response to management directives. At present theorists cannot keep up with this kind of thing, any more than they can with the sheer size and complexity of large software systems.18

该报告还引用了牛津大学计算机科学家 Christopher Strachey 在最后一天为解决这一差距而添加的讨论中的一句话：

The report also contains a quote from Christopher Strachey, a computer scientist from Oxford University, from a discussion that was added on the last day to address the gap:

我想谈谈理论和实践之间的关系。在我看来，这是本次会议未提及的潜在主题之一，但尚未得到充分讨论。我饶有兴致地听取了有关非常大的项目管理方案以及使用这些方案编写的程序的描述；我还听到了昨晚表达的一种观点，即从事这项工作的人感觉他们像一群猴子一样被邀请到这里接受理论家的审视。我还听到来自理论方面的人士也感到他们同样被孤立；他们在这里却不被允许发表任何言论。……

我认为我们应该记住某人的定律，即 95% 的事物都是垃圾。你不应该根据 95% 的计算机科学垃圾来判断计算机科学对软件工程的贡献。你不应该从纯理论的高度来判断软件工程，因为 95% 的软件工程也是垃圾。让我们试着从另一个角度看待好的东西，看看我们是否真的能建立起一座小小的桥梁。19

I want to talk about the relationship between theory and practice. This has been, to my mind, one of the unspoken underlying themes of this meeting and has not been properly ventilated. I have heard with great interest the descriptions of the very large program management schemes, and the programs that have been written using these; and also I heard a view expressed last night that the people who were doing this felt that they were invited here like a lot of monkeys to be looked at by the theoreticians. I have also heard people from the more theoretical side who felt that they were equally isolated; they were here but not allowed to say anything. …

I think we ought to remember somebody or other’s law, which amounts to the fact that 95 per cent of everything is rubbish. You shouldn’t judge the contributions of computing science to software engineering on the 95 per cent of computing science which is rubbish. You shouldn’t judge software engineering, from the high altitude of pure theory, on the 95 per cent of software engineering which is also rubbish. Let’s try and look at the good things from the other side and see if we can’t in fact make a little bridge.19

他很可能指的是科幻作家西奥多·斯特金 (Theodore Sturgeon) 提出的斯特金定律，该定律认为“90% 的东西都是垃圾”。20

He is likely referring to Sturgeon’s law, coined by the science fiction writer Theodore Sturgeon, which posits that “90% of everything is crap.”20

Knuth 曾表示，他认为在 20 世纪 70 年代初，学术界是优秀的程序员，而行业专业人士则不是。然而在那十年里，随着行业编写的软件范围不断扩大，情况发生了逆转，到 70 年代末，学术界已经与行业的发展脱节，他们的编程（因此他们的专业领域）仅限于较小的程序，而这些程序不再有助于为行业提供建议。21巴西利 (Basili) 表示：“研究人员解决的是可解决的问题，而不一定是实际存在的问题。”22可悲的是，尽管偶尔会出现一些设计模式等亮点，但这种差距至今仍然存在。

Knuth has stated that he feels that at the beginning of the 1970s, academics were good programmers and industry professionals were not. Yet during that decade, as the scope of software that industry wrote increased, the situation reversed itself, and by the end of the decade the academics had drifted out of sync with what was going on in industry and restricted their programming, and therefore their area of expertise, to smaller programs that were no longer useful for generating advice for industry.21 Basili stated it as, “Researchers solve problems that are solvable, not necessarily ones that are real.”22 The gap, sadly, still persists to this day, despite the occasional bright spot such as design patterns.

但实际上，软件工程学术研究的衰落有一个明显的原因。这个原因就是我。

But really, there is one obvious cause of the decline in academic research on software engineering. And that cause is me.

当然，不只是我。还有我和像我这样的人：那些在 20 世纪 70 年代中期个人电脑革命开始后成长起来的人，这场革命将交互式终端的出现加速到了光速。温伯格在《计算机编程心理学》的 25 周年纪念版中对此发表了评论，他在 20 世纪 90 年代中期观察了一家他为之提供咨询的公司的程序员团队：“然而，更有趣的是，巧合的是，他们所有人都在学校正式学习编程之前就学会了编程。这是个人电脑带来的重大变化。在我那个年代，在 1956 年去 IBM 工作之前，我甚至没有见过电脑。”23

Not just me, of course. It’s me and people like me: the ones who came of age just after the personal computer revolution started in the mid-1970s, which took the move to interactive terminals and accelerated it to light speed. Weinberg commented on this in the silver anniversary edition of The Psychology of Computer Programming, observing a team of programmers at a company he was consulting with in the mid-1990s: “More interesting, however, was the coincidence that all of them had learned to program before they studied programming formally in school. That’s a major change brought about by the personal computer. In my day, I had not even seen a computer before I went to work for IBM in 1956.”23

这并非巧合。从 20 世纪 70 年代末开始，使用计算机不再需要您在计算机硬件公司工作或与大学有联系。任何人都可以买得起个人计算机回家，无需经验丰富的程序员的监督和建议，也无需工程公司的方法论，就可以开始自己编程。他们大批这样做，没有从过去吸取任何教训，而是一遍又一遍地重新发明一切。无论是从字面上还是从比喻上来说，我们都从未回头。独立软件公司蓬勃发展，而硬件公司的软件部门则萎缩，因此现代软件行业是由从未接触过工程严谨的人创建的。

It’s not a coincidence. Beginning in the late 1970s, access to a computer no longer required that you work at a computer hardware company or be associated with a university. Anybody could afford to bring a personal computer home, free from the oversight and advice of more experienced programmers and the methodology of an engineering company, and start programming on their own. And they did just that, in large numbers, learning nothing from the past and reinventing everything, over and over. Both literally and figuratively, we never looked back. Independent software companies thrived while the software divisions of hardware companies shrank, so that the modern software industry was created by people who had never been exposed to engineering rigor.

这是我成长为程序员的时代。我开始使用电脑时，个人电脑才刚刚开始普及。但我在常春藤盟校主修计算机科学！正如我之前所说，我们所有人都是自学编程的，如果我的教授知道温伯格和米尔斯，他们也不会向本科生谈论他们。我不知道为什么会这样——软件世界似乎变化太快，这看起来已经过时了，有太多其他东西可以教我们，以至于没有空间，或者他们尝试过，但被初出茅庐的个人电脑爱好者忽视了。可能这被视为不相关，因为这些主题往往被归类为“心理学”（这个术语出现在施奈德曼和温伯格的经典书籍的标题中）或“人为因素”，这听起来非常不符合工程学。

This is the era in which I grew up as a programmer. I started using computers just as the personal computer was becoming established. But I also majored in computer science at an Ivy League university! As I’ve said before, all of us were self-taught in how to actually program, and if my professors knew of Weinberg and Mills, they weren’t talking about them to the undergraduates. I don’t know why it was like this—whether the software world appeared to be changing so fast that this looked obsolete, there was so much else to teach us that there was no room, or maybe they had tried it and been ignored by callow personal computer habitués. Possibly it was seen as not relevant, because these topics tended to get lumped under “psychology” (a term that appears in the title of both Shneiderman’s and Weinberg’s classic books) or “human factors,” which sounds awfully un-engineering-ish.

1976 年，施奈德曼帮助创立了非正式的软件心理学协会，该协会每月举行一次会议，讨论计算机科学和心理学的交叉领域，包括软件工程主题。1982 年，该协会举办了计算机系统中的人为因素会议，这促成了 ACM 计算机-人机交互特别兴趣小组 (SIGCHI) 会议的成立。24然而无论出于什么原因，SIGCHI 更关注用户与计算机界面的交互而不是程序员与软件工具的交互（Shneiderman 本人最终也这么做了）。25所有这些的最终结果是，在普林斯顿大学，我没有听说过任何这方面的研究，而这些研究在当时只有大约十年的历史，而且在当时肯定具有现实意义——现在也同样具有现实意义。

In 1976, Shneiderman helped found the informal Software Psychology Society, which met monthly to discuss the intersection of computer science and psychology, including software engineering topics. In 1982, the society put on the Human Factors in Computing Systems conference, which led to the creation of the ACM Special Interest Group on Computer-Human Interaction (SIGCHI) conference.24 Yet for whatever reason, SIGCHI focused much more on the topic of user interaction with computer interfaces rather than programmer interaction with software tools (as eventually did Shneiderman himself).25 The net effect of all this was that at Princeton, I heard about none of this research, which at the time was only about a decade old and certainly relevant then—and relevant now as well.

我在微软工作初期曾遇到过几个曾在硬件公司工作过的人，他们离开的原因是觉得在硬件公司编写软件的速度太慢，而且官僚主义太严重：这些公司对软件的流程与对硬件的流程相同。我的意思是，为什么不呢？如果你可以不受既定先例的束缚，而是自己发明一切，你难道不想这样做吗？没有规则！免费的钱！这就是 Agile 今天所宣传的：你使用的方法越少，你就越能自由地创造天才作品。不幸的是，我们没有试图从这些难民身上学到一些关于流程的知识，而是帮助他们摆脱了束缚。

I met several people in my early days at Microsoft who had previously worked at hardware companies and left because writing software there felt too slow and bureaucratic: The companies followed the same process for software that they did for hardware. I mean, why not; if you can work unencumbered by established precedent and instead invent everything yourself, wouldn’t you want to? No rules! Free money! It’s the same pitch that Agile is making today: the less methodology you use, the more you will be free to create works of genius. Unfortunately, rather than trying to learn something about process from these refugees, we enabled them in their quest to be freed from their shackles.

我现在意识到，这就是戴夫·卡特勒（Dave Cutler）与公司其他高管之间的区别。在我早期的微软职业生涯中，他曾为戴夫·卡特勒工作，负责 Windows NT 项目。卡特勒比我大一辈，曾在硬件公司 Digital Equipment 工作。在那里工作期间，他了解到软件开发需要规划和严谨。在开始编写 Windows NT 第一版代码之前，团队制作了一个大型笔记本，列出了系统的内部细节，重点关注每个部分提供的 API；这本笔记本的副本现在保存在史密森学会。26这是我加入团队之前的事；如果我亲眼看到这种活动，我不确定我会怎么想。我可能会想知道为什么我们没有加入并编写代码。就此而言，我不确定比尔盖茨对此有何看法（尽管他显然允许卡特勒按照自己的方式行事）。盖茨还很年轻，他能够自学编程，就像温伯格指责的那种让程序员走上歧途的终端一样。

I realize now that this was the difference between Dave Cutler, who was in charge of the Windows NT project when I worked for him early in my Microsoft career, and almost any other executive at the company. Cutler was a generation older than me and had learned the ropes at Digital Equipment, a hardware company. Working there he had acquired an understanding of the need for planning and rigor in software development. Before beginning to write the code for the first version of Windows NT, the team produced a large notebook laying out the internal details of the system, focusing heavily on the APIs provided by each section; a copy of this notebook is now preserved in the Smithsonian Institution.26 This was before I arrived on the team; I’m not sure what I would have thought of this activity if I had observed it in person. I likely would have wondered why we weren’t jumping in and writing code. For that matter, I’m not sure what Bill Gates thought of it (although clearly he allowed Cutler to do it his way). Gates was just young enough that he was able to learn to program on his own, on a terminal like the one that Weinberg accused of leading programmers down the primrose path.

威尔逊在 SPLASH 2013 主题演讲中描述了他当时的感受：“我怎么不知道我们知道一些东西？”这一时刻，是受到他在业界工作十年后发现史蒂夫·麦康奈尔 (Steve McConnell) 于 1993 年出版的《代码大全》一书的启发。27这是第一批试图汇集关于如何编写软件的智慧的书籍之一。它值得特别提及，因为它确实引用了学术研究来支持其建议，至少在已经进行过研究的领域，例如“单个方法中代码行数的正确值是多少？”值得一提的是，根据 McConnell 所研究的研究，关于方法长度的共识是，大约 200 行代码太长了。28此后，该主题已脱离任何研究，现在在充满激情的冗长言辞的海洋中欢快地摇摆，以至于几乎没有任何正数不被人认为方法中的那么多行太多。有些人声称，当你觉得需要在代码中添加注释时，你应该立即将该代码移到一个单独的方法中，该方法具有句子长度、驼峰式方法名称，该方法名称作为完整的文档；这些人在我们中间行走，却没有被旨在保护公民社会的机构发现。

Wilson’s “How come I didn’t know we knew stuff about things?” moment, described in his SPLASH 2013 keynote, was inspired by his discovering, after ten years in the industry, the 1993 book Code Complete by Steve McConnell.27 This was one of the first books that attempted to assemble wisdom about how to write software. It deserves special mention because it does refer to academic studies to back up its recommendations, at least in areas where studies had been done, such as “What is the right number of lines of code in a single method?” For what it’s worth, the consensus on method length from the studies McConnell looked at was that around two hundred lines was getting to be too long.28 The topic has since been unmoored from any research and now bobs merrily in a sea of impassioned verbiage, such that there are scarcely any positive numbers for which somebody doesn’t consider that many lines in a method to be too many. Some people claim that the instant you feel you need a comment in your code, you should instead move that code into a separate method with a sentence-length, camel-cased method name, with said method name serving as the complete documentation; these people walk among us, undetected by the institutions meant to protect a civil society.

麦康奈尔引用的大部分研究至少已有十年历史，因为到那时这种类型的研究已经基本枯竭（2004 年出版的该书第二版几乎没有发现任何新研究）。但至少他尽可能地引用了这些研究。他甚至花了五页来讨论匈牙利表示法，提出正反两方的论点，但没有选出赢家。29这并不奇怪，因为匈牙利符号作为工业产物，从未被正式研究过——双方反而喜欢继续互相谩骂（在第二版中，他将匈牙利符号的处理一分为二，并将其概括为“标准化前缀”，但他也删除了大部分反对它的论点，给读者留下这是一个好主意的印象）。三十

Most of the studies cited by McConnell were at least ten years old, since this type of investigation had mostly dried up by then (a second edition of the book, published in 2004, barely unearths any new studies). But at least he referenced them where he could. He even spends five pages discussing Hungarian notation, presenting arguments pro and con without choosing a winner.29 This is not surprising since Hungarian notation, being a product of industry, has never been formally studied—with both sides instead preferring to continue hurling invectives at each other (in the second edition, he cuts the treatment of Hungarian in half and genericizes it as “standardized prefixes,” but he also excises most of the arguments against it, leaving the reader with the impression that it’s a good idea).30

IEEE 计算机学会是一个与 ACM 目标相似的专业协会，它创建了软件工程知识体系 (SWEBOK)，该体系在《SWEBOK 3.0：软件工程知识体系指南》一书中进行了总结，该书被称为SWEBOK 指南（ACM 最初参与了 SWEBOK，但由于对其发展方向存在分歧而退出了）。31这项倡议有货物崇拜的一面；其他工程学科都有知识体系，所以也许如果我们创建自己的知识体系，我们就会获得它们所拥有的工程严谨性。从本质上讲，IEEE 汇集了当前关于软件工程的智慧，但没有对其实际价值作出判断。

The IEEE Computer Society, a professional association with similar goals to the ACM, created the Software Engineering Body of Knowledge (SWEBOK), which is summarized in the book SWEBOK 3.0: Guide to the Software Engineering Body of Knowledge, known as the SWEBOK Guide (the ACM was initially involved in SWEBOK, but pulled out after disagreement on the direction it was taking).31 This initiative has a cargo cult aspect to it; other engineering disciplines have bodies of knowledge, so maybe if we create one of our own, we will acquire the engineering rigor that they possess. Essentially the IEEE has assembled the current wisdom on software engineering, without passing judgment on the actual value of it.

鉴于 API 设计是软件工程中最关键的领域之一（McConnell 在《Code Complete》中用整整一章来讨论这个主题），看看SWEBOK Guide对此有何评论将大有裨益。不可否认，这本书的内容不如《Code Complete 》那么详尽，但发现只有四分之一页的内容涉及如此重要的主题，还是令人泄气。在解释了什么是 API 之后，它指出“API 设计应尝试使 API 易于学习和记忆、代码可读、不易误用、易于扩展、完整并保持向后兼容性。由于 API 通常比广泛使用的库或框架的实现更持久，因此希望 API 简单易懂且保持稳定，以方便客户端应用程序的开发和维护。”32就是这样。这个建议没有错，尽管可能有点矛盾，但它非常不完整。“应该尝试”是什么意思？它没有任何地方说明如何实现所有这些目标，也没有提供任何关于这些目标的研究参考。

Given that API design is one of the most critical areas of software engineering (McConnell spends an entire chapter on the subject in Code Complete), it is instructive to see what the SWEBOK Guide has to say about it. Admittedly the book is less expansive than Code Complete, but still it is deflating to find only a quarter of a page devoted to such an important topic. After explaining what an API is, it states that “API design should try to make the API easy to learn and memorize, lead to readable code, be hard to misuse, be easy to extend, be complete, and maintain backward compatibility. As the APIs usually outlast their implementations for a widely used library or framework, it is desired that the API be straightforward and kept stable to facilitate the development and maintenance of the client applications.”32 That’s it. This advice is not wrong, although possibly mildly contradictory, but it’s woefully incomplete. And what does “should try” mean? Nowhere does it state how to accomplish all these goals or give any references to studies of them.

SWEBOK 指南指出它不包含详细信息，但会向读者推荐其他文献：“知识体系可以在参考资料本身中找到。”33就 API 设计而言，重定向到书籍《记录软件架构》，这是一本关于在各个粒度级别（包括单个 API 层）记录软件设计的合理书籍——但它是关于记录已经创建的设计，而不是关于如何创建它。三十四

The SWEBOK Guide notes that it doesn’t contain detailed information, but points the reader to other literature: “The Body of Knowledge is found in the reference materials themselves.”33 In the case of API design, the redirect is to the book Documenting Software Architectures, which is a reasonable book about documenting your software design at various levels of granularity, including down to the individual API layer—yet it is about documenting a design that has been created, not about how to create it in the first place.34

同时，由三部分组成的《软件工程要点》一书旨在提供有关 SWEBOK 的更多详细信息，并对其进行逐一匹配，其中对 API 设计进行了如下总体介绍：

Meanwhile, the three-part book Software Engineering Essentials, which is meant to provide more detail on SWEBOK and matches it point for point, has this to say about API design, in toto:

API（应用程序编程接口）是应用程序用来与操作系统或其他控制程序（如数据库管理系统）进行通信的一种语言和消息格式。API 意味着计算机中存在一些程序模块来执行操作，或者必须将其链接到现有程序中才能执行任务。三十五

An API (application programming interface) is a language and message format used by an application program to communicate with the operating system or some other control program such as a database management system. An API implies that some program module is available in the computer to perform the operation or that it must be linked into the existing program to perform the tasks.35

这并没有什么深刻的见解；这只是对该术语的一个定义，源自《PC Magazine 百科全书》。

There is no great insight there; it is only a definition of the term, attributed to PC Magazine Encyclopedia.

过去二十年，软件工程界所推崇的很多理念——敏捷开发、单元测试、错误与异常之争以及不同编程语言的优势——都是在没有任何实验支持的情况下提出的。即使是面向对象编程本身也没有经过严格的测试，以查看它是否比以前的更好，或者只是更符合程序员的思维。正如 2001 年对面向对象编程的少数研究的一篇元评论所说：“证据的权重倾向于略微偏向 OOSD [面向对象系统开发]，尽管大多数研究未能建立在理论基础之上，许多研究存在实验设计不足的问题，有些研究从证据中得出了非常值得怀疑的结论。”三十六

Much of what has been espoused in software engineering in the last twenty years—Agile development, unit testing, the debate about errors versus exceptions, and the benefits of different programming languages—has been presented without any experimental backing. Even object-oriented programming itself has not been subjected to rigorous testing to see if it is better than what came before or just more pleasing to the mind of programmers. As one metareview of the few studies of object-oriented programming put it in 2001, “The weight of the evidence tends to slightly favor OOSD [Object-Oriented Systems Development], although most studies fail to build on a theoretical foundation, many suffer from inadequate experimental designs, and some draw highly questionable conclusions from the evidence.”36

有几位坚定的研究人员一直在对软件工程进行实验研究。巴西利（2003 年 IEEE 米尔斯奖获得者）值得特别提及，他是最早也是最长期的从业者之一。除了在马里兰大学担任计算机科学教授的漫长职业生涯外，他还在 NASA 戈达德太空飞行中心担任软件工程实验室主任 25 年。为了纪念他 65 岁生日，《经验软件工程基础》一书于 2005 年出版，收集了他整个职业生涯中的 20 篇论文。37如果您对“定量比较软件开发方法的受控实验”和“比较软件测试策略的有效性”等标题感到好奇，那么我鼓励您更多地了解实证研究。但他的这类工作往往出现在《实证软件工程》或《系统与软件杂志》等期刊上，从未进入行业，而工作程序员则蜂拥参加有关敏捷开发和其他热门话题的会议。

There are a few stalwart researchers who have continued to do experimental investigations into software engineering. Basili (an IEEE Mills award winner in 2003) deserves special mention, as one of the first and longest practitioners. In addition to a lengthy career as a professor of computer science at the University of Maryland, he spent twenty-five years as director of the Software Engineering Laboratory at NASA’s Goddard Space Flight Center. In honor of his sixty-fifth birthday, the book Foundations of Empirical Software Engineering was published in 2005, collecting twenty essays from throughout his career.37 If your curiosity is piqued by titles like “A Controlled Experiment Quantitatively Comparing Software Development Approaches” and “Comparing the Effectiveness of Software Testing Strategies,” then I encourage you to learn more about empirical studies. But too often his sort of work winds up in journals like Empirical Software Engineering or the Journal of Systems and Software, and never crosses over into industry, while working programmers flock to conferences on Agile development and other trendy topics.

当我们所有“年轻刀锋”在 20 世纪 80 年代初联合起来并成功向大型计算机发起进攻时，我们把工程学科这个婴儿连同大型计算机一起倒掉了。软件工程面临的挑战是如何将它找回来。

When all of us “young blades” banded together in the early 1980s and mounted our successful assault on mainframe computers, we threw the engineering discipline baby out with the mainframe bathwater. The challenge for software engineering is how to get it back.

笔记

11 

未来

11 

The Future

自 1968 年北约会议以来， “软件工程”一词已进入日常用语，至今已有五十年了。

It has been fifty years since the 1968 NATO conference, when the term software engineering entered the vernacular.

会议上提出的担忧与我们今天面临的问题大致相同，尽管已经取得了进展。声明GOTO已从顶层套房降级到二楼地下室。我们有更好的编程语言，即使人们天生反对采用它们。面向对象编程可能不允许我们通过将代码块相邻放置来构建程序，也不允许我们更轻松地设计可用的 API，但它为我们提供了设计模式、单元测试和代码模块之间更清晰的抽象。程序员仍在争论变量名的正确格式以及制表符是否比空格更好，但至少他们现在半讽刺地这样做。

The list of concerns voiced at the conference is largely the same one we face today, although progress has been made. The GOTO statement has been demoted from a top-floor suite to the second underbasement. We have better programming languages, even if people are constitutionally resistant to adopting them. Object-oriented programming may not allow us to build programs by placing blocks of code next to each other or make designing usable APIs any easier, but it has given us design patterns, unit testing, and cleaner abstraction between code modules. Programmers still argue over the proper format of variable names and whether tabs are better than spaces, but at least they now do so semi-ironically.

与此同时，新的管理方法虽然没有改变手头的基本任务，但已经承认并适应了当前的现实。敏捷方法在其各种形式中让人们意识到了当前软件项目调度的不足，并明确指出需要能够理解和持续修改的代码。开源运动也强调了可读、可修改代码的必要性，在开源运动中，一群可能从未见过面的人一起开发软件。此外，由于开源贡献者通常自愿选择参与项目并通过实际生产代码而不是面试来证明自己的价值，它凸显了一个事实，即顶级大学计算机科学课程并不能垄断培养称职的程序员，而老牌软件公司也没有任何神奇的软件工程技术。

Meanwhile, new approaches to management, while not changing the fundamental task at hand, have acknowledged and adapted to the current reality. Agile, in its various incarnations, has opened people’s eyes to the inadequacy of current software project scheduling, and made explicit the need for code that can be understood and modified on an ongoing basis. The open-source movement, in which a team of people who may never have met in person work together to develop software, also emphasizes the need for readable, modifiable code. In addition, since open-source contributors often self-select to work on a project and prove their worth with actual production code rather than interviews, it has highlighted the fact that top-tier university computer science programs don’t have a monopoly on producing competent programmers, and established software companies don’t have any magic techniques for engineering software.

然而，改进软件工程最有希望的前景是转向“云”：一家公司以服务的形式提供软件，该软件在该公司的计算机上运行，​​而不是在客户的机器上运行。

The most promising prospect for improving software engineering, however, is the move to “the cloud”: a company delivering software as a service that runs on that company’s computers instead of as software that runs on customer machines.

IBM PC 成为标准平台之后的那段时期是软件行业的黄金时期，各公司专注于所谓的套装软件。他们编写软件，根据他们选择执行的质量标准认为软件“足够好，可以发布”，然后基本上就大功告成了；剩下要做的就是计算销量，看着股价上涨。客户会报告软件错误，公司可能会提供更新版本，但运行软件的大部分痛苦——获取软件、安装软件、管理软件、忍受软件错误以及推出更新——都由客户承担。

The period after the IBM PC became the standard platform was the gravy years for the software industry, with companies focused on what became known as packaged software. They wrote software, deemed it “good enough to ship” by whatever quality standards they chose to enforce, and then were mostly done with it; all that was left to do was count sales and watch the stock price rise. Customers would report bugs, and companies might provide updated versions, but most of the pain of running the software—acquiring it, installing it, administering it, living with bugs, and rolling out updates—was felt by the customers.

这使得程序员相对独立于工作中出现的问题。如果客户报告了一个错误，而程序员可以在自己的机器上重现该错误，那么他们就可以修复它，但除此之外，很容易将不可重现的错误视为可以忽略的不可靠问题。偶尔，一个错误会被广泛报告，程序员会因此感到焦虑（例如，Zune“Day 366”错误打乱了 2008 年除夕派对计划，主流媒体对此进行了报道），但大多数情况下，他们可以无忧无虑地睡觉，并尝试按照自己的时间表解决错误。微软的一些团队甚至有一组单独的工程师负责在软件发布后修复错误，因此当原作者忙于开发很酷的新东西时，其他人必须处理错误；值得注意的是，但并不令人惊讶的是，这种“持续工程”角色，就像测试员角色一样，在工程图腾柱上的地位低于开发人员。

This left programmers relatively isolated from problems arising from their work. If a customer reported a bug, and a programmer could reproduce the bug on their machine, then they could fix it, but otherwise it was easy to treat nonreproducible bugs as flaky problems that could be ignored. Occasionally a bug would be widely reported enough that programmers felt angst over it (for example, the Zune “Day 366” bug that messed up New Year’s Eve 2008 party plans, which was covered in the mainstream press), but mostly they could enjoy a blameless sleep and try to tackle the bug on their own schedule. Some teams at Microsoft even had a separate group of engineers responsible for fixing bugs in software once it had shipped, so somebody else had to deal with bugs while the original author was off cranking out cool new stuff; notably, but not surprisingly, this “sustained engineering” role, like the tester role, was viewed as lower on the engineering totem pole than developers.

随着软件转向在云中运行（这种软件通常称为服务），这一切都发生了变化。编写软件的公司也会安装并保持软件运行；客户通过 Web 浏览器访问软件。不要建议客户尝试关闭机器然后再打开；最终用户根本无法控制在遥远的数据中心的机器上运行的软件。他们必须将所有问题报告给公司——为了让客户满意，最好让您的软件已经发现它正在发生故障，这样您就可以在客户注意到之前收到警报。此外，您不太可能在调试问题时让机器停止一小时。必须从运行系统中持续捕获的遥测数据中找出问题——记录有关系统的信息、记录访问的文件、跟踪数据库查询等。

With the shift to software running in the cloud—such software is generically called a service—all that changed. The company that writes the software also installs it and keeps it running; the customer accesses it via a web browser. Forget about suggesting that customers try to turn the machine off and then back on again; the end users have no control at all over software running on a machine in a faraway data center. They have to report all problems to the company—and to keep customers happy, it is best if your software has already figured out that it is malfunctioning, so you can be alerted before customers notice. Furthermore, it is unlikely that you can stop a machine for an hour while you debug the problem. Issues have to be figured out from telemetry data that is continuously captured on the running system—recording information about the system, logging what files are accessed, tracking database queries, and so on.

20 世纪 90 年代初，当我在开发 Windows NT 时，每天晚上下班前，我们都会开始在所有计算机上运行“压力测试”。这些自动测试是连续运行的程序组合，执行读写文件或在屏幕上绘制图形等基本操作；目的是看看 Windows NT 能否撑过这个夜晚而不崩溃或挂起。1开发人员越来越害怕早上收到电子邮件，告知他们拥有的机器代码出现故障。一般来说，在机器可以恢复之前，需要调查压力故障，因为这可能是间歇性错误的独特例子。问题经常发生在另一位开发人员的主要机器上，导致他们陷入困境，直到调查完成。我记得那些调试会话是最紧张的，因为其他人被困住了，直到我完成。忘记重现步骤吧；错误可能是由于软件各个部分之间的精确交互而发生的，这种交互可能永远不会再发生，所以你必须尽你所能追溯到底出了什么问题，通过法医挖掘内存的当前状态来尝试隔离第一个故障，从而隔离代码缺陷。在放弃任何给定故障之前，你调查得有多彻底取决于你，但如果再次发生，压力就会加大；那些仍然无法修复重复出现的压力故障的开发人员会倒霉。

When I worked on Windows NT in the early 1990s, every night before leaving work we would start “stress tests” running on all our computers. These automated tests were a mix of programs that ran continuously, performing basic operations such as reading and writing files, or drawing graphics on the screen; the goal was to see if Windows NT could make it through the night without crashing or hanging.1 Developers grew to dread the morning e-mail indicating that a machine had failed in code that they owned. By general agreement, stress failures needed to be investigated before the machine could be reclaimed, since it might be the unique example of an intermittent bug. Frequently the problem had hit on another developer’s primary machine, leaving them dead in the water until the investigation was completed. I recall those debugging sessions being the most stressful, because somebody else was stuck until I was done. And forget about repro steps; the bug likely hit due to precise interactions between various pieces of software, which might never reoccur again, so you had to do what you could to retroactively figure out what went wrong, by forensic digging into the current state of memory to try to isolate the first fault and thence the code defect. How exhaustively you investigated before giving up on any given failure was up to you, but the pressure ratcheted up if it happened again; woe betide the developer who continued to be unable to fix a recurring stress failure.

对于服务而言，每次调查都是如此。突然之间，错误就成了开发人员最关心的问题。一种广泛使用的策略是给开发人员发寻呼机，让他们轮流查看问题，将开发人员转变为活生生的异常处理者。这迫使程序员直接感受到错误的痛苦，同时也激励他们确保监控和警报准确无误；没有人愿意错过真正的问题，但没有人愿意半夜被误报吵醒。如果您的遥测数据不够丰富，无法调试故障，那么您就有很大动力去改进它，而且要快速改进。

On a service, every investigation is like that. Suddenly, bugs become an immediate concern for developers. A widely used strategy is to give the developers pagers and put them on call to look into issues on a rotating basis, transforming developers into living exceptions handlers. This forces programmers to directly feel the pain of bugs, and it also inspires them to make sure the monitoring and alerting is accurate; nobody wants to miss a real issue, but nobody wants to be woken up in the middle of the night by a false alarm. And if your telemetry data isn’t rich enough to debug the failures, then you have lots of motivation to improve it, and quickly.

从好的方面来看，由于这些错误发生在公司自己的机器上，因此更容易跟踪它们并找出哪些错误会造成最严重的破坏，然后回过头来找出如何避免问题以及如何避免将来出现同类问题。是设计选择不当吗？是 API 有未记录的副作用吗？是应该编写的单元测试吗？是编写了测试但没有在正确的时间运行吗？是因为有人不小心或没有写下来而错过了部署清单上的某个步骤吗？现在，人们是否在跳过这些程序员以前可以忽略的工程行为变得更加明显了。

On the plus side, because the bugs are happening on machines that companies own, it is easier to keep track of them and figure out which ones cause the worst disruptions, and then go back and figure out how the problem could have been avoided—and how future problems of the same sort could be avoided. Was it poor design choices? Was it an API with undocumented side effects? Was it a unit test that should have been written? Was it a test that was written, but not run at the right time? Was it a step on a deployment checklist that was missed because somebody was not being careful or it wasn’t written down? It is now much more obvious if people are skipping out on these engineering-like behaviors that programmers had previously been able to ignore.

在某些时候，你甚至可以设想将其与多年来困扰程序员的所谓宗教辩论联系起来。你喜欢你的特定编码风格吗？你认为你最喜欢的语言会导致更少的错误或更快的开发吗？你喜欢在变量名上使用匈牙利前缀吗？一家公司不太可能提供足够的数据来单独得出答案，但如果你对整个行业进行分析，就有可能从混乱中得出真正的答案。即使公司自己无法回答这些问题，他们至少会积极关注答案（有时还会将发现的任何缓解措施强加给他们的团队），因为服务有一个很好的方式将这些决策转化为金额。如果你的 bug 比另一家选择不同编码风格的公司多，如果你的服务运行速度更慢，如果部署更困难……所有这些都意味着你需要在某个地方花更多的钱来保持它的运行，这使得它在市场上的竞争力更强。

At some point, you could even conceive of tying this back to the so-called religious debates that have befuddled programmers through the years. Do you prefer your particular coding style? Do you think your favorite language leads to fewer bugs or more rapid development? Do you like Hungarian prefixes on your variable names? It’s unlikely that one company is going to produce enough data to individually come up with an answer, but if you analyze this across the industry, it’s possible that actual answers could emerge from the murk. Even if companies are not able to answer the questions themselves, they would at least be motivated to care about the answers (and sometimes to impose whatever mitigation was discovered onto their teams) because services have a nice way of converting these decisions into dollar amounts. If you have more bugs than another company that has made a different choice of coding style, if your service runs more slowly, if it is harder to deploy … that all translates to more money you need to spend somewhere to keep it running, which makes it harder to compete in the market.

本质上，运行服务会自动对软件工程中充斥的那些无聊的传说施加一层“不胡说”的过滤器。

Essentially, running a service imposes an automatic “no bullshit” filter on the old wives’ tales that permeate software engineering.

另一个好处是，服务组件之间或客户端计算机与云服务之间的数据传输方式比单台计算机上运行的软件通常实现的方式更接近面向对象编程的理想。在计算机网络发展的早期，当所有机器都在同一个局域网上时，网络带宽较低，但延迟也较低；通过网络发送大量数据很慢，但小网络数据包可以相当快地到达另一台机器。因此，早期的网络协议专注于将尽可能多的数据打包到尽可能小的空间中，这使得编写处理这些数据的代码变得很棘手；正是处理这种传入的网络数据包导致了 2014 年的 Heartbleed 蠕虫病毒。

As an added benefit, the way data is transferred between components of a service, or between a client machine and service in the cloud, is much closer to the ideal of object-oriented programming than is typically achieved with software running on a single computer. In the early days of computer networking, when machines were all on the same local area network, the network was low bandwidth but also low latency; sending a lot of data through the network was slow, but a small network packet could reach the other machine fairly quickly. As a result, early network protocols focus on packing as much data into as little space as possible, which made writing the code to handle them tricky; it was processing this sort of incoming network packet that led to the Heartbleed worm in 2014.

将客户端连接到云的现代网络具有更高的带宽。1990 年，微软的计算机网络以每秒 10 兆比特的速度运行，由整层楼共享，而今天，家庭宽带连接通常支持每秒 100 兆比特的速度直接连接到单个家庭，而将您连接到互联网的主干连接的速度要快得多。但是，由于数据包必须在计算机之间进行多次跳跃，因此连接的延迟更高。因此，数据包中的数据量并不那么重要 - 大数据包到达目的地所需的时间不会明显长于小数据包 - 并且通信通常以更详细的格式编码，称为可扩展标记语言 (XML)。

Modern networks connecting a client to the cloud have much higher bandwidth. The computer network at Microsoft back in 1990 ran at 10 megabits per second shared by the entire floor of a building, while today it is typical for a home broadband connection to support 100 megabits per second directly to a single house, with the backbone connections that get you to the Internet running much faster than that. The connections have a higher latency, however, since a packet has to make multiple hops between computers. As a result, the amount of data in a packet doesn’t matter as much—a large packet doesn’t take noticeably longer than a short one to reach its destination—and communication is usually encoded in a more verbose format known as Extensible Markup Language (XML).

XML 是用于在流水线 UNIX 命令之间进行通信的文本字符串的稍微分类版本，以前它是“面向对象”软件构建块的最有效实现。在包含紧密打包的二进制数据的旧网络协议中，任何给定字节的含义都取决于其在数据包中的确切位置，人类很难解析数据以弄清其含义；存在称为数据包嗅探器的整个独立程序来帮助调试网络流量（我早期在微软使用的嗅探器是完全独立的机器，如果您在打开时不小心将网线掉入其中，更换成本会非常高——我对此一无所知）。相比之下，XML 使用人类可读的标签来识别数据，因此程序员可以扫描 XML 请求本身以弄清其含义，并且可以更通用地编写解析 XML 的代码，因此更安全（Microsoft Office 在其较新的文件格式中使用 XML 以避免隐藏在旧二进制格式中的漏洞问题）。这类似于读取机器语言原始字节和读取高级语言代码之间的区别。

XML is a slightly more categorized version of the text strings used to communicate between pipelined UNIX commands, which previously had been the most effective implementation of “object-oriented” software building blocks. In older network protocols containing tightly packed binary data, the meaning of any given byte depended on its exact location in the packet, and it was hard for a human to parse the data to figure out what it meant; entire separate programs known as packet sniffers existed to assist in debugging network traffic (the sniffers we used in my early days at Microsoft were entirely separate machines, quite expensive to replace if you happened to drop a network cable into the back of one while it was turned on—not that I would know anything about that). XML, by contrast, uses human-readable tags to identify data, so a programmer can scan the XML request itself to figure out its meaning, and code to parse XML can be written more generically and therefore more safely (Microsoft Office uses XML in its newer file formats to avoid the problem of exploits hidden inside the old binary format). It’s similar to the difference between reading raw bytes of machine language and reading code in a higher-level language.

第二个好处是，与早期协议相比，XML 通信对版本不匹配的容忍度更高。具体来说，如果客户端在请求中发送了服务器不期望的数据，它可以简单地忽略它，这使得扩展网络协议变得更容易，而不会破坏与旧客户端的互操作性。如果早期的网络协议就像 C++ 等注重性能的语言中紧密绑定的 API 调用，除非所有调用者都更新，否则单个添加的 API 参数可能会破坏代码，那么 XML 更像是 Smalltalk 带有命名参数的消息方法——速度稍慢，但在变化面前也更不脆弱。

A second benefit is that XML communication is much more forgiving of version mismatches than earlier protocols. In particular, if a client sends data in a request that the server doesn’t expect, it can simply ignore it, which makes it easier to expand a network protocol without breaking interoperability with older clients. If early network protocols were like the tightly bound API calls in a performance-focused language like C++, where a single added API parameter could break the code unless all callers were also updated, XML is more like the Smalltalk messages-with-named-parameters approach—a little slower, but also less fragile in the face of changes.

话虽如此，但有一个有趣的分歧正在发生。程序员们在开发具有几乎无限计算能力的云服务的同时，也在编写可在小型设备上运行的程序。就像上一代程序员在 20 世纪 60 年代资源有限的大型机和小型机上成长起来，新一代程序员在 20 世纪 80 年代资源有限的个人电脑上成长起来一样，另一代人也有可能在资源有限的手机和平板电脑上学习编程。还有待观察的是，第三次软件资源瓶颈是否会让程序员养成上几代人的所有坏习惯，即追求性能和便利性，减少打字，而牺牲简洁的设计。

That said, there is an interesting bifurcation going on. At the same time that programmers are working on cloud services with almost infinite computing power, they are writing programs to run on smaller devices. Just as a generation of programmers came of age on the resource-limited mainframes and minicomputers of the 1960s, and a new generation came of age on the resource-limited personal computers of the 1980s, it’s possible that another generation will learn to program on resource-limited phones and tablets. What remains to be seen is whether the Third Great Software Resource Bottleneck will teach programmers all the same bad habits of the previous generations, favoring performance and convenience, and less typing of course, at the expense of clean design.

对于有套装软件开发经验的程序员来说，服务方法可能难以适应。服务需要将注意力从性能转向可维护性和可靠性，并进一步将注意力从专注于软件的交付转向专注于保持软件的运行。微软有一个著名的 Ship-It 奖，每个为交付给客户的项目做出贡献的人都会收到一张小小的纪念金属贴纸，贴在牌匾上，由此产生的累积成为每位员工在微软工作时间的记录。2该奖项是在 20 世纪 90 年代初设立的，当时一些大型项目显然失败了，被取消了，多年的努力毫无成果。该奖项旨在强调真正完成软件并将其交付给客户的重要性。尽管该项目在启动时遭遇了传奇性的挫折，3人们确实关心他们的 Ship-It 奖项，许多微软员工自豪地在办公室展示他们的奖牌。

The services approach can be difficult for programmers experienced in packaged software to adapt to. Services require a mind shift away from performance toward maintainability and reliability, and a further mind shift away from concentrating on shipping software toward focusing on keeping it running. Microsoft famously has a Ship-It Award where everybody who contributes to a project that ships to customers receives a small commemorative metal sticker to attach to a plaque, with the resulting accretion forming a record of each employee’s time at Microsoft.2 The award was created in the early 1990s after a few large projects visibly flamed out and were canceled, with nothing to show for years of work; it was meant to emphasize the importance of actually finishing software and delivering it to customers. Despite a legendary stumble at the launch of the program,3 people do care about their Ship-It Awards, and many Microsoft employees proudly display their plaques in their offices.

十五年后，作为管理我工程卓越团队的职责之一，我全权负责确定微软编写的一款软件是否值得获得 Ship-It 奖。这项权力被赋予我的职位的过程有些复杂，但我尽我所能以我认为合适的方式公正对待（Office 和 Windows 的新版本：是；Microsoft Store 使用的销售点软件的更新：否）。Ship-It 计划是为套装软件设计的，但大约在这个时候，大型服务团队意识到，发布只是开始；真正的诀窍是保持服务正常运行。他们开始鼓动获得同等认可，以装饰他们的奖牌（工作名称是 Run-It 奖），但最终他们的请求被否决了——这是“这只是持续工程”心态的遗留问题。

Flash-forward fifteen years and your humble narrator, as part of the duties managing my team in Engineering Excellence, was solely responsible for determining whether a piece of software written at Microsoft was significant enough to deserve a Ship-It Award. The process by which this authority came to be vested in my position was somewhat convoluted, but I did my best to dispense justice as I saw fit (new versions of Office and Windows: yes; update to the point-of-sale software used in the Microsoft Store: no). The Ship-It program had been designed for packaged software, but around this time the large services teams were realizing that shipping is only the beginning; the real trick is to keep a service running. They began agitating for an equivalent recognition of this to adorn their plaques (the working title was Run-It Award), yet in the end their request was shot down—a legacy of the “it’s just sustained engineering” mentality.

2009 年，微软的许多程序员开始从事服务工作，因此我们工程卓越部门在公司内部向那些已经经历过转型的人征求建议（除了“给我们颁发 Run-It 奖”）。最有见地的评论来自 Exchange 电子邮件服务的一位工程师，他之前从事过套装软件工作。在浏览了所有需要重新学习才能有效地从事服务工作的内容列表后，他遗憾地说：“问题是，如果我回到两年前并告诉自己所有这些，我不会相信的。”布鲁克斯曾引用本杰明·富兰克林在《穷理查年鉴》中写道：“经验是一位亲爱的老师，但愚人不会从其他方式学习。”4

In 2009, a lot of programmers at Microsoft were beginning to work on services, so we in Engineering Excellence went around the company asking those who had already been through the transition for their advice (besides “give us a Run-It Award”). The most insightful comment came from an engineer on the Exchange e-mail service who had previously worked on packaged software. After walking through a list of all the things he had needed to relearn in order to be effective working on a service, he ruefully said, “The problem is, if I went back in time two years and told myself all of that, I wouldn’t have believed it.” Brooks at one point quotes Benjamin Franklin, writing in Poor Richard’s Almanac: “Experience is a dear teacher, but fools will learn at no other.”4

转向服务是朝着正确方向迈出的一步，但还需要做更多的工作。

The move to services is a step in the right direction, but more needs to be done.

葛文德的《清单宣言》一书的副标题是《如何把事情做好》。书中有一段他和一位结构工程师谈论建筑行业的变化：

Gawande’s book The Checklist Manifesto is subtitled How to Get Things Right. At one point he talks to a structural engineer about how the construction industry has changed:

他解释说，在现代历史的大部分时期，追溯到中世纪，人们建造建筑物的主要方式是聘请建筑大师，由他们设计、建造并从头到尾监督施工。……但到了 20 世纪中叶，建筑大师们已经不复存在。建筑过程每个阶段的进步都多种多样且复杂，超出了任何个人掌握它们的能力。5

For most of modern history, he explained, going back to medieval times, the dominant way people put up buildings was by going out and hiring Master Builders who designed them, engineered them, and oversaw construction from start to finish. … But by the middle of the twentieth century the Master Builders were dead and gone. The variety and sophistication of advancements in every stage of the construction process had overwhelmed the ability of any individual to master them.5

当今的软件工程师都是建筑大师，他们面临着不堪重负的危险。

Today’s software engineers are master builders, and they are in danger of being overwhelmed.

葛文德还讨论了汤姆·沃尔夫在《太空先锋》一书中记录的高速飞机早期的英雄试飞员。他们通过即兴发挥和大胆尝试取得了成功，但最终“安全和尽责的价值观占了上风，试飞员的明星地位不复存在。”6宇宙会对无法适应的试飞员施以自然的矫正，但软件行业却没有这种效果；软件公司的中高层管理人员都是成功的自学成才的程序员。希望最近的毕业生听说过设计模式和单元测试；虽然这些距离为软件工程提供科学基础还很远，但至少它们让人们意识到，公认的知识在软件行业是可能的，这反过来应该会让他们更愿意学习新方法，如果我们能发现它们的话。但当然，它们必须先被发现。

Gawande also discusses the hero test pilots from the early days of high-speed aircraft, as documented in Tom Wolfe’s book The Right Stuff. They succeeded through improvisation and daring, but eventually “values of safety and conscientiousness prevailed, and the rock star status of the test pilots was gone.”6 The universe applies a natural corrective to test pilots who fail to adapt, but no such effect exists in software; the middle and upper management of software companies are full of successful self-taught programmers. Hopefully, more recent graduates have heard about design patterns and unit tests; while those are a long way from providing a scientific basis for software engineering, at least they have opened people’s eyes to the fact that accepted knowledge is possible in the software industry, which in turn should make them more amenable to learning new ways if we can discover them. But of course they do have to be discovered first.

否则，我们将不得不面对葛文德书中的另一句话：

Otherwise, we will have to confront another quote from Gawande’s book:

在几乎所有的历史时期，人们的生活主要受无知的支配。……我们可以原谅因无知而导致的失败。如果在特定情况下没有最佳做法的知识，我们很高兴人们会尽最大努力。但如果知识存在而没有得到正确运用，我们很难不感到愤怒。……哲学家们给这些失败起了如此无情的名字——无能，并非毫无道理。7

For nearly all of history, people’s lives have been governed primarily by ignorance. … Failures of ignorance we can forgive. If the knowledge of the best thing to do in a given situation does not exist, we are happy to have people simply make their best effort. But if the knowledge exists and is not applied correctly, it is difficult not to be infuriated. … It is not for nothing that philosophers gave these failures so unmerciful a name—ineptitude.7

程序员无能吗？我认为他们并不像 Gawande 指责医学那样无能，而医学正是他这本书的重点。他谈论的是这样的情形：如何提供适当的医疗服务的知识毫无疑问是可用的，并且得到了所有参与者的认可，但由于各种原因，这些知识没有得到适当的应用。Gawande 认为，这种挣扎在“几乎任何需要掌握复杂性和大量知识的努力”中都有相似之处——在他看来，这份名单包括外国情报失败、摇摇欲坠的银行，以及（他所知甚少的）有缺陷的软件设计。8

Are programmers inept? I don’t think they are in the exact way Gawande indicts medicine, the prime focus of his book. He is talking about situations in which the knowledge of how to deliver proper medical care is unquestionably available and agreed on by all involved, but for various reasons is not applied properly. Gawande sees parallels to this struggle in “almost any endeavor requiring mastery of complexity and of large amounts of knowledge”—a list that to him includes foreign intelligence failures, tottering banks, and (little does he know) flawed software design.8

反对将程序员贴上无能标签的理由是，他们甚至还没有达到知道如何正确完成工作的阶段。这是因为他们已经停止尝试弄清楚这一点，这并不是一个很好的辩护理由：我们仍然无能，只是方式略有不同。

The argument against labeling programmers inept is that they have not even reached the stage of knowing the right way to do their jobs. That’s because they have stopped trying to figure this out, which isn’t a great defense: we are still inept, just in a slightly different way.

1986 年，布鲁克斯写了一篇题为《没有灵丹妙药》的文章——这里指的是杀死狼人所需的弹药。“我们听到了对灵丹妙药的迫切呼声，希望有某种东西能让软件成本像计算机硬件成本一样迅速下降，”他哀叹道，

In 1986, Brooks wrote an essay titled, “No Silver Bullet”—a reference to the ammunition reputedly needed to kill werewolves. “We hear desperate cries for a silver bullet, something to make software costs drop as rapidly as computer hardware costs do,” he lamented,

但是，展望未来十年，我们看不到任何灵丹妙药。无论是技术还是管理技术，都没有任何一项发展能够单独保证生产力、可靠性和简易性有哪怕一个数量级的提高。……不仅目前看不到任何灵丹妙药，而且软件的本质决定了未来也不太可能出现任何灵丹妙药。9

But, as we look to the horizon of a decade hence, we see no silver bullet. There is no single development, in either technology or management technique, which by itself promises even one order of magnitude improvement in productivity, in reliability, in simplicity. … Not only are there no silver bullets now in view, the very nature of software makes it unlikely that there will be any.9

布鲁克斯描述了他认为问题的本质，即软件固有的困难：复杂性、一致性（需要将新代码纳入现有 API）、易变性和不可见性（难以将内部结构可视化）。他列出了各种可能有帮助的发展，包括面向对象编程（当时它刚刚开始转变为面向对象的银弹 Amalgamated Holdings），但他怀疑其中任何一个都无法提供所需的魔力。

Brooks describes what he feels is the essence of the problem, the inherent difficulties of software: complexity, conformity (the need to fit new code into an existing API), changeability, and invisibility (the difficulty of visualizing the internals). He lists various developments that may help, including object-oriented programming (which at that time was just beginning its transformation into Object-Oriented Silver Bullet Amalgamated Holdings), but doubts that any of them will supply the magic needed.

九年后，几乎在他考虑原始论文的时间结束时，布鲁克斯发表了一篇后续文章《‘无灵丹妙药’重现》，讨论了对原始论文的反应。他写道：“其中大部分都攻击了没有神奇解决方案的核心论点，而我明确认为不可能有。大多数人同意‘NSB’中的论点，但随后又断言，作者发明的软件野兽确实有灵丹妙药。”10斜体字是我加的，因为我无法想到对正在进行的所谓软件万能药的总结有更简洁的概括。

Nine years later, almost at the end of the time period he was considering in the original paper, Brooks produced a follow-up essay “‘No Silver Bullet’ Refired,” discussing reactions to the original. He wrote, “Most of these attack the central argument that there is no magical solution, and my clear opinion that there cannot be one. Most agree with the arguments in ‘NSB,’ but then go on to assert that there is indeed a silver bullet for the software beast, which the author has invented.”10 The italics are mine, because I can think of no more succinct summary of the ongoing procession of alleged software panaceas.

布鲁克斯在第二篇文章的结尾处有一个简短的章节，题为“Net on Bullets—Position Unchanged”。他在《System Development》杂志的一篇文章中引用了著名软件观察家罗伯特·格拉斯的话：“最后，我们可以专注于一些比空中楼阁更可行的事情。现在，也许我们可以继续逐步提高软件生产力，而不是等待不太可能出现的突破。”11

Brooks ends his second essay with a short section titled “Net on Bullets—Position Unchanged.” He quotes noted software observer Robert Glass, in an essay in System Development magazine: “At last, we can focus on something a little more viable than pie in the sky. Now, perhaps, we can get on with the incremental improvements to software productivity that are possible, rather than waiting for the breakthroughs that are not likely to come.”11

软件工程的历史就是在寻找灵丹妙药。结构化编程、形式化测试、面向对象语言、设计模式、敏捷方法——所有这些都很有用，但没有一种可以单独杀死狼人。我亲身经历了所有这些转变，甚至是结构化编程；由于我早年一直处于自学 Fortran 和 BASIC 的泡沫中，我能够亲身体验软件的衰落GOTO，比业内其他人晚了十年。这些软件都是从小处着手，获得支持者，最终被炒作成解决所有编程问题的解决方案，最终导致不可避免的失望和幻灭。我可以理解为什么程序员对灵丹妙药寄予厚望，并热切地抓住了一系列闪亮的东西。俗话说，“暴风雨中的任何港口”。不幸的是，正如帕纳斯所说，“[程序员] 被灌输了太多‘灵丹妙药’，以至于他们不再相信任何东西了。”12

The history of software engineering has been a search for the silver bullet. Structured programming, formal testing, object-oriented languages, design patterns, Agile methodologies—all are useful, but none alone can slay the werewolf. I personally lived through all these transitions, even structured programming; due to spending my early years in a self-taught bubble of Fortran and BASIC, I was able to experience the twilight of GOTOs firsthand, ten years later than the rest of the industry. Each of these started out small, gained supporters, and wound up being hyped as the solution to all programming problems, leading to inevitable disappointment and disillusionment. I can understand why programmers hope beyond hope for the silver bullet and have eagerly glommed onto a succession of shiny objects. “Any port in a storm,” as the saying goes. Unfortunately, as Parnas put it, “[Programmers] have been fed so many ‘silver bullets’ that they don’t believe anything anymore.”12

此外，软件行业已经养成了在旧方法失去光彩后将其抛弃的习惯。这是一种二元世界观：一种编程技术要么能解决所有问题，要么毫无用处。当微软开始聘请软件测试工程师来测试软件时，之前负责这项工作的开发人员很快就进入了“把它扔过墙去测试”的模式。2000 年代中期，微软用软件设计工程师取代了软件测试工程师，负责编写自动化测试，不再依赖手动测试。后来，随着单元测试的转向，由开发人员编写，该公司摆脱了许多软件设计工程师和他们提供的用户界面级测试。现在，随着向云计算的过渡，人们强调“生产测试”，即将软件更新快速部署到一小部分真实客户，并进行检查以快速检测问题并回滚更新。每种新技术都有用，但应将其视为箭筒中的另一支箭，而不是消除之前技术的需要的全部。

Moreover, the software industry has gotten in the habit of abandoning old silver bullets once they get tarnished. It’s a binary view of the world: a programming technique is either going to solve every problem or it’s useless. When Microsoft began hiring software test engineers to test the software, the developers, who previously had been responsible for this, quickly segued into “throw it over the wall to test” mode. In the mid-2000s, Microsoft replaced software test engineers with software design engineers in test, responsible for writing automated tests, and stopped relying on manual testing. With the later move to unit tests, which are written by developers, the company got rid of a lot of the software design engineers in test and the user-interface-level tests that they provided. Now with the transition to the cloud, there is an emphasis on “test in production,” where updates to the software are quickly deployed to a small percentage of real customers, with checks in place to quickly detect problems and roll back the update. Each new technique is useful, but it should be viewed as another arrow in the quiver, not the be-all and end-all that obviates the need for what went before.

1978 年，Harlan Mills 预测“下一代程序员将比第一代程序员更有能力。他们必须如此。就像在‘过去的好日子’里更容易进入大学一样，在‘过去的好日子’里当一名程序员也更容易。对于这一代新人，程序员需要具备以前从未梦想过的精确度和生产力水平。”13正如米尔斯写的几乎所有东西一样，今天和当时一样真实。

In 1978, Harlan Mills predicted that “The next generation of programmers will be much more competent than the first ones. They will have to be. Just as it was easier to get into college in the ‘good old days,’ it was also easier to get by as a programmer in the ‘good old days.’ For this new generation, a programmer will need to be capable of a level of precision and productivity never dreamed of before.”13 As with almost everything Mills wrote, this is as true today as it was back then.

那么该做什么呢？

So what is to be done?

我的大部分建议都涉及改变大学教授软件工程的方式。我并不完全责怪大学；他们不知道该教什么的主要原因之一是行业过于自满和自满，不愿与学术界互动。如果你问公司他们希望大学教授什么，他们可能会开始谈论所谓的软技能：沟通、准时和与他人良好合作。这很好，但这并不奇怪，一群现在有家庭、抵押贷款和其他责任的成年人能够认识到大学毕业生并不像他们那么成熟。确定大学毕业生可能缺乏哪些技术技能更加困难，尤其是当经验丰富的员工也可能缺乏这些技能时。

Most of my recommendations involve changing how students are taught software engineering in universities. I am not entirely blaming universities; one of the main reasons they do not know what to teach is because industry is too self-satisfied and complacent to interact with academia. If you ask companies what they would like colleges to teach, they will likely start talking about so-called soft skills: communication, being on time, and working well with others. That’s nice, but it’s not surprising that a bunch of adults, who now have families, mortgages, and other responsibilities, are able to recognize that college seniors aren’t quite as mature as they are. It’s more difficult to determine what technical skills may be lacking in college graduates, particularly when those same skills may be lacking in the experienced employees as well.

本着《清单宣言》的精神，我不会过于规范。只要业界和学术界已经讨论并同意要做什么，我就会相信他们的判断。但“同意”并不意味着 ACM 会举办一个教授和业界研究人员都会出席的会议；这样的会议已经足够多了。值得称道的是，ACM 有超过 30 个特别兴趣小组，包括专注于计算机科学教育、编程语言和软件工程的小组，但它们在软件专业人士中并没有获得足够的关注。我希望软件工程项目能够改变其课程设置，公司能够关注这一点。

And in the spirit of The Checklist Manifesto, I am not going to be too prescriptive. As long as industry and academia have talked and agreed on what is to be done, I will trust their judgment. But by “agreed,” I don’t mean the ACM has a conference where professors and industry researchers show up; there has been enough of that already. The ACM, to its credit, has over thirty special interest groups, including ones focused on computer science education, programming languages, and software engineering, but they do not get enough traction among working software professionals. I want software engineering programs to change their curriculum, and companies to care.

无论如何，这只是一个时间问题：未来的程序员通常在接触软件工作之前就接受过软件教育，所以让我们从那里开始吧。通过学术界、行业和天意的结合，需要解决以下领域。

In any case, it’s a question of timing: future programmers usually are exposed to software education before they are exposed to software jobs, so let’s begin there. Through a combination of academia, industry, and divine providence, the following areas need to be addressed.

强迫学生学习新东西

Force Students to Learn Something New

20 世纪 80 年代独立软件行业兴起，彻底改变了 20 世纪 60 年代和 70 年代编写的软件项目管理方法。很难想象这浪费了多少时间和精力。然而，这种情况在下一代程序员身上不会再次发生。

When the independent software industry emerged in the 1980s, it reinvented everything about managing software projects that had been written in the 1960s and 1970s. It is hard to fathom how much time and energy was wasted because of this. Yet there is no reason why it won’t happen again with the next generation of programmers.

有些学生刚上大学时对编程一无所知，但许多人都有丰富的经验。学生越早放弃“他们知道所有需要知道的东西”的想法，他们就越早接受新的想法。我通过了普林斯顿大学的计算机科学课程，在某种程度上，我通过了微软的早期课程，这都是基于我在高中时自学的技能，为 IBM PC 编写 BASIC 游戏。课程并不轻松；我必须编写大量代码，并在冯·诺依曼上度过很多个深夜，使我的程序运行起来。但这并没有让我对广阔的软件工程世界敞开心扉。

Some students arrive in college with no knowledge of how to program, but many have significant experience. The sooner students are disabused of the notion that they know everything they need to know, the sooner they will become receptive to new ideas. I made it through my Princeton computer science classes, and to some extent my early years at Microsoft, on the basis of the skills I had taught myself in high school, writing BASIC games for the IBM PC. The classes weren’t easy; I had to write a lot of code and spent a lot of late nights in von Neumann getting my programs to work. But this did nothing to open my mind to the wide world of software engineering.
